this is my favorite assassin's creed game, which probably puts me in the minority of most people but i just love the charm this game has. it was my first time beating an "M" rated title as a kid and it means so much to me. i wish that the original was on here as well as the remaster because this coat of paint they slathered on really did the game more harm than good. the characters look like wax figures and the facial expressions look like they've just downgraded. the story is amazing and i cannot for the life of me understand why people don't like it. the american revolution is my favorite time period in history, so i guess i'm a little biased, but still.

the set-up in the beginning couple hours of the story ends up being a huge curve ball and i always loved that about it. haytham is my favorite ac character and one of the most interesting characters in gaming (imo). i could sit here and write for hours about him, but you get the point. connor, while yes, bland, i think is perfect the way he is; it's his personality - a rock-solid exterior that he's formed in response to his childhood and forthcoming trials. people just missed the charm of ezio, which is fair, but connor is really a great assassin that is largely overlooked.

i think my biggest gripe with this rerelease is the dropping of steam achievements. i was actually replaying this game to 100% it, and realized that there weren't any achievements for me to get. definitely ruined my night.

but, if you haven't yet, give this game a go. the combat is fluid and super satisfying and the characters and settings are really enjoyable. i would purchase this on xbox/ps for achievements, however, and i'll go a step further in saying you'd be better off playing the original 2012 title for the better atmosphere.

when Ubisoft actually made good games:

This is End of the Desmond Miles Games, you should only play it once you've beat AC, ACII, AC Brotherhood & AC Revelations. This game changed a lot, all the games that came before it really built on each other and could be seen as one long game, considering how similar they "felt". This one is simply different, it really feels like a new game which (at least to me) isn't a good thing in this case. I feel like they took a risk with this one and in my opinion, it payed off:
The combat is really different but in a good way. Many say its too easy but I love it. They added Rifles & Pistols really well, the animations are great, there are different enemy types, different kinds of weapons and much more, I don't really get why they removed the block but other than that I don't see anything bad about the combat, It's great.
The Stealth is weird. It seems to just never work. NPC's spot you very easily & even though there are some stealth tools, it seems as if the most important ones where removed. You really notice that they heavily focused on the combat.
Parkour is alright, i guess. I can't think of anaything thats missing but it's just not as good as the games before.
The Story is really good to be honest. Definitely my favorite out of the Desmond Games. Connor's relationship with his father is really interesting and his hate for Charles Lee is apparent. Because of his father, all of his connections to the Templar felt really personal. It's really a shame that most Assassination Missions for most of them aren't that good.
All in All, the game has amazing combat and a great story but it somewhat lacks in Stealth & Movement / Parkour: 7/10

I have to say that the game left me very surprised. But above all positively.

The story gets better and better as the game progresses. As I think everyone already knows, you play as Connor's father for the first few hours. It takes a long time, but it's very well integrated. After that, you briefly play as the teenage Connor and then more or less grow up with him. Up to the point where Connor is accepted into the ranks of the Assassins, however, it takes around eight hours. As I said, that's okay though, as it all makes sense in the end and you're left with the feeling of how incredibly weak you seem to be between all the intrigues and the strength of the Templars at the time.

I also enjoyed the so-called homestead missions much more than expected, where you build and colonise more and more houses in a section of the map.
Overall, the map is very beautiful. There are more or less two large map areas, which are in the countryside, and Boston and New York, but they are not as varied as the other two.

I was also told that AC3 runs on the same engine as AC2 and co. However, you don't notice this so much in the game, as the parkour runs much more smoothly in many places. Many sensible improvements have been implemented here compared to its predecessor. 

The most obvious is, of course, the ship driving. It's really fun and is very sensibly embedded in the overall setting.

More or less at the very end, the tragic story of Desmond Miles, who has accompanied us through five games, comes to an end. 

After all, I didn't even realise that the game had been with me for 30 hours. I recommend it to everyone. A somewhat neglected masterpiece.

Is this "remaster" worth it? No, absolutely not.

All of the little QoL features that they implemented into the base game unfortunately don't outweigh the glaring issues the game and it's DLC as well as AC:LIberation have: bad controls with mouse and keyboard, camera that does whatever the hell it wants, a terrible and I mean TERRIBLE plot for Tyranny of King Washington as well as AC:Liberation and (optional) mission challenges that make you want to rip your hair out because of the godawful controls.

Why are there so many pointless chests in Washington DLC? Why is the story so godawful? Why is it episodic?
Why is the plot of Liberation all over the place and barely coherent making you wonder in the middle of a main mission what exactly the end goal here is? What is it with the pointless collectibles?

Answer to all of the above: incompetent and arrogant projectmanagement that wanted to sh1t out another Assassin's Creed ASAP so number go up this quarter. Pathetic.

My personal ragequit moment in AC LIberation: trying to do the challenge "not take any damage" while on one of the last missions with your mentor. The game ignores its own rules here: usually enemies that are immune against specific counters are identifiable because of their looks. Not so in this mission. Have fun GUESSING what this enemy is immune against to beat this challenge. Bad game design, obviously not thought through, just released it with no second thought.

At least the main game has some reedemable qualities and doesn't ignore its own rules it sets up.

My review for - Assassin's Creed III : Reload Last Checkpoint

The absolute worst Assassin's Creed game of the entire franchise (see Liberation below). It seems like the developers of this installment went out of their way to painstaking make the most frustratingly finicky game possible. It's like they sat around a campfire on some company wilderness outing (picture that Office episode) devising ways simply to piss off anyone playing the game. And it's easily the most bugged installment of the franchise as well.

Oh, look, there's an NPC. Let's go see what he has to say. Oh, great! Three other NPCs talk over that NPC.

ME: Oh, hey! Look! A rock on the ground. Let's jump over it horsey!
HORSE: Ummm, no thanks. 
ME: How about this log here!
HORSE: Ummm, not really feeling up to it, bud.
ME: What about that nice fence over yonder? 
HORSE: Ummm, come to think about it...I'm not really the jumping type of horse, you know?
ME: It's becoming vastly apparent.
ME: Well, how about walking through this stream?
HORSE: Ummm, that sounds like A LOT of work.
ME: It's pretty shallow. Barely ankle deep. I could EVEN walk through it.
HORSE: Well...you see...I don't really like getting wet.
HORSE: And since you CAN walk through it...
ME: Okay, well, maybe just trotting up this hill over here? It's not really steep?
HORSE: Ummm, I use to do things like that.
ME: But...not anymore I take it?
HORSE: It's an AWFUL lot of work!
ME: Well, how about just running in a straight line without stopping for no apparent reason AT ALL other than to piss me off? 
HORSE: Ummm, well that's kind of my entire point in the game, son, sorry!
ME: What!? To stop running for no apparent reason!?
HORSE: Oh, no! I like running.
HORSE: I run ALL the time!
ME: You do!?
HORSE: Especially when you're not looking.
ME: Hmmm...
HORSE: I'm just programmed to piss you off.
HORSE: Perhaps walking would be easier?
ME: Yep! I think I'll throw away that whistle that's already a pain in the ass to use!
HORSE: Sounds like a plan, chief!
HORSE: How about some oats?
ME: Try the redcoats, tubby.

Since you can't play the Liberation HD without accessing it through Assassin's Creed III in the game library, you can't write a review for Liberation alone, so this next bit is for Liberation.

Assassin's Creed III in general is a terrible game, but Liberation is hands down the worst installment of the franchise. There will be many spoilers in this review, but seriously, read them because you're simply wasting your money by buying this.

First and foremost, this installment doesn't add anything to the main story line. It has nothing to with Desmond or the modern day events whatsoever. They try to tie it in with Connor in one sequence, but it's a ham-handed job that rings completely hollow.

You are not in an Animus, and you aren't reliving an ancestor's memory. It's simply: here's a crappy character we liberals who programmed this game know that you won't connect with or even like, but we want you to play it for no other reason than the fact that we want to inject our identity politics into a game.

The only bit that relates to anything seen in the main story line is that somehow or another the crappy character that you're forced to play may or may not be a descendant of Eve.

This installment feels completely linear as opposed to an open world.

The missions are simplistic, but you'll still have plenty of "Assassin's Creed III: Restart Last Checkpoint" for 100% sync.

All of the collectibles are not needed, nor necessary for 100% sync.

The economy of the game can be completely ignored.

They added a persona system into the game so that you play three distinctly different roles that have limitations that simply make the game retarded, and seemingly, the other reason they were added was so that you could play as a slave.

TL;DR: It sucks! Like a Hoover!

Assassin's Creed III Remastered brings the iconic American Revolution adventure back to life with enhanced visuals and refined gameplay. While the remaster addresses some of the shortcomings of the original release, it introduces new elements that enhance the overall experience. Here's a breakdown of the pros and cons:

Pros:

Visual Overhaul: The most noticeable improvement in Assassin's Creed III Remastered is the visual upgrade. The remaster boasts enhanced textures, lighting, and character models, breathing new life into the game. The revamped visuals make the historical setting even more immersive, with improved details and realistic environments.

Technical Improvements: Many of the technical glitches and bugs present in the original game have been addressed in the remaster. Players can expect a smoother experience with fewer interruptions, contributing to a more polished and enjoyable gameplay experience.

All Downloadable Content (DLC) Included: Assassin's Creed III Remastered includes all the original game's DLC content, providing players with additional missions and narratives. This comprehensive package adds value for both newcomers and returning fans, offering a more complete and expansive gameplay experience.

Updated Parkour and Combat Mechanics: The remaster takes advantage of advancements in gaming mechanics since the original release. Parkour movements feel more fluid, and the combat system benefits from refinements, providing a more responsive and enjoyable player experience.

Naval Warfare in 4K: The naval warfare, a standout feature in the original game, is even more breathtaking in 4K resolution. The remaster allows players to appreciate the beauty of the open seas and intense naval battles with greater detail and clarity.

Cons:

Limited Innovation: While the remaster improves upon the original, it doesn't introduce groundbreaking innovations. The core gameplay remains largely the same, which may leave some players hoping for more significant updates or additions to the mechanics.

Character Animations: While the character models have seen improvements, some animations may still appear slightly dated. Facial expressions and character movements, while better than the original, may not meet the expectations set by more recent releases.

Repetitive Mission Structure: The remaster inherits the original game's mission structure, which can still feel repetitive at times. Some players may find certain side quests lacking variety, though the inclusion of additional content helps mitigate this issue to some extent.

Stealth Mechanics Unchanged: Similar to the original, the remaster's stealth mechanics remain somewhat basic. Players seeking more nuanced and sophisticated stealth experiences may find the mechanics lacking depth.

Performance on Older Hardware: While the remaster offers an enhanced visual experience, it may struggle to run smoothly on older hardware. Players with less powerful systems may need to compromise on graphics settings to maintain a consistent frame rate.

In summary, Assassin's Creed III Remastered successfully revitalizes the American Revolution adventure with a substantial visual upgrade and technical improvements. While it may not introduce groundbreaking changes, the inclusion of DLC content and refined gameplay mechanics make it a worthwhile experience for both returning fans and those discovering the game for the first time. The remaster strikes a balance between nostalgia and modern gaming expectations, offering an enhanced journey through the pages of history. Yet i still cant recommend this title due to game breaking bugs.

[h1]DO NOT BUY THIS IF YOU INTEND TO BUY ASSASSIN'S CREED ODYSSEY. BUY ODYSSEY'S GOLD OR ULTIMATE EDITION AS IT COMES BUNDLED.[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Assassin's Creed III Remastered is a remaster of the original AC III, including all it's DLC and AC Liberation.
In the present day you, once again, follow Desmond Miles in his efforts to stop an impending disaster that could destroy humanity. To do this Desmond must relive the memories of another of his ancestors, Ratonhnhaké:ton/Connor, a Native American driven to join the Assassins in order to protect his people and avenge the burning of his village.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Combat is probably the best and most brutal of the original games.
[*]Naval combat is great.
[*]Good weapon variety. There are also new weapons like the bow and the rope dart.
[*]Graphics are a huge improvement over Revelations and, for the most part, an improvement over the original.
[*]Good story.
[*]Connor and Haytham's debates about the differing ideals of their factions, which help to shed a new light on both the Assassins and the Templars.
[*]Parkour is an improvement over the previous games. You can now climb trees and rocks.
[*]Homestead missions are great and show another side to Connor's character that the main story doesn't.
[*]Connor's suit is my favourite.
[*]The Tyranny of King Washington is a good DLC, although the map feels empty.
[*]Modern day missions are pretty good.
[*]Fantastic soundtrack.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Poor optimization. Relugar fps drops in Boston.
[*]Characters' faces look like they're made of wax. A huge step down from the original AC III.
[*]Some of the rock textures in the Homestead area are really bad. The texture's pattern repeats far too often.
[*]Enemy shooting markers don't work properly. I got shot regularly even though the marker wasn't bright red yet. It also doesn't show up at certain angles.
[*]The longest intro out of any AC game.
[*]Poor story pacing. Some important reveals are made off-screen.
[*]Optional objectives. They're a blight in AC games.
[*]Terrible modern day ending that pretty much killed the modern day storyline.
[*]Having to use the tunnels to unlock fast travel stations.
[*]Viewpoints don't reveal the whole map. You have to walk around to fully reveal it. Terrible decision.
[*]Collectibles, though not as many as the other games.
[*]AC Liberation isn't interesting.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Assassin's Creed III Remastered is a decent upgrade over the original, although some things are definitely downgraded, and comes bundled with all it's DLC and AC Liberation.
The game itself isn't perfect but it has a good story, great combat and a fantastic soundtrack that, in my opinion, rivals the Ezio trilogy.

This is my favorite Assassin's Creed game of all time, so I was very curious to see how the remaster would come along. 

After playing for 14 hours in this, there are surprisingly some bugs that weren't present in the original game that can get pretty distracting. But overall, it's not a deal breaker. 

If you can get your hands on a 2012 copy, get that, but tbh, just save the hassle and get the remaster.

My opinion has not changed over the years. Connor is still the most boring protagonist ever, he has as much personality as a dull knife. While Haytham made some compelling arguments, Connor still decided to go with his indoctrination. Seeing those two continue to work together would have definitely made this game a lot better.

With Connor it's the same as before - Give me Lee or give me death! I have no idea who put this idea in his head that Charles Lee is the worst human being ever, despite his actual father being the head of the American Rite of the Templar Order. 

The change in the graphics is subjective - some things look better and some look much worse for the wear. This is one of those many Assassin's Creed games that are just forgettable. You play through the story, you finish it and then just delete the game. Get this game only if it's on a -75% sale.
I really enjoyed the enhancements from the following couple of games that they brought back into this one.

Utter shambles.

Bugs/glitches around every corner, visually worse than the original and the story is weak enough already to make this such a drag to finish. 

4/10

Few of the bugs I found during my playthrough:

- Flailing clothes and other fabrics as if there's an ongoing tornado in cutscenes at all times.
- Audio cutting out and ruining some dramatic moments.
- British soldiers firing through walls, and detecting the player through walls.
- They did something to combat and its counter indicators, sometimes they don't show up, they often show up late, not an issue I recall with the original.
- Teleporting british people that seemed to come back and forth from the shadow realm (bonus feature from the ones who respawned seconds after death multiple times, ruining stealth approaches on forts).
- Lighting ruins some scenes being either too dark or too bright, also everyone looks smooth like they're made of playdough.
- General animation glitches and the parkour feels way more finnicky and buggy than the original.

A lot of this was hilarious to play through, but it's an absolute shame what they did to this game.
TL;DR: A demaster on all counts, significantly downgraded the game, an actual ripoff, broken and wasn't fixed since 2019.

I've been playing AC in more-or-less reverse order and AC3 still stands up to Black Flag or even Origins/Odyssey. The ship battles aren't quite as good, but it otherwise plays well against current standards.

The word to describe this game is "Frustrating".  Poorly designed missions, bad or inconsistent event/action triggers, a main character thoroughly lacking in character depth, and a historical story that lacked any of the history of the events in the New World or connection to the greater brotherhood that would have made it more engaging.  The mechanical problems should have been cleaned up with the remaster to bring the game closer to Black Flag, which feels much better in many of the regards that annoyed me with this one.  

The worst mechanic is in the Washington DLC, but thankfully not the main game.  If you get detected in the open world more than a dozen enemies spawn out of thin air around you to attack you.  It is horrible.  Another problem that I had only in the DLC is many enemies were not marked in red on the minimap.  The mission design in the DLC is also much worse.  It is baffling that this was released twice is such a bad state.  

The stories in this time period would have been better suited for the post-Origins style of games, as well as with a better main character.  Or even the same main character with a bit more personality and better writing.  

If you like the series, it is worth one playthrough.  But it is one of the weaker games in the franchise and even with a "remaster" has not aged well.

[h1] « The American Revolution. » [/h1]

[quote=Connor Kenway]"In the name of liberty, I will fight the enemy regardless of their allegiance. While men of courage write history of this day, the future of our land depends on those who are truly free."[/quote]

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

After a long time of absence here is the review of the game [b]Assassin's Creed III Remastered[/b] the story is primarily set during the period of the American Revolution, with a protagonist named Connor Kenway. I remind you that this is my personal review, all my evaluations are based on my personal opinion, if you do not agree with certain points, it would be interesting to talk about it. But first you have to become an Assassin.

[h1] Assassin's Creed III Remastered [/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Assassin's Creed III Remastered[/b] is the fifth installment in the Assassin's Creed video game series, developed by Ubisoft. It is an action-adventure, stealth, platform, combat and adventure game. It was published on October 30, 2012, as the protagonist we find Connor Kenway (Ratonhnhaké:ton): An assassin of Native American and British origin, whose role is crucial in the fight between the Assassins and the Templars.

[*]As for the historical context, we find ourselves during the American Revolution (1754-1783), the game takes place during this tumultuous period, where the American colonies revolted against British domination.
[/list]
All original single-player DLC including The Tyranny of King Washington, and Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered are bundled with the game.

[b]Note:[/b] Multiplayer mode no longer available, servers are offline.⚠️

[h1] Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered [/h1]

The remastered version of the original [b]Assassin's Creed Liberation[/b] game is provided with the game, I am not going to review this game in addition to this one, to find the review of Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered, click here:

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
[list]

[*]To begin with, the main character's movements, whether on foot or by climbing structures, are generally fluid, contributing to an immersive experience. I can say that the combat system has also been improved to offer more fluid interactions, with more varied counter movements and attacks as well as even more spectacular eliminations than the previous opuses.

[*]Well, as always (otherwise it's not funny), the artificial intelligence of the enemies can sometimes seem predictable, which can reduce the perceived difficulty of certain sections of the game. And I'm not even talking about the weakness of the allies to certain missions.

[*]Naval missions add interesting gameplay to the game even if we can't do as much as we want, but our navigator or pirate will be present in the next game, the remastered version has benefited from improvements, offering a more refined experience and entertaining.

[*]For the side side of the game, I'm not going to talk about the story to avoid spoiling future players but some side missions are repetitive and without much interest or purpose, it's the kind of mission that gives you an objective without really subsequently affect the player experience or the flow of the story.

[/list]
[h1] Graphism [/h1]
[list] 

[*]This remastered version benefits from an improved graphics engine, offering sharper graphics and improved visual details compared to the original version. This version resolved several stability and performance issues present in the original game, providing a smoother gaming experience. Lighting effects have been improved, contributing to the game's more realistic and immersive atmosphere, especially during dynamic weather changes.

[*]I find that the character models can seem dated by current video game standards, which is respectable for a game from 2012. Certain animations in particular can sometimes seem stiff or off, affecting immersion. Some locations may suffer from uneven lighting, which can alter the visual experience in certain parts of the game.
[/list]

[h1] OST [/h1]
[list]

[*]The soundtrack features a variety of musical styles, ranging from more contemplative and emotional pieces to more dynamic and energetic compositions, thus adapting to the diversity of situations in the game. An epic and immersive atmosphere, perfectly complementing the key moments of the gameincluding certain musical themes are memorable and well integrated into the plot, reinforcing the emotional impact of key scenes in the game.

[*]The presence of repetitiveness in the soundtrack, where certain themes may appear to recur frequently, which could potentially diminish their impact. The integration of music in some parts of the game can feel uneven, with times where the music can seem intrusive or poorly coordinated with the action on screen.
[/list]

[h1] Do I recommend the game to you ? [/h1]

If you are looking for a breathtaking gaming experience, I recommend the game if you want to immerse yourself in a captivating historical epic, if you want to explore breathtaking environments and feel the intensity of the fights between Assassins and Templars. This game is made for you, I'm not going to say too much, I'll let you discover this game, and describe the secrets it contains, we'll see you very soon at the brotherhood, future assassin!

[quote=Achilles Davenport]"In your haste to save the world, boy, take care you don't destroy it!"[/quote]

[h1] Two Full Games & One Drug Trip Inducing DLC All For The Price Of One. [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ Two Fully Fledged Story Campaigns 
+ One Overpowered Crazy DLC
+ 3 In One Gamepack 

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- Ubisoft Bugs Included
- Several Teeth Pulling Missions
- Lot of "What The Fuck Am I Playing?" Moments 

[b] The Aspect Of Games & DLC [/b]

[b] Assassins Creed III [/b]
[i] At the beginning of the game you play as a grand master templar Haytham Kenway who's goal is to seek out a hidden vault in the colonies of America. In the later half of the game you play as tribesman now assassin Ratonhnhaké:ton AKA Connor with the goal of stopping the templar activities in the American colonies. [/i]
 
[b] The Tyranny Of King Washington [/b]
[i] You once again step in the shoes of Ratonhnhaké:ton AKA Connor playing a three episode adventure of a different reality where Washington becomes corrupted by a piece of Eden and he must be taken down at any cost... [/i]

[b] Assassins Creed Liberation [/b]
[i] Step into the role of Aveline de Grandpré the first playable woman assassin who's fights for the New Orleans brotherhood. Who's goal is stop templar activities in the region while finding her lost mother in the downtime. [/i]

[b] My Two Cent Review [/b]

[b] Assassins Creed III [/b]
[i] This is actually the second time I have played and beaten AC III. I decided since I was going to attempt to play every AC game from to start finish I should take another look at this game from all those years ago. AC III isn't an amazing game but it is a good game. There are parts of the story I really like and then there parts of the story I really hate which same could be said for the missions you undergo. In the second half of the game you manage an estate and a trading business that I never cared enough to get off the ground fully. Some of the characters were just as memorable as when I first played the game many years ago and other characters mostly templars and anyone who isn't in a memory sequence for more then 4 missions. Lot's of collectibles just like other assassins creed games which I don't know who likes spending there free time looking for pages of an almanac but it's there for those who are bored enough to do so. Despite everything this was still a fun adventure! [/i]

[b] The Tyranny Of King Washington [/b]
[i] Oh boy this DLC is all over the place... You play as Conner in an alternate timeline where George Washington becomes king of America betraying every belief we have come to know about him in an epic three part episode. Through all three episodes one thought kept on going through my head and thought is "WHAT THE FUCK AM I PLAYING?!". You get a new super power each episode that will help you take down king George and his goons. [spoiler] Once you get the power of flight you can forget about parkouring for the rest of the game that power is just too damn OP. It's like playing Saints Row IV and getting superpowers I mean why use cars and planes anymore when you can just wall climb and fly in the air which planes and cars were a main mechanic in the other saints row games. So why parkour in AC when I just click a button and fly to any rooftop close by within 3 seconds?! [/spoiler] The endings about what I expected honestly for the DLC. This is not a DLC I will be revisiting anytime soon... [/i]

[b] Assassins Creed Liberation [/b]
[i] Gotta be honest wasn't a big fan of this one. Story was boring and the character was okay to play as but it didn't really stick to me like the other assassins I've played as in the past. They brought back that damn trading company side business you can run again which I never cared for originally. There are of course collectibles it wouldn't be an assassins creed game without them. [/i]

[b] The Value Of The Games & DLC [/b]
[i] It's a great thing to buy when your bored and want to waste some time but only if it's on sale. I do not believe this worth full price despite you getting two games and a DLC out of it. [/i]

[h1] Final Score 71/100 Ranking C- Tier [/h1]

I don't have much good to say specifically, but I did enjoy sequence breaking by killing bears with the animation of a hidden blade without having earned one yet. I did complete the game satisfied with my experience and willing to play it all over again in future. The actual interactions between Assassins and Templars was refreshing and I hope future games do it more often.

Biggest gripe: Horse movement. I don't expect Skyrim levels of off-road travel, where the horse can scale a mountain, but I'd at least like to ride around trees and hop down a small rock ledge, instead of getting a brake slam and whinny. I have pivoted around and tediously picked my way around rocks and snowbanks, in the name of filling in the map completely (Viewpoints are nerfed insanely when it comes to map discovery).
Personal gripe: I never quite adapted to the movement systems when they changed High Profile (Right click -> Shift), but there's parkour bits where Connor bends over a little or slides along the ground where it is VITAL that you are only pressing shift and forward, or else Connor wouldn't slide. Once my hands got used to pressing more buttons, I could side and back eject almost like previous games, but it always felt heavy/plodding.

Spoiler gripe: I wish I could have stabbed Lee instead of it being a cutscene.

okay, where the hell to begin with this. I guess the first thing is the damned audio levels, they are all over the place, no two scenes have the same audio levels, hell even in regular gameplay it seems that the audio levels are all over the place between NPC's walking past you, you constantly have to go into the settings and adjust the audio levels so that either you can HEAR what someone is saying, or so you don't get your eardrums burst from the character or SFX being louder than a jet engine in your room.

issue #2: the controls seem to have been messed up during this "remaster", by messed up I mean that the controls are slightly wrong when it comes to direction and speed. if you hold (on a controller obviously) straight forward, sometimes Conner will inexplicably veer slightly to the left or right at random moments, and this is something I have tested across multiple different controllers, and this isn't such a big deal when just running on the ground, but when you are parkouring across buildings like you do constantly in this game, then at points you will just fling yourself off in the wrong direction which a lot of times means that you are now no longer on that building and instead are on the ground. 

the third and final BIG issue I have with this "remaster" : the game crashes randomly during cutscenes or loading screens, I have tested disabling any background processes, tried running the .exe as admin, hell I've even verified the games files multiple times, fresh installed the game and started over on a new save. now while it's maybe 2-3 crashes in each "act" of the game, that is 2-3 more than there should be. 

in short, this "remaster" is a pile of steaming hot, rotting, shit covered, festering garbage.

[h1] Assassins's Creed III Remastered - A Classic Revisited [/h1]
Graphics: ★★★☆☆
Assassin's Creed III Remastered brings an improved visual experience to the critically acclaimed action-adventure franchise. While the graphics are undoubtedly upgraded, there are a few noticeable shortcomings. Character models and environments generally look great, but texture quality can be inconsistent at times. Overall, a visually satisfying experience that delivers a fresh coat of paint to an already stellar game.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
Assassin's Creed III Remastered offers an engaging and polished gameplay experience that retains the essence of the original game. The parkour mechanics, combat system, and stealth elements all work seamlessly, allowing players to fully immerse themselves in the expansive historical setting. The addition of some quality-of-life improvements and refined controls further enhance the overall gameplay experience.

Storyline: ★★★★★
As an integral part of the Assassin's Creed saga, the narrative of Assassin's Creed III remains as compelling as ever. The story follows the journey of Connor, an Assassin during the American Revolutionary War, as he battles the Templars to secure the freedom of his people. The depth of the characters and intricate plot twists keep players engrossed from start to finish. This thought-provoking storyline is an absolute masterpiece.

Audio: ★★★★☆
The audio design in Assassin's Creed III Remastered deserves high praise. The stirring background music, voice acting, and ambient sounds successfully create an immersive atmosphere that brings the historical setting to life. While there are occasional audio glitches that break immersion, the soundtrack and sound effects elevate the overall gaming experience.

Content: ★★★★☆
The remastered edition brings forward all the original content from Assassin's Creed III, including the main campaign and various side quests. Moreover, players will also get access to the bonus DLC content. This wealth of content offers countless hours of gameplay, making it a value-packed experience for both returning and new players alike.

Conclusion: ★★★★☆
Assassin's Creed III Remastered successfully revitalizes the classic game for modern consoles. While the graphics could be more consistent and the occasional audio glitch might break immersion, these shortcomings are minor compared to the exceptional storyline, polished gameplay mechanics, and wealth of content on offer. Fans of the franchise and new players alike will find much to appreciate in this gripping journey through history.

[h2] TLDR at the bottom [/h2]

 Assassin's Creed 3 is the second AC game I've played, and boy were my hopes dashed. I'll mention here I completed the whole story, every side quest I could, and got 91% completion on the game. I won't mention the uPlay launcher issues, as that's expected in every Ubisoft game.

[h2] Pros: [/h2]
- [b]Guard AI. [/b] The AI seems to be quite a bit smarter with guards compared to AC2, actually being able to hurt you from further away, mainly because of guns, but more enemies will climb up to you as well, making roof tops far more dangerous compared to AC2.
- [b] Naval combat! [/b] My favorite part of this game, the introduction of ships and naval missions. Firing cannons can be a little janky at times, but the missions feel fresh and a nice change of pace to break up the main story line. Add upgrades to your ship and you've got a great gameplay loop in a vacuum.
- [b] Side Characters. [/b] Achilles and many of the other side characters that get included in your homestead missions are people you can actually get invested in. You meet most in a dynamic way, in the middle of their lives falling apart, similar to Connors life. You give them a better life, hopes, and dreams of the future in conversations that make you care about them. It'd be even better if Connor wasn't a brick wall of a conversation maker.

[h2] Cons: [/h2]
- [b] Connor. [/b] He's about as plain as a cardboard box. His comments are few and add little to anything he's apart of. He's an annoying character despite that. I somewhat understand why they've done this, but even contrasting with Haythem, who can be witty but serious as the same time, it's a massive downgrade compared Ezio in AC2.
- [b] Level design. [/b] Despite the worlds being larger compared to AC2, it feels more empty due to less shops and buildings you can go into. Shops are all in one general stores now, instead of separate weapon, art, doctors, and clothing stores. There's no brothels or thieves guilds either which helped break up the skyline. They counteract this with minigames, which are quite common, but lack any flavor or real reason to play them. No story tid-bits, gossip, and terrible rewards when offered.
- [b] Crafting system. [/b] Just like AC2, you get a "city" to be in charge of. This time being a homestead, where via quests you can gain new people to offer new materials to craft with and trade for profit. Worry not though, we'll make it as painful as possible to use. Everything costs money, which your fellow homesteaders don't produce at all compared to AC2. Plenty of weapons are locked behind crafting requires that I feel most players will ignore entirely. The highest level of crafting also isn't unlocked until the very end of the game, Sequence 11-12.
- [b] Restrictive tools. [/b] The game teaches you to use ranged weapons like muskets, pistols, and your bow to deal with enemies from afar. Of course to enforce this extension of your range, they include lots of chase missions where you kill the person upon catching, but aren't allowed to use said ranged weapons. As an example, during one of the missions several of the templars you are sworn to kill are easily within range of your weapons, but if your ranged weapons are just fully restricted instead of proper level design. The game picks and chooses when you're allowed to use the tools you're provided, which just causes frustration.
- [b] The Story. [/b] It's quite predictable, switching between Real world and Connor missions. In the RW it's a man with daddy issues and a team of characters that do nothing but complain during a 2012 end of the world event. In Connors case, it's a naive man trying to kill people who are targeting his people, and get this, more daddy issues.

[h2] TLDR: [/h2]
  AC3 lacks a compelling story, main character, and environment. City development took a major step back, ranged weapons are heavily restricted, and the crafting system is tedious and outdated to use. I wouldn't recommend it, as AC2 is a far better game, and AC4 has better ship play if that's what you're looking for.

Assassin’s Creed 3 Remastered is a collection that comes packed with a heap of visual improvements and gameplay tweaks, yet maintains all the things that divided players back with the original release. There are still problems around, but it is a collection that transforms the experience to the modern-day standards and keeps us reminiscing the days when the series had much more promise.

Only OGs remember the unreal AC3 hype in 2012.

This will be forever one of my favorite AC games. The game came out during my 11th/12th grade year in High School right when I was taking US History. It was absolutely EPIC to learn about the revolution in school and go home and play it in Assassins Creed. I adored experiencing the story of the American colonies and the events in Boston on school and then at home so much, I barely even had time for my girlfriend. Being able to experience history through both mediums made this a 10/10 when I first played it.

Remastering makes a good game better, there are very few cases where a bad game gets better with a simple remaster. AC3 was always fantastic, Remastering it just made it shine more. 

The world looks miles better, the people look like total s**t. It’s kinda buggy on controls but the combat and climbing’s still good as ever. Colonial America looks completely transformed. Gone are the grey filters and lifeless streets. Now It feels like Boston and New York are actual cities with very unique personalities.

It has all the good parts and bad parts of the original version when it comes to gameplay. For example, the combat is extremely smooth and fluid while attempting to play stealthily is still a pain in the ass due to the oversensitive detection meter of the guards.

Connor was my personal favorite character in all of AC. He's hyper focused, loyal, and stoic yet kind and deeply sensitive and understanding. He was slightly hindered by the writing of the story, but you can definitely see his character shining through.

I also love how Ac3 is kind of cinematic. It is more touching and handcrafted in its cutscenes. I was blown away by how some simple stuff was made interesting and "artful" on Haytham's initial segments. 

On a whole, I would definitely say that it's worth the money. If you enjoyed the original AC III, then you're sure to enjoy the remastered version as well. If you've never played AC III, I'd still wholeheartedly recommend this as long as you keep in mind that this is mainly a combat game and not a traditional AC game where stealth is very important.

8/10

Assassin's Creed III takes players on a thrilling ride through the American Revolution. Exploring colonial America was a treat, with vibrant settings that truly captured the era. The addition of wilderness areas and cities like Boston and New York brought depth to the gameplay and made every corner worth exploring. The storyline, woven into historical events, provided a captivating backdrop, although pacing was occasionally uneven. The introduction of a new protagonist, Connor, and his quest for justice in a divided nation added a fresh perspective. Despite some gameplay quirks, the naval battles were a standout feature, offering adrenaline-pumping moments. Assassin's Creed III's historical immersion and engaging gameplay made it an intriguing chapter in the series' saga.

The game is as fun as I remember. I did encounter the crashing people are talking about, but the problem isn't the game itself but rather Ubisoft Connect. If you play the game with your PC disconnected from the internet, it fixes the crashing. It's something to do with UC synchronizing your achievements with the cloud that causes the crash. 

The graphics are great on my old GTX 1650, and the gameplay is smooth. If you want to play this game, this is a decent way to play as long as you disconnect from the net while you play.

I loved every single Assassin's creed game up until this point, and it was pretty hard to pick favorites because they are all just that good, but this one is where the series started to go downhill. Combat is weird as hell, the climbing is buggy as hell and just downright comical, the story and the cutscenes had me cringing most of the time, Desmond and the others look like apes in this game for some reason, and Vidic looks younger: He used to be gray in the first game and now he has black hair? Maybe it's because of the remaster version because I don't originally remember this game being this bad, but it's still the least liked game in my book. Also there's not much point in buying new weapons because they seem to be the same exact thing in combat. The game feels rushed and there's lack of detail unlike the previous ones.

The only good thing about this game was the introduction of ship battles, which potential was in full bloom in AC4 Black Flag.
Loved it!

This game is a mixed bag.

It has interesting moral debates similar to AC1's post assassination discussions. 

It has pretty funny inter-character dialogue and chemistry on the same level as AC2.

The parkour of this game [i]can[/i], I repeat [i]CAN[/i] look good, but the game trips and falls constantly. Often, enemies you chase run in efficient straight lines. Spending any time climbing up and down is a massive waste of time and the only option is to run like normal person. [i]Normie's Creed 3[/i]. Even if the enemy was slow enough to catch with parkour, there are times when there are no parkour-able objects nearby. The real problem, is the choices of locations for this game. Boston and New York suffer from [i]city planning[/i] and as a result have pretty consistent straight lines and common unparkourable wide streets. And casual parkouring through the forest is a pain. Tree Parkouring, again, can look good, but it is quite the learning curve to know what is and isn't climbable.

The combat of this game is more cinematic, in both good and bad ways. The main character has to do a complete flurry of attacks to kill somebody. So if, god forbid, you stab someone in the abdomen only 4 times instead of 5, that person is completely healthy and will go back to attacking you. To put this victim down you have to stab him 5 or so times in a chain, not in total, so the theoretical amount of stabs someone can take approaches infinty. This may be a personal skill issue, but I did not understand how counterkilling worked in this game until the second to last mission. Unlike AC1-R, to counter kill you have to hold the counter button and the attack button instead of just tapping them, i think. I dont really know, but after I started to hold these buttons, combat felt way better.

Dont bother with the Ubisoft Checklist of collectibles. Dont bother with synchronization either.

The visuals in this game range from ok to bad. Mostly ok. This is due to the limited heights and weird fog in the developing cities. Some characters look horrendous like the boy from the theater and Juno.

The set pieces are usually very cool and fun. Running through burning ships is cool! But sometimes, either the runup to or the entire set piece doesnt really feel Assassiny. I dont think an assassin should run directly at a line of muskets...

Ship gameplay is in its infancy here.

The DLC is very weird in a good way.

Good game. Not record breaking

games genuinely fun if you dont mind the small amounts of glitches and bugs, definitely rough around the edges with tons to nitpick about, but if you don't like it, it'll grow on you. promise.

I played this game for the first time in 2023, 11 years after its initial release. I also played the Liberation DLC, but since it's technically its own game I'm reviewing them separately.

[b]AC III[/b] : very good, I'd place it third after the original AC and Revelations. (I haven't played further AC games as of this review.)
[list]
[*]What I enjoyed : The combat mechanics feel insanely good in this game. Enemies are harder because they can block and counter you, sometimes unforgivingly so, but finishing them is always violent and bloody. Very, very satisfying. There are forts to take over that require combat skills, stealth skills, a bit of thinking and planning, so it's super rewarding when you manage to capture one. I liked all characters, they all have a lot of personality. The relationship (or lack thereof) between Haytham and Connor was all at once interesting, funny, and heartbreaking. Most sidequests are related to the plot so it did not feel like sidetracking to do them. And if you don't want to engage with side mechanics (like trading or crafting) it doesn't take away from the game. Finally, the environment and characters evolve throughout the story so it helps feel immersed in the world.
[*]What I didn't enjoy : The story took SO LONG to start. Spending three chapters establishing who Haytham is and what he's doing is just too long. Spending two more exploring Connor's past is just too long. That's almost half of the game ! I spent my time pleading "just get to the point !!" And once the story started it was a bit confusing to follow, in part because the Assassin/Templar divide does not always line up with the conflict itself, and because it feels like the game assumes you're familiar with the people and events. Which I am not. Finally, at one point you enter a new city but you CANNOT explore it because you're immediately caught in an inescapable quest, that takes the whole chapter to resolve. It's an important event and emotionally charged, but I spent my time shaking in frustration just wanting to explore. So extremely bad timing.
[/list]
While writing this review I realised there are lots of negative points (I didn't write everything), but overall I truly enjoyed playing it and I like the game as a whole.

[b]Liberation[/b] : mostly good, but mixed feelings.
[list]
[*]What I enjoyed : Finally playing a female character in a story with important female characters. The fact that missions can be resolved differently depending on which persona you choose to play. The very dynamic combat like in AC III, while keeping stealth as an important mechanic. Regarding the plot, while some things were easy to guess and others I was simply spoiled about, I had a few unexpected surprises that made sense in retrospect, so that felt good. The easy to guess things are easy only if you pay attention, so it's rewarding when you get to the point when your theories are confirmed.
[*]What I didn't enjoy : The story was incredibly confusing. While I understand the different characters' goals, I did not understand how they related to the missions I had to do. And the whole thing about Erudito showing up to tell you how things really happened adds to the confusion because it comes with no context (fortuntaly I was spoiled about that). It was also tedious to have to use one specific persona to do some missions, because you have to find a spot to change and you may be restricted in what you do. And when I stumbled upon a side quest for one persona while wearing another, I simply did not bother to do it^^'
[/list]
All in all it could be better, but it had really good elements that made it enjoyable.

Let me start off by saying, I love Assassin's Creed III. I was always a defender of Connor as a character and I adore the world, combat, and naval gameplay. However, as far as the PC port goes.....it doesn't even work for me. I have a very powerful PC  with an RTX 3080 and can only get the game to run at 15-20 fps, literally unplayable in every way. I can run games like Assassin's Creed Origins and Syndicate at 4K 60 fps so it is not a problem with my PC. Therefore, I have to conclude that the optimization for this PC port is just bad and if there is something I'm missing that I have to alter to get the game to work than it has still failed as a competent port. I never played more then the first game in the series when it came out and even if its essentially a demo for what was to come ,it was a very enjoyable experience. Now i decided to buy and play every single game in the series even the spin-off ones ,in order. After playing from AC1 to AC Brotherhood ,I was pleasantly surprised to not be fatigued by the gameplay and mechanics yet ,so i was excited for AC 3. Oh boy ,for every step forward it does 2 steps backwards. It felt like a soft reboot made by a different companie.
The specifics:
-The weapon wheel is gone and has been replaced with a menu screen where you can change your main and secondary weapon .
-You now need to change your ranged weapon to be able to call your horse for some fucking reason.
-Now most of the map is just woods and cities where most buildings are too far from each other to jump form rooftop to rooftop so you will do much much less parkour then any other AC games that came before it.
-Unlike previous installment when time elapse you just sit there and wonder why would your character just sit there and wait for things to happen and not further its cause, it doesn't feel justified in the slightest.
-The father son relationship is barely addressed in the entire game and the only missions you do with your father are the only missions where your character doesn't stop blabbering with the other character your with.
-Alot of missed opportunity with cinematic that could have been interesting playable set piece.
-Many stupid plot point made to make the game artificially longer.
-Removal of alot of mechanics like sending your assassins on mission to replace with mechanics that you wont need for the entirety of the game.
-Low incentive to do any side mission or trading since you all you can do with the money is buy different main and ranged weapons.

[i]*Since this is a remaster and I have already played the original two games, this review will not be about the two as games, but as remasters. If you wish you can check my review for [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/recommended/208480?snr=1_5_9__402]Assassin's Creed III[/url] and my review for [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/recommended/260210/]Assassin's Creed: Liberation HD[/url], where I "talk" about Assassin's Creed III & Assassin's Creed: Liberation HD as "whole" games.[/i]

Assassin's Creed III Remastered offers a bundle of two games, Assassin's Creed III and Assassin's Creed: Liberation HD. I'll break down my review into the good and bad aspects.

Starting with Assassin's Creed: Liberation HD, the remaster delivers noticeable improvements in graphics, environment, and lighting. Bugs were significantly reduced, making for a smoother gaming experience compared to the original. While some textures weren't replaced, this doesn't detract from the overall positive impression of the remaster. The addition of new features from the ACIII remaster, such as the mini-map, is a welcome enhancement.

As for Assassin's Creed III, the remaster impresses during outdoor activities like parkour and combat, offering stunning visuals and a vibrant atmosphere. The updated lighting adds a refreshing touch, although some may find certain instances of orange lighting to be overdone. The remaster includes new implementations missing from the original, like double-assassination from behind, killing from bushes, and improved free-aim with ranged weapons. These additions enhance the gameplay significantly. Additionally, some textures have been updated, adding to the overall positive experience of the remaster.

However, the story-mode faces some issues. The lighting at times breaks immersion, especially indoors, and weather effects occasionally act inconsistently. But the most significant problem lies with the character faces. While some remain the same as the original, others have been reworked and appear downgraded. This discrepancy is noticeable when comparing the original to the remaster, and it becomes the most substantial complaint about the remaster.

Furthermore, the remaster disappoints by not updating all in-game textures. Many textures remain unchanged, resulting in a clash with the improved lighting and visuals.

Another letdown is the locked 60fps cap. While the original allowed higher framerates, the animations from the original were not meant to be played at higher than 60 fps and they would at times break. The remaster fails to repair this, instead falsely presents the option to change the hz in the settings, but the fps stays capped at 60. 

A a big disappointment for me is not including Connor's amazing monologue. Check it [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a5bNt2LAfm8]here[/url] if you don't know what I mean. It's a missed opportunity not to include it, as it was also missing in the original, and it has been requested since forever.

Regarding multiplayer, the remaster does not have it at all, which may disappoint fans who enjoyed that aspect. Not me though. Although Ubisoft's decision to remove the original games from purchase is a really horrible move. Only to force players into buying the remaster. Offering players the choice between the original and remastered versions would have been a fairer approach.

Despite these criticisms, the remaster mostly shines, offering a stunning experience during 90% of the playthrough. For newcomers to the series or those who never played the original, the remaster provides an enjoyable experience without any complaints. However, for players familiar with the original, the downgraded character faces remain a significant concern, overshadowing the otherwise positive aspects of the remaster.

In terms of price, the remaster offers a good deal comparing to the prices of the two original games + their DLCs they once had. Best of all, you can get this whole remastered package for free (check if still available) if you purchase the Assassin's Creed: Odyssey Season Pass. 

For achievement hunters: on the downside, the lack of properly implemented achievements on Steam is a letdown. Although present in the remaster (84), players cannot see them in-game or on Steam, making it difficult to showcase their accomplishments. One can only see them as [url=https://imgur.com/gallery/iGRbtNj]screenshots[/url], on [url=https://www.backloggery.com/games.php?user=ciocolici&search=Assassin%27s+Creed+III%3A+Remastered&console=&status=&unplayed=&rating=&region=&own=0&alpha=1]Backloggery[/url], and written by myself on my [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/]Steam profile[/url]. The only place where you can see your achievements officially is Ubisoft Connect, but unfortunately, at the time I am writing this, they have still even to this day not implemented a way for people to see your achievements there, only you can do it. On top of that, (again: at the time I am writing this) you don't even get in-game notifications when you unlock/earn an achievement, with or without Ubisoft Connect's overlay on, with or without Ubisoft Connect's notifications options enabled.
If you go for 100% sync and do everything there is to be done in the game, you will end up with only a handful of achievements missing. These handful of achievements are though some of them not the easiest to complete. Especially "Original Gamer" and "An Extraordinary Man". And, of course, doing everything that's optional in an Assassin's Creed game, and going for 100% sync, is a challenge and time-consuming feat itself. Completing this game is not an easy task at all.

Got the game with the bundle of AC Odyssey([i] P.S.- Need to Install this first if you want to play AC III [/i]) which i feel is the best and only sensible option if you want to play it . Past reviews have mentioned it had quite a bit of negative feedback, and as you play along you can see why many hate this game in comparison to other AC series . Its true- not really much of remastered, it still feels old and glitchy. But if you do get a chance to download the game keep you expectations low and you will have a good time exploring colonial America which is made quite nicely in comparison to everything else in the game

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]-  it has a big learning curve for occasional gamers, meaning theres too many concepts to learn as you play the story, which seems nice in the start but you will realize you will have to wait for instructions every time and will never feel confident on the controls which may make you feel a bit irritated. Then adding to the discomfort of this is the non Intuitive movements of the character(s) through obstacles, just be prepared to keep restarting the mission if you want to finish the challenges and the mission in a smooth way, this honestly felt it wasnt at all developed to a final stage.
Few details regarding graphics were nice, tree movements and animals attacking make it less stressful at times. It gave a nice feel of Colonial America. Also extra activities and board  games played during that time were added which is a nice break from stressing on not able to complete a mission.

[h3] Storyline [/h3]- Okay now this is subjective, but in short- they could have thought a bit more on the character development, thats really missing as you play along or it doesnt come out strong as you end the game. The excitement or drama is missing for a long story telling process. One aspect for this missing element is that we don't engage much on the story line as a player- it passes of as cutscenes so we dont engage too many elements that feels like being a bi stander
Tho the ending does seem to wrap up nicely with a nice touch of drama  but finishes quickly with a lot of conclusions all cramped together.

[b] In conclusion [/b]- dont buy it as a standalone or in full rate, do play it or atleast try it out for a short while if you are a AC series fan cause its still a bit of Assassin in it tho maybe a lot weak in comparison to its previous series.it has a lot of flaws but again its a n AC game so if you want to play for the knowledge of what the story is  can try it out for a while before you give up.

I never much liked Assassin’s Creed 3. I found the setting and environment kinda dreary. Wasn’t too fussed by the anti-British stuff. Most people I know if you asked them about the British Empire they would look upon it with a mixture of pride and shame. We know we were massive dicks about things but it’s ancient history now.

Anyway, AC3 is the fifth instalment, Ubisoft apparently forgetting how to count, set during the American war for independence and is the start of what I think of as the second generation of Assassin’s Creed games defined by an improved free-running engine, open wilderness over sprawling cities and a de-emphasis on the struggle between Assassin’s and Templars in favour of exploring the setting. It’s almost laughable how you just stumble upon every major character and event from that time period. Every plot point is contrived coincidence just so they can crowbar in what feels like fan service.

Desmond’s woken up from his coma in the last game and has travelled to a precursor control room that will apparently save the world in some way. He’s got no idea how to use it but thankfully, the ghost of Juno knocks him out and his mated plug him back into the animus because it’s the only thing they know. They’re like those 18th century doctors and leaches, their only bloody solution to every problem is to plug you back into the animus. We also get to do some free-running segments outside the animus as he looks for batteries to power the machine, which is nice because so far the series hasn’t made much use of the potential for a modern Assassin’s Creed, running up the side of skyscrapers, infiltrating stadiums and slaughtering his way through Abstergo facilities.

For the first few hours, you play as Haytham, a composed and often bewildered British gentleman with an undercurrent of violence always ready with a sarcastic quip who sails for America searching for a first civilization storehouse, which may confuse anyone who looked at the cover art and saw a Native American in assassin whites. In the first scene of the game, he stabs someone up for a key that Desmond needs to turn the machine on, and that Haytham eventually discovers is no use to him as he can’t get past the door.
The game then shifts to his son Connor, a half-Mohawk boy whose mother, whose name I won’t even try to pronounce, is killed when the Templars burn his village down. He then goes off to join the Assassins when a glowing crystal ball says it’s the only way to protect his village from the encroaching European settlers and then we’re just stumbling from event to event doing everything from the history books about the independence war. The line that had me in hysterics was “How could this happen?! We destroyed the tea!” It’s a shame because Haytham was full of personality and I was enjoying playing as him, whereas Connor is a bit of a blank slate with no charisma.

It sound’s strange, but I didn’t feel like I was playing a game with this one. It’s more like a movie where I occasionally get to play the concluding scene. There’re lengthy cutscenes setting up a mission, and then the mission will be an extremely linear set of instruction following with little room for improvisation where often the support character does the work for you. And then it’s back to lengthy cut scenes to conclude the mission. This is a video game. You’re supposed to weave the narrative into gameplay, not just make me sit here watching your pre-animated movies.

Also, I don’t think they did a good job marrying the main Assassin’s versus Templars plot with the Civil War plot. You’re supposed to help out in the war to get closer to your targets but events unfold with a kind of inevitability that to me didn’t make any sense. I was struggling to see why everyone all agreed throwing tea into a harbour would solve all their problems. I think maybe we were too close to events, or even possibly too far. All the decisions are made by people you’ve only just bumped into or some minor secondary character and Connor just goes along with it and we end up with no agency in the story. The plot was strongest when it avoided the civil war stuff so I think we should have been either stabbing people up while a war happened in the background, or maybe we should have been leading it. Round about sequence 8 the game picks up for me but that’s a hell of a slog to get there.

I’ve mentioned it before but I really don’t like the environments this time round. They’re wooden ramshackle towns separated by a sparse, and yet somehow compacted, wilderness with no interesting landmarks to explore. Running through the streets of Constantinople, the entire map was built around how fun it is to scale buildings and towers from multiple sides, and leaping from roof to roof because the streets below were a maze. You don’t get that here. The maps have been built with historical accuracy in mind and often the only free-running sections are linearly laid out taking away the go-anywhere freedom that has defined the series. It’s a real shame.

Free-running has been much improved. It no longer requires me to hold down two buttons to run. Now it’s just hold down the trigger and you’ll sprint up a tree. Oh yeah, you can climb trees now, seeing as we’re a wilderness sandbox and there’s not many buildings about, along with rocks. I was impressed the first time I learned I could climb vertical crags, not sure why. But it created a freedom of movement that wasn’t previously available so I guess I just appreciated the step forward amongst the rest of the game’s flamboyant summersault backward.

Some complexity has been put back into combat requiring well-timed button pushes to counter enemy attacks, and it still flows well. I quite liked the feature where you can use an enemy as a human shield when you’re being shot at. This is the 18th century so muskets and flint-lock pistols are common, and I was surprised to see the game go for a realistic approach to reloading them, meaning it takes about fifteen years so you’re probably better off just grabbing a fresh one off a corpse. There’s also a new range of assassination tools to play with, which are interesting but that I never used because it’s never as efficient as just stabbing them.

Rather than buying up the whole of Rome, this time you’re given a manor house and its surrounding land to manage. You can unlock new buildings, upgrade existing ones and trade resources for money which is done in a similar way as to how sending your assassins on mission was done in the last two games and is kinda necessary now normal missions don’t pay out. This brings me to the point that one of my favourite parts of those games were the assassin recruits who grew as you used them and, while that’s still here, it’s been scaled down to just certain specific characters who don’t grow or evolve which is disappointing. But I don’t mind that because what they’ve been replaced with are naval missions where you upgrade your ship and sail around blowing up anything that looks at you funny and it’s a whole barrel of fun. These missions, for me at least, are easily the highlight of the game. You have to pay attention to wind direction, fullness of sails, rocks, enemy vessels, all sorts of stuff. I particularly enjoyed the stormy mission where fifty-foot rogue waves threatened to ruin your day and you had to duel a boat in between them.

The core issue with Assassin’s Creed 3 is that for a good portion of the game the player is just a bystander to the main plot and as such it’s impossible to be invested. Assassinating the Templars and arguing the philosophy was interesting and it should have lent more into that but the ending wraps everything up nicely and conclusively ends the Desmond arc, I suspect so they didn’t have to keep crowbarring him into whatever setting they wanted to do next. Despite all its faults I did enjoy the game but I definitely think it’s the weakest of the series.

This is one of those games where a conditional recommendation would be helpful, because Assassin's Creed III wasn't up to the standard of previous AC games, but I don't think it deserves a negative review, either. I got this for free with Assassin's Creed Odyssey, but I had played it previously on the PS3 and decided to give it another crack on PC.

Desmond Miles returns as our core protagonist, along with the Animus, which is again being used to uncover the past and the conflict between Assassins and Templars. The game is set around the time of the American Revolutionary War and centres around a Native American ancestor of Desmond's named Connor, beginning with his early life and training as an assassin. You'll explore the burgeoning cities of New York and Boston, as well as the wilds of the American frontier, participate in some notable historical events of the Revolutionary War and sail your own ship on the Atlantic.

The PC port is nothing spectacular and features a varierty of bugs, graphical and audio issues, some rather embarrassing control issues when using a mouse and keyboard... it's definitely far from perfect. But for those who've played it previously or who've enjoyed other Assassin's Creed titles, I still think it's deserving of a buy, when on sale. I wouldn't pay full price for it and I wouldn't recommend it as an introduction to the Assassin's Creed franchise, but it was too enjoyable for me personally to give a thumbs down, despite a few issues with the port.

The DLCs were also not upto the mark. The side quest and stuff were also not as enjoyable as well. But the game is required to be played for finishing the Desmond storyline which was according to me the only redeeming thing about this game. Though there is nothing about it that want us to play it again after our first playthrough.

According to various internet lists, [i]Assassin's Creed III[/i] (AC3) never ranks among the top tier Assassin's Creed games, so I adjusted my expectations accordingly when starting to play the Remastered version of the game. There is nothing wrong per se with AC3, but aside from the new setting and protagonist, it does not offer much new to the franchise (except perhaps the sailing mini-games). As a player, to enjoy this game, you have to find your balance and/or threshold for enjoying the main story versus trying to complete every arbitrary achievement or every menial side quest. Still, the game is a solid Assassin's Creed game, when compared to the prior games in the series. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
No real revelations since Revelations when it comes to gameplay mechanics with the exception of the sailing missions--but even those are not a new in-game mechanic but rather separate mini-games, albeit pretty good ones. The Remastered version may have introduced some other changes, but overall the mechanics are mostly the same as in the prior three games. In the frontier section of the game, there are some hunting mechanics not found previously in the series.  The expansion of the homestead, the protagonist's base of operations, was a nice addition and did provide some moments of levity and quiet.

[b]Characters/Customization[/b]
The new protagnist has a reasonably interesting story arc as a character, but unfortunately the voice acting performance lacked the correct rhythm and energy to entice me as the player and perhaps some of the "angst" dialogue written for the protagonist did not help their cause. So while the protagonist was great in a fight, I did not particularly look forward to the dramatic performances during cutscenes. In terms of customization, the new protagonist has pretty large assortment of outfits and weapons, although I pretty quickly settled on one outfit for the majority of the game. 

[b]Story/Atmosphere[/b]
In the early going, I found the new setting to be fresh and remarkably polished (perhaps courtesy of the Remaster). The New England setting during the days leading to the American Revolution should have been a rich source of inspiration. Colonial cities of Boston and New York are reasonably well represented, but at some point repetitive architecture and the mobs of cloned civilians and British soldiers start to dull the mind.  The "frontier" component of AC3 is also bit hit and miss--pretty landscape but not too many memorable landmarks: just a big patch of land with a few colonial buildings.

Overall the story of AC3 is pretty much par for the series except it does contain a remarkable plot twist, certainly the best one in the series to this point, certainly more intriguing than those non-sensical sci-fi events occuring outside the Animus.  The main story does try to tangentially touch on events that were taking place during the American Revolution with mixed success.

[b]Graphics/Sound[/b]
The Remastered version of AC3 looked and sounded good (although I did not play the original AC3, so I cannot say if the Remastered version looked or sounded better. For the most part, the engine seemed fairly similar to the one used in the prior two games.  I did not encounter any bugs that come to mind.

[b]Replay Value:[/b] None.  At the time of writing this review, I have not embarked on the DLC yet and still have some unfinished side quests--namely sailing mission--and I am undecided whether I will complete those or not before moving on to the next game in the series.

[b]Overall Score:[/b] 7/10
