By, 2023, many rankings of the releases in the main series of Assassin's Creed place AC3 at or near the bottom. This surprises me, not because the game is exceptionally good, (it's not), nor that you need to play it (you most certainly don't), but because it seems to be at least a minor improvement on the games that came before it, which themselves were, at best, mediocre. While I've not played any subsequent releases, the plot is just as engaging as the Ezio and Altair entries. The voice acting is solid outside a scant few characters (I don't speak Mohawk, but the clan mother's performance is as wooden as the forest.)  The main line missions are varied and often fun. The new sea-faring battles are probably the best and most original gameplay element in the series up to this point, period,  Building a town in the homestead is a novel and worthwhile variation on how to add a ton of side-quests, and all in all, it works.

For completionists, the game can be a grinding slog, with many nearly meaningless collection side-quests and tasks, but in a wilderness outerworld, a developing town, and two colonial cities, that grind seems a tad more varied than similar quests in the games before it.  Dropping some of the previous quest typess, namely feather collection and assassin guild training, would have made the game more fun, but it appears that Ubisoft wants to keep growing the individual games until they're bloated.

Like I said, I do think the plot is fairly strong, but this is despite the main character, not because of him. Besides occasional anger issues, Connor is too much of a white knight, and he can be aloof to the point of icy and idealistically naive, emotionally pushing away many of the parties he's trying to help and save.  Avoiding spoilers, there is another, far less heroic character (or three) that if adjusted to be less fundamentally immoral, could have made for a more interesting protagonist.

The controls are a bit glitchy, but the combat and stealth, for the most part, work.  The battling like all games in this genre, becomes monotonous, but there's enough weapons, environments, and enemy types, to keep it borderline entertaining. 

To reiterate, the game is not great.  But I read of players who consider skipping from Revelations to Black Flag, and frankly, it's not bad enough to justify such a course. If you've enjoyed the previous games enough to want to suffer through another Assassin's Creed, it may as well be this one.

Don't get me wrong AC 3 is definitely a classic and a great game. Though it takes a while to really get going it is good. The problem is with this remaster. Constant stutters and frame drops, occasional crashes, and a few glitches. The glitches can be game-breaking. So its better to play the classic version if you have it and if you still decide to buy this keep in mind all the problems I mentioned above.

Parts 5 & 6 of my Assassin's Creed replay in 2023. AC3 was the first game in the series that I beat. After AC1 left a bad taste my mouth, having abandoned it after multiple attempts, I avoided the series throughout the Ezio trilogy when they were first released. Yes, a thing I regret later on. The trailer for AC3 got me so hyped up to kill redcoats that it drew my back in. I'm a sucker for American history, being from here of course. And being from the NY region that the game was set made it even more relatable. When I finally began playing I found a far more polished Assassin's Creed experience. The combat was a blast, the story was engaging and coherent, everything was improved! And then... that opening twist! Boy howdy this game had me hooked.

I was shocked to find that it was a fairly popular opinion that this was a weaker entry to the series around it's release. But it seems that over the years, public opinion has grown far kinder to it. And this remaster certainly helps. Upgraded graphics, cleaner UI, bug fixes (though not all of them, this is still a Ubisoft game after all). The lighting in particular makes such a difference. Don't be turned off by the hideous screenshots you may see of facial animations during cut-scenes. Yes they are there but they're such a small part of the game-play experience. When you're actually in the game and playing as Connor, the improvement of the world is far more appreciable. I'm not really sure what happened to the faces close-up though.

Also included in this remaster was Assassin's Creed: Liberation. I had played this one before and also replayed it now. And both left me kind of... meh? Not a terrible entry but also nothing exceptional. If it weren't for the remaster I likely would not have replayed this one and stuck strictly to the main-line games. Makes me wonder if I want to replay Freedom Cry. I'm sure this was a good game for portable gaming or on the toilet. And the remaster certainly makes it more playable for modern desktops.

Overall, Asssassin's Creed III is a must play entry to the series. Be it the original or the remaster. Liberation is probably a pass unless you're an AC superfan.

Assassin's Creed 1 was pretty good. A great start, humble beginnings, but the gameplay gets a little repetitive. AC2 builds on it. There's new weapons, new mechanics, new maps, and new ways to play the game. AC Brotherhood builds even more, giving you upgrades to your old weapons, and the ability to build a team and call them in to strike when you need someone else to take out a target for you. The storytelling is the best part of these games though, the way they explain what's happening by showing, not telling is masterful. They let you understand the story from the perspective of the character you play as, and reveal information as they would know it.

AC 3 rewinds a lot of things. The UI looks like Time Splitters 2, the "remastered," graphics are hot garbage, they didn't build on anything AC2's trilogy had to offer, like mechanics, weapons, or anything, and the storytelling reminds me of those old hood movies like Baby Boy and Juice, where they narrate the entire time. Fucking boo, I'm loathing the game and moving on.

Also, I skipped Revelations because it wasn't in the AC bundle for some reason. No idea why, but Brotherhood ends with someone getting stabbed and I have no idea how Desmond's dad got here. I'm not paying $20 for a game that's well over a decade old, you know?

[h1] Tomahawk chop is my death blow! [/h1]

[b] Assassin’s Creed III [/b]
Assassin’s Creed III is the fifth installment in a third-person stealth franchise that uses historical drama to tell its narrative. The story follows directly after the last game, where Desmond has woken up from his coma and is using the memories of a different ancestor. This time we explore the history of 18th-century Colonial America at the beginning of the American Revolution. You take control of an Indigenous American who, for brevity’s sake, we’ll refer to as Connor.

It’s immediately evident that this game is much more ambitious than its predecessors. Using a brand-new engine with a much larger world and an expanded range of game mechanics. However, they have prioritized flashy combat over the stealth mechanics featured in earlier titles.

The choice of setting AC3 in Colonial America, not only limits the architectural features to admire but also compromises the parkour aspect. The camera is positioned closer to Connor, creating a sense of confinement and he feels less responsive and more sluggish to control, particularly when compared to previous installments.

Despite these complaints, there is a glimmer of hope in the form of AC3's innovative addition of naval combat. While deviating from the traditional Assassin's Creed gameplay, this feature is a welcomed addition largely absent from video games at the time, save for top-down strategy games. You face formidable ships and battalions whilst contending with stormy weather and large waves. It’s both thrilling and claustrophobic, whilst you learn to anticipate the delay in maneuvering your large vessel. 

Sadly, I have very little to say regarding the narrative, other than a clever bait-and-switch that I’m not going to spoil, there wasn’t much intrigue to be had. As someone not as familiar with the finer details of early American history, I’m not qualified on the accuracy of the depicted events. It mostly felt like a slideshow of all the significant events, with Connor serving as the sole driving force behind each part of the American Revolution. 
However, I must commend the portrayal of certain historical figures, such as Benjamin Franklin, who, from my understanding was a chauvinistic and generally unpleasant guy.

[b] DLC: [/b]
Tyranny of King Washington is a brief non-canon narrative that is included in this edition of AC3. For what it’s worth it’s a bit more experimental incorporating more fantastical abilities in the form of animal spirit guides. The Eagle ability made rooftop traversal a much more pleasant experience, something the aforementioned core game didn’t manage to do. 
While not an essential component, it is a worthwhile addition.

[b] Assassin’s Creed Liberation Remastered [/b]
Originally released on the handheld console Playstation Vita, the gameplay resembles AC:2 albeit with some minor adjustments. Set in 18th-century French Louisiana, the game follows the story of Aveline, the first black female protagonist in the franchise. 

The narrative delves into the transatlantic slave trade and the player is required to experiment with Aveline’s relation to class and gender. 
Aveline can alter her appearance to suit specific social circumstances, which can either limit or enhance her combat capabilities. 

For instance, her dress may impede her movement but enable her to blend in with the upper-class society she belongs to. Alternatively, she can don a slave or assassin disguise, which provides her with greater mobility but also restricts her movements in certain areas. Despite its small scale, the game manages to tell a more captivating story than the one it was bundled with.

[b] Conclusion: [/b]
AC3 is my least favorite game in the series thus far. This is unfortunate as the opportunity to explore the American Revolution from the perspective of an Indigenous person presents a wealth of potential for an engaging and thought-provoking experience. Despite efforts to improve upon previous titles, AC3, unfortunately, retains the series' most unfavorable aspects, which not only detract from the enjoyment of this game but also negatively impacted AAA game design for years to come.

Titlu: "O aventură istorică captivantă în timpul Războiului de Independență"

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Review:
Assassin's Creed III aduce o experiență fascinantă în lumea Războiului de Independență a Statelor Unite. Cu o poveste complexă și un protagonist memorabil, jocul combină acțiunea asasinilor cu istoria reală într-un mod captivant.

Puncte forte:

1. Decorul istoric impresionant: Jocul reușește să creeze o reprezentare autentică a Americii din secolul al XVIII-lea. De la străzile aglomerate ale orașelor la peisajele pitorești ale pădurilor, fiecare detaliu reflectă atenția acordată istoriei și autenticității.

2. Personajul principal memorabil: Connor Kenway, un amestec între amerindian și britanic, adaugă o nouă dimensiune seriei Assassin's Creed. Evoluția sa de la un tânăr curios la un asasin hotărât este captivantă și te ține angajat în cursul acțiunii.

3. Mecanici de luptă și navigație îmbunătățite: Sistemul de luptă a fost revizuit, oferind o gamă mai variată de mișcări și abilități. De asemenea, navigarea prin mediu a fost îmbunătățită, permițându-ți să explorezi lumea cu mai multă fluiditate și ușurință.

Puncte slabe:

1. Probleme tehnice sporadice: Chiar dacă jocul în sine este bine realizat, există momente în care tehnica jocului poate întâmpina mici probleme, precum bug-uri sau anumite aspecte de clipping.

2. Ritm narativ neuniform: Povestea jocului poate părea dezordonată în anumite secțiuni, cu un ritm narativ neuniform între evenimentele dinainte și din timpul Războiului de Independență.

Concluzie:
Assassin's Creed III reușește să aducă o nouă perspectivă asupra seriei, transportând jucătorii într-o epocă istorică captivantă. Cu o poveste complexă și îmbunătățiri semnificative în mecanicile de joc, acest titlu este o alegere excelentă pentru cei interesați de aventură, acțiune și istorie. I got this as part of my Odyssey season pass, and it is absolutely worth it if you got this similarly. Not too sure about the standalone price, though. 

I was first introduced to the franchise with AC III and Bloodlines (PSP), and I appreciate that Ubisoft remastered this game. However, please understand that this version is a REMASTER, and not a REMAKE. Big difference. As such, you cannot expect the gameplay to change much from what it originally was - the fact that they improved it as much as they did is quite surprising. You also cannot expect graphics on the level of Unity, or the later games. This is because the devs are working with the same engine as they did back in 2012, and to update that would mean recreating the game from scratch, at which point it steps into remake territory. 

That being said, I was pleasantly surprised with the improvements made to the game overall. The graphics look much better (although the character models in some scenes could do with some work), and the gameplay is less frustrating than it originally was. I am quite bummed that the story doesn't really change much, though that's really what's to be expected - This is a REMASTER, not a REMAKE, after all. I was also slightly put out by the lack of Steam achievements.

In summary, do not expect this to drastically change the older game - it doesn't. Do not expect gameplay on the level of the concept footage - it won't happen. DO expect a somewhat better visual experience, and less frustrating gameplay. DO expect a more seamless, less buggy version of the original. And above all, take it as a damn REMASTER, not a REMAKE.

Title: A Stunning Return to Revolutionary Greatness!

Rating: ★★★★★

If you're a fan of the Assassin's Creed series, prepare to be blown away all over again with Assassin's Creed III Remastered! As a long-time follower of this franchise, I couldn't be happier with the care and dedication that has gone into bringing this classic gem back to life.

The first thing that struck me was the jaw-dropping visual overhaul. The attention to detail is astounding – from the intricacies of the environments to the characters' expressive faces, everything has been lovingly revamped. Boston and New York have never looked so vibrant, and the sprawling frontier is now a breathtaking wilderness waiting to be explored.

But it's not just the graphics that have received a facelift; the gameplay enhancements are equally remarkable. The controls feel smoother and more responsive, making the parkour and combat sequences even more thrilling. I was thrilled to rediscover Connor's unique fighting style, and the naval battles are an absolute blast with their revamped mechanics.

The narrative, one of the highlights of the original game, remains as engrossing as ever. The historical backdrop of the American Revolution is captivating, and the story's twists and turns kept me on the edge of my seat. With the Remastered version, the already engaging narrative is now supplemented by even more detailed character models and animations, further immersing me in this rich world.

The addition of all the DLC content is a fantastic bonus. I got to experience the intriguing alternate history scenarios of the Tyranny of King Washington, adding extra depth to the game's lore.

In conclusion, Assassin's Creed III Remastered is an absolute triumph. Ubisoft has truly outdone themselves by revitalizing this beloved classic. Whether you're a die-hard fan or a newcomer to the series, this remaster is a must-play. It's a nostalgic trip back to a pivotal chapter in the Assassin's Creed saga, now brought to life in stunning detail. Don't miss out on reliving the revolutionary adventure that captured our hearts all those years ago!
You can actually get this game for free with AC Odyssey's season pass.

A Reimagined Classic with Enhanced Visuals and Nostalgic Charm

Rating: ★★★★☆

Assassin's Creed 3 Remastered breathes new life into the iconic 2012 installment of the Assassin's Creed franchise, delivering a visually stunning and polished experience that revitalizes the epic tale of Connor Kenway during the American Revolution.

The remastered version pays great attention to the game's visual fidelity, enhancing character models, environments, and textures. The result is a significant improvement over the original, with crisp details, improved lighting, and vibrant colors that make the game world more immersive and captivating. Players are treated to breathtaking vistas of colonial America and the bustling cities of Boston and New York, bringing the historical setting to life in a way that modern gaming technology allows.

The core gameplay mechanics remain faithful to the original, with the smooth parkour and combat system that the franchise is known for. Players can still enjoy free-running through trees and engaging in thrilling stealthy assassinations. However, the remastered version includes some quality-of-life improvements, making the overall experience more fluid and enjoyable.

The main character, Connor, is a complex and layered Assassin with a compelling personal story, grappling with themes of identity and justice. The narrative explores the turmoil of the American Revolution, showcasing the morally gray nature of the conflict and its impact on Connor's journey. The game's historical accuracy and attention to detail in recreating notable events and figures of the time add an educational aspect to the gaming experience.

The inclusion of all the original game's post-launch content, including the Tyranny of King Washington DLC, is a welcome addition to the remastered edition. These expansions provide players with extra hours of engaging content that further enriches the story and adds new challenges.

The remastered version also benefits from improved performance, offering more stable frame rates and reduced loading times compared to the original release. This optimization contributes to a smoother and more enjoyable gameplay experience.

While the remastered version breathes new life into Assassin's Creed 3, some aspects of the game may feel dated compared to more recent entries in the series. Certain gameplay elements, particularly the combat mechanics, may feel less refined compared to newer Assassin's Creed titles. Additionally, the pacing of the story and certain mission structures could have been improved to align with modern gaming standards.

In conclusion, Assassin's Creed 3 Remastered is a nostalgic trip down memory lane for fans of the original game and a fresh opportunity for newcomers to experience the story of Connor Kenway in all its visual splendor. The enhanced graphics and additional content make it a worthwhile investment, and the historical setting provides a captivating backdrop for an engaging and immersive gaming experience.

If you enjoyed the original Assassin's Creed 3 or are curious about exploring the American Revolution through the eyes of an Assassin, the remastered edition is well worth playing.

Assassins Creed III:
I miss Ezio and every element he brought to the franchise, but this game is worthwhile in a different way. First of all it's the final chapter of the Desmond protagonist in a quick and unsatisfying manner. Still, the modern story line throughout the rest of the game branched out from previous games and actually made me excited to leave the animus. In the revolution story line, Conner was a far less interesting character than I expected, and I really enjoyed my time playing as Haytham, or with him, significantly more. There is a lot of lost potential with many of the characters and overall the plot felt shallow. Enough of the negatives. Overlooking the downsides, the combat system was completely reworked in a very good way. It makes way for a lot more cool animations and keeps me on my toes, having to pay attention to who I'm fighting to change my play style accordingly. The parkour feels lacking with the loss of my hookblade, but the actual climbing style is a nice touch, appearing more realistic as a human scampering up the side of a building (If only the cities were more dense to enjoy the parkour). Most of all the immersion provided the aura of excitement. Having learned about the events of the Revolutionary War in history, here I am living vicariously through many significant events like the Boston Tea Party and the Battle of the Chesapeake. Would recommend playing and a worthy successor to pick up after leaving behind our beloved Ezio.

Assassins Creed Liberations:
There's really not much to say I did not enjoy playing this game and I would not recommend playing unless you absolutely want to play every single title in the franchise. It was a struggle to get through with the graphics and ui paling in comparison to AC3, which could be forgivable considering it's history in development, if it had any semblance of an interesting story line.

As of writing this review, I've completed the main game and have yet to play the DLC/Liberations.

Assassin's Creed III to me always felt like a very underrated game in the series, and overhated as well. To me the story was very interesting from beginning to end (although somewhat depressing in certain areas). The American Revolution was a great theme and something I'm deeply interested as well.

The remaster leaves a lot to be desired though. To me the game looks and feels no different from what I played back in 2012/2013 and the game is still as buggy as I remember. There were a lot of points in the game where I got soft-locked and had to reload a checkpoint. If anything, this remaster feels like a way to re-release an older game for a 40 euro price tag.

But shoving that aside, the game itself is extremely fun and engaging. You get a lot of content with this remaster (the DLC + AC Liberations), it runs great on both my PC and Steam Deck, and in the end it's worth playing and picking up if you haven't done so already.

If you already own the original version of Assassin's Creed III, I'd pass on this one.

There's a couple things that put it at a disadvantage coming off of the Ezio trilogy though. First, a lot of people disliked Connor after the charismatic Ezio. I won't lie, Connor is different enough to be pretty jarring, but he's actually a really interesting character for a number of reasons, and anyone who says he's dull doesn't understand the point of the character or his culture. Second, the game shipped with a bunch of bugs. Early patches fixed a lot of them, but some are still present. It's really luck of the draw whether you encounter one any more. I've played through four times, the only occasional thing I've seen is npc pop in. Third, the cities are laid out based on actual maps, making running over rooftops continuously more difficult. Personally I think it's cool they did something like that to make their historical representation more accurate. Fourth, they introduced new things that met with mixed reactions. They changed the way parkour works, they put in ship combat, and they put in tunnels to unlock fast travel. The new parkour is awesome when tree running, the ships are a cool experiment that gets even better in black flag, and the tunnels were at least fun for me, but I like mazes and puzzles and I guess most people don't.

Also, for a remastering of a game you would assume that the bugs in the original release would have been fixed or made manageable, but they sadly did not.  Overall, it is a decent game and concludes the main arc with Desmond.

I have started multiple Assassins Creed games but dropped them soon after because I lost interest, except Assassins Creed 3. This game's story is captivating (minus Desmond's story), and always has me wondering what will happen next. The plot twist at the end of the first arc (IFKYK) literally had me stand up and audibly yell "WOT!" The combat in this game is fluid, reminding me of Spiderman PS4, which is a good thing. 

The main thing I HATED about this game was Desmond's story. I could not give less of a shit about Desmond, or anything happening around him. The whole last part of running around the cave and watching cutscenes that I don't care about was so excruciating. I have never wanted a game to end as badly as I did playing the end of this game, which is unfortunate because Connor's story is incredible. 

The whole remaster thing is a bit of a joke. There were multiple times during my playthrough where I genuinely forgot that this is a remaster from 2019. It's buggy, I got softlocked twice, the characters' faces look a bit goofy, and whilst the lighting looks kinda good, the rest of the game looks subpar for 2019. If you're expecting an amazing overhaul to a game from your childhood, you will be disappointed. But if you have never played this game before, this is a good way to experience it.

It's been a long time when I first stepped on Connor and Aveline's journey. The process is rarely excruciating but I still have to say the game was not bad. Long live the assassins. Requiescat In Pace.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Okay, so I 100% sync'd more or less all of the content that this game offers, so I'll give as thorough a review as possible.

First, buy this game in the bundle with AC: Odyssey, even if you don't play Odyssey it's still the better deal. You will have to open Odyssey first for the game to link to your Ubisoft account though, so just keep that in mind.

The first game I played was AC Liberation, which comes as a part of this bundle. Don't waste your time with this one, it's honestly just really bad. I went through and did all the collectibles and all the story and full sync and everything. It sucked. They had an interesting idea with the persona system which would be interesting to see come back. The combat was also good, but that's because it's identical to III's combat. The movement and parkour in general are pretty janky, and all the side content to this game is just not fun. The story is super flat too, the characters suck, and the plot ends without leaving any real impact on the player. DO NOT BOTHER WITH LIBERATION.

Here's the real meat; AC III is actually a pretty good game. The plot is pretty fun imo, and even a lot of the side stuff is relatively fun too, particularly the naval missions. Connor is a good character too, and Haytham is a badass. Desmond's real world sections are more action packed than in the Ezio Trilogy, and I found them to be very fun. The combat is awesome and feels a bit more polished (and easier) than in the Ezio Trilogy. However, it's not all good news. The parkour has been simplified, but somehow it feels like you have even less control than you did in the first games of the franchise, and it sometimes felt like you had no control in those. Like in all Ubisoft games, there's a lot of side content that just isn't that fun. Tons of collectibles, lots of exhausting open world challenges, full sync requirements that sometimes come straight from the pits of hell, and a LOT of bugs that weren't fixed from the original game despite this being a remaster. Overall, I wouldn't try to 100% complete this game, but it's definitely worth a playthrough.

Lastly, the Tyranny of King Washington DLC. Honestly, super fun and unique! My verdict is basically the same as with the main game, you should definitely play it but I would not advise doing 100% completion. I'd do the memory fragments to help better understand the plot, but don't bother going for the side quests (they can be kinda buggy and really boring) and don't bother going for the full sync requirements (although none of them are that bad in this DLC)

TLDR; Buy this game in the bundle with AC Odyssey. Don't play Liberation (it's bad), and don't bother with 100% completion for III or its DLC, but definitely play the main story missions and any side content that you find fun.

Honestly, I really enjoyed this game. The modern day story was my favourite so far and the American setting was definitely interesting. That being said, I don’t think it deserves to be called a remaster. So many textures clearly had no work done on them since the first game and every character still looks as lifeless (only at a higher resolution now). The TAA solution produced very obvious artifacting around water and the screen space reflections on water never looked any part realistic (eg. parts of the city hidden by fog are reflected on the water but you can’t see them otherwise)
For players who really want to play this game, I recommend getting it through one of the higher editions of Odyssey (by which this game is included) as this game is not worth even the sale price in most regions.

[h1]7.8/10[/h1]

[b] Pros [/b]
     - Solid conclusion to the Desmond Miles story arc (not the best but defiantly not bad)
     - Fluid and fun assassin's creed gameplay, up to this point it's some of the better implementation of it all 
        mixing a solid balance of the aggressive and stealth styles
     - Good amount of content, the original game plus the DLC is a solid amount to get through
     - Liberations is better than expected, not amazing and definitely could have been so much more, but for 
        what it is, solid
     - Overall a fun gameplay experience 

[b] Cons [/b]
     - The "remaster" part seems a little weird, some portions of the game don't look like much of a remaster 
        at all, some look better. This is definitely more evident when playing the DLC which seems to have no 
        been remastered? 
     - The DLC while solid, leaves a lot to be desired, the Tyranny of King Washington just feels like it's tacked 
        on and doesn't provide much there. As mentioned above, Liberations is decent to play through but 
        100% could have been a great entry and just never got fully realized
     - Bugs, nothing game breaking this time around, but plenty of strange ones. Most common was people 
        randomly walking backwards, and random visual glitches that fixed themselves when pausing and 
        unpausing
      - The story definitely gets a bit tedious, but still relatively satisfying when figuring things out
      - I feel there's a missed opportunity here to make the hunting a more involved piece of the game

Overall Assassin's Creed III Remastered is solid enough. The remaster portion means kinda little as it doesn't seem that upgraded or remastered from the original content. It's definitely slightly improved but nothing even close to ground breaking. The overall gameplay is good fun, it's Assassin's Creed after all and I think they did a great job once again of just making a fun overall game. The free running is still finicky but definitely a cool addition to add the more forested areas. 

At this point you're likely someone who's already played the first bunch of games and if that's the case, it's a worth entry to finish off this particular story line. It definitely could have been better. The bugs could be toned down, the overall story could feel a bit better paced and more involved, and I think there could have been a deeper dive into the Miles story line. Some of the gameplay just gets a bit frustrating but I think it's bound to happen in these titles. I felt like the first time around I definitely enjoyed every element of this game, but now experiencing it nearly 12 years later it just falls a bit more flat than I remember. Still overall a good and fun game, with a solid amount of content.

DON'T BUY THIS WITH THE AC: ODYSSEY SEASON PASS 

I can't believe that they made it like this. If you buy the AC: Odyssey season pass, you get AC III Remastered and Liberation HD basically for free, but you can't play them without downloading AC: Odyssey first! The game asks you for a CD key that is nowhere to be found and Ubisoft support team's solution is to download a 100GB game, run it so that you can gain access to AC III Remastered/Liberation HD and then download another 30GB on top of that! This has to be the most ridiculous thing a game developer has ever done. I'm truly at a loss for words. What a waste of time.

Assassin's Creed 3 had me hooked from the start with its captivating story and immersive gameplay. Despite encountering a handful of bugs throughout my playthrough, I still managed to have a blast with this game. The exceptional storytelling kept me engaged and motivated to push through these setbacks.

One of the major annoyances I faced were the NPCs occasionally getting stuck during tail missions. It could be frustrating to have to restart or find workarounds to progress, but the intriguing narrative helped me stay committed. The horse mechanics also suffered from some notable bugs, which could disrupt the flow of gameplay when attempting to ride them. These issues did detract from the overall experience, but they were not game-breaking.

My decision to play Assassin's Creed 3 was primarily driven by my desire to experience the entire series in chronological order. Despite the frustrations caused by these bugs, I'm glad I embarked on this journey. The game's strengths lie in its compelling storyline and the rich historical setting it offers.

Considering the bugs, I find it unlikely that I will revisit this particular installment. However, I wholeheartedly recommend giving it a try, especially if you're a fan of the Assassin's Creed series or enjoy captivating narratives set in historical periods. Just be aware that you may encounter some technical hiccups along the way.

Assassin's Creed 3 is undoubtedly a great game, marred only by its occasional issues. If you're willing to overlook these bugs, you'll be rewarded with an engaging experience that will leave you hungry for more of the series. Give it a shot and join the adventure!

Didnt even make it past sequence 3 before writting this... How awful. First of all, I love how the game will sound like salt and pepper unless i turn windows spatial sound on, and then off again every single time i launch it. I also find the 3-4 times ive managed to get stuck in between objects to be absolutely thrilling gameplay. But what really got me is that damn modern day cave vault door; the ONE thing youre supposed to care about as a player. "What is this door? what secrets lie behind it? is there anything that can save us in there?" which would be cool and all, except the door is actually invisible, just leaving the cave with this giant skybox at the ass end of the cave at all times. Yeah, its a petty reason, but if youre gonna waste my time with an 80% broken game, you can do me the courtesy of animating a blue fucking door properly.

Edit: I decided to play through and 100% every Assassins Creed, but after even further hours of play ima have to drop this one entirely. These bugs are game breaking at this point, a camera locked in place until my character gets attacked, jumping off of a moving wagon, and end up jumping 3.5 stories to the top of a building's ledge, even an invisible (and incounterable) ghost slowly hitting me to death. THIS GAME DOES NOT WORK. This is a remaster of a 10 year old game, the remaster itself being 4 years old now. Get this game if you are passionate about the series or really wanna *try* to relive the og AC3 memories, just know the glitches on here are even worse than the og, and eventually while playing youll feel like this specific title was given a golden goose opportunity to elevate itself over the mediocre critical acclaim of its first release, yet chooses not too. Playing now, i truly wonder if its better at all than the og AC3, and in some cases even worse than i remember. It really is sad when i can confidently say that my elective gamedev class back in highschool could cook something up more reliable than a professional AAA studio has. All the worse theres no buying the old version, and this is the FINALE of Desmond's arc. Fuck Ubisoft

AC: 3 - The ending to epic story of Desmond Miles. To me, this is where the AC series should have ended. But Ubisoft fired the man who started the series, proceeded to turn this IP into a cow for milking and killed off everyone's beloved character. Oh well, that was the downside. The upside, though, is how they revamped the combat system in this game. Comparing to its predecessors, the game is much more polished. Mechanics are better implemented, although it wasted all of our time practicing parkour with the W and right-mouse from all the previous games. 

Overall, a 7/10 would suffice. It is not outstandingly good, but it is far from being the worst. If you want to complete the AC feelings with Desmond, you should pick this one up.

My experience with the older AC games is few and far between. I played the original Assassin's Creed game of Xbox 360 and this game was my first attempt to play some of the older titles. Odyssey and Valhalla have been the games I'm more familiar with. 

Onto the game itself. Wow, the critics were certainly right about the main character of this game. Conner is one of the most boring and uninteresting characters I've seen in a story-driven game in my life. He is nothing but a plank of wood that speaks, he either has no emotion at all or is brash and angry, with no in-between or depth. When it comes to the gameplay, there is definitely some left to be desired. I personally struggled with the social stealth mechanic, however, there were certainly times where the enemy detection was quite ridiculous and unfair, especially on the medium difficulty. 

When it comes to the word 'Remastered', they used it quite loosely, the main differences is just an updated lighting engine and upscaled textures. The models have absolutely no change in terms of polygons and the faces are still quite rough around the edges, quite literally. I would've liked to have seen a bit more when it comes to the remaster, even if it meant adding in some stuff from the other games that came out after, such as making the naval combat more similar to Black Flag which is, to some, more superior than this game's is. 

Overall, 5/10. A game, but just not that good of one.

Summary:
Assassin's Creed III is the fifth major installment in the Assassin's Creed series, developed by Ubisoft Montreal and released in 2012. Set during the American Revolution in the late 18th century, the game follows the story of a new protagonist named Connor Kenway, also known as Ratonhnhaké:ton, a half-British, half-Native American assassin.

The game begins in the 18th century, where a Templar named Haytham Kenway travels to the American colonies to retrieve an artifact that holds great power. He establishes connections and forms alliances, ultimately leading to the birth of his son, Connor, with a Native American woman named Ziio.

As Connor grows up, he witnesses his village being destroyed by colonial forces, leading him to join the Assassins in their fight against the Templars. Under the guidance of his mentor, Achilles Davenport, Connor trains to become an assassin and seeks revenge against those responsible for his people's suffering.

Throughout the game, Connor becomes involved in significant events of the American Revolution, including the Boston Massacre, the Battle of Bunker Hill, and the signing of the Declaration of Independence. He encounters historical figures such as George Washington, Benjamin Franklin, and Thomas Jefferson.

Connor's primary objective is to find and eliminate Templar targets who are manipulating the conflict to further their own interests. These include Charles Lee, a high-ranking Templar and the main antagonist of the game. Connor's journey takes him through various cities and wilderness regions, from Boston to New York, as he uncovers the Templars' plans and attempts to prevent them from achieving their goals.

As the story progresses, Connor discovers the existence of an ancient First Civilization temple and a grand conspiracy that spans centuries. He must navigate the complexities of the war and confront the ethical dilemmas of the Assassin-Templar conflict.

Assassin's Creed III combines elements of open-world exploration, stealth-based gameplay, and historical fiction. It explores themes of freedom, justice, and the blurred lines between good and evil. The game received positive reviews for its immersive world, engaging storyline, and innovative gameplay mechanics.

[h1] Thoughts [/h1] 
I feel AC3 is starting to become more appreciated these days. I like the setting, Connor as a character and a more "grey" story. While the remaster is simple cash grab, it's definitely worth it if you get it through the Odyssey edition.

[h1] Score: 8/10 [/h1]

[table]
    [tr]
        [td]Story📖[/td]
        [td]Dynamic.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay🎮[/td]
        [td]Visually Improved.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Difficulty💪[/td]
        [td]Fairly easy.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Length⏱️[/td]
        [td]16 to 30 hours.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Visuals🎨[/td]
        [td]For a remaster, pathetic.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Audio🎵[/td]
        [td]Soundtrack always hits.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Performance⚡️[/td]
        [td]Capped at 60fps[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Price💰[/td]
        [td]Not worth full price.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Worth Getting? 🤔[/td]
        [td]I'd say it is.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
[list]
   [*]The first 5 hours or so are you playing as Haythem Kenway, coming to like him and his companions, especially Charles Lee. I appreciate what they have done here as I've gotten older. Showing you a different point of view of the world.
   [*]Essentially a second prologue takes place when you swap to the actual games protagonist, Connor or Ratonhnhaké:ton, his actual name. This feels tedious, and you essentially get taught how to do all the same stuff as you did with Haythem.
   [*]I like Connor as a character, he's Stoic, Stubborn, and focused. Which are traits he shares with Altair but he is also Naive, inexperienced and bitter, which it makes sense considering what he experiences through his life.
   [*]Instead of creating a brand new story in a historical setting, Ubisoft has essentially forced these characters into well known events, while being really cool to witness, it's awkward and makes no sense, especially for Connor. 
   [*]Scenes were Haythem and Connor are together are by far the best in the game, they challenge each other and are a great dynamic.
   [*]Modern day, has us continuing right off the previous games, and to be honest i did not like the direction it headed. Desmond's story did need to end, that was a given, just the whole premise of it felt rushed. 
[/list]
[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
[b]Movement[/b]
[list]
    [*]Animations for parkouring look so much smoother and fluid then what we have had in all the previous games and It all flows nicely together. Unfortunately, it's not utilised well in the game, it's quicker to just run in the streets most of the time then go via rooftops.
    [*]Connor has the ability to jump through trees, which is a really cool addition, it makes sense with his character as well. 
    [*]Certain open windows and doors you can run through which will show a little in engine cut-scene of you passing through the building, it's a cool way to get around when needed.
[/list]
[b]Combat[/b] 
[list]
    [*]Has phenomenal animations, tools can tie into executions as well, and pulling off a multi-kill execute is amazing. Connor feels powerful and ruthless, while still feeling nimble.
    [*]Massive array of weapons. From his new signature weapon, the tomahawk, to war clubs, a bow, guns, swords, with even more to buy/craft and pickup.
    [*]It does feel way to easy to combo executions, and with large icons appearing above enemies telling you exactly what they are going to do, with ample time to respond you never feel truly in danger.
[/list]
[b]Stealth[/b]
[list]
    [*]New assassination potential with the rope-dart while in trees, corner assassinations, and being able to crouch in low bushes and move around.
[/list]
[b]Questing/side content[/b]
[list]
    [*]Hunting has been introduced with the ability to track, bait, snare and take down animals, even having some "legendary" animals to take down which make for some neat sequences. 
    [*]The ledger is a new feature where you can buy/sell resources, craft new equipment or upgrade existing gear. I barely touched this feature, the menu for it is awful and most of the time you sell things means you have to run across the map just to save the convoy.
    [*]We are introduced to Naval battles and these are short and sweet, have a clear objective. They give you a taste of what's to come in Black Flag.
    [*]Peg Leg missions are some of the best in the game, they have you go off and exploring a completely new environment. Feeling very Uncharted/Tomb Raider like. 
   [*]Homestead missions are great and shouldn't be missed. Each character is unique and completing them also shows a different side to Connor. The more of them you complete for each character will unlock more upgrades/craftables based on that characters respective trade. Completing them will also visually add to the homestead. 
  [*]You can recruit members to the brotherhood as well, but it's done in such a cool way. Each one you recruit is a unique character with their own story, and ability. Once you recruit them they will actually show up in story sequences.
  [*]You get to play as Desmond and go on actual missions, but outside of the skyscraper one they are mostly pretty boring sadly. 
  [*]Assassination contracts are boring and have you running across the map just to kill someone that's walking around, and they all look the same.
  [*]Liberation missions have you completing a bunch of the same tasks over and over again depending on the area. It get's tedious pretty quickly.
  [*]Forts are a pretty fun experience, take out the leader, blow up a cache and replace a flag. It doesn't feel like there is to many of them and they are all different and allow you tackle them how you want.
  [*]Of course collectables are back and starting to get very obnoxious. Although i do always enjoy being able to collect outfits and weapons. It's everything else that can feel like to much.
[/list]
[b]Difficulty[/b] 
[list]
    [*]This game is by all means not hard, it gives you plenty of tools to get by and enemies make their actions clear.
[/list]
[b]Length[/b] 
[list]
    [*]16 hours just for the story, i did just about everything, aside from the DLC and spent 25 hours in the game. I imagine 30 or so hours with the DLC content.
[/list]

[h1]Visuals, Audio, and Performance.[/h1] 
[b]Visuals[/b]
[list]
    [*]With the remaster, characters faces have lost all detail, faces are smooth and just bright, it looks genuinely awful.
    [*]The environments in the open world look stunning, especially with the weather system and having seasons actually change.
[/list]
[b]Audio[/b]
[list]
    [*]Assassin Creed games never fail to disappoint when it comes to the soundtrack, picking up and creating tension, and drama when needed, or slowing right down to give you that ambient backdrop as you explore.
    [*]Audio in general is done really well, marching bands, animals, cities, and gunfire all draw you into the game.
[/list]
[b]Performance and Bugs.[/b]
[list]
   [*]While being capped at 60fps, it runs well. No bugs either.
[/list]

[b]My system at the time[/b]
Operating System: Windows 11
Processor: 12th Gen Intel Core i9-12900K  3.20 GHz
RAM: 64.0 GB
GPU: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti
[i]Installed on an M.2 SSD[/i]

I'm on my journey of playing every Assassin's Creed game back to back and so far this has been the worst one for multiple reasons. I loved Assassin's Creed 1 through Revelations but I have to actively force myself to play this game since it's really frustrating. I probably won't cover everything that bugs me about this game but I will cover most things that truly ruin my experience.

I AM PLAYING THIS GAME WITH A PS5 CONTROLLER CONNECTED TO MY PC VIA CABLE. SOME OF MY ISSUES MAY OR MAY NOT APPEAR FOR M&K PLAYERS.

The camera: For some reason the camera in this game keeps on focusing on useless stuff that you don't even want to look at. The camera then locks itself and you're unable to move it for around 1 second which get really annoying once you need to do some stealth climbing. And if the camera manages to move through your input, it just focuses on the next point of interest which is often up to 180° away from the point you were trying to look away from. Small camera adjustments are almost impossible to do which makes navigating horrible.

The combat: Overall combat feels nice, but sometimes the indicator to parry just doesn't appear or appears too late which makes it impossible for you to do long combos of killing. Also the "human shield" mechanic when you're being shot at also seems to work only 25% of the times you're trying to do it. 
Then there are the quick time events. When you're traversing the wilderness a lot of wildlife keeps interfering with you, which wouldn't be a problem if the quick time events would actually work. It isn't a hardware problem since my controller is working fine in any other game other than that one. When you get attacked by wildlife I press my button to parry but it doesn't work and when the wildlife pins me to the ground and I have to spam-click a button to free myself it also only works about 10% of the time.

The missions: Oh god the missions. As someone who loves to 100% games this game really is a pain in the ass. Go on and tell me it's a "skill issue" but in my opinion there is a fine line of "challenging" and "stupidly hard just so the player has to reset 30 times" which this game managed to overstep by a wide margin. 
The other AC games had their fair share of challenging mission if you were to try and 100% them but so far the only mission that really made me ragequit was the Da Vinci's tank mission in AC brotherhood but for some reason AC3 managed to make every other mission a chore to 100%.
"Go on that boat and make it go boom. Also don't get seen by a single person on the ship. Oh and also kill a grenadier through an air assassination but good luck getting to the high ground because the enemies can see you wherever you are! And don't bother trying to kill one of the four grenadiers in a different way because as soon as you kill one of them you lost the challenge!" This mission was so utter bullshit that it was my wake up call that maybe I shouldn't try to 100% this game. I tried and tried and tried and even watched a YouTube video where someone managed to do it but I just couldn't get it to work. Was it a skill issue? probably. But IMO you shouldn't make such bullshit missions in the first place. Remember what I said about the camera? When you're trying to climb up the ships (you need to do it twice) the camera just keeps focusing on the wrong point and makes you jump somewhere you didn't even wanna go. To make things worse sometimes your character decides that he doesn't wanna climp anymore and just starts standing on some invisible ledge on the ship which in return makes you visible to the enemies. 
Just everything about that mission was so utterly frustrating that I even considered skipping this game entirely and just moving to Black Flag since I really wasn't having any fun at this game.

The bad camera paired with quick time events that only work 50% of the time and a mediocre story which isn't even fun to explore since the missions are designed badly make for a experience that really isn't worth the price. The only reason I haven't skipped the game is because I want to see the ending of the Desmond arc by myself and I don't think it's even worth it.

Buggy and frustrating are the two words that keep popping into my head every time I try to play AC 3 Remastered. I'll admit though that I'm coming from later games in the series and that is probably why I'm having such a hard time getting into this game. For a "Remaster" it doesn't seem to really update anything to put it in line with more modern AC games and bugs that were in the game 10 years ago are still in this so-called remaster; how is that even possible? I've counted at least 5 or 6 bugs I looked up online where the threads were from 10 years ago. One of the most annoying aspects of the game is the combat. Enemies fight like trained ninjas blocking at least half your attacks and they all take too long to kill. And kill streaks constantly get interrupted. One of the worst things is hacking at a Hessian soldier 20 times only for him to grab your arm and slap your face. That's what this games combat feels like: A slap in the face. Another thing I hater is the environments because in many places you're surrounded by mountains and trees that cannot be climbed. That makes exploration extremely difficult and time consuming since you wander the maps looking for ways to move vertically. And don't even get me started on the horse riding. If I didn't know better I'd say this game invented the horse riding mechanics because it's just so terrible. Again, how is this a "Re-Master"?  If the game was going to fix anything it should be the horse riding. The horse oftentimes moves slower than you running, the "Spur" command only works for a few seconds and for some reason the horse will just...stop for no reason. 

Another problem are the aforementioned bugs. I've had to restart just about every mission, especially the numerous escort missions (I assume this is the game that spawned a lot of the memes regarding escort missions), because either someone gets stuck and doesn't movie or a random NPC or animal knocks them into some water or off a cliff or something and they die. Even the very last mission in the game bugged out on me. Twice.  The usual error I've run into is reaching a specific point in the mission and a cut scene fails to trigger. 

Finally, there's plenty of minor tweaks they could've added to the remaster that wouldn't have taken any real work but would've improved quality of life. For example why not have Eagle Vision actually highlight stuff? There's a lot of hunting in the game but unlike AC 4 using Eagle Vision doesn't highlight animals. And it would be nice if there was some way to tell what can cannot be climbed. As I said earlier there's so many cliffs that can't be scaled despite all of them having some sort of objective on top of them. Eventually you'll come across a place you can climb but it's never obvious.

All in all I'd only suggest this game for true fans of the series. Otherwise if you're a casual AC fan like me stick with later games in the series.

Assassin's Creed 3 is not dog water. Not as much as I originally thought. The ending is still poopoo, but the story. I don't know what I was smoking when I was younger to make me think it didn't have much to do about assassin's and the actual conflict between Templars and assassin's, but it has absolutely a lot. I really thought it was Connor on a revenge game, and don't get me wrong, it definitely is, but he learns a lot about both sides, specifically from his own father, and it's really interesting. Connor as a character, a ton of people saw him as really boring and emotionless, but I saw something completely different. The dude is just noble more than anything and definitely caring. I also never realized that Achilles, the old man who trained Connor and the person who gave him his English name, named him after his dead son. Bittersweet in a way, and I never really realized it until I saw him burying the key for the Great Temple at the end by a grave marker for Connor Davenport. 

So yea, anyways, not completely doodoo like I used to think, I definitely dogged on it way too hard.

As a returning player who just finished Assassin's Creed III Remastered for the second time on PC, I can confidently say that it's an impressive game that offers a captivating storyline, polished gameplay mechanics, and a beautifully recreated historical setting. The improved graphics and combat system make for a more enjoyable experience, and the attention to detail in recreating historical locations is impressive. It's definitely worth checking out, whether you're a fan of the series or just looking for a well-crafted action-adventure game.

So, at the beginning I was really upset by the game, as I had some trouble getting it to run well. However, it took a while until I understood that the game was running fine, but rather my PC setup was the problem. I've been using a 4k display which was connected via HDMI to my graphics card (Geforce RTX 2070 Super). This made the graphics card behave strangely As soon as I switched to an appropriate DP cable the game started running at 4k@60Hz very smoothly and the real fun could start.

I think it's a typical Assissins Creed game. I am in the process of playing all parts in sequence. The setting - colonial America - is completely different from the first 4 games. But it is giving the game a nice touch. I am still in the Haythan phase - so looking forward very much to becoming a real Assassin.

Review for original AC3: The leap in game-play is massive since revelations. The graphics are a major improvement over revelations as well. On my first play-through years ago, I didn't like the main character. But upon replay, I grew to like him, but not as much as Ezio obviously. The music by Lorne Balfe is one of my most played for any video game. The addition of naval sequences were a welcome change and paved the way for Black Flag. 

9/10

Remaster Review: The remaster was unnecessary, If you own the original, don't get the remaster. There are a few bugs and the improved graphics is not worth it.

I've included a review for Assassin's Creed Liberation below this one, as I received both games from the Odyssey bundle.

Assassin's Creed III Review:
Truly the next step in advancement, Assassin's Creed III is a beautiful game, full of advancements in the series. The story is probably one of the most rich in terms of twists and turns, that it left me unable to predict where it would move next.
Took me roughly 70 hours to 100%.

Assassin's Creed Liberation Review:
A much shorter Assassin's Creed game compared to all others in the saga; however, I truly believe that because of the shortened length this game is, it has received a ton more polish. Experience "flowy" combat unlike any other of the Assassin's Creed games, and a story not unlike Assassin's Creed III's. Out of all the games prior to Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag, this is the greatest.
Took me roughly 33 hours to 100%.

Its a good game. Unfortunately its plagued with technical issues. Right from the start, if you procured this title as a DLC from Assassin's Creed Odyssey, Ubisoft will ask for a authentication key when you try to start the game, in order to bind the game to your Ubisoft Connect account. Problem is the game doesn't give you any key. Turns out you need to download a fucking 100GB worth of Assassin's Creed Odyssey, boot up that game in order to bind that game AND AC3 to your UbiConnect account. 

The game also suffer from various game crash. I am playing on the steam deck, which is more than enough to handle the game most of the time, but still at times the game will slow down to a crawl before stopping entiring, forcing me to restart.

[h1] The Official Assassin's Creed III Review [/h1]
[b] First few words [/b]
I see most people not giving actual reviews to this game but giving warnings about how to purchase it the “right way”. I’ll get into that at the end but for now I’d like to give my take on the game itself, gameplay, bugs, and ofcourse the steaming pile of crap that is the remastered edition.
This game was amazing, it may not beat the megalopolis that is Black Flag or Brotherhood, but it does okay.

[b] Story (Spoiler Free) [/b]
It’s one of the best I've ever played, up there with greats such as the GTA Series, Mafia Series, Red Dead Redemption Series, etc. Hell, even God of War. The writing, as in pretty much all AC games, is nothing but stellar. It’s only enhanced even more by the game changing performances of the actors. They are so good at the roles they play that I just want to jump into the screen, enter the AC3 world and have a chat with them. Honestly some of the most believable performances in gaming, up there with Roger Clark as Arthur Morgan.

Though the story may be a bit slow paced, and I do admit it could’ve been sped up a little. It doesn’t stop you from feeling the emotions of the characters. The story is long so you can feel, bond, and attach yourself to these characters, making for a better experience.

It’s a very serious and dark story, that of the likes of GTA IV. Granted, we may not be meddling dope and doing odd jobs for multiple crime families in search of the lost diamonds. But we are however in search of freedom, freedom for Connors people to be treated like normal. The type of freedom that says the American Government can’t take the land we rightfully own. [spoiler] If you’ve played the game already you’d know this didn’t work out [/spoiler]
It’s a very sad and gripping story that latches you into the world the moment you meet Haytham. You play as Haytham Kenway (Edward Kenway’s son) for around 4 - 6 hours give or take, depending on how much you grind the story missions. During this time you learn about the character and the many people he surrounds himself with. One being Charles Lee, I won’t go into detail because you’ll have to play the game for yourself. 
Once you’ve finished playing as Haytham Kenway you’re immediately dropped into playing as Connor (Ratonhnhaké:ton) A child living in an Indian village with a mostly carefree life, but that all changes after a Hide and Seek game with his friends goes wrong. You play as Connor for the remainder of the game and play as him from childhood to early adulthood. In this timeframe of 23 years you watch him endure pain, grief, and rare strokes of happiness. On the other side of the spectrum you see him commit acts of Murder to those who “deserve it”. Justified or not, it serves as a major point for growth in his character, and it succeeds very well at doing so.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
The gameplay is the typical Assassin’s Creed style of gameplay. (excluding the reboots of course)
Your typical, [i] Go hear - follow this person/travel somewhere - gather information/eavesdrop on conversations to garner a location of a target - find that target, kill them (you made endure a chase sequence) move onto the next mission [/i] Of course I am exaggerating, but that’s only the jist of a very small portion of the game.

Your primary weapon is no longer swords but rather a hatchet. Hidden blades are still in the game of course, along with many variations of guns. You may still take enemy weapons if you so desire.

[b] Bugs [/b]
Unfortunately being a Ubisoft game, comes with an incredible amount of unpolished material. I won’t go into the details but more so mention the common bugs that can occur so you may avoid these.
A lot of glitches occur with[i] wanted posters [/i]. Typical things that may happen are posters not disappearing when incognito, getting stuck on walls when interacting with posters[i] (fast travel to escape)[/i], posters that cannot be interacted with despite indicating they can be, etc. Honestly the list goes on.

Other encounters can be the following, during brawl sequences in missions, after defeating all enemies the game may not realise and keep you in the sequence, allowing you to move around but unable to progress.
Animals and NPC’s having a brain freeze in their AI and getting stuck and multiple objects and places of scenery, Trees, Tables, Barrels, etc.
Floating Objects such as, Cannelballs, debris, apples and other items of detail.
Mouths not moving and audio and sound effect may not be synced or not be there at all.
Invisible walls being misplaced during missions.
Some objects are not solid whatsoever and NPC’s will walk right through those objects. I once watched a redcoat walk straight through a table like he was a ghost or something.
You get the point, there are a lot of bugs and glitches that can occur in this game and unfortunately Ubisoft decides to ignore it, even in the “Remastered Edition”. Yes, at this point bugs are kind of a staple for the AC franchise, but too many just really get on your nerves.

[b] The Remastered Edition [/b]
There are so many things I could say about this, so many uses of profanity, so much to say, but really it’s boiled down to one thing. [u] Greed [/u]
Ubisoft is by far (maybe) the most money hungry, stingy, greedy, arrogant, and brainless company in the history of gaming.

I’ve been playing the AC franchise for as long as I can remember, (ever since I watched my Dad play it when I was like 4 or 5) and to play this "remastered edition", is nothing but pain and a chore. Ubisoft forces their TERRIBLE launcher upon you, without which you cannot play the game. 
Here's a pro tip for anyone making a game. If you decide to put your game on steam, LET STEAM TAKE OVER! Don’t try to create unnecessary garbage to ensure you get an extra dollar. Unnecessary garbage that us as gamers have to keep on our desktops downloaded at all times.

To revive an almost decade old game, put in some brightness and “improve” graphics on an already stunning game, yet don’t do a single thing about the bugs, whilst slapping a $60 price tag on it, and also removing the original version from anyplace it can be purchased is a really scummy move by Ubisoft. The Graphics make the game look extremely glossy in a way. You’ll see what I mean just by looking at any of the character models in the game.

[b] This game gets an 8/10, the remastered edition gets a 3/10 [/b]

[b] P.S. [/b]
Here's the bit where I talk about the right way to purchase this game. Assassin’s Creed Odyssey Gold Edition comes fully kit with AC Odyssey Gold Edition of course, but also copies of AC3-Remastered and ACLiberations-Remastered. Of course buy this on sale.

this game is almost the peak of this series . it has a really strong story , the intro with haytham is a great display of character building and sets up the game perfectly . this is also the best the story of desmond ever gets , and tbh this is the most interesting the modern gameplay / story ever gets to be . desmonds mission thru the sky scraper is gorgeous . ratonhnhaké:ton is my favorite assassin due to just how cold he is . hes is logical and calls it how it is , but shows clear growth from beggining to end .   altho new america is not a great urban enviroment for parkour , the frontier and trees make up for it . extremely fluid movement and a really great sense of weight and momentum . these are also the nicest robes in the whole series , imo . connors robes and equiment look amazing and have real weight to them . my only complaint is that we dont have access to the original version of this game because a lot of cool mods are for it . the hard mode mod comes to mind . as always i wish there was a female character to play as but thats a complaint i have about most assassins creed .

Connor is able to freely explore 18th-century Boston, New York City, and the American frontier to complete side missions away from the primary storyline. It is the fifth major installment in the Assassin's Creed series, and a direct sequel to 2011's Assassin's Creed: Revelations.

As a long lasting fan of Assassin's Creed, i decided to try the remastered version of a game i loved. I can say i am disappointed. The game isn't any more polished than it was when the original version was released, i can probably say it is probably even more riddled with bugs than before:
______________________________________________________________
-Sound distortion
	Every time i approached a shore, the water was really loud despite my settings for everything sound related being relatively mild or even close to being muted.
______________________________________________________________
-Action Input Bug
	As in most games, you use right click to aim, and left click to shoot (talking about using a bow this time), but after the arrow shooting animation ended, it immediately send an input to start the assassination of the nearest target, despite me not touching the keys anymore.
______________________________________________________________
-Poor Optimization
	On a PC with RTX 2060 and Ryzen 7 3700X, the 1% was around 50 fps, altough everything was maxed. (not using an ultrawide monitor)
	(The 1% in games is a measurement about those extremely low fps you get every once in a while in game, as games are not made uniformly, some levels, graphics, mechanics, etc are different in every part of the game)
	For a 10 year old game that didn't get as much of a glow up for the remastered version, but a minor upgrade in graphics, this is poor performance.
______________________________________________________________
I truly recommend the game, but not the remastered version. The original is better, from sound, mechanics, and performance.

I have mixed feelings about this game.

Pros:
The interactions between Haytham and Conner were really well done.
Ship combat was an amazing addition to the franchise.

Cons:
Both the modern and the animus stories were incredibly boring.
Horse riding in free roam was a good addition, but stumbling over every rock got very old, very quickly.
The game took WAY too long to get to the good stuff, and the good stuff was incredibly short-lived.
I'm a history geek, and I still didn't enjoy their version of the American Revolution.

This game for me is the definition of mediocrity. 

I found myself bored or annoyed almost the entire time playing. There were some objective improvements of many AC mechanics, but even though I really tried liking this game (as the AC community gives it a bad wrap), I can't in good conscience say I recommend it, or that I will be revisiting it in the future.

Overall, a 5/10, wouldn't recommend.

TL;DR: The story is boring, and the game takes way too long to get interesting... and then becomes boring again shortly after. Buy this only if you're a fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise as a whole.

This is by far one of my favorite AC games I've played so far. For context, I've only played the 4 games before this. Not only was the story really cool, there were several aspects of gameplay mechanics that I enjoyed. 
- The "through" hallways to evade attackers
- The reflex shots using pistols and the bow and arrow
- Insanely cool kill combos with the variety of weapons
- Parkour through trees

I'm probably missing a few things on the above list, but the gameplay was super smooth compared to the other games I've played. The monetary system was fitting for the time period. The ship mechanics were really fun to play with too.

First off, if you really want to play this game, [b] do NOT buy it from this store page[/b]. You can get it at much greater value if you buy the Assassin's Creed Odyssey Season Pass. 

This review is a little weird for me to write. ACIII was my introduction to the series and growing up it was one of my favourites, and I didn't understand why this game got such a bad rap. But playing this "remaster" really put into perspective how undercooked, janky, unfun, and sometimes downright unplayable it is.

Let's get the good stuff out of the way first. The story is pretty good, with some really emotional moments and impactful storytelling. The modern-day component is also a lot more interesting, as Desmond actually gets to go out and do stuff. The characters are great, with ACIII even providing probably the best villain in the entire franchise. I also really love the time and care Ubisoft put into portraying the Kanien'kehá:ka (Mohawk) people and having characters speak the language, hiring a cultural consultant to ensure that the details were right. The movement system also got a much needed upgrade, completely changing how your character moves parkour-wise like allowing him to climb through trees, and introducing the ability to make running kills, making everything much more fluid and intuitive. The switch to arkham-style combat may be a bit simple, but the combat animations and finishers are extremely cool and stylish. The soundtrack is also one of the best if not the best in the whole series. 

Now the bad. ACIII feels like a mishmash of game mechanics that really feel out of place and are essentially pointless, stretching the game out to feel like an incoherent experience. I have only engaged in the hunting system in the tutorial and never again. Same with the convoy trading system. The assassin management system seems really tacked on and could be missed by most players. The naval missions, while fun, are also stuffed in some menu that could be missed by many players. Even certain weapon types feel gimmicky and unusable in most parts of the game. A lot of the side content is literally reduced to a list of challenges, making this game a completionist nightmare because there's so much boring stuff to do. There are also a bunch of optional objectives for some of the missions that are excruciatingly difficult to achieve, sapping the fun you may have trying to complete them. It really feels like the devs threw as much "content" as they could into the game to distract people from how undercooked and unfinished it felt. I had very little actual fun playing this game, and when a game makes you feel like you're working rather than enjoying yourself, something is terribly wrong. 

The presentation side of things is also extremely sloppy. The dialogue audio is very low quality, clothes clip through characters even though that's the only set of clothes they wear the entire game, and the lip-sync and animation quality for some side conversations and missions are absolutely horrible, just to name a few. It could just be the setting which I personally have no interest in, but I found the cities and locations featured in the game to be unappealing and monotone. The quality of the game varies dramatically, almost as if multiple different studios worked on it (hmmmm I might be onto something there). 

ACIII is also definitely the buggiest game in the series (yes, I'd say even more than Unity). The bugs are too many to name, but it includes dialogue overlapping and cutting in and out, looping music that also gets progressively louder to the point of deafening noise, NPC pathways just bugging out, flickering screens, incompletable objectives, and so much more. I've had to reload saves countless times, and the bugs in general detracted from the whole experience significantly. I don't think I've ever stared at my monitor in bewilderment and threw my hands up while playing ANY game as much as I did while playing ACIII.

Now, the remaster itself. The only thing I can confidently say that this remaster does well is make the environment look better, with more vivid colours and much better textures. That's it. A lot of people talk about the overhaul of the lighting system but I think it made things worse: some scenes are nearly pitch black or blazing white, and characters look like smooth wet plastic dolls. And seeing as this remaster really made me realize how buggy this game was, bugs were not fixed, and even perhaps new ones were introduced. 

In addition to the base game, this package also includes the ACIII King Washington DLC and AC Liberation HD. The DLC is good; it has a fresh story and introduces some fun new abilities, if at the cost of recycling locations and repetitive filler content if you choose to do it. AC Liberation HD is a pretty solid short game that honestly seems more coherent and polished of a game than ACIII, with a really interesting and unique "persona" system and creative ways that the story is told, but some of the repetitiveness of the side missions and collectibles (if you wish to do them), awful framerates in certain parts of the city, lack of musical variety, and frustrating objectives needed for 100% sync hold it back from being a standout in the franchise. 

[b] TLDR; While getting some things right in the story and parkour/combat department, ACIII feels like an undercooked and bloated mix of different game mechanics rife with bugs and issues not at all fixed by this "remaster", which made some visual changes that make this game even worse. AC Liberation HD Remastered is a really nice inclusion in this package but it has a few (admittedly more minor) issues that hold it back from being a great game. [/b]
