For a remaster version this game has so many bugs and UI design weaknesses that one must wonder why the devs bothered to put it out again. And that's not talking about the frustrating gameplay mechanics: at every instance when I began to enjoy some of the game's elements they broke the flow.
What makes me angry about the UI: It is so cluttered that I don't recognize when vital feedback and tips are displayed.
What makes me angry about the gameplay mechanics: I never have the feeling that i'm an adequate asssassin, being able to stealthily use my environment and surroundings to my advantage in order to dispatch my targets and get out unscathed. Brutal overt offensive works better at too many times due to the lacks in stealth gameplay. (Rhetorical question BTW: Why is it called Assassin's Creed?)
But maybe I shouldn't expect a Dishonored or Thief. And maybe I'm too tired of Open World-style gameplay with parts of the game locked behind gazillions of collectibles just to stretch playtime.
The only thing that keeps me in the game is my wish to experience an interesting story. But I'm not looking forward to have exactly those issues because I want to play the next AC games in my backlog in order.
AC 1 gave me the most fun, the fun to have in all the following games fizzled out around the edges of their bloated content.
Dear Reader, I'll invite you to tell me that I'm wasting my time with these games in the comments

[original review follows:]
I have only bad experiences with this game and I didn't even enter the tutorial course and anything that will come after it:
My wired Xbox360 gamepad is not recognized (it works absolutely fine in AC:Odyssey and RDR2, just checked) .
To start AC3:Remastered I had to register it in Ubisoft Connect. To register it in Ubisoft Connect I first had to download 80GB+ of AC:O and start it once.
I've spent two evenings of my precious time just for the above.
Cannot recommend and strongly advise against until Ubi comes forward with a better way.
[update 2021-04-27]
Ubisoft provided me with a solution to my Xbox360 controller issue:
manually edit Assassin3Remaster.ini in the \Documents\Assassin's Creed III Remaster\ directory and replace the [input] section with

[Input]
SelectedPad=XBOX 360/ONE For Windows (Controller)
KeyboardMouseEnabled=0
AutoSwitchEnabled=1

Works also in the original AC3! I'm going to play some more (at least the main story) before I come back and eventually change my verdict.
[/update]

If you have played to recent AC titles, starting with Origins... don't bother. This one is in my opinion, absolutely terrible. I had it as a free gift with the purchase of another AC title... Story is fine, but the gameplay is atrocious. No wonder why they improved to the current game dynamics.

The characters and plot are good, the homestead is a nice mechanic.

Sadly, that is where the good parts end.

The combat is janky, some attacks simply can't be mitigated because the indicators don't show up and with that you're unable to parry. Sometimes inputs get flat out ignored. Fighting near cliffs is dangerous as the animations may cause you to roll into open air - with gravity kicking in once you've left the animation.

The menus are the most horrendous style choice I've seen so far.

Buttons like 'B' on the gamepad are overloaded with context sensitive commands while other like 'Y' on the gamepad barely do anything.
E.g. B is responsible for:
 - interacting with objects
 - starting quests
 - looting
 - picking up
 - dropping weapons
 - parrying
 - whistling

Y is reponsible for:
 - reloading
 - shooting

Stealth is abysmal - sometimes guards see you through walls, other times you kill the person next to them while looking them in the eye and they do nothing. In one mission I've had a whole group of guards follow me around without doing anything - no matter how many people I killed.
It also seems like guards automatically know where you are if you're wanted and exit a hiding place. I can't imagine how else a mob of guards would immediately sprint to the other side of a building.

The game keeps spawning enemies in in your vicinity while you're wanted, making hiding and fleeing extremely cumbersome and not fun.

The boston underground was fun for the first half but got just tedious and annoying very quickly.

The climbing is definitely the worst in the entire series. In the few cases where it works it feels good - but I've never had that many ledges where the MC just refused to climb further or where the AI just decided to jump somewhere else entirely.
In the frontier a couple of the synchronization points are the _same_ tree over and over - this tree is terribly unintuitive to climb and feels like it was specifically designed to be terrible.

The list goes on, but I'm not wasting more of my life on even writing the review.

Look what they have done to my boy.

The only positives I can think of are the voice acting, the homestead, the music, and the nature. Conner is a fine character but due to his stoic ass-holeness he is not that likable.

Meanwhile, the nature parkour is buggy at the worst times, the AI is broken (elk can't see you 1 ft away yet guard can see you while his back is turned), the combat is buggy with indicators showing up after attacks or not at all, the in-cutscene graphics are horrendous (lee getting his ring), and the majority of the new mechanics are uninteresting or unnoticeable. The rest is build upon from previous games without much improvement.

I wanted to like this game. I *really* wanted to like this game. My HUSBAND wanted me to like this game.
And it started off so well, with so many improvements over the previous games. Weather animations and animals in the world and i could PET the ANIMaLS. And it had a lock that kept me from jumping off cliffs while I was running through the trees. It even told me how many damn sequences were in the game so I knew how far along I was. All awesome things!
A native american main character, and actual native languages being spoken throughout the game? Absolutely incredible, I was so excited!
Plus the game was gorgeous. I'd seen a bunch of people complainin that the remastered version was pretty much no improvement for a lot worse lighting, but to me it looked awesome!
Other nice points:
-Actually lets you return to the game after it's over so you can finish grabbing collectibles.
-Checkpoints actually work now for getting full synchs.
But then...all the infuriating things about it started overshadowing the pretty, sleek, interactive parts.

I literally have so many issues with this game that I can't possibly fit it in a review.
To attempt to sum it up;
-Contradictory and confusing characters
-Horrible running mechanics (too slow by far, and spurring your horse is disabled whenever you're in a 'city' even if you're on the outskirts where it's nothing but fields and hills and no fast travel points.)
-[bold]Horrific fighting mechanics [/bold] ENemies coming in wave after wave with limited ability to kill streak and the E key needing completely abused to survive any of it, since the only healing is time-based.
-Zero exposition or reasoning for 95% of side quests. Kill dog. Kill person. Deliver mail. Collect item. No purpose or meaning to it.
-Quest markers and collectibles markers that just break and stay on screen when there's nothing there, or disappear without letting you get to them. I was going through the epilogues and it told me one was in boston. I go to boston. No more quest marker. Guess it's over?
-Extremely repetitive gameplay (gives you an entirely new city to start from scratch in when there's only 3-4 sequences left in the game)
-Homestead missions and outfits and gear are extremely sequence locked, pretty much completely unavailable until sequence 7.
-Tons of glitches, as always with ubisoft. Got stuck in walls, and it rained indoors. Animus notifications were borked and constantly threw old information at me like it was new.
-Inflammatory characters whose sole purpose seems to be being a jerk. And im not JUST talking about shaun, though he's obviously the biggest culprit.
-Constant lack of proper explanation for how to actually accomplish objectives. "Follow me to this tunnel to avoid the guards" character is following YOU and there are no directions except an objective marker.
-Homestead convoy premise was grindy, boring, and not worth the money it made you, plus upgrading the homestead made everyone ELse's homes look better and expand, but did nothing for your own house, which looks barely lived in right up to the end.
-Bizarre controls for everything from fighting to calling for your horse
-Stupid mistakes with voicovers and cutscenes, even for main story stuff that cut off speakers or started them midway into talking, and voices in side-quests that randomly got far too quiet, or Connor just began shouting his lines as if he thought u were across a field from him.
-Meaningless scenes treated as vitally important. The whole naming scene is completely pointless. He's supposed to take the new name and pretend he's spanish so people actually listen to him and dont realize he's native american. Except then everyone in the game knowws he's native american, and they never even bring up the 'spanish' thing again. so what was the point of the new name?!
-Even the guy whose entire introduction is about how minorities deserve more respect, flat out refuses to attempt to pronounce Ratonhnhaké:ton's name. Didn't even TRY. wtf. The only person who ever cared what it even was was some random dude named Duncan in a bar in Boston. He made a whole point about it, and then Still didn't say it.
-And most importantly, i nearly broke my stupid pinky holding the shift key for the entire game. It was agony compared to just holding right-click, as weird as that control was. :(

TLDR; I wanted to love this damn game, and it just didn't happen. If you want an assassin's creed game to play, I just can't recommend this. Try the Ezio trilogy, it's glitchy as all hell, but I still came out of it enjoying myself.

I loved this game when i played it. But after uninstalling it, then reinstalling it my game refused to go past a white screen in a non-full screen window. I have tried everything, if someone reading this can help me, please recommend me a way to help.

MUST READ BEFORE YOU BUY!. 2-3 Minuets of reading to save you from a bad experience. 
All in all the story is pretty great; the way it flows through the immense history of the American Revolution is impressive. However, the game-play is utter garbage and buggy: 
First, if you happen to exit the game during a cinematic there is a good chance the next time you log in to play it will crash every time and that save will be ruined- it happened to me twice: once early on, and another halfway through!
Next, the combat system is not well refined; here's some examples: The warning icon (letting you know an attack is incoming) does not appear multiple times during engagements causing you to get hit or shot when if it would just appear when it should you would be fine. It's so bad I've learned not to rely on it, and I'm sure most have too. When an enemy is about to shoot you: you have the option to use a nearby enemy as a human shield, but half the time you press the button and your character will just break the defense of that enemy or do nothing -SERIOUSLY-
Still on the topic of combat; Animations: This one isn't as big a deal as the rest, but it's worth mentioning that the animations for the daggers are the same as the tomahawks?! They are completely different weapons yet you will see Connor awkwardly hacking enemies down with a skinny little knife; it just looks horrible, again not game breaking just lazy on the developers part.
Parkour: Oooh now this is a big one. The parkour in Assassin's Creed III is "wow" bad. You have significantly less control over your character's actions than in previous AC games. Even after spending a few hours mastering the movement system of AC III you will still find yourself jumping all over the place, and jumping down instead of out, climbing up instead of passing over, glitching sideways and grabbing onto a random wall 6 feet away instead of running straight?? I've heard from a few sources that the parkour had an update a couple years after release that jacked it up, but this isn't a review of the way game was, it's a review of the way the game is. Now I will admit that Ubisoft added some cool new parkour features such as the room traversal cinematic or the slick passing over animations (which as previously stated don't always work), but that's not enough to make up for the rest of the sh** we put up with.
Missing missions: When completing a sequence (such as Sequence 7 or 9) certain side missions will become available to you, however if you happen to complete another sequence before those side missions those missions will disappear! And no this isn't a feature most players never experience this bug but it does happen sometimes and it is definitely game breaking. Not only do you miss out on some good content, but you need these missions to craft and unlock certain items, such as weapons and capacity upgrades.
I could honestly go on about various other things, but I said this would only be a 2-3 minuet read. I truly hope this review helps you and it is very disappointing to me that a game with such great potential has so many issues. I hope you have a great day and find another way to experience the story like through a cinematic montage off of YouTube or maybe a Let's Play; that way you can get the full story of this amazing franchise.
PS I played this game both on console and PC, and my experiences were very similar.

I believe I got this free with the Odyssey bundle a year or two ago. The "remastered" version plays worse than AC2 ever did for me. Buggy and glitched. I just left when my char got stuck in a doorway. I was hoping by Chapter 2 the pace would pick up. It does not. 

Edit: I played up to chapter 7. The pace does pick up (I'm being generous when I say that). I'm like "oh maybe I can finish this story!" I like completing games. I started playing a mission where you need to escape on horse. The horse literally FALLS OVER every 3 seconds, even when there isn't a shot fired by the enemy. The gameplay gets even worse as you need to actually, you know, do stuff. 

It's not just that we have higher standards today, but this game came out bad, they polished the turd, but it's still just a turd. If anyone at Ubisoft is reading this, when you go to "remaster" a game, don't just sharpen the graphics, please make it run a little better. Or just leave it where it needs to be.

P.S. I will say as a Native gamer, I do appreciate that they tried to use Native voice actors and it seems they really did their research with the Mohawk language and songs.

What an excellent game.

To be honest, I didn't like AC3 very much before. 
The reason is that the advantages and disadvantages of this work are particularly outstanding. Its plot and task settings are the top level of the whole series. In addition, it also has a large number of feelings bonus - it is Desmond Saga, the end of the Desmond saga. In the early generation, the Akalin protagonist, who was hated by all the players, fully demonstrated his personality charm and even became the hope of mankind. This work is also the beginning of the North American trilogy (liberation is 0.5, rebellion is 0.5, which adds up to just three), and it is also the beginning of Ubisoft blurring the position of the Temple and the assassins, and abandoning the previous binary opposition between black and white. There are two chapters in the game when Connor and his father sea cucumbers act together. Although they also have resentment, they have a lot of conversations and are trying to understand and protect each other - just like all the weird, ordinary and touching feelings of father and son in the world. The similar feelings were used by Yubi in another very unfortunate work two years later. There, the temple and the assassin once again had a chance to bridge the gap between them. 
However, the end was still a disaster, and a pair of miserable mandarin ducks were buried with them. Many of the plots in this work can only be understood after playing with the later works, especially the master of the manor, Achilles. When I first played, I only thought that this was an old man who was making a fool of himself, just like the master in Chang'an Chaos. But after playing mutiny, I realized what kind of past he carried in every word. In the mansion of Davenport Manor, Shea once left his footprints, probably also left his laughter with his brother Liam, his roast about the serious Indian Kensegoworth, and his vague affection for Hope. In 1781, the man ran on the streets of New York for his great goal. Twenty two years ago, Shea ended Hope's life in the same street after a close pursuit. So far, the North American Brotherhood was nearly wiped out, leaving only Liam and Achilles who were desperate. Hope's mansion was destroyed by the fire in New York in 1776. In the same year, Shea went to Paris, ending the life of the old Dorian and the childhood of the young Dorian. Since then, Shea has also embarked on the journey of looking for the artifact everywhere, and has hidden himself from history. In 1781, when the man set foot on the land of New York, time seemed to have erased the traces of these predecessors. This is a connecting work in the plot. It is more obvious to play again now. This is the greatest part of AC3.
 In addition, this is the most abundant work in the whole series, without doubt. In addition to the main line, there are two secondary lines. One is the obvious home task, and the other is the obscure and weak sense of regional liberation task. The doctrine of assassins has been the tradition of attacking strongholds since the Brotherhood, but this work has split the stronghold invasion and attack in the Brotherhood and the Revelation into a series of regional liberation missions focusing on dynamic tasks and fortress invasion missions focusing on sneaking in, which is quite an interesting attempt. My personal evaluation of this attempt is still good, but it's a pity that this method has not been continued. However, considering the map of Heiqi, it is probably impossible to do so.

However, the awkward aspects and shortcomings of this game are also very prominent. Compared with the above feelings, it is quite a bit of sugar and shit. I don't pay much attention to the image quality, so I don't think this copy is too difficult to accept. But in fact, as far as the host platform is concerned, there is no improvement compared with the original version in 2012. No matter how touching the above stories are, they will be discounted with their rough pictures and weak expressiveness, especially when I played the Odyssey six months ago. This work also has bugs, but they are not fatal. Apart from the fact that I had to reopen because the farmer was stuck in a tree during the homestead mission, I didn't encounter any major problems. So what became such a controversial masterpiece? Personally, I think it is mainly because of two awkward points and one really bad point. One of the two awkward points is the strange feel of this work. The combat feel of this game is probably the most weird and difficult to grasp in the whole series, especially compared with the first three games. The main reason here is that the feedback after the player presses the key is very long, that is, the man's action animation after the player presses the key is very long, which makes it difficult for the player to grasp the time to press a key. At the same time, the enemy's offensive desire is also stronger than that of the trilogy period, and they will also compete with players for frames. Therefore, players are easy to be beaten if they don't grasp the key timing properly. In addition, this action has reduced the player's attack power. Even if it is an ordinary soldier who directly attacks the weakest, the man will have to cut for half a day. The significance here is that every time you cut a knife, the player has to press the key once. The more keys you need to press, the more likely the player will make mistakes. In combination with the extremely long animation, the timing of the keystroke requires completely different counterattacks, weapons unloading and blocks. In addition, the players' active defense breaking and throwing skills make the changes in the rhythm of the keystroke very complex. In addition, the offensive desire of the soldiers is much higher than that of the trilogy era. The combat difficulty of this work is actually much higher than that of the trilogy.This combat system was finally polished after the mutiny (in fact, the three generation climbing system is also), so the sense of mutiny is the best in the North American trilogy. So maybe someone will ask: Since that man is not very hard and the fight is more difficult than the previous one, why is this one so famous? The answer is simple, because it is very difficult to sneak in, especially when fighting blockhouses. Oasis has a song called Don't look back in anger. Although the life I want more now is the title of their other song: The importance of being idle.

Review - ([b]On Hold[/b])
Very nice remaster, fixed a lot of the annoying things of the original, but some flaws still remain.

Easily the worst game in the entire series, and that's saying something since this franchise is a rollercoaster of good, bad, and ugly (mostly ugly). I have a special place in my heart for these shitty games but I will have no nostalgia for AC3.

Where to start... ugh, ok, the price tag. They still want to charge $20 for this I guess because it was "remastered" in 2019, although that doesn't mean much and the game is much older. I am not even sure why this qualifies as remastered other than maybe some slightly smoother graphics and better lighting? idk, I actually didn't play the original so whatever. And it almost NEVER goes on sale even when all the games after it are 75% off, so they are really proud of this crap for some reason.

The game engine is unchanged from 3 games prior and somehow actually worse. The fighting is terrible but stealth also doesn't work because the environment and controls are so damn finnicky and buggy you have no idea what your stupid wooden character is going to do. It's an all around mess to be sure.

The only saving grace this game has is the naval combat, which you can easily skip out on in lieu of playing the much more polished AC4 which is a masterpiece in many ways. All in all, save yourself and skip this one.

WHERE THE FUCK IS LEE

Это одна из прекраснейших частей с интересным дополнением. Будем сравнивать попарно. Начнем с гемплея. В 3 части изменился паркур. Стал проще в управлении. Теперь можно с легкостью с дерева на дерево прыгать. Добавили механику кустов. Очень помогает в преследовании. Появился животный мир, правда особого смысла в нем не вижу, так затрагивает частично сюжет, ну а так в целом для лутеров или убить время. Прекрасно реализованы времена года, сразу чувствуются сугробы при передвижении. Можно заниматься мореплаванием, что очень доставляет. Увы экономические сделки здесь хромают, очень слабо, проще сундуки лутать. По поводу Liberation: является неким комбо 2 части и 3. Где вновь доступны магазины, которые можно купить. Механики торговли намного интереснее реализована чем в 3 части. Покупай новые корабли, отправляй грузы в другие города, получай прибыль и по новой. Увы в 3 эту штуку убрали. По поводу оружия для Эвелины отравленные дротики это основное оружие для дальнего тихого убийства при помощи трубочки или зонтика, есть еще дротики-берсерки. У Коннора же больше лук, хотя присутствуют ядовитые дротики но это больше все же ножики. Шэнбяо - самый интересный инструмент 3 части, при помощи него можно легко подвешивать жертв на какой-нибудь ветке. У Эвелины аналогом есть кнут, который так же можно юзать в битве, но подвешивать на нем нельзя, зато можно прыгать дальше цепляясь за "специальные балки, лианы, ветки". Животный мир в Liberation также есть, но не такой богатый как в 3. Есть механика каноэ, такая же как и во 2 части, увы 3 лишена такого. Ну и следует отметить главную механику этой прекрасной игры - переодевание. У нас есть 3 личины: ассасин, госпожа, рабыня. Каждая обладает своими преимуществами и ограничениями. при этом рейтинг обнаружения у всех разный (но заметьте для ассасина всегда рейтинг 1). Также рабыня при переносе ящиков и бочек получает инкогнито. Возьмите на заметку. По поводу графония и звука во всех частях все нормально, "не вырви глазно". Что по поводу багов и вылетов? Увы Liberation в этом плане проигрывает. Есть и то и то, также немного технически недоработанное управление. Также пропадает при каждом запуске звук диалогов, мне приходилось перед запуском удалять файл options чтобы послушать озвучку, а то как-то не камильфо, рот открывается, субтитры идут, а звука нет. В 3 части намного лучше, хотя тоже баги есть, при чем в отличии от Liberation немного бесячие (например, я застрял в дереве и пришлось грузится с контрольной точки). Кстати для Liberation придется выучить английский или сидеть с субтитрами, тут русской озвучки не завезли☺. По поводу сюжета. В обоих случаях наши герои хотят добра и делают все на максимум, чтобы дорогие им люди (индейцы или чернокожие рабы) были свободны. И каждый в своей очереди сталкивается с тамплиерами и их взглядами, немного бунтует против философии своего наставника. И мне реально нравится наблюдать над этим, что у них есть свое мнение. А теперь детальнее. Коннор (Радунхагейду) по подсказкам Юноны находит старого ассасина, обучается и по списку пытается их всех уничтожить, даже своего отца. Все клешировано, но довольно интересно, есть поворотные моменты, которых никак не ожидал. Но не забывайте, что здесь главным героем также является и Дезмонд. Концовку которую, как по мне, слили. Может бюджета не хватило. У Эвелины - ее история, является игрой, а точнее воспоминания Объекта 1, которые "изменили" и представили перед публикой. Но "хорошие" хакеры решили взломать игру и выдают в определенные моменты правдивые сведения, для активации нужно просто убить цель "Э", как простой триггер. И все скрытое станет явью. В конце концов мы тоже убиваем тамплиеров (но не по списку), а как это было во второй части. Начинаем исследовать, искать. Кстати в Liberation попытались немного усложнить механику детектива, где кроме следов можно изучить улику и восстановить цепочку событий.
Как итог, мне обе игры понравились, оценочки для AC3 - 8.3 из 10, ACL - 8.7 из 10 ( было бы выше, если бы до ума довели бы техническую часть.

Good things:

Things I don't like: Oh boy, Oh boy...

I have a soft spot for ACIII, as I feel it is a bit underrated and caught more flak than was due simply for having a more stoic main character without the charm of Ezio, as well as perhaps the glitches and poor performance of the original console release. The story in general is, however, quite fantastic, if not one of the best in the series. The "villains" are much more complex and "gray" than they were in Ezio trilogy, each with backstory and goals that are not entirely unsympathetic. The homestead and its side missions was a great feature most players likely ignored that really filled out the story and made it all feel more alive and dynamic.

It also brought so many new things to the series after a relatively stale previous entry (Revelations). The tree parkour, rebuilt animations, the new combat system, the ship combat, animals, and so on. The Remastered version here too got a lot of negative attention due to a select few scenes getting a lot of attention where one could argue the original looked better, but by and large this is the definitive version with far superior lighting and improved mechanics (you can now whistle from hiding places, like in Black Flag, for example). It's not the best in the series, but for me it is a big step up from Revelations.

Where do I begin? I started playing Assassin's Creed when the first game came out in 2007 I believe. I remember loving that game and the same for the second. I distinctly remember on Christmas day opening this game up for my Xbox 360 and playing the game all day long. I can remember everything from that day, the sights, smells, and feelings of warmth and happiness. To my delight when I first popped this game into the disc tray and played it I felt transported in time. I truly felt like I was Connor, and I felt like I could see the sights taking place in the game as if I was there and the same goes for the sounds etc. I think this game is easily IMO the best Assassin's creed game. To be fair I only have dabbled in the games after this one. Anyone is certainly welcome to argue with me and I am sure they will have their valid points. To me this is one of those games that you never forget. It is a game that you can lose yourself in and never get bored of and if you do you will inevitably find your way back to it just like I did. Sure there might be some bugs and mechanics that aren't the greatest, but in my humble opinion Assassin's Creed 3 is the greatest of its series.

It's been a while since i first played this game and this play through has made me change a lot of my thoughts on this game. 

The story line is brilliant as always and with a new protagonist to run around revolutionary america. Lots of new mechanics were added to this game and so is very different to the Ezio games.
Some mechanics are really great and fun like being able to steer a ship and using the rope darts and blow pipes. Hunting and skinning animals were an added touch that worked really well with the native american overarching story. 
Free running became a lot easier somehow than previous titles and made the whole running and jumping from one thing to another far more fun than before.

Also big shout out to the davenport homestead. The homestead missions were brilliant and you feel like you're part of a community, it really is a joy to watch the village grow.

The fast travel underground was definitely a weird take on the fast travel mechanics and after spending a couple of hours fleshing the whole map i definitely needed a nap, they could have made it more interesting.

Now to the bad stuff. I absolute can not stand the long riflemen. They are certainly one of the most annoying aspects since the arrival of the gun, they can spot you a mile off and will annoy the heck out of you, definitely one of my more hated newer elements to the series. 
Another one i misliked was the almanac pages. My god i hate running after these sods and then you just happen to jump at a wrong angle and you've fallen and lost the page.
Finally the battle missions were just rubbish i didnt care for using cannons to kill oncoming armies, i didnt care for dodging behind one rock then another whilst an army is firing towards me and i definitely did not care about ordering a firing line at an oncoming army. it just sucked and didnt feel very assassin like and more like a general or officer of the patriot army.

I remember the first time i played this i enjoyed it a lot more than i did this time round. With some mechanics being downright annoying it really knocked my nostalgia. However despite that there was a whole bunch of new mechanics that really felt true to the assassins and to the expansion of the universe.

Lastly, i have to say the game is easy to play(mostly) and i enjoyed yet another assassins story [spoiler] and for a time a Templars[/spoiler] However this was the last game in the Desmond arc and i was very sad to see our modern day protagonist leave the franchise.
[spoiler] I was sorry to see you go Desmond but you'll live in our hearts forever and thank you for saving our world. Laa shay'a waqi'un moutlaq bale kouloun moumkin. [/spoiler]

Play the game if you have played the others it's worth seeing the finale of the Desmond arc and also see the newer mechanics in this ever growing universe. Buy on sale ;)

This remaster doesn't make any sense, at least on PC. Not only was III always the worst AC game in my opinion, but this almost entirely graphical remaster somehow manages to make everything look worse than the original. Textures are worse, the game is locked to 60 fps which the original was not, faces now look absolutely atrocious (the scared kid in the opera house at the beginning was always a bit creepy looking, but now he's nightmare fuel) and facial textures are far, far worse than before - and lip syncing is off in places where it didn't use to be. It's just amazing to me how a supposed "remaster" - and one for which they charge as a new game - can manage to take a step back in every area, seven years after the original came out.

Sadly, the conclusion of the Desmond story is also the worst installment. If you are a hardcore fanboy play only the story missions to find out what happens and utterly avoid the map mess around it. If you do not care about the real world story, avoid like the plague.

A good game with some naval battles added for some reason (I still don't know what they're doing in Assassin's Creed but oh well). Can be pretty challenging if you're going for 100% sync (with all the "challenge objectives" which are incorrectly called "optional" - they're often pretty hard to perform and you need to go out of your way to make it happen, so they should've been called "challenges" instead, IMHO). Gameplay is fluid, the plot is somewhat cinematic. The difficulty is just right (not hard, not always a cakewalk), but some parts can be pretty challenging if you go after 100% sync.

The graphics is nice, music is forgettable, but not annoying. Main character is rather naive, voice acting could've been better, IMO. It's okay, but I liked the main villain more, to be honest.

Overall, I enjoyed the experience. Especially after getting through some of the hardest challenging objectives (also known as "optional if you don't care about 100% sync"). Almost done with achievements (they're not available in Steam, only in Ubisoft Connect).

This also comes with Liberation Remaster packaged inside. I liked it in general but it wasn't anything special.

I'm seeing a lot of negative reviews about this game and it feels very unfair to the game.
I'm a hardcore AC fan and take it from someone who's been playing AC games for a log time, this game is great!
here are some key points to be noted about this game.
- This is the first game in the franchise to experiment new combat mechanics implementation.
- This is the first game in the franchise to use new game engine
- This game is the reason AC games have NAVAL COMBAT!!!
- This is the first game in the franchise to try new navigation mechanics.
As you see this game was an experiment ground for the devs to lay out the foundation for [b]Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag[/b].
Black Flag is just a better polished version of this game.

So there were bound to be a a lot of bugs and From the points of Customers I can understand the frustration. 
but if you can look past the plastic looking face models and some silly bugs that makes you wanna smash your keyboard a few times It's a beautiful game with lots to offer.

The story is beautiful.
The character development of Ratonhnhaké:ton and Achilles is wonderful.
the game environment feels smooth with  the new parkour mechanics. sure it removed the agency over manual complex parkour movements like in the previous ac games but feels more cinematic and the transitions are way smoother.
Combat is now also cinematic that changes the game-play experience from previous ac games.

LOOK, if you're gonna keep comparing this game with Ezio triology to meet your expectation then you're going the wrong way.
This game is different from its predecessors and is a whole new experience. Try to enjoy that as it is.

AC III was always one of my favourite AC games. While there are definitely things that I wish were done differently for this remaster, some major some minor, at it's core it's still the same basic game. I still enjoy the combat, the parkour, and the story, bland as the protagonist may be.
He so angy tho fr

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ all of the AC3 & AC:Liberation content in one bundle
+ visual overhauls (especially for AC:Liberation)
+ more fast travel options in AC3
+ free aim guns/bow

[b]CONS:[/b]
- uPlay
- same bugs, glitches & game crashes
- some new bugs & instabilities
- constraints to 100% missions are still terrible
- (for some) removed multiplayer

[b]Special review section for Ubisoft games:[/b]
[u]Should you play?[/u] YES
[u]Should you BUY???[/u] NO, IT'S A POOR REMASTER

[b]Comment:[/b]
[b]AC3:[/b]
This review is about changes from the original, that review is [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/artibius/recommended/208480/]HERE[/url].
You still play as Haytham and Connor. Haytham's part has been limited as the collectibles and side missions were reduced. Chests are distributed along the chapters and not all at once. Visually it is better in some regards but not the characters. They became too waxy and/or mannequin-like with eyes looking like glass. Improvements were done for icons and fast travel in Homestead and most other areas too. UI looks smoother. Multiplayer has been removed but apart from the Wolfpack mode it was not that great anyway though some people may miss it. Playing it a second time to 100% (kill me) I realized why the only parts from AC3 that are memorable to me are the Desmond & Homestead parts. Because the constraint are so damn glitchy, difficult and downright annoying in some missions ... that you just focus on the objectives instead of the stories. Especially because checkpoints are made by Satan himself so the game saves just as you fail an objective so you have to replay the entire memory. Epilogue was slightly changed, it removed some vital info/closure for Desmond's memory. But here is where the issues start: Store icon bug (icons are swapped, the ones you visited will say 'Not visited' and vice versa); Almanac pages not showing up so you chase the icon. The same glitchy AI plagues the game; Final Desmond cutscene glitched and did an Alt+Tab; And many MANY more. Considering I write this 1 year after the remaster came out I doubt they will still fix some stuff. Possibly it would have been better to make a GOTY version where they fixed all the bugs and glitches. Instead they remastered the visuals but left all the issues from 2012 still in there...

[b]AC3 - Tyranny of King Washington:[/b]
Reviews of the original DLCs: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/artibius/recommended/227130/]The Infamy[/url], [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/artibius/recommended/227131/]The Betrayal[/url] and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/artibius/recommended/227132/]The Redemption[/url].
Looks better, just like AC3. Thankfully bundled so you avoid the DLC store mess the originals had. It is still as difficult as the original though, to 100% it you will do missions over and over. Same bugs are still present, unfortunately. Like "Chain 3 Eagle Flights, twice" constraint working properly only with gamepad. Or convoys not having prisoners in Boston (you need to exit the game and load it again). Or when a selected weapon is not being used, just fists instead. Or falling through the world map if you air assassinate from a certain angle. Or that sometimes it doesn't allow you into tactical mode in the damn checkers mini-game. And finally, the game behaving weirdly with heavy weapons and their chests after every mission or save load (removing the weapon and showing the icon again). This DLC was a hot mess when it came out and it remained that mess even when remastered.

[b]AC3 Liberation Remastered:[/b]
Review of the original version can be found [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/artibius/recommended/260210/]HERE[/url].
Definitely more visible graphical and movement improvements than in AC3. The UI is much smoother and the areas had much more life added to them. Probably the combat and parkour had the best rework. Bayou had added light but it is still just a bunch of shades of brown, even remastered. It is a terribly designed area that you have to endure without any fast travel options, even remastered. The collectibles also don't stay on the map once discovered, only when you are near them. The cutscenes are skippable now and trade system has been fixed. Side objectives are still not viewable on main screen (need to open map for that) but this is a problem of the series. So this remaster threw a new coat of paint but left many of the issues. Unfortunately, one of the new things added are also compatibility issues. The "Your connection to the Ubisoft servers has been lost." message appears with start of the game (but uPlay rewards and achievements still work). Exiting the game also always crashes the application. By the way all of the DLC and uPlay unlocks are still present.

[b]TL;DR:[/b]
Overall, if you take quantity over quality approach there is a ton of content here - all the items, DLCs and AC:Liberation; so you can spend plenty of hours playing this game. And because they removed the original AC3 this also is the only version that you can buy to finish Desmond's story. [b]So, while I give it a thumbs down, I'd say the best way to get this is to [u]acquire it via the AC Odyssey - Season Pass[/u][/b] (you need to install and activate that in uPlay first before starting AC3) or a super deep sale if you are a fan. Otherwise just ignore this game entry, it is a disappointing remake that had potential but squandered it and is not worth the money...

[b]P.S.:[/b] [u]uPlay unlockable DLCs:[/u] Alexios' Outfit (skin for AC3), Arno Dorian's Outfit (skin for AC3), Bayek's Outfit (skin for AC3), Edward Kenway's Outfit (skin for AC3), Ezio's Outfit (skin for AC3), Jacob Frye's Outfit (skin for AC3), Shay Cormac's Outfit (skin for AC3), Pirate Armor Pack (2 weapons for AC3; 1 weapon for AC:L), Initiate Pack (1 mission for  AC3; 1 mission for AC:L), Assassin Pack (1 naval mission & 1 pistol for AC3; 1 weapon for AC:L), Master Assassin Pack (1 naval mission & 1 skin for AC3; 1 weapon for AC:L), Extra Tool Pack (upgrades for AC3 and AC:L), Obwandiyag's War Club (weapon for AC3), Upgraded Naval Convoy (naval upgrade for AC3).

If you want to re-play AC 3 because you liked it the first time, or want to play it for the first time, then I recommend the remaster as you get the main game, added Tyranny of King Washington, and AC Liberation. However if you didn't like playing AC 3, this isn't going to change your mind. The remaster changes are minimal, with improved lighting, and some combat improvement, and other small things, but the game is still buggy with weird dark or extra bright spots now added too and the facial animation is flatter than before. I'm a fan of AC 3, accept its faults, and this is my third play through so I'm glad for the remaster with the add on games.

What I thought was the best AC when I was a kid turned out to actually be the most boring one. The stealth seems overlooked, and the naval combat is just plain not fun in my opinion. At 20 hours in and New York, I struggle to enjoy this game. The story is good for the most part, and the combat is very good, but stealth and assassinations were the staple of previous titles. It feels like they focused on combat the most, while it is nice for the player who rushes in, leaves the player who wants to remain anonymous feeling limited. The notoriety system is somewhat interesting, but I feel as if it builds a little too fast (maybe that's just me). Finally, the the amount of content in the Frontier area is lacking, despite its vast size. Think AC Revelation's Constantinople but 70% of it is forest - That's the Frontier. 

I just think that the previous titles do Assassin's Creed a lot more justice. It feels half baked for an AC game. By all means, get it on sale, but even at $20 I think I should have let memories remain memories.

While the story was great, the game had a lot of issues -
* counters not working half the time
* lots and lots of graphical glitches - eyes shining, sun shining thru aps and hoods, everything clipping thru evertyhing in storymode - didn't they really not bother checking and changing some movements to make it less obvious?
* controls were weird when fighting - in previous games it was clear what button did what in high profile. Here not so much.
* So many missions with no hints on what to do or where to go. Some missions took 8-10 retries
* Climbing on rocks - no way to see what can be grabbed on and what can't be
* Horses doing a 100 to 0 when hitting a spruce edge or a random tiny tree in a forest
* No progression in weapons, no armor. After getting your first sword youre done with character progression.

In conclusion - if you're doing a binge on AC series, go for it. The story is great. If you plan on 100%'ing the game, better stay away as it's an excercise in frustration.

The game itself is alright, however the remaster kinda blows. There isn't much improvement other than the lighting engine, but I couldn't care less if it looks like gold considering this is the only version I can have. The biggest issue, and it's incredibly glaring, is the audio, the mixing is all wrong, things are significantly louder than others when they should be equal or quieter, and the dialogue audio sounds like it went through a compressor 10 times to sound worse than a PS1 game. Graphics are nice, but audio is just as important, when your first game has better audio quality than the remaster of your 5th entry, I think something's gone wrong. I've been playing through the games in order, and seeing the first hour of gameplay here, it's just sad, especially compared to the game just before it. I remember playing this when it came out on the PS3 and seeing it treated poorly like most ubisoft games now, it sucks. I wouldn't have bought this on its own, I got it in the big bundle of games when it was on sale, but with Ubisoft and where they're headed, none of the games are worth it.

TL;DR
If the game wasn't busted it'd be a 7/10, but with it in the state that it will die in, it's a 4/10. There are still bugs from before, and more bugs added on top, inconsistent quality with both audio and graphics, and a blatant cash grab. Ubisoft has fallen in many ways and shouldn't be supported, not just because of this being a bad "remaster"

I love ACIII. As a junior historian, the AC games were always something more powerful for me than for the average gamer.  A chance to dive into a fictional story set in a fixed history period. I loved every AC title.  Played the original ACIII on PC back in the day and really enjoyed the end of the trilogy, the Desmond story coming to an end, and the new gameplay features introduced were a blast. This review is based on a recent replay of the remastered version on PC (tried the remastered on Series X but is way too inferior to the PC remastered,  recon modern titles like AC Valhalla have great performance on consoles but these older AC entries really shine on PC)

The colonial American setting was brilliant. The game starts in 1754 during the French Indian War that led to the 7 years' war. But the majority of the game events take place during the revolutionary war, starting in 1775. You get to see the main character connor / Ratonnagethon take part and even influence the most historic events of that time, he gets blamed for the Boston Massacre in 1770 and takes place in the Tea Party 1773 when the king's tea gets tossed into the sea by angry citizens.  I really enjoyed comparing the game events and battles to the actual historical records and seeing how they implemented fiction upon a solid historic framework. After completing the game, I compared my notes taken during gameplay with events during the John Adams miniseries and the movies The crossing and The patriot, both released in the year 2000.

There is still a problem with some new gameplay mechanics, The headquarters/homestead evolution system is nice compared with previous entries but still feels incomplete. I can't tell how some of these mechanics were improved upon in the remastered. The convoy trading system is something I ignored completely in the original, and with the remastered, I wanted to give it a try, but it is just dumb and serves no purpose. The main problem is the progression, I guess. I had redeemed some weapons packs from Ubisoft club, but the game would not let me use them "you need to complete sequence 6" but after doing that you are almost in the final part of the game. Weapons are way too expensive you need to complete the game 1st and then do some forts and side activities to get the money to buy good swords, but then as the game is over there is not much to do with the items. The same with the naval missions. Tried to take them head-on at the start and quickly realized that I needed to upgrade the ship 1st to withstand those battles, but that requires a LOT of money. After I completed the game, took on some side activities to gather money and resources and finally upgraded the ship and then only then able to complete the SHIP missions, but they all take place during 1773 as they are prequels to the events of the main story... There is something wrong here. But I was happy that my expensive officer sword would at least be used in the DLC that I intended to engage in after completing all the main game activities, so I was equipped with good tools for the job.

The Washington Tyranny DLC was a blast, love the take on an alternate reality where Washington got corrupted by the apple. The new gameplay features were amazing, but here is the shock: you can't carry those special abilities back into the main game. And you can't carry progression from the main game into the DLC, I know there is an alternate universe and all. But still, there is a clear progression design that was not solved during the remastered process. So everything I did during the main game as far as progression, the fancy sword, the upgraded expensive ship... oh my :/

If you enjoyed ACIII, the remastered version is the best way to re-experience one of the best AC of all time. There are clear design flaws in the progression system, but it's only natural since these are the 1st entries of this franchise and many of these flaws were corrected and improved in new releases.

STEEP DOWNHILL

I had weird off-putting feeling in every second I spent playing the game, and I don't really know where to put it. This remaster is my very experience for AC3 and I haven't played the original. A jump of graphics from AC Revelations and then back to AC4 Black Flag can be a bit off putting since this remaster features modern visual fidelity compare to other original installments. I'll get to the graphics later but this remaster whole existence is very much unneeded and felt cashgrab-ish. Since the Ezio trilogy has a remastered collection, why not just take AC4 and Rogue too for the remastered treatment? These three games are pretty much set in almost similar time periods with AC4 and Rogue taking place before AC3.

Let's start with the story. There's is alot of controversy with the ending of AC3, and I pretty much on the majority side of the group. I have no idea why the ending is the way it is. Isolating the ending, what about the overall story? Well, the story is okay, The bar to reach is very high with this game since the past 3 games are pretty much top-notch in storytelling. AC3 also has an interesting story that tackles in theme of morality and the grey areas of both Assassins' and Templars' philosophy. Also a tale of revenge by the new main character, Connor, which can be badass but sometimes boring. Him being stoic is not very entertaining for me. He needs a character to bounce off from to shine, atleast in my opinion. I cannot recall any other feats Connor has other than steadfast and serious. 

The gameplay is fun. The combat here is the most satisfying I've had in an Assassins' Creed game. I would not say the best, but incase I'm stuck with the franchise and have a choice to pick an installment where I can turn off my brain and go wacky, its this game. All hits feel satisfying and crunchy with sometimes accompinied by multikills which have unique animations depending on the weapon and number of enemies. The combat here is very amazing. 

On to the downsides, the graphics looks very weird although being a remaster that prides in high visual fidelity. I don't if its because of the lighting or texture or old artstyle not evolving with the new, it just looked very unsettling. I've mentioned the story abit but yes, taking place after the compelling Ezio Trilogy made AC3's story feel very mediocre. 

The soundtrack by Lorne Balfe is something I will cherish from this game. One of the best in the franchise with banger after banger.

Overall, a mixed bag.

3/5

While the homestead "convoy missions" / crafting part of this game is clunky to the point of being awful and hard to understand, the main mission game play, interspersed with actual historical characters is fun and intriguing. I think this game is a fun, albeit sad, ending to Desmond's Journey, and this game is another great iteration of AC. I love how the small amount of ship/sailing-based missions are building toward what we now know is Black Flag, but there is some fun variety there.

I'm also very appreciative of this game's approach in getting rid of grinding -- mainly, the hundreds upon hundreds of chests scattered throughout the world. Now, the chests provide some money but tangible recipes/plans to be used in the (previously mentioned as awful) homestead building.

I'm not a fan of this game's approach to Brotherhood building. It seems like a step back from what we got in Revelations. I had trouble getting assassin's leveled up to the point where they could complete missions. Most of the time, I could only get to an 80% success rate -- regardless of how many I chose -- which is perplexing. I much prefer the previous build in how it worked.

Overall, this is a great game and one that I will come back to every few years for sure.

After 100+ hours of gameplay on the third installment of AC, and its DLC, I can say that the remastered version of AC3 is incredible in many aspects, most notably the visuals. There is a few issues with the lip sync and the voice in the game, but nothing terrible.
The mechanics are amazing and entertaining, especially for the combat and the free run is quite fluid which let's you work around the scenery much more.
When it comes to the story, I will go with a hot take here, but yes... is noticeable that Ratonhnhaké:ton/Connor suffers from a lack of dialogue and seems hellbent on his mission. But the game provides life through the NPC's, been quite lively and balancing the lack of dialogue from the main protagonist of the game, but thankfully so, sometimes even he has some moments that can be remembered. His father as a starting character during the first part of the game is quite the choice but makes everything fit all together for this tale.
And about the present day part... what an ending right there!

Anyway, anything I can say about this game has been already written, but this is still part of my first ever marathon of all the AC games because I've never played before and I'm doing this on the proper sequence. And now for the next one, which is almost everybody's favorite, AC4: Black Flag!

If you're reading this and you're on the fence about AC3, give it a chance, the game starts slows but picks up fast and you will enjoying a lot! And don't forget to take PLENTY of picture of the Davenport Homestead during the summertime while is the afternoon, absolutely gorgeous!

8/10 - Will fight for freedom again!

I went in to Assassins Creed 3 knowing what I was getting myself into, and after finishing it, I can’t really endorse playing this game in 2022 or beyond. There are definitely better things to do with your time, however if you really want to do it, I mean… it’s really one of the most mediocre games I’ve ever played and it has aged rather unevenly.

It’s functional, and it is fun on the Steam Deck to an extent, but for the most part it’s just barely fun. The movement is super awkward and a lot of missions are just repetitive. There’s this whole open world thing going on, but none of the things are required to beat the game, nor are any of them really that engaging.

There just aren’t many reasons to play this game. My reason was that I wanted to finish the trilogy, having played AC1 and AC2, but I really had no clue what was going on. It wasn’t really worth it in the end.

I consider Assassin's Creed III to be a solid entry in the series, and the original 2012 game was a very ambitious game by the standards of its time, and while it fell short in some areas (story pacing, absurdly long tutorial, some tedious mechanics), it brought a much-needed refresh in mechanics (naval combat, tree parkour, a new, more action-packed combat system, a whole new setting) to a series that was starting to feel rather stale to some after the Ezio trilogy. While Assassin's Creed III technically doesn't impress with its scale as much today as it did in 2012, it still offers a very entertaining portion of gameplay for players patient enough to sit through the lengthy intro.

However, I cannot recommend the remastered version with a clear conscience. Although this version offers significant improvements over the 2012 version and adds all the DLC and Assassin's Creed Liberation to the package, the game is riddled with technical issues, particularly lighting problems that completely undermine the original art direction of the game.

Given Ubisoft's silence, I don't expect the situation to improve in the future. If you get a chance, play the original 2012 version. This remaster is hardly up to the standards of modern games.
If you can get past the extreme clunk of the game then it's actually not too bad.
The Ezio Trilogy was way better.

Graphics are nice in some places but that seems to be the only "remastered" aspect of the game. The voice acting is terrible and 99% of the time is either way too quiet, extremely loud, doesn't play at all or gets randomly cut off mid sentence. The parkour system is decent but would certainly be better if the controls weren't wildly imprecise, at times it feels like Connor is both blind and deaf and is just feeling his way around rooftops. The combat is average at best, would definitely help if the camera wasn't just randomly swinging around and zooming in on completely random shit. Every mission seems to be pretty much exactly the same as the last, either following someone around for 5 minutes or walking for 10 minutes then killing a group of people. Countless bugs, I don't think I saw a mission that didn't have at least 3 or 4 bugs completely halting progress and making you restart from a checkpoint. The worst aspect however is the new "enhanced" ai. They are pretty much impossible to escape after getting level 1 notoriety and whilst the game has lots of ways to lower your notoriety they are impossible to reach because the ai can see you from miles away. Truly a Ubisoft moment all around.

On paper I should have loved this game. Best historical setting (IMO) to come out of the franchise and riding the high of the Ezio trilogy surely meant this game was going to be good right? Absolutely f*cking wrong, this is, by far, the worst entry into the AC franchise to date (yes I'm aware that Odyssey exists). Some minor spoilers (duh) but this game is a decade old so f*ck off.

Let's start with the positives though.
Haytham is a very well  written character who's ideals and actions feel not just justified, but respectable and dare I say commendable. His plot twist at the end of Sequence 3 is one of the best in the franchise, and every moment he shows up on screen is pure gold.

The world building is also pretty well done, if telegraphed and a bit predictable. visually it's what you would hope for and expect for a game this old, and there is a lot to be said for running through the canopy of the frontier just to hang a freezing redcoat from a branch in the dead of winter is absolutely marvelous and visually stunning.

Unfortunately, that's all the positives I can think of without pandering to my favorite franchise of all time. So let's talk about the mediocrity. Things that were kinda cool/gimmicky or had a good foundation but just weren't built up as well as they could have been.

Homestead Missions - I actually really enjoyed these. Connor's interactions with the Davenport citizens was awesome. The idea of building up a settlement with unique characters that provide value both storywise and mechanically to the game was really good, but fell short in a few places. I think that upgrading citizens should have more impact than just unlocking more crafting options. There would have been a lot more added value through uncovering hidden treasures, more customization options, the tower defense mode from revelations, while it was kinda bad in AC:R, I think could have actually worked here if you could build your own defenses, visually showing upgrades/enhancements to the homestead rather than just adding a new building and dialog options for each citizen. Etc, Etc, Etc... Basically Ubi could have put forth a tiny bit more effort and this part of the game would have gone from mediocre to absolutely awesome.

Naval missions - there was actually some uniqueness here and being that this was the shell for the magnificent naval mechanics of AC4, I can't hate this too much. These missions and mechanics actually boded well for what was to come in AC4 and while the system here isn't great, that is mostly due to just being unpolished and underdeveloped, for what was ultimately side content in this game regardless. Definitely could have been better, but looking at all the sh*t later in this review, it could have been way worse.

Homestead leads to my next point of the Creed. Using Davenport as a mechanic to build up the Creed and using the citizens to supply/enhance/etc would have made a rather dull mechanic much better. The assassin recruits are ultimately just busy work, they aren't necessary, you can go the entire game never interacting with the other 5 and Stephane is only there due to being part of a main story mission. It was a nice thing to add in, but could have been way more rewarding and way more than a copy paste from AC:Brotherhood/Revelations.

Wow this review is long, and the negatives are the longest too -.- I'll try to speed run the negatives like playing Russian Roulette with Connor's one shot flintlock.

Let's start with Connor - what an absolute sh*t show of a bland, entirely forgettable character. No character growth, no emotional growth, and honestly after playing this game to 100% completion twice now, I don't think there has ever been a character who needlessly whines about things that don't feel important whatsoever. Maybe Joffrey from Game of Thrones, but if we are comparing Connor to a 10 year old boy who is the product of incest than we have a lot of other problems. Connor doesn't speak much, and I don't think he ever says anything impactful. BuT EnGlISh Is HiS sEcOnD lAnGuAgE. F*ck right off, Ubi didn't do that intentionally, this is poor writing and character development at it's worse. It's evident through Connor not being the only poorly scripted character, just about every character in the game is dreadfully boring (Haytham excluded, see above). It's such a systemic issue in this game even groups of people are just dull. Templars, assassins, sons of liberty, The Masons, everyone is just uninspired.

Combat - it was nice that Ubi streamlined the combat system, but it was at the expense of feeling like you could actually become skilled at it. The prior games had a bunch of key/control combos that did different things that were really interesting, whereas as this just felt like a press "B" sim. Combined with the fact that enemy actions were so telegraphed that the whole experience just sucked.

(The speedrun isn't going well, must be stuck in reload animation)

Traversal - never has running across rooftops been so frustrating and legitimately pointless. Snipers target you as soon as you start to climb, there's just enough gaps between buildings where you can't seamlessly sprint from one side of a city to the other, plus Connor likes to take the least desirable traversal option every chance he gets. Literally just running on the ground is better. There is also the fast travel system. I understand that sync points aren't used for fast travel since they introduced the underground, but WHY don't sync points reveal more of the map then??? I want fast travel to save time, not to spend 2 hours wandering in pitch black tunnels to complete sh*tty puzzles. Is this a little nitpicky on my end? Yes. Do I care? F*ck off with your bullsh*t Ubi. Not to mention that there is effectively no useful fast travel locations in the frontier. Oh, and moving around during winter is awful, despite how pretty it can be in game. Realistic? Sure. Infuriating? Mind-numbingly so.

Side quests - for something that is meant to be a time sink, these really were a sink. Collection quests that get botched by the shoddy crafting and hunting QTE systems, Go somewhere and do something that you'll never do in the normal course of the game activities, etc. Side content is supposed to add value in some sort of way. There's a lot of ways to add value. This content didn't. Did you know that Sasquatch and the Headless Horseman are in the game? I say "in like they spend more than 1.7 seconds on screen. Sasquatch is just a tall loner dude and the Horseman *Exists*. Absolutely just wasteful with their ideas.

Stealth - For a franchise that's built on stealth, running across rooftops and silently reducing the population of evildoers one assassination at a time, there is no stealth mechanic here. Enemies will detect you basically anywhere if you arent hiding, especially in the frontier where for whatever reason you always have notoriety? Like why. Not just that, but the dumbed down combat dissuades you from even trying stealth. Why would I spend 15 minutes pulling 3 guys into a stack of hay just to be detected by some guard on the other side of the map for the 3/10's of a second that I'm technically visible for when I could run in and just start committing homicide by mashing the B button and be done with it in 30 seconds?

TL;DR - 2/10, There are a few redeeming qualities about this game, none of which are worth spending money on, there are a bunch of points I didn't touch on because they've been talked to death (Desmond/modern setting scenes, bugs, plot holes, etc). I tried to compare this game only to previous games as each game should be better than it's predecessors and this is just nowhere near that. The only reason I would recommend this game is there is some slight lore set up for future games (Black Flag, Rogue, and Syndicate) but not anything necessary to enjoy those experiences.

Unlike most of the people here I'm going to properly review this game as it is, not with all the Ubisoft drama currently.

I've been working on completing every main AC game since I bought AC4 back in 2016. Before this entry, I've played most of the titles minus Valhalla and Syndicate. I'll have a Tl;dr at the end. By the way, my hours are bugged. I have around 15 hours instead of the 6 that is listed.

Going off what I've been told and the first hour of gameplay, my first impressions of the game were positive. The story seemed to start off well, and I really enjoyed how much care they put into the native American side of Connor's life. I really enjoyed Haytham and his way of operating in the tutorial sequence.

But as I progressed in the game, some glaring issues popped up. First of all, the climbing is atrocious. Maybe it's because I just finished Unity, but I honestly was having such a horrible time with the climbing. It took me forever to figure out how to climb a tree, along with the infamous running up a wall issue that I heard so much about. I failed the final chase mission with Charles Lee at least 10 times because of the absolutely horrible climbing mechanics. Connor and Desmond were always doing the exact opposite of what I wanted all the time. It honestly felt like a downgrade compared to Revelations. Along with this, I found the movement to be bugged in general. Connor glitching through rocks and ledges, bodies being flung 40 feet in the air for no reason, etc. The one thing that pissed me off the most was the horse. It gets stuck on anything and everything. It won't jump over the smallest things, its pretty slow, and it controls like garbage. When you get shot, the horse gets hit instantly regardless of if the shot hit or not which I found more annoying than anything. Probably the worst movement / climbing since AC1.

Next, was the story itself. Although I loved the setting, the story really fell apart later in the game. At the beginning I really liked where the story was going until I was introduced to Connor. I found him very aloof, and like an angsty teenager. He was kind of an asshole to everyone except his own people, and he really wasn't too warm to them either. He was constantly saving the founding father's asses the whole game. Seemingly out of the FF's incompetence. They were indifferent to his annoying behavior and he was well liked in the end regardless. Washington's portrayal also didn't sit right with me either. I found most of the supporting characters minus Achilles to be pretty annoying overall. The only good part was the modern storyline, which has its own issues but ended Desmond’s story pretty well.

There were multiple chances to completely take out the Templars that Connor was hunting yet Connor opted for some bullshit plan when the answer was right in front of him multiple times. For example, one of the last missions was where Connor had to approach Charles Lee while he was giving a speech. Instead of shooting him, rushing in there and stabbing him, or stealthily climbing buildings for an assassination, he instead opted to walk right up to him and get caught. This is after years of assassin experience. Just one example.

Graphics for 2012 were decent, but the remastered version did nothing to improve on this. I heard they reworked the weapon menus, so I guess that's a plus. Speaking of weapons, I found myself not caring about the weapon variety. I went through the whole game with the stock weapons, didn't touch anything other than the bow, hidden blades, pistol, and axe. It just shows you how pointless it all is. I never used any consumables either, or hunted for that matter. There were a lot of things that were useless to me unless I was trying to 100% the game.

The ship mechanic was kinda cool, but not even close to AC4 in that front. I found it boring and the controls to be worse than AC4. Also is useless unless you're trying to 100% the game. I didn't like how you had to hold shift to charge a shot and fire, selecting different shot types was annoying, pressing spacebar and E to raise or lower sail was also a dumb choice. Swivel guns were mostly useless even against the smaller ships unless it was on a weak point that only appeared on the bigger ships. Ship combat frankly didn't flow like it does in AC4, good news is that there were only 2-3 missions that used the thing.

AI across the board is pretty bad, either they are super dumb on 0-1 notoriety level, or omnipotent gods on level 2+. I hate the notoriety system in general. Too hard to lose notoriety, and the game becomes unplayable at anything above level 1. Another thing AC4 does a lot better. In AC3, I can sometimes bait enemies to jump off docks and drown while sitting there, other times they would know exactly where I was after weaving through buildings for a while and broke line of sight 2 minutes prior. Its inconsistent as hell.

People claim the combat was gutted in the new gen AC games, yet the combat here felt like: Press R to shoot some people till you run out of ammo, spam left MB, spam E when an enemy attacks you, or press spacebar when you can’t counter an attack. Another thing I noticed was that if you’re in the middle of a chain attack on an enemy and don’t complete it for the kill, it seems that their health just completely goes back to full. I had an enemy survive 6 cancelled chain attacks once because I was hit out of each one before it finished. None of the flair from the Ezio trilogy is present here. A pretty boring experience tbh, AC4 does a little better on this side of things (Along with just about everything else).

I’ve touched on the bugs a little bit, but I found this to be the buggiest AC game I’ve played thus far. I didn’t play Unity on release but I’m sure AC3 on release could rival it. And they clearly didn’t fix much in the remastered version. 

Tl;dr: A trial run for AC4, its like how Windows Vista is to Windows 7. A proof of concept. Meh to decent story, half-baked / useless mechanics, bugs out the ass, pointless items and collectibles, inconsistent AI, no notable improvements over the OG version, and a subpar experience. Good for the nostalgia, not for much else. Seriously just go play AC4, it’s worth a lot more than this game is. 4/10
