65/100 ACIII Remastered is the very definition of inconsistent.  Only play this if you are an AC completionist, and expect lots of frustration.  I'd recommend playing any of the ACII trilogy, AC IV, Origins, or Odyssey instead.  

The world is beautiful, the historical time period is interesting, the naval missions are fun.  The biggest issue is one minute you're enjoying the game, the next minute the game takes away player agency and frustrates the heck out of you with instafail or restricted sections.  You can spend 40 hours crafting, getting weapons and extras like smoke bombs, increasing the pouch sizes etc, but then the game will decide to take away your ability to use most of these tools, and force you to play sections in a particular way without access to these.  

The story is even more jarring than usual, you are not just flipping back and forth between in the animus and outside the animus: partway through you simply change to playing a different ancestor, and suddenly you are playing this sappy child, and you are trying to kill the old player character, who was cool.  And no, that doesn't spoil the story, the story is already spoiled by being just weirdly told and disjointed.

The Remaster is half-baked, there is no PDF manual, there is an in-game manual but it does not include basic things like controls for the naval battles, playing the mini-games etc.  Customise controls does not allow you to see/change all the keys, nor does what they are named in customise controls match what you see on the screen for ingame prompts.  The controls have been radically revised between ACIII (2012) and ACIII Remastered (2019), with practically every key changing.  Ubisoft has not bothered to update the naming for onscreen control key prompts for things like run, nor does customise controls tell you what key to use for run.  Ubisoft support sent me a 2 page PDF of controls, but it is for ACIII (2012) not ACIII Remastered (2019) and the keys are very different.  Run is actually called high profile in customise controls now, ie the name of the action in customise controls (high profile) does not match the onscreen prompts (run), and don't even bother trying to find the naval battle key for take cover (left mouse) in customise controls, it's not there, nor is it in the in-game manual, nor is there a manual on the Ubisoft website, and Ubisoft will tell you the wrong control keys/the control keys for a different game.  

Overall definitely the weakest of all the AC games I've played so far.

UPDATE after completing The Tyranny of Washington DLC: just like the base game, this included DLC is inconsistent, 65/100, and not recommended.  The DLC is completely linear, there are no sync points, only one active mission, no side quests.  There are chests containing consumables, but there is no money, and your inventory regularly disappears between play sessions, so going after the chests is pointless.  The missions are frustrating, especially in the first two episodes of the DLC.  The first animal power mission tells you to follow the heartbeat of the elk, I have 7.2 sound in my home theatre which is directional in other games, but the sound is not directional in this mission.  The only saving grace is that Episode 3 is enjoyable for the most part once you have all 3 of your animal powers.  But again, the game has a habit of making you work to earn rewards, then taking away player agency.  Eg when exploring the zoo, you can't simply use your eagle flight to move around everywhere, you are forced to platform some sections even though you now have your eagle powers.

UPDATE#2 after completing Assassin's Creed III: Liberation Remastered.  I really enjoyed Liberation, and give it 85/100.  It is about 12 hours long, mostly a lot easier than other AC games, and I would say one of my favourites (along with Odyssey, Origins and Black Flag).  I really liked Aveline (she just reinforces what a sap Connor is).

I thought the idea and execution of the 3 personas was really well done and made the game more interesting.  I would suggest Liberation is a good place to start if you've never played any AC games, as it's shorter and easier (although as a newcomer, you would find a lot of things not well explained by the tutorials, eg leaping through trees, leaping backward, leaps of faith, etc).  

It still has a lot of the usual Ubisoft rubbish, like "you dropped connection to the Ubisoft server" immediately upon starting every time, the game started crashing every time you quit, from about halfway through, and it seemed there was a lack of QA and testing on some of the missions, getting stuck underwater inside rocks etc.

Anyway it's kind of bizarre that this is just chucked in with AC3 Remastered, in my opinion it is far superior to the main act (albeit a lot shorter), but it was nice to finish this package on a high.

worst AC for ever. So many chasing mission, is this a speeding game or an assassin game??? The last 2 chapters are so poorly designed, no assassin at all!!! always chasing!! And the stupid horse can only run for 5 seconds!!!

What a stupid game!!

我是从刺客一开始就在Steam上买的AC 知道奥德赛， 可以说铁粉了吧。

刺客三可以说是最差的一代游戏。除了很多人说的手感和难度，我最不可以忍受的关卡设计。太多关卡是关于追踪的了，尤其最后最重要的两关。

倒数第二关就是对打用防反，和一个支线任务打擂鬼一个操作。 倒数第一关又是追上去抓住James就行了。这是刺客任务还是跑步任务？一点没有刺客任务该有的潜入暗杀。

这破游戏还有好几关这种追上去的任务， 那匹破马也是所有AC中最慢的，体力只能加速不超过10秒然后就停了？能理解游戏想做得真实马不可能一直跑，但停了是几个意思。

这游戏根本就不该算在AC里，潜行暗杀少，最后两关一点高潮没有，包括那个华盛顿的DLC烂到极点，根本不值得玩。

This is horrendous, even by Ubisoft standards. I played the original release many years ago and definitely do not remember it being this miserable of an experience. At the time, it was my favorite AC game. I am genuinely shocked at how buggy and poorly designed this game is. 

There's two major things this game claims to have improved upon which I wholeheartedly disagree with. I just finished playing through the Ezio games, and I can say with certainty that the movement and combat systems in those older games was much better than this one. Movement in this game feels unpredictable and unwieldy. 

There's no hard locking in combat now, and the camera is poorly designed which will leave you disoriented during combat as it swings around and puts enemies out of line-of-sight. This is made worse by the fact that heavy enemies and officers are absolutely everywhere and make combat boring and slow. 

The AI awareness is OFF THE CHARTS. You could assassinate someone from a bush 1000 meters from a soldier facing away from you, and they will immediately notice you and alert the entire fort. Enemies seem to have 360 degree vision. The notoriety system means burping in public will alert every enemy to your presence and merely walking down the street will start to build awareness. 

Every system in this game feels like it's just there to slow progress and frustrate the player.  

The bugs. My god. The bugs. I cannot play a single mission without same BS game-breaking bug. I hopped off my horse and fell through the map. I stopped an enemy caravan and one of the horses merged with the cart, trapping me inside so I had to fast travel to get away from it (thus losing the loot which I should have gained). I mean, it's real bad. 

I am going to finish this game because I'm trying to play through all the AC games in release-order to follow the story. That said, every moment feels like a punishment. I've stopped doing side missions and am focusing on story only so I can get through this nightmare as quickly as possible.
Good game
The graphics are improved but the AI seem too alert. You cant play the game if your notoriety is 1+, and they will attack you in a cut scene if you do.

Assassin’s Creed III is still a solid game to me despite its shortcomings and this does remaster provide some improvements that makes the game more enjoyable. However, it has to be said that most of the changes aren’t deal-makers that would change peoples’; minds if they didn’t like the original.

Certain small improvements like controls more in-line with modern Assassin’s Creed games, more detailed map outlines, new outfits, being able to whistle in bushes, and ability to craft multiple items at once are all fine and good. All the DLC from the original is automatically included in the game as well.

Sadly, there are a few “improvements” that don’t really improve the game that much or even seem worse than the original. The character models look less detailed despite the environment looking better, and it’s now required to have a recipe to craft items. Finally, as multiplayer was completely removed, thought how much of a loss that is depends on the person.

In addition to changes in Assassin’s Creed III, Remastered also includes the remastered version of Assassin’s Creed Liberation, though aside from the DLC and Ubisoft Connect items being included and actually working in this version, there really isn’t much to talk about. It’s still a subpar Assassin’s Creed spin-off that may as well be seen as a novelty or bonus to the main content.

These remastered versions are overall a net positive compared to the originals, but not by much. Problems like the slow start, mapping system, and bugs from the original are all not fixed that much in Remastered, so anyone that didn’t enjoy the original won’t be swayed. That said, with both the original ACIII and Liberation delisted and having their DLC and other bonuses already or soon be defunct, this will be the version to buy (or pirate, since you just know online services for this version will also be taken down in a few years).

Ubisoft if you're going remaster a game then at least make sure you actually know what the fuck you're doing. I had to go out of my way to watch the scene where Connor buries the hatchet into the post, on Youtube, because your dogshit remaster of a game decided to glitch and have the white loading screen over the entire cutscene. It has been an amazing game no matter how stupid the AI may be

First off, activating this game is incredibly frustrating. I got it with the Odyssey Season Pass. When launching AC3 Remaster, Ubisoft Connect asks for you to enter a CD key. This was par for the course with previous titles. However, Steam does not provide CD keys for AC3R. In order to activate, you must download and link Odyssey to your Ubisoft account, which will allow you to link AC3R next time you launch it. This is not stated anywhere to inform new customers.

The game is capped at 62 FPS, but consistently drops to 40-50. The option for 144Hz is there, but selecting it does not do anything. Some people have claimed that the original game could break above 60FPS, but I have not experienced that. If that is the case, I would rather take some bugs at 90+ FPS over this version, which is capped at 60 and can barely even maintain that.

I eventually got annoyed enough to reinstall the non-remastered version, which ended up looking better in my opinion anyway. The remastered version looks great for screenshots, but cutscenes look pretty poor. Lighting causes face models to be so bright they appear plastic. The lighting also makes shadows extremely dark. I had trouble finding a haystack to jump into under half the viewpoints in Boston because when you're high up, the streets appear so dark you can hardly make anything out.

Light sources are, again, screenshot pretty. They are so blown out in gameplay. In cutscenes, I would find that light sources behind the camera would give the entire screen a massive bloom effect that took me out of the immersion more often than not. It ended up being more distracting than anything.

The controls are also a bit off in this version. Using a Series X controller, the X axis aiming is way off. If I point straight while freerunning, I'd often end up jumping to the side off of building because the analog controls are not very precise. There is a massive deadzone, and when you eventually move the analog stick far enough, the aiming response is very strong, even when I lowered the sensitivity to 2. I don't find this problem in the original version. This might be fixable with third party controller software, but that's more trouble than its worth in my opinion,

If you got this game with the Odyssey Season Pass, enjoy it. But if you are trying to pick between this and the normal version, I'd highly recommend the original despite.

If you want to buy this, please keep in mind that AC Odyssey Ultimate Edition will grant you a free copy of AC III Remastered, with other benefits as well (it can go as low as £24 to collect both games during the right sale). If your plan is to play all AC games, might as well keep that in mind.

Writing the base review of the game at 6 hour play time:
I remember playing this game on the XBox 360 back in the day, it was by far a favourite of mine and I had always wanted to buy the PC version. 
The remastered version of this game when not on sale is highly unreasonable for the changes they have made, i recommend you buy this on sales for this very reason.
Although unimpressed with what they have actually remastered I can 100% recommend the game to anyone wanting to re-play or even play for the first time, you explore different characters and for those who played on the old consoles it will bring a sense of nostalgia. 

Thanks for reading my review, I will write more once I have experienced more of the remastered version of this game!

I wrote this review for the original game, which I played two years ago. I got the Remastered version with the Odyssey season pass, and played it to check out the DLC, which I haven’t played back then (it was great!). The remastered version adds new visuals, which look better for the most part, although the lighting and faces look weird in some scenes. There are some minor gameplay improvements too, but for the most part it’s the same, with all the bugs and jank that was in the original.

Originally, I was curious about Assassin's Creed 3 mostly because the main character is a native. It is something that sounded interesting to me as Native American cultures are massively underrepresented in gaming.

As I thought, Connor being a native wasn't the focus of the story, but it was still a nice inclusion. I learned some things about them, and I liked that they spoke their native language. As for the story itself, I think it was great idea to start with Haytham and basically show the world from the antagonists' perspective (even though I knew he wasn’t the main character, the twist actually managed to surprise me). I think the characters were reasonably well written, and the conflict was pleasantly shades of gray. I also liked Connor, I just found him quite relatable. It is a bit comical sometimes how he ends up involved in every main event of the revolution, but this is not really a problem, just funny. Even with that, I think the story was good, and I think it’s the game’s main strength.

The locations, colonial Boston and the frontier, first seemed boring, but they slowly grew on me, and I ended up liking them. The Frontier was particularly atmospheric. I really enjoyed just exploring it, and hunting there, especially in the winter. Speaking of hunting, there are a bunch of side activities that I enjoyed: the Peg Leg missions, which were short linear, but well designed, fun quests, the Boston Brawlers, bare handed combat challenges, and the Homestead Missions, story heavy quests about people living near the Assassin HQ, chronicling them becoming a real community over time. Many of these quests involve combat, which I found to be really well done. It is based around counters, but has enough variety to make it interesting, and the character animations are top notch. I can't stress this enough, the movements are just spectacular, and every weapon type has its own moveset.

Gameplay was a mixed bag though. Having separate slow walk and fast walk was really nice, but the newer games have normal sprint and parkour sprint, which would've been really needed here. Many times I just wanted to sprint at street level without Connor trying to climb every random nearby object, but it is not an option. This made chasing or being chased very annoying. It also has that thing common in the old games where you press a direction and jump, but the character jumps in another direction. The controls in general were simply not reliable enough, although I did like the tree parkour. Jumping from branch to branch was fun.

Stealth did have its problems as well. For example, a basic method of hiding is crouching into bushes. The problem is that there is no crouch button, Connor does this automatically, except when he doesn't feel like it, and you just get detected without doing anything wrong as a player. I also encountered multiple situations where I got detected when I shouldn't have been, or when I got attacked out of nowhere, even in incognito. It was cool when I could pull off a stealthy segment, but this game is just not a very good stealth game.

I have to say, there was one mechanic that was really well done, and it's the assassin recruits. Unlike in Brotherhood, every recruit is a named character with their own story, but more importantly, they all add a unique assassin ability when recruited. For example, apart from the default assassination, you can order a sniper shot on an enemy, or call a friendly assassin to lure away guards, or the best one, Covert Escort: two of your buddies dress up as enemies, while you pretend to be a prisoner. You can walk into enemy strongholds like this without arousing suspicion, and cause mayhem at the desired moment. This is legit one of the coolest things in the franchise.

So, as much as I ended up liking the world and the story, the unreliable controls, stealth, and mechanics in general were a big annoyance, but despite these pissing me off many times, I still enjoyed the game. I guess the magic of historical adventure sucked me in, like it did with the other AC titles. It wasn't bad for "edutainment" either, as I pretty much got a crash course on the events of the American revolution while playing.

good fighting animation and story

Pros
1. The graphics are better than the previous entries
2. Fighting is improved
3. Parkour is more fluid than in previous versions
4. The prologue

Cons
1. Final act of the game sucks in all regards
2. Scenery and presentation not very interesting with the exception of the frontier
3. Lack of tutorials and guidelines at some points that make the experience frustrating
4. The map is not so good

Summary
This game had bad reviews but I was willing to give it a chance. People said they hated the prologue and the protagonist. Up until the 8th sequence of the game I considered this game to be better than any previous entry. The prologue was a big pro for me and the protagonist was on par with Ezio in terms of how intriguing he was, even though he is different - the better protagonist is a subjective matter. Better gameplay, better graphics and even if many aspects of the game are not polished, it's logical since the game was a step up in terms of how big and complex it was. Everything was fun until the end of the 8th sequence.
And then everything went sideways for me. The story became like your typical Steven Seagal b-movie. Inconsistent behavior from the characters, plot holes, the story stopped making sense and it was so hasty as if D. Weiss and D. Benioff wrote the final act along with the final seasons of game of thrones.  And when the story and characters gets so messed up, all the cons of the game, the small glitches, the lack of guidelines in certain parts, the lack of tutorials BEFORE you enter a mission, the unpolished aspects of the gameplay, the repetition of certain side missions, all seem way more frustrating than before. I started the game and wanted to complete every part of it for the first time in an Assassin's Creed game, but at the end of the 8th sequence everything broke up for me and I just run through the main story up to sequence 11 and then I just couldn't have any more of this. I will watch the ending on youtube just to see how the Desmond story ends. I do not recommend this game. Read the story and just go to the next one. Most people say the next one is a treat.
I played this game in the past and I still recommend it  to those who love the assassins creed franchise

I have a mixed review regarding this game. Although I have played Assassin's Creed III in PS3 before, I thought buying the remastered one. So, after playing this game, here are pros and cons of this game:

PROS:
1. In terms of texturing and lighting it is not as bad as most people take it to be. In my opinion, developers have done a good job in field lights and shades in the game, and skin textures are also nicely done as compared to the original one.
2. Volumetric fogs: I saw some complsining about it too, but, according to me, volumetric fog fills some sort of realism in the overall environment of the game.

CONS:
1. Glitches: I had to deal with glitches and bugs before, in the original game, while playing it in PS3. Seems like developers have little effort to draw attention to this, as this game also jas a same problem.
2. Although, I can somewhat appreciate colour brightness in this game, but in most cases, you will find that it is being overused. Like, the nighttime looks more like morning time in it due to heavy increase of colour brightness.
game still has some glitches

Really good game. I remember rushing through the original and thinking it wasn't very good, but when you take your time and go through everything at a leasurly pace, this game really holds up. The graphics are good, gameplay is fun, parkour animations are great. Would recommend.

The only thing I don't like is that I had to install AC Odyssey before I could play AC3 Remastered because I got the game code through the Odyssey Gold Edition. UPlay wouldn't register AC3 as a game I owned until I had at least played Odyssey on my UPlay account.

Let's be honest, I dislike Ac3 when first played and fast went through it in 20+hours, but recently just completely immersed in it. 


[h1]graphics[/h1]
not the top-tier, but definitely meet modern 3A standards. Environments are spectacular. This world expertly captures the lost grandeur of north American landscape. Every single scenic shot is gorgeous. From colonial brick buildings and waving grasses to thin lips and plastic faces of characters, performance is more or less better than original one.


[h1]EXCELLENT soundtrack[/h1]
My second favourite soundtrack behind Black Flag. Main theme sounds so heroic and epic, and fits the story of American Revolution well. It always conjures up images of Connor (or Ratonhnaké:ton) racing through forests, leaping from one tree to another, or killing an entire redcoats in snowy valleys. 

Here are some I highly recommend: 
1. Main Theme
2. Trouble in Town 
3. Connor's Life


[h1]gameplay[/h1]
There're still some BUGs, remastered only means better graphics, instead of remake. Stalwart AC activities like climbing a peak for synchronization, gain information, eavesdropping, shadowing, taking over Templar areas or ripping posters off wall to preserve your anonymity. Compared with old ACs, you can ran across trees in parkour now and there's a much better combat system. Most important component is the exemplary naval combat. It's like a sailing simulation and allows you to accomplish different mission with Connor, obviously he inherits something from Edward Kenway.

 By the way, though Connor is a deadliest badass who can kill the whole district, but it's hard to get all his 100% story sync, strict optional objectives are designed for assassin more than warrior.


[h1]story[/h1]
I like this story, but weirdly for some uncertain reason, devs delete some plots like Connor's speech, and they put important scences in homestead mission, which means you will miss them if just uninstall game after story over. e.g. Connor is named after Achilles's dead son.

'Life is not a fairy tale and there are no happy endings'. [spoiler]Connor as a native american, he wants safety and security for his people, fights against Templars who try to control the whole colony, but he almost loses everything in end. His tribes, allies, people and land, all gone, except his strong belief in freedom. He helps the american revolution, but the man he aids not only burns the village, but ultimately forces his people out of their territories for expansion of settlements. He seeks for unification with templars but ends in tragedy.

The reason Connor being one of my favourite protagonists is he is real. Irrational, naive, no matter the cost, and finally become a strong, stoic, wise man who fights for his belief as always. Remember he shouts out, 'because no one else will'. He is such a relatable role. Feel the same thing replaying the Desmond trilogy. I also like in homestead, how he tries to help friends and shows his kindness, everyone likes him, where he expresses more emotion than in main story. [/spoiler]

What makes AC3 so potent to me is the fact that it has an overarching climatic feel, and the timeline was more or less had a greater impact to the leading events that would shape our modern history.


At the end of this review, I love AC3, it's fun to sink hours into Ubisoft's version of colonial America, fight against redcoats or just ride across Frontier and enjoy beauty of nature. It may not displace Brotherhood as the high watermark of the series, but it revitalizes what is in danger of becoming another tired franchise, and sets it back on track.

One of the most underrated games in the series. And I just can't comprehend why.

I think the story is great, because it has a good setup, because you get to play as the bad guy, which is a long-needed addition to the series. It gives you more perspective on the side of the Templars. I also think that Haytham is a stellar character. He's my second favourite character in the whole series and they should've made another game about him in my opinion.

Next to that, I think Connor is a pretty good character, he's not really a fun character, but he's determined and he's just a more introverted character than the fan favourite, Ezio. And I don't think there's anything wrong with that, not every character has to have the charisma of Ezio to qualify as a good character. 

The father-son dynamic is really interesting, because they're also on the opposite sides of their beliefs. They often argue about what's right. These conversations are very interesting, because Haytham often wins the debate, which makes me doubt whether the Assassin's are really the good guys and the Templars are really bad. 

Another thing I love about this game are all the historical characters this game includes, like Washington and Benjamin Franklin which are one of my favourite historical figures. I'm really glad they made a dlc where Washington was seduced by the apple of Eden, which was an interesting concept, which they've executed very well. I actually think that this was the best DLC in the AC games that I've played. 

Aside from the story, the combat system is really neat as well and it really feels like Connor is such a beast, which makes the combat more fun. 

I also think that the modern story line is improved on a lot, because things titened up and they brought a satisfying conclusion to the Desmond story line.

I will admit, that the city's aren't too great. They don't look that pretty, because they're all made of wood and their isn't much variety, then again the creators of this game wanted to respect the architectural design of these cities. So it might not have been the right choice to make these cities prettier, because the credibility of the series might get compromised. I think a lot of the things in the open world are actually quit fun and I liked all of the side content in this game. 

All in all, I think this is a really solid game and I definitely think people should cut this game some slack. After Origins this is my favourite Assassin's Creed Game and I give this game an 8,5/10.

What a game... what a story. Honestly, one of my favourites. Somehow it also manages to be the buggiest in the series, in my experience. Nothing game-breaking, just little things. As a remaster, it looks a lot better than the original when it comes to environments which now use PBR (Physically-Based Rendering) textures and materials, which means everything looks and interacts with lighting much more realistically. I love it. Turn off the HUD during gameplay, and this is a seriously stunning, immersive experience. It's easy to get lost in the beauty and busyness of 18th Century Boston, New York and the Frontier. The character face models look a little off during cutscenes, probably because they worked better with the older-gen lighting system. It supports 4K HDR, but it's still locked at 60FPS, like the original. This is probably because of the physics engine being tied to 60FPS. All in all, I love it, but it's far from perfect.

This was the game that began a new era for Assassin's Creed. Everything changed, for the better in my opinion. The movement, animation, parkour, combat, etc.. looks very weighty, realistic and has a cinematic flow to it. It is also the first game to introduce tree parkour and ship sailing along with sea combat, good horse riding mechanics, and generally, it's massive in scope compared to previous titles. Very ambitious. There's new tools such as rope darts, flintlock pistols, muskets, bow and arrows, and the biggest selection of weapons including some new unique types, each with their own animation, combos and finishing moves. You truly feel like a killing machine... that Assassin Tomahawk... Oof! ;)

There is also wildlife hunting such as rabbits, deer, wolves, bears, and many more! It's a way of making money by selling / trading pelts or using them as crafting materials.

Oh, and the Homestead Missions are amazing!

"Used to be when people talked about the end of the world, we locked them up or laughed them off. Sometimes both. But we never took them seriously. Maybe we should have. But I'm getting ahead of myself. Better to start at the beginning - with the abduction of Desmond Miles. My son. This boy... had no ambition. No direction. No plans for the future. What he DID have was a heritage. One he chose to deny. It nearly cost him his life. He was captured and imprisoned. Those who took him believed he could help them find something. The Apple. One of several artefacts we call Pieces of Eden. Bits of ancient technology scattered across the globe. Some hidden. Some found. All of them dangerous. Most are held by a single group - the same group that now had Desmond. You know them as Abstergo Industries. We know them as the Templars - as the enemy. We've been fighting them for thousands of years. Even longer if you believe the stories of their origins. I do, after all, I've seen the truth. That's the beauty - and the horror - of the Animus. A device that allows us to enter and experience the lives of our ancestors. It holds the power to change everything. To show us history the way it really happened. Up until its creation - to the victor went the spoils - went the truth. We're trying to fix that. To free minds and bodies both. But there's only so much we can do. And the Templars have the upper hand these days. But something larger than the Assassins and Templars is approaching. Bigger than all of us. And if we can't find a way to stop it - these next few weeks will probably be our last. EVERYONE'S last. In the end, it all comes down to him. To Desmond. Through the Animus, he discovered his heritage. Explored the lives of his ancestors and uncovered their secrets. When that was done, he trained. He used another ancestor to provide decades of experience in the span of a few days. It worked. We think. We hope. Soon, though - soon, we'll know. That ominous date fast approaches. December 21st, 2012. None of us knows what it'll bring - only that this is where they want us to be when it does. They've been guiding us, in their own fractured, frustrating way. These voices from the First Civilisation, The Ones Who Came Before. A Precursor race of immense power and uncertain motives. They're the ones who made the Pieces of Eden. This is where they've led him, and through him, us. He stands at the entrance to this long-lost place, armed with the knowledge of Altaïr and the abilities of Ezio, he holds in his hands the Apple of Eden. And we stand at this side, ready to support him, however we can. His name is Desmond Miles and he has brought us to the end." - William Miles, Mentor of 21st Century Assassin Brotherhood.

There is so, so much I want to say about this game. But it would turn into an essay. From the modern day missions with Desmond climbing corporate buildings, doing leaps-of-faith off skyscrapers, to infiltrating a Brazil stadium using social stealth and crowd blending, to muscling his way through Abstergo HQ like a boss, to the tragic story of Native American ancestor Ratonhnhaké:ton, or Connor Kenway, as we know him better, how he grows up into an absolute tank of a warrior, on the path of revenge, similar to young Ezio, witnessing the destruction of his village and death of his mother when Templars burned everything to the ground after the Mohawk people of Kanien'kehá:ka refused to let them take over their home land. He grows up to be Master Assassin of the Colonial Brotherhood, rebuilding what was lost and training under the watchful eye of previous Mentor Achilles Davenport, the Old Man On The Hill. 

Connor is the "Batman" of the series. Serious. Mature. A man on a mission. A beast in combat, he'll charge across a battlefield at an entire army firing musket shots and come out without a scratch. Nothing stands in his way. The Templars in this game are some of the best, and their motives, this time, due to excellent writing, make you question the Assassin's goals for once. 

That's not to say the Templars aren't bad. But it's the first time in the franchise that we begin to see the moral grey areas of both sides, both ideologies. The fact that the Grandmaster of the Templars is also Connor's father (Haytham Kenway) makes the journey even more interesting and, of course, emotional. Father and son - sworn enemies. Damn, I love Connor's story and character arc. 

And the soundtrack by Lorne Balfe! 
An adrenaline pumping, emotional and cinematic listening experience like no other in the franchise so far, in my opinion. Everything is just worthy of a blockbuster movie...

The story ends with Desmond seeing where Connor had hidden the "key" taken off the Templars, a special key needed to open the gates to the Grand Temple, where he saves the world - at a great price. The First Civilisation helped us, but they didn't tell us everything...

Assassin's Creed 3 is also the game that massively expands upon the First Civilisation, or as we know them these days due to recent games' lore, The Isu. Their Six (or Seven, actually) "Methods of Salvation" , etc... This is lore that recent games such as AC: Valhalla, digs deeper into. It's crazy how expansive and connected the entire franchise is, for references to make their way into new titles a decade later!

Pure badass, exciting nostalgia trip worthy of discussions, speculation and debates. YouTube channels like "Access the Animus" are great at decryption and researching the lore and events that happened in this game and how they link into later titles. I do recommend this game. It would be perfect if it wasn't for the occasional bugs that never got patched, even in the remaster. I have 100% completed it, including all optional sync objectives, many times since 2012... that's right. The game released in 2012, when the present day story in AC3 also takes place ;)

A wonderful game that takes during the start of the american revolution, and how you start as a son to a tribe in the woods, and have to fight through hard trials to get rid of the people whom has terrorised your tribe and also the people of the colonies. A action and thrilled game where you will eventually find out where your father has been all the years when you were growing up in the tribe, and find your true assassin's spirit animal (yes there will be plently of those trials too, creative and fun as well). Or take on the english men with your friends and assassin's alike and free the colonies!
The remaster is super underwhelming. On top of this, the game is bogged down by a boring story and incredibly restrictive mission design.

As a game franchise progresses, you wouldn't expect it to get uglier, more tedious and clumsy to play, and less understanding re what about itself is fun. But so it is with the AC games, which were once cleverly designed (believe it or not). AC3 is a bloated, garrulous, and unendearing waste of time, like a gossiping zombie; in every way deader and dramatically worse than AC1/2.

I got this game for free so I gave it a shot since Origins was so good and Odyssey was meh.  I regret playing this.  There are so many things about this game that are bad that its no surprise this one was not liked.  

Navy: Now I don't expect the boat to have the maneuverability of a jet ski but this was not fun at all.  The boat had the turning radius of a beached school bus and the acceleration of a tortoise.  Then there are the cannons.  For the bow and firearms you hold the right mouse button and then click the left mouse button.  When you do that with the swivel cannons it cancels the shot and puts you in cover.  Why couldn't they keep the controls consistent.  The cover is horrible because you have to wait way too long to get out of cover.  The enemy has enough time to reload and fire a second shot by the time you get out of cover.  The aiming of the swivel cannons are horrible.  They are constantly aiming at the ocean floor or dolphins or something.  I kept wanting them to aim up but they would go left and right just to shoot into the water under the boats.  The main cannons were horrible as well.  There is a delay from you want to fire until they actually fire.  By the time they fire the other ship has docked and hit the pub already.  I tried the chain mail and that was terrible.  It has the flight speed of a seagull and the range of a junior high baseball pitcher.  Origins pirates experience was fun but this was not.

Movement:  The parkour thing is way overplayed in this.  Everything and I mean everything is climbable.  It is incredibly frustrating.  I'm just trying to run down the street and then he suddenly darts off 90 degrees and jumps on a table. I try to get off the table and then he is on a fence, now hes on another fence, now hes climbing a building, now he jumping on top of a person.  The floor is not fucking lava.  Not every object in the entire game has to be climbed on.

Hunting:  This one bothered me the most.  There are so many challenges where you just kill animals over and over.  Many just for their fur and sometimes a trophy.  This was one of the many things the native americans hated about the settlers.  Killing just for fur or fun and leaving so much waste.  Not only does this game make you do it but you also do it as a native american character.  It's extremely disrespectful and an absolute disgrace to attach that behavior to them.

Ultimately if this was the first game of the series that I played I would have never played any of the other games.  It really is that bad.

Okay, overall an okay game, but the controls aren't precise enough to really feel good. I was disappointed by the synchronization views as well--they seem to mostly all be churches of modest size, no truly captivating views. Also, the walnut trees you climb to sync are all the exact same tree. This really pulled me out of the game.

Other than that, Ubisoft still includes incredibly frustrating tasks in the game, such as tailing (while remaining a certain distance from the target) and chase scenes (they aren't very fluid feeling). Also, the notoriety system, consisting of bribing, paying printers, and tearing down posters, is awkward and silly and I just didn't buy any of it. I recently played Assassin's Creed Unity and they've fixed all of these issues, so that's encouraging.

Brief Description off Google: 
Assassin's Creed 3 Remastered includes the base game, all of its solo DLC (Benedict Arnold and Hidden Secrets missions, and The Tyranny of King Washington expansion), and Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered.

Assassin's Creed III Remastered is playable. but not sure what is "Remastered" about the game.
But it is a buggy glitchy mess including crash to desktop. Looks as ugly maybe worse then the original
The menu's is made for consoles and horrible to use as a PC player with keyboard and mouse.

The standAlone dlc liberation has interesting mechanics with the different persona's but same messy system.

(To provide context for my review, my system specs are Windows 10/RTX 2080/i9 10980HK)

[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Some character and clothing textures look nicely updated, but a lot of the open world (particularly the Frontier area) looks pretty bad and polygonal
- There are lots of strange visual bugs, ranging from distance fog and water reflection not agreeing, to spagettification of enemy models when you knock them into walls
- The soundtrack is appropriate but not terribly exciting
- Voice acting is largely good, but non-main characters can sound a little wooden

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- The setting is intriguing and one of the highlights of the game. Running around the colonial US and taking part in historical events would be fairly engrossing if it weren't for all the immersion-breaking bugs
- For an AC game, there's not much intrigue. It really dampens the emotional impact of the end-of-game events for both Desmond and Connor

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- The flow of combat could be really fun, but the rope darts trivialize the challenge of opponents that can parry your counters or block your attacks
- If combat we're a little more challenging, I think the stealth mechanics would feel a bit more useful
- Skills and abilities aren't necessary since combat isn't hard
- Naval battles were pretty fun
- No real reason to revisit this one after beating it

[b]Overall Impressions[/b]
- I'm far beyond the required specs, and I still had to mess around with process priority/affinity to get rid of frame rate issues each time I booted the game
- Lackluster story and poorly balanced gameplay overshadow the few bright spots

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]4/10.[/b] Unless you're a diehard who really wants to know the AC lore, maybe consider skipping this entry. If you do play it, maybe consider doing so on console if possible. Playing it on PC is a buggy mess. Hell, you can't even play it at all unless you have AC Odyssey to activate it.

Pros:
-Story is good
-Combat mechanics feels quite outdated, but still fun to play, combat animations are cool and satisfying to watch
-Naval missions are fun to play, hating them is alright as they are optional for the most part
-Good soundtracks, battle and chase music is quite amazing

Cons:
-So many bugs, some are minors but some require you to restart the mission to proceed.
-Side missions are very repetitive, just like all the other Ubisoft open world games
-The pacing of main story is awful, the prologue/tutorial part of the main quests is very long that it takes you about 4 hours to complete, which is obviously too much. And the objectives in these missions are often restrictive tedious things such as "follow xxx" with forced slow-walking speed or going from here to there that it feels like chores to play. The first few hours can make people who are impatient to instantly hate this game, because most of the time you are watching cutscenes and dialogues without you actually engaging into the game. The tutorials of this game is also poorly done that you can miss out some of the game elements without you actually knowing
-Naval missions are fun, but lacks incentives for people to complete them as they don't really have substantial rewards, playing them is only for fun/completion for the most part.
-Optional objectives in the quest for increasing difficulty of the game, but only if they make senses. Some of the optional objectives in this game are just ridiculous and require you do go all out of your way to do very specific things, especially the one that requires you to air assassinate a single grenadier on a ship full the enemies and blow up two ships without being detected AT THE SAME TIME. They can be very frustrating for perfectionist.
-Very bad UI, looks very bad and is also quite user unfriendly
-Awful horse riding control, horse always stop and stuck at random places, horse cannot jump down a rock of two metres height, it is hilarious how riding a horse ended up wasting my time because horse always refuse to move for whatever reasons and i need to get off the horse and run on foot.
-Enemy detection mechanics can be inconsistent and ruin your missions sometimes.
-The money management of the game is not good enough because you can complete most of the stuffs of the game without actually buying anything from the shops.

Conclusion: Not recommended unless for the sake of completion of the assassin's creed series or you having very high level of tolerancy to a poorly polished game (even though for a game released in 2012). It is fun but there are just so many things that piss you off again and again and again.

There's so much that they've improved upon and changed for the better this time around. I love sailing on a ship and fighting other vessels and being able to upgrade yours as money allows. It took me a long time, after sequence 7, to figure out how to send my assassin recruits out on missions like in the previous games, which you were guided through iirc. This game, not so much...you're left to figure it out on your own and I stumbled upon it by accident. The biggest thing that really is annoying though is once you've got one little 'x', or even 3 of them, it's so hard to remain hidden and try to return to be anonymous. Other than that, this game is perfect.
Graphics overhaul from original game was great, still full of bugs which will hopefully get fixed

I bought AC III back in the day and the King Washington DLCs a few years later. Now, with the Remastered I could get both for free (as part of the AC: Odyssey), along with Liberation HD a former PlayStation Vita exclusive that made it to be released for the Windows platform as well in 2014. 

Connor and Aveline are likable characters. Connor’s unwavering determination and seriousness makes him the second most believable assassin (the first being Altäir). And Aveline has a certain grace and compassion that all the other female characters lack in the AC lore. She is not just a man in a woman’s body (a murdering machine with cocky demeanor), which seems to be the only way writers can imagine a female hero these days.

Their backstory is relatively well developed, and in Connor’s case he is put in the middle of very important historical events, to play a key role without twisting the real-life events into laughing matter (unlike for example the murder of Julius Caesar in Origins – for me that was an all-time low).

While the voice acting in AC III is spot on (with all the native actors and actresses – dialect coaching from Akwiratékha Martin, who played Connor’s childhood friend in the game – they did an excellent job speaking the language), the replacement of all these native actors and actresses for the DLCs totally ruined the immersion for me (the Kanien'kéha language was totally omitted for the use of English, and the replacement actors were just terrible). 

Lorne Balfe’s score in AC III is memorable, the same cannot be said about Winnifred Philips’ atmospheric music in Liberation.

AC III is a glitch-ridden disaster. And to top it off it comes with the most agonizingly hard mission constraints to get 100% synch. Some of the optional objectives seem to depend on luck to trigger, or to avoid glitches. Liberation on the other hand is the exact opposite. It’s an AC game on smaller scale, simplified with a no-frills approach to accommodate the handheld device it was developed for, making it one of the best gaming experiences of the whole series. Not to mention that the addition of character personas with different notoriety levels is a great game element, that would have change the perception of all the other installments of the series. Imagine a world where a hooded figure armed to the teeth cannot just blend in with the pedestrians just by sitting on a bench... Right?

The King Washington DLCs are just plain awful. Rehashed locations filled with next to no content, almost lifeless and torturously repetitive.  

Let me mention that the game’s list of Uplay Achievements represent an unbalanced mixture of tasks way to easy and outright impossible. Things like Original Gamer (even with all the help I could find winning those games remain a dream), An Extraordinary Man (endless hours – look at my total playing time – of observation and people like Norris who is a major gold brick make it impossible to finish. Whenever I try to scan him, he is just sitting on his porch shining his helmet or has his helmet shined by Sheena the Queen of the Jungle.), Coureus Des Bois (Hunting? Great. Plant a snare, add some bait and wait for target rabbit to come. Okkkeeey. Except every single time a stupid deer comes and ruins the trap. Every f**ing time. Or a peacefully feeding elk starts running the second I aim at them with my bow. Holding the bow and aiming at something else is OK, though. Also, running in the woods is about stumbling from quick time event to quick time event, because everything that moves wants a piece of Connor's tenderloin.

Controls are bad as ever. Running activates the parkour whenever I'm close to objects. So instead of running ahead Connor/Aveline jumps on the vendor's table... Well done, Ubisoft. Tackling from above option simply doesn't appear. Connor can't tackle from above. Hangs instead.

And the point of this Remaster? The graphics. The biggest letdown. I personally barely see any difference apart from the option of 4K. And the characters are way uglier then in the original. The remake craziness had reached the gaming industry too, resulting in projects like this one, where the developer just phoned it in instead of a quality upgrade.

Shame. Get it for free if you can.

[code]Assassin’s Creed III: Remastered bundles up Assassin’s Creed III and Liberation – however, unfortunately, the whole package just screams wasted potential[/code]

One quick note before I continue with the review: I haven’t played the original games, so when I’m reviewing [i]Assassin’s Creed III Remastered[/i], I won’t be able to comment on how they compare to the updated versions.

It’s rare to review two games at once but after finishing both of them, I was surprised how similar my feelings were about both of them. To be more precise, I’m equally disappointed by both. But I’m getting ahead of myself, so let’s brush up on the basics first.

[i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] and [i]Assassin’s Creed: Liberation[/i] both released on the same day in the October of 2012. Yes, this means that we once again only got a year between the release of the previous [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] title ([i]Revelations[/i] in this case) and the new one – or in this case, two. While [i]Liberation[/i] was a PlayStation Vita-only title at first, [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] made its debut on the “big” consoles as well as PC.

What’s really important here is that [i]Liberation[/i] was made with a handheld device in mind. As such, a lot of design decisions had to be made to accommodate the hardware. The menus, the size of the in-game world and of course features that didn’t make it over from [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] (like naval battles). Even with a (slightly) new coat of paint, you will notice that [i]Liberation[/i] is a much smaller game in scope and doesn’t really feel at home on the big screen - but more on that later.

Let’s talk about the game that’s really the focus of this Remaster package first: [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i]. Not only did it introduce a lot of changes (a more “modern”  settings, overhauled gameplay options like free-running as well as new addions such as naval battles or hunting) but it was also intended as the conclusion to the modern-day Desmond arc that has been ongoing since the very first [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i].

So, as the previous [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] mainline games started to get kind of stale (especially in regards to gameplay) – does [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] manage to revitalize the franchise? Hahahahaha - no.

Almost all of the new additions are really not that great. The free-running and close combat overhaul doesn’t do that much – you’re still occasionally jumping up obstacles when you just wanted to sprint by for example and just countering enemy moves is usually enough. Thanks to dual-wielding, we can now use guns – but as they take a lot of time reload, you’ll mostly just use them once per encounter.

As for actually new features, we got activities like hunting (why?) or catching flying book pages. Oh, hey, remember the empty field parts of Rome during [i]Assassin’s Creed Brotherhood[/i]? The ones that are just a pain to pass as there’s nothing there? Yeah, Ubisoft expanded upon that: with the introduction of the Wilderness, you can look forward to much more forest to run through in order to get to the next mission. Fast-travel points are still a thing but at least you can now fast-travel FROM everywhere – even if I’d have preferred fast-travel TO everywhere as well.

Speaking of travelling, you’ll do that. A lot. I feel like I spent most of my time doing the story missions just running around & occasionally killing a few enemies with the same moves as always. That has been a problem with the previous [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] titles as well - but thanks to the bigger areas (& the Wilderness), it’s only gotten worse. We got our horses back again, but they still like to get stuck and can’t cross rivers. Some help you are, mount.

Ultimately, even with all the new things, I still felt like I was playing the exact same game as the predecessors. All the new features and side activities might look nice on paper but as I was working through the main story, I felt like I was stuck in a timeloop. I reached the end of the game thinking that I didn’t even feel like I made any progress – protagonist Connor was as powerful as before and I didn’t even bother switching up my combat style since the tutorial – because there was simply no need.

There’s one last thing I need to mention about the gameplay of [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] though and that are of course the new navel battles. These are probably my favourite part of the game, as they are a) genuinely different from the rest of the game and b) a lot of fun to play. It’s probably no coincidence that the sequel, [i]Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flack[/i], doubled down on them.

What probably bothers me the most about [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] is the wasted potential – especially in regard to storytelling. A Native American as a protagonist, the story set during 1760 – 1783 – those are event rarely covered in videogames and I was genuinely interested in how the story might turn out.

The answer is extremely bad. In terms of settings, for example, if you don’t know the exact historical backgrounds, the game is doing very little to set things up for you (short fact sheet entries aren’t a good way to do so). That’s not really new for the franchise but I feel like it’s gotten even more extreme here. But besides not really expanding on some of the setting as much as I’d have liked it to (Native American culture for example, is barely a part of the main story) – the fictional parts aren’t good either. Pacing issues, lots of head-scratcher moments, events and characters being all over the place – after a promising start I only wished for the entire thing to end a few chapters in. 

Naturally, Ubisoft managed to squander the modern-day plot once again as well. We actually do get some Desmond gameplay sections this time around but ultimately, I don’t even know why I bothered with the previous games if they lead up to this. Not to mention Ubisoft actually put in another cliffhanger ending. If I didn’t have so little space, I could complain about the story of [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] for hours, it’s easily the worst part of the game considering how great it could’ve been.

Unfortunately, [i]Liberation[/i] doesn’t fare much better. As with its big brother, the plot is an aimless mess and the historical setting neglected to the point that it sometimes just serves as background flavour. With Aveline de Grandpré, we got a female protagonist of colour, which makes for a more than a welcome change – but I feel like her entire potential has unfortunately not been realised here.

Gameplay-wise, as mentioned before, [i]Liberation[/i] really is limited by its original hardware. It feels like many cuts had to be made in order to still offer something resembling an [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] game – and as such, the game really is nothing more than a stripped [i]Assassin’s Creed III[/i] experience. I wish this spin-off was less interested in imitating the mainline series and did something more original, like expanding on the new clothes changing mechanic. That way, we might’ve gotten a genuinely interesting game instead of just a hollow copy.

Concluding, both games featured in [i]Assassin’s Creed III Remastered[/i] ultimately turned out to be huge let-downs. It was genuinely frustrating to see the promising concepts turn out this way. Both games could’ve been so much more but all we got is just more [i]Assassin’s Creed[/i] in a way. If that’s still enough for you, go ahead and buy them (be aware that they’re also part of the [i]Assassin’s Creed: Odyssey[/i] season pass though). If not – maybe play [i]Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag[/i] for the only good thing that came out of instead: naval combat.

[h1] [b] Assassin's Creed III Remastered [/b] [/h1]

The fifth Assassin's Creed game, confusingly named Assassin's Creed III makes you take the reigns of Conner, also known as Ratonhnhaké:ton, A native who after having his village destroyed and family slaughtered by Templars, joins the creed of Assassin's. You play through Conner's journey of training to his eventual influence and work within the American revolution and the fight against the British regulars. With such an interesting topic, does it live up to all the hype? Lets get into it.

[h1] [b] The Good [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Story [/b]

- The Assassin's Creed games have always had extremely interesting, immersive, and unique stories crafted to not only highlight historical periods but also tell a fictional tale of the Templar/Assassin conflict and their influence on the world. AC3 is no different as you play as Conner,  a native american who is thrown into the middle of the Templar/Assassin conflict, which is also at the time disguising as the American revolution. 

[*] [b] The Combat [/b]

- In a game about assassins, the combat has to be strong. Thankfully, AC3 does nothing but improve the combat compared to earlier games, as well as introducing many new tools, weapon types, and fighting styles that make AC3 one of the few games that I purposely go out of my way to decimate enemies rather than simply get to where I need to go. 

[*] [b] The Graphics and Design [/b]

- AC3 is the most beautiful and graphically improved Assassin's Creed games so far in the series, not to add the remaster which vastly improves the characters looks and various other elements. The serene, virgin land of colonial America is a rarely used setting for games and it is just as enthralling to look at as you'd think.

[*] [b] The Naval Gameplay [/b]

- AC3 introduces a revolutionary gameplay mechanic to the series, which is naval combat. New to the series, taking over a large seafaring vessel and bringing justice to the seas in one of the shining stars of AC3. Not to mention this amazing gameplay mechanic is what would inevitably influence the creation of Assassin's Creed Black Flag.

[*] [b] The Homestead [/b]

- AC3 adds another expansive gameplay and immersion mechanic which is the homestead. You can recruit talented individuals into a community you are building which not only allows additional stories, collectibles, and building mechanics but also allows you to access crafting and new equipment mechanics as well as trading routes. This allows you to immerse yourself farther into the world than any Assassin's Creed game so far.

[h1] [b] The Bad [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Tiny Glitches [/b]

- As far as I can tell from talking to others, the glitches present in AC3 seem to actually stem from the remaster, rather than the game in general. This is not uncommon as many remasters tend to bring in countless new problems. Playing through the game you'll see plenty of glitches, some entertaining and some irritating. Horses getting stuck in the ground, launch glitches, and dozens of model glitches which distort and mess up mainly enemies and sometimes allies. 

[*] [b] The Camera Angles [/b]

- A common problem for me in Assassin's Creed games, AC3 does not improve and continues to shove you into locked and completely disorienting camera angles and the seemingly worst possible times. Whether force locking your view while preforming menial actions or forcing you to do intense parkour while your camera faces away from your  desired destination, thus forcing you to fail jumps or launches, these camera angles can be the most irritating things in the world

[h1] [b] The Ugly [/b] [/h1]

[*] [b] The Game-Breaking Glitches and General Problems [/b]

- AC3 Remastered's fatal flaw is its annoying amount of problems in it's general gameplay, and the countless game-breaking glitches it boasts. There will be dozens of missions where you will fail multiple times because it spawns you in a broken location, or you fall through the map, or you spawn detected by enemies thus making you fail and respawn which traps you in an endless loop of failure. Then you have to restart entire sections and waste hours. The game inevitably breaks your will and then you give up for a while. The original AC3 wasn't broke like this. The remaster did this, and that is unforgivable.

[h1] [b] Overall [/b] [/h1]

AC3 is still a great game, and one of my favorite Assassin's Creed games. However, AC3 Remastered has broken my bond with the game, made it more irritating to play than fun, and overall just ruined the game. If you want to play AC3, just get the regular version not the remaster.

AC3 had an uninteresting main character, glitches made ragdolls fly all over the place, viewpoint that were the same kind of tree taking way too long to climb up compared to any other viewpoint in the entire franchise, and the desmond miles saga just had a sad, unsatisfying end. Also, the complete lack of side stuff to do compared to ezio trilogy. it's like everything i had that was super fun about ezio trilogy was now magically gone. and why? i don't know. at least black flag and rogue are much better than whatever this is.

Easily one of the weakest links in the franchise.

- The world and characters are uninteresting. Not the game's fault - American history is just boring and uninteresting. Connor is just so plain and bland you will forget what he was like after beating the game.
- The auto-parkour is incredibly clunky. Connor will magnet himself to random ledges and walls even if you never meant to. The game will try to pretend it knows what you want to do and fail at doing so.
- The lighting is completely broken. Some parts of the game are too bright and some parts are too dark to the point that they are unplayable. The animals in the forest look like plastic toys when the light hits their body.
- "Optional" objectives but will tell you the mission is incomplete if you don't fulfill them. Not to mention, you WILL keep restarting checkpoints if you wish to fulfill them and the game will put you to unfavorable positions when you do. Also, some optional objective are just straight up BS. Pair that with terrible AI and clunky physics, you're sure to have a terrible time fulfilling them.

If you're playing the series for completion's sake, just rush through the story in this one. Playing the rest of the game is not worth your time.

Unlike the other Assassins Creeds i've played i've been forced to review early due to the fact that this game is littered with bugs, its such a good concept yet its squandered due to poor controls terrible ai and other game breaking bugs, i've been detected when the i'm behind walls, shot through buildings for pete's sake and don't even get me started on the movement mechanics which seem to be destined to fling you off from wherever you are without you touching anything. What i genuinely question is how Assassins Creed 2, Brotherhood and Revelations which were all made before this outshine this game in every conceivable way and not only that but this game was also remastered meaning Ubisoft you had a chance to fix this game and make it better instead it feels like its regressed even more id dare even say that the first Assassins creed was less broken then this. I feel such frustration playing this that if it wasn't for the story line keeping me interested i would have given up this game already i mean for gods sake after the entire Ezio Trilogy, Yes the bar was set high but goddamn its like you forgot where that bar was because this game is shambolic and the worst part is ive still got to play Rebellion Remastered which means ill no doubt return to this review and have to say that even Rebellion was ruined in this remaster. Ubisoft you had potential and its like you just gave up on this game and thought, there we go a few tweaks in graphics and that'll do leaving it only just about playable. Also i wonder why were so many game mechanics like buying shops and all scrapped after the previous 3 games and not only this but that half your items you never use outside of the tutorial that teaches you how to use them, realistically its just your melee, hidden blade and pistol and that's about all you use all game. Thank god i got 2 games for this price making them both around 15 quid because otherwise you would have to be mad to pay 30 quid for just 1 game especially if this is the quality we're getting.

Got this bundled with Assassin's Creed Odyssey. I played 3 when I was younger, and for the most part this game is exactly how I remember. It is at it's best when you are just killing random soldiers in the street, and it's worst when doing anything else. Trailing missions suck, eavesdrop missions suck, ship combat extra sucks. I think the most interesting aspects of this game are largely unintentional; when you "liberate" a section of a city, the British soldiers are replaced with American, but they behave in the exact same way. Also, you don't get the notoriety bar as Haytham; you only get it as Connor. Again, probably not intentional, but still stuff that left an impact on me as a kid. The DLC is wacky fun but a bit too stretched thin, and Liberation is it's own fun. I think this Remaster is worth the price, as long as you are willing to ignore a lot of "content" this game tries to throw at you.

Game, weather physics, snow, atmosphere, they nailed it. Naval missions were amazing.

But story is stupid, I did not liked it at all, characters are knowing important informations out of the blue, writing is just frustrating. The story of Desmond kinda ended abruptly, no justice to the character at all.
Connor is one dimensional robot with no charisma and emotions, and only likeable character was Haytham.
Soundtracks are not memorable, liked only main theme and that is all.
Apart from cringe virtue signaling and social justice this game is good, and I recommend it to all.

IMPORTANT INFORMATION IF YOU GOT AC 3 WITH THE GOLD EDITION OF ODYESSY.
If you try to just install and play AC 3 then Ubisoft will ask you for an activation code, and there is none.
So you need to install and press play on ODYESSY first to allow ODYESSY and the Season Pass in install to Ubisoft Connect.
It took my system about 4 hours to install and verify ODYSSEY which is 108 GB.
I installed AC 3 first and did not touch play, then installed Odyessy and touched play so everything would be installed to Ubisoft Connect at one time.

I would never understand the unjustifiable hate for this game. Especially ever since the remaster came into play, it's been far worse. Assassin's Creen 3

The game sucked balls really hard the first time around when it came out and it does the same with the remaster.

The new charcter we play as is named RatAmageddon, don't know why they decided to name a character rat but what do i know. The Rat is the most annoying character in the series as far. The Rat is really naive and childish. The Rat is more bland than Altair, don't know how they managed that but they did.

The story is all over the place. They expect us to know who some people are and appear one mission then dissappear for ever. The Rat has a bone to pick with George Washington for some reason even before he ordered a hit on his home.

I'm not an expert in indian language but it feels really off, like they hired some knockoff voice actors for the parts.

I love the people of the homestead, really liked their little stories.

I still hate how they removed the rpg elements from the Ezio series with the armor upgrades.

I did pull through and got 100% even tho the naval missions were so annoying considering the ship is really slow. So glad they improved it in AC 4

Liberation

Omg what is this. Story doesn't make an sense, you move through out the years with no reason why. The start of the game doesn't explain anything and just jumps a good couple of years. I wrote better stories when i was 7, this game was a disgrace

The ending was a cliche joke.

Don't bother with liberation, it's boring.


Conclusion for the whole pack. Ac 3 is semi worth at a huge discount rate it 6/10, the dlc is really fun but the wolves are annoying rate it 7/10 and liberation is a joke rate it 4/10.

Well, no matter what your opinions are on this game's story, i can say for sure this game is not DOA (Dead On Arrival) usually with mixed reviews on Steam that means not only does the core game suck but there is also something wrong with the technical aspect as well like crashing and other technical issues.
