DO NOT waste your money on this game. I purchased AC: Odyssey on massive sale and this game was packaged with it, so I thought I'd give it a go after completing Odyssey. Oh boy. Glad I didn't go out and buy this game on its own. It's janky as all hell. The "mechanics" work only about half the time and the story is slow, if not downright boring at times. Climbing (particularly trees) is frustrating and the fact that there is no way to hide/stealth other than relying on the elements around you is just plain stupid when you're trying to be AN ASSASSIN.
combat system makes me (real)

First off the stand alone Liberation:
Liberation is too long for a bad short story. Not well delivered. Gameplay is okayish.

(Text below is a rant. After a week of bickering i picked it up again, and suddenly i'm in the flow.
It got to me, and i will 100% this game i'm sure. BTW don't believe any of the fairytales that you can complete the game in 15-ish hours. No fucking way. ACIII is MUCH better than Black Flag. At this time Connor is on par with Ezio. ACIII is one of the best AC games, let me tell you why people think it's not, and what my gripes with the game are, and why i still think it's one of the most ambitious and fun AC-games to play:

Remastered III is very good and sometimes terrible. Though much more lineair and much more unpolished than other AC games, it still got me. The bugs are super annoying, and the sum of its parts gives a very frustrating but fun experience, especially when you are set loose in the world. It's nice, and the scope of all the different assets is beyond me. There's so much going on! (There is naval combat, land battles, managing etc.) This one also shows that Ubisoft doesn't give a *** about the afterlife of its games. All the annoying issues are still in this remaster, Synching is a chore, you're often fighting against the controls and systems of the game itself. Instead of showcasing your skills, you're hoping for the best. Hopefully Connor won't attach itself to a pole, instead of running to catch someone. Or that you'll shoot your bow, instead of suddenly jumping and attacking in the midst of an army. These issues have always been in Ac games, but this time around, ai 'thinks' it knows what the player wants to do. Instead of three buttons for parcour, you only use 2. Therefore the game thinks it's smarter, but it takes away control of the player. Your stupid horse will 'know' what you want it to do! Except it won't. MY god the horses are terrible. 
I completely abandoned 100% synching. The different parts of the game seem glued together, hoping for the best. Parcour is another beast in the ttrees than rooftops. It works, but not really. Only barely. I couldn't care less about the story after some missions, there are simply too many characters and i have no clue who is who. Especially on my side of the fight. They are scarcely introduced and suddenly i know exactly who my mates are? Very weird. But after a few missions suddenly the story felt engaging and apart from Connor being a very shallow character, the journey is worth it. More and more the world opens up and different aspects of the game come to fruition. Even though it asks for a lot (a LOT) of patience, it gives its rewards eventually, when it clicks. But the sound glitches, uneven dialogue, bugs and terrible mission structure (execution) and efficacy of the different systems make me NOT encourage you to buy it full priced. Or buy the Odyssey Season Pass instead and you'll get this one for free. 

The sounds are awful. It goes from very loud to very soft. Sometimes the music is not to be heared and then suddenly BLAM there it is! Same with speech, too loud and too hard. Sometimes whole passages of speech are cut off, because the cutscene requires something else. (I know it has to do with the mixing, when you lower volume of speech, the music suddenly can hit very hard during battle. It's hard to get an even sound) Of course Ubisoft says that i have to upload savefiles and they'll look into it. But of course they won't! It won't make money to solve the issues right? Even though 100's of players experience the same issues.
MY advice is, leave everything on 10 and just deal with the volume of speech here and there. 

The first 2-3 hours of the game i simply adore. It is the most filmographic intro of a game, and it sets the mood perfectly. But after that the game just loses much of its charm, only to get better when you're wandering the land, doind sidestuff and picking up the sotry whenever you choose. There comes a time it will grip you.

When did i stop playing?
The moment Connor starts a row, when Washington is holding a speech and you have two separate dialogues intermingle and fuck up the scene, is when i thought. Ok, this is too bad.
Why do you have a setting like this? First of Connor doesn't know Lee is there when only 10 people are present??? Then you as a game designer think it is a good idea to have TWO different conversations at the same time in a cutscene is a good way of tewlling a story??
That is the moment i quit the game, never to return.

An important note. It seems the world has been deliberately developed to restrain you from flowing nicely through it. F.E. There's a mission where you have to tail someone and steal his belongings, never have i seen so many dogs (steal = e, pet = e) in the street. So everytime i tried to nick belongings i was petting a dog instead. When i wanted to turn to hide, suddenly there was a wall of barrels that avoided me to do so. There are countless examples that show that the mission is quite straightforward, but the barriers to oevrcome to get the point are deliberately there. Example: freerrunning, when you have to follow a person. There are birds on roofs that means you can jump down in a haystack. When i follow the route and jump down where the birds are, i miss the haystack, because it is slightly to the right and my freerun parcours is to the left. So i have to start again. It is clear these decisions are deliberate. One last example, s simple one. There are viewpoints that are OPEN at the top, so you'll ALWAYS first enter them before you manage to climb one of the small pillars on top. Talking about the top, sometimes you cannot climb the small ornament. Sometimes you can.

However a week later i picked it up again, and it got me hooked, and it won't let go. Connor has his own outfit, i do missions here and there. I'll just look passed the bugs as much as possible, i'll skip horseriding and just do my thing. I'm loving it, again. (Still Ubi should adress bugs. No question about it)
This is a perfect example of a failed remaster, and it shows the personality of a company like Ubisoft.
A shame, because the setting, even though not very AC-like, is a wonderful one to explore bug-free.

As it stands, it is a very flawed game that tries to do a lot at the same time, in the process losing the charm and mystique of the first 4 Ac games. But Connor being an Native Terminator, hacks through the story like butter, and for all it's worth, i'm having a decent amount of fun (and frustration. Luckily the axe takes care of that)

LAst notes: The spawnrate and detection of enemies are ludicrous.
And whomever thought collecting WHITE almanak pages in a SNOWYWHITE environment was a good idea, needs to be put down immediately.

Stealth in this Assassin's game is by far the worst I've played.   It seems enemies will detect you for hiding in a bush somewhere on a Battle field, just by stealth killing whoever walked past.  They're literally unaware of your presence, but as soon as you press Assassinate on the closet target, everyone is somehow alert, that their buddy was silently, "Silently" killed. 

As for the Remastered version of Assassin's Creed III, it does look better, but from what I've heard the Story following Connor was supposed to be more depressed like, but in the Remaster from others, the visuals look too colorful to be serious.  But, I don't really mind the colors they've added, brings more life to the game, but that's my opinion.


  To top it off, the Devs have Unlisted the Original Assassin's Creed III from Steam, so now you can't get the OG game, you're forced to buy the HD version.   Apparently the Original AC III had less bugs and glitches than the Remastered has, and that's not good, lol!  You made a HD Remaster, but included more bugs than you had, oof my guy.


  As for Combat, I enjoy it, but I suck at it, lol!  I had to look up a guide on how to actually play properly.   I feel ashamed, lol!  I'm not a True Assassin, I'm like Connor, someone who found out about the brotherhood and goes on a reckless rampage of Murder, and besides him, I get my Arse handed to me.


I have to state my opinion on the Notoriety system in Assassin's Creed 3 Liberation, that if you're playing as slave Aveline, and you are climbing buildings or you pickpocket someone, you will gain notoriety to yourself, stating, Hey, you just did a bad so people are suspicious of you.  The Game counts it as you gained a suspicious level, even if no guards were around to feel the need to keep an eye on you, it gains the level even with Civilians.  I find that to be the dumbest system.   The Developers really thought, "This is a realistic system, lets add that to the game."   I think how the Notoriety system should work, is if ANY guard or guards see's you do anything of an illegal act, THEN you should get a suspicious level of caution, not when no one was around to witness it, TF?


   My Final Review for ACIII but for ACIII Liberation.   I must say I've played and beaten Liberation before on the Playstation Vita, when I thought the Voice acting  and combat was good, lol!   I gotta say, the voice acting is absolutely HORRIBLE!  There are times I cannot take the characters seriously, because it just sounds like the actor had hardly any practice in Voice Acting.   The Combat, it's literally the same as Assassin's Creed III when you play as Haythem in the beginning, there's no Original take on the Combat.  As for the Graphic overhaul, it's decent, but not a spectacular improvement, but better than it was on the PSVita being all Pixelated and low resolution.   The Story is mainly about Aveline who's mother left her when she was just a child, but she apparently had a good reason for this, which the game is awful at telling the story, or "Stories" of the past.  The whole game you go through freeing slaves and taking back your rights.  Aveline at a young age was taken into the Assassin's Brotherhood, but she had no idea what she was getting into, but her master trained her anyways.  Again, the game doesn't go into A lot of detail of why all of this is happening, it just expects you to know by playing, and or reading information you pick up along the way in the Notes the game gives you.  But, who wants to read hours of notes, we want a Prequal!   It's a shame the Devs didn't include a Prequal to Aveline's life in a DLC to the DLC of ACIII.   This is a new Story and Character, but it takes place in the same years as Assassin's Creed III, so that's why it's mainly just a DLC.  They don't show in Assassin's Creed III Connor meeting with Aveline, because my guess is that it would be longer than intended, but it shows in Liberation Aveline meets Connor, probably before Connor goes on his journey of stopping Charles Lee, and his Father Haythem, which we don't learn anything about his father till you play Assassin's Creed Rogue, but that review is for a different day.

Aah one of the best stories in the Assassin's Creed Franchise. I'm writing this review only after completing the game. The story, the score, the setting, everything was just fantastic and was perfect for the American Revolution era. The ultimate best part of the game is Haytham Kenway and only Haytham Kenway, the son of Edward Kenway, famous pirate Assassin from Assassin's Creed Black Flag. You start playing Haytham and then his son Connor Kenway, the main protagonist.

IMPORTANT NOTE: Don't buy this game individually if you're looking to play all the Assassin's Creed titles. Just buy the Assassin's Creed Odyssey Gold Edition, or if you own the game then buy the Season Pass of Odyssey and you'll get this game free. It comes cheaper in that way :)

now, i don't know if it's just me, but the graphics for me are a major improvement, others may not see too much of a difference, in fact, some think the original looks better, but i think the remastered is better. that's enough of the graphics tho, the storyline? 10/10, i've played the original before and i even 100% it. Controls? 10/10, mostly just press a few buttons. Combat and gore? 10/10, Combat is soo soothing, not to much gore, but just the right amount. Characters? 9/10 Both  characters are very interesting. Overall rating? 10/10! amazing game!

A good game at the time that it came out, but this remaster barely changes anything and imo the game play doesn't hold up well. Parkour in these older assassin's creed games is sloppily done, especially when playing on a mouse and keyboard. The combat is boring and easy, just mash E and you will never die. The only way to die in this game is by the parkour system fucking up and running off of a rooftop by accident. There are a huge amount of bugs in this game. The game actually ran fine for me but there are lots of bugs like chase sequences getting broken, animals and some enemies becoming impossible to hit and non-responsive to the world, and one fun one where my ship hit a rock and just instantly sunk even though I had over half my armor remaining. 

Moreover, this game constantly craps on Connor, the protagonist, by basically smearing it in your face via epilogues that the Templars were exactly right with their evaluation of the colonists and their government. Connor fights the templars to save his people? Too bad, you get a few lines of dialogue from a random NPC saying the whole tribe moved west because the american government sold their land. Connor fights the templars to ensure freedom for all in the colonies? Too bad, you get a 4 second glimpse at a slave auction as the british ships are pulling away. All of this is historically accurate, but it's handled so poorly and hamfistedly and it makes Connor seem like a complete tool in the end. His entire fight is rendered pointless in two brief cut scenes. It takes someone who is a better writer than I, and certainly smarter and more talented than the writers at Ubisoft, to acknowledge the complicated history surrounding the American government and its relationship to the native americans and african americans. They could have sprinkled these sorts of events throughout the game to really force Connor to evaluate what he's fighting for and whose side he should be on, if either at all, but no. Ubisoft just shits all over their own protagonist. And then they release an idiotic DLC about George Washington becoming king, ya know, the one thing George Washington constantly opposed, to the extent that he wouldn't allow people to address him with any titles or regal formalities. Ubisoft is company full of cowards making C tier games.

A wonderful remaster of an already beautiful game. The assassin Creed series always did a great job of making the time period and cities within the best parts of their games. Boston and New York are breath taking. A definite step up in clarity from the PS 3 version and the frontier is absolutely teeming with life. The plants and dense forests are also presented in better clarity but not as much as the cities. The game plays the same with minor improvements to the mini map and ability to whistle from cover that has become a staple of newer entries to the series. Connor is still as brutal as ever. The tomahawk is the most brutal weapon introduced in any game including origins and odyssey and really shines here. Do yourself a favor whether you’re revisiting AC 3 once again or experiencing it for the first time clear your schedule and get lost in the beautiful recreation of the American revolution. You will enjoy every second of it.

As a whole this game is much better than I remembered it being. The graphics are great if you adjust them in the settings of the game, and the addition of the Tyranny of King Washington DLC makes this a great purchase for the sale price of $20.

Every time I go back to give III another chance, I remember why it's terrible.
Haytham is great, and Liberation is actually really worth your time and it's a damn shame more of those features (and Avelline) didn't stick around. But the actual game of 3?

It isn't good. It was never good. It's story is anywhere between bland and motivated only by everyone involved being stubborn idiots (apart from when Haytham comes back, where the writing gets some life in it again thanks to him), as one of three people who really liked the Desmond story it gets so sidelined for what was blatantly supposed to be a focus at some stage in development... it's a mess. The 'cities' don't have the same fun actor to just run-around in as they used to, likely a result of them being frontier towns rather than bustling metropolises with narrow roofs, and while the tree running is nice it's not really used to all that great effect because it's easier and often times better to just get a horse and run along.
Anything this game did well, was done better by Black Flag. Everything this game did poorly would become endemic to the series.

I know Unity went through a renaissance of people saying it 'wasn't actually that bad'. Please, for the love of all that's holy, don't be fooled by a few hour long video essays or a new bad release into thinking III wasn't actually that bad. It was.

This remaster is a mess. Glitchy and buggy. Only get on a sale, They should have just let the game be tbh.

Assassin's Creed III is sorely lacking in comparison to other titles from the franchise. It suffers from pacing issues where the story is concerned while also feeling incredibly disjointed. There is no rewarding feeling or like you're learning much of anything from completing each quest, but awkward is probably the best description for the interaction between characters. From a writers standpoint it feels like they were unhappy covering the setting, but who knows for sure.
To speak of the issues AC3 has in playability, the game suffers bugs, stealth is almost impossible due to the AI noticing you virtually immediately every time, and more of what is echoed throughout the reviews. While I disagree about some of the comments on graphics, believing that the game does look ok for a remaster, I can't recommend this title on that alone. Trying to complete the game just for the story was a complete slog and almost painfully tedious.
If you're invested in the franchise and playing every title like me I would recommend trying to buy the bundle with this on sale. At least that way you get a bit more for your money (Black Flag), which is definitely worth the play through.
Imagine Red Dead Redemption, about 30 or 40 years chronologically earlier. If that sounds good to you this is your game!

I played the original version some years ago and fell in love with the story and characters. I was excited to get back into it once I saw that it had been remastered, but to my disappointment the improvements weren't where they needed to be. Environmental elements such as lighting and textures were improved everywhere but the most important area; the characters' faces. They somehow completely downgraded the shading and textures of many faces and bodies in the game, making things look oddly shiny and unrealistic. I love the game itself, but these "improvements" have turned me off of the remastered version and right back to the original game which I thankfully still have.

It's far from the best assassin's creed, but there is still plenty to like.

The biggest issues that people have, myself included, is that the game just isn't a great port.
All of the menus and functions were clearly made with a console controller in mind. I have played this way and the experience is far better. But that doesn't cover the limited options that haven't been improved in the remaster. So, as far as playing the game on PC through Steam, it isn't great.

But this is still an AC game. There's lots of fun to be had sneaking up on people, getting into trouble, gathering the collectable items. Connor is a good protagonist, and the story is one of the stronger in the series for both ancestor and Desmond missions. 

There is plenty of exposition as to why Connor is going down the path he is, which you will either love or hate. The dual-prologues can be a little slow, and this often gatekeeps people interest in the game. They are a slog if you're not terribly interesting in the world or characters.

Overall, it has a place in the bottom third of AC games. Okay, not great, but with enough for lovers of the series to get by.

The controls on this game are so bad, even with a controller, I'd honestly rather play this game with pc controls, and pc controls are trash with any AC game (though they've gotten better with Origins and up). The ship battles are god awful and good luck maneuvering with the damn thing at any given time. The on land combat isn't as bad, but the break defense ability is basically pointless since pretty much anyone it needs to be used on can block it. The free running is disgusting as well, I've pointed forward with the joystick while trying to jump to a building right in front of me and it instead decides to jump way off the camera to the right? Horrible game design, I honestly want to learn how to code and design things like this just so I can fix it. Then we're not even gonna talk about the god awful graphics (how a remaster manages to have even worse graphics than its original game I'll never know). I like Connor, he's not my favorite by any means, but I liked the thought of a Native American assassin. Connor's story isn't that good imo, but the modern day story with Desmond and the rest (which I'm normally not a fan of) is actually quite good in this game. It's possible it seems better to me since the modern storyline isn't being outshined by its historical storyline, like with Brotherhood where the historical part of the game with Ezio is so good, it feels odd to "pause" it and go into a completely different storyline with Desmond, despite how intriguing the storyline with him is. I want to like this game, and I want to cross it off the list of the few AC games I have left to play (if I got through Origins I thought I could get through this), but with the way the gameplay is, I can't, and for the sake of a future player's sanity, I can't recommend this game to anyone. If you really wanna know the storyline, just watch a playthrough or read up on it, it'll save you many a headache.

Overall Impressions: By no means a "bad" game. I had fun revisiting the game, as this was one of my favorite games when it first came out. Its not a great Assassin's Creed game by any stretch of the imagination even, but there are fun set pieces and missions (Sequences 6, 7, 9, 10). Recommend it if you haven't played it before, or you tie a LOT of nostalgia to this game (like I do).

Note: I 100% this game about 9 years ago when it came out over ~150 hours, so I only went through the main story. 

Time played: 19 hours (Full Sync, rushing through modern day missions)
The Good: Fun missions, good stealth, decent graphics, good story, great villains.
The Bad: Visual bugs (hoodless, bald Conner in early sequences), stiff protagonist (not nearly as bad as he's made out to be though), not a great remaster, why remaster this and not Black Flag? 

Recommend?: Yes if you haven't played it and like stealth/ classic Assassin's Creed, or are super nostalgic for it. Dont pay full price though, its not worth the 40 dollar ask up front. Wait until its on sale for half or more off. 

Will I go back to 100% it?: Probably not. Not dying to replay all the boring Homesteam and Liberation missions, but if you're into those, it'll stretch for a total of like 50-60 hours for a 100% run.

Assassin Creed 3 brings in two new characters and a new view of the Assassin and Templar struggle. It also concludes the story for the search of the precursor sites and explains the origin story of these mysterious artifacts. In terms of the story, the concept was fascinating but, its execution was a bit dull with the exposure to characters beings rushed. They were all there to move the story along and were pretty much forgetful after that.

In terms of gameplay, there were many changes. Now the game focuses on base up-gradation for revenue generation rather than buying up landmarks or shops. I prefer the old system as the new one makes it hard to generate revenue as generating revenue is now like a side game that you need to play if you want money apart from the chests. Also, upgrading weapons become pointless because if you are good at countering, the weapons stats are insignificant. The one thing I like to hear is the introduction of naval combat. Getting to experience the open seas was a fresh change to the usual city settings. Also, now we can climb and move using trees, which is interesting as it makes playing the game more fun. The DLC also brought back the feel of Prince of Persia with all those epic powers. Thou having played this series for this long, you kind of forget that you have these powers when hunting down the collectables.

All in all, apart from the storytelling, the game is fun to play with all those new features introduced to the world of the Assassins.

Although it feels a little dated, I find the setting and the story excellent. It could really do with much better stealth though, you end up slaughtering hundreds of soldiers because most encounters descend into a brawl really quickly.

This game is a poorly assembled soup of impotent story threads, terrible pacing, lackluster environments, and an incredible lack of self-awareness. For the then-climactic entry in a blockbuster series that had come to be among the forerunners of the seventh generation, it has never ceased to amaze me that they chose to do a soft reset on so many plot points, hunting down yet another MacGuffin to open the exact same door they hunted a MacGuffin for two games ago, as the very epitome of 'making it up as you go along' storytelling.

Each protagonist has individually interesting elements, but none get enough time in the sun to get a satisfying arc. Similarly, each conflict told over the game's twenty hours is underdeveloped and undercooked, leaving the whole experience feeling like a mishmash YouTube compilation of the Revolutionary War's greatest hits, featuring Ubisoft's OC. Characters will come and go with no greater purpose in the plot than a referential nod like 'Oh wow that's Ben Franklin! You know who that is, don't you? Isn't that awesome?' What few characters that do possess a hint of staying power are either killed off unceremoniously or completely forgotten about as the game reaches its closing chapters. The entire story feels rushed, unfinished, and by far the least satisfying in the series to date.

None of that is why I don't recommend this game.

I can say without reservation that this is among the buggiest software Ubisoft has ever released. Rain and thunder will constantly fill your ears even when it's shining daylight outside. Ships will blink out of existence on the high seas. The main character will hitch and hobble over every little thing on the road. NPC's faces look like they're carved from rock with googly eyes pasted on. Objective markers will glitch halfway across the map to the opposite end of where you should be going. I lost my bow eight hours into the game, leaving it floating in the air after a battle. 'No big deal,' I thought. Surely a reboot or reload would get it back. No such luck. None in sifting through the weapon stash either. A quick search online revealed that not only was this an issue in the original's PC release, it made its way on to the Remastered version without hindrance, and there is still ***no way whatsoever to fix it.***

That gross negligence in quality pushed me to do what I so rarely pursue in video games. I chased the main questline down with a single-minded determination to burn through it as quickly as possible. I have fond memories of the Homestead side missions culminating in one of my favorite moments in the whole series, but in this version, I couldn't care less for seeing it. 

This game has redeeming qualities hidden in the muck, and as far as the original release goes, there are so many bright ideas that are so painfully executed with a lack of time and ability, that this really is the worst type of bad game, in my opinion. It's something that tries so hard to be the definitive entry in a series, yet ends up being the worst.

Nostalgia

You know... I used to be a MASSIVE Assassin's Creed fan back in the PS3 days. When AC3 first came out I was so excited, partly because of me watching the trailers and Smosh's song parody. That Christmas, I got the game. This was the most excited I had been in a while for a game. My memories are faint, but I remember getting to Charles Lee's chase mission and found it unbeatable due to him falling through the floor at the start of the mission every single time. I had to wait an entire month for a patch to come out just so I could beat the level. That was the most disappointed I had ever been over a game in a franchise so close to my heart.

Fast forward to now where I'm replaying through every Assassin's Creed game. I was hesitant with AC3 and decided to finally play it. Is it as bad as I remember? Actually, it's not as bad as I remember at all.

In fact - it's WORSE.

The controls are at their worst yet, I don't understand how they managed to downgrade this much from Revelations. Connor is the most unlikeable and boring protagonist yet, the fact people like him more than Arno is baffling and makes no sense. His entire story is just wanting revenge, and being a dick to everyone he meets. I actually preferred the Templar more, as Haytham was such a fun and great character. But Connor is just overly serious and is just sooooo boring at all times and doesn't ease up at all.

Frontier sucks. It's the issue I have with most open worlds in most games, they're just lifeless and empty fields with trees and the occasional animal. To make matters worse, in the snow Frontier is a pain in the ass to get around, the ground becomes heavy snow except for the paths which make your journeys longer by going all over the damn place, then you have trees which are also slow to get around since they also divert all over the place.

The combat is pretty good, but I'm sick of enemies that can counter literally everything for no reason. It's annoying af having to constantly disarm an enemy just to kill them. Also for Unity I hated how enemies with guns were too OP, in this they're pathetic. If you are climbing, it is impossible to get shot unless you stand still. That one mission in Abstergo as Desmond, you can just move side-to-side in the elevator shaft at the entrance where enemies are unloading their pistols trying to hit you but they can't because they're pretty much stormtroopers. I got to the Charles Lee chase, he didn't fall through the floor at least, but instead he was knocking over his own men and they fell down like dominoes which made the chase laughable to complete.

This ship fights are actually really fun though, good thing AC4 is a pirate game. :^)

Goodbye AC3, thank you for killing my love for Assassin's Creed back in the day, and for almost doing it again in present day.

I played Assassin's Creed III quite a long time after it was released. I also mainly focused on the main story, so keep that in mind. I liked the story of the game although some bugs and the frustrating optional goals with each mission made it quite hard to finish.

The graphics of the game are alright. Not the best, but I felt like they were better than the graphics of Assassin's Creed III: Liberation. Nothing special though.

The gameplay was good most of the time, although I wasn't a big fan of some missions. I also didn't like the optional goals which each mission had. Most of them were too hard to complete which either made me spend too much time on a single mission, or made me feel like I didn't really complete the mission.

Overall I would say Assassin's Creed III is not a bad game. I think it's worth playing if you are a fan of the series.

When I was approaching this review I had faced a lot of difficulty in regards to finding the right words for Assassin's Creed 3. To be blunt. Back in 2012 I had a severe bias towards this entry mainly because I had just came hot off the heels of the Ezio trilogy, a trilogy that provided probably one of the most beloved characters in the series as well as set the standard for what we as fans wanted from the series. Now in 2021 I will say after replaying the game my original view has tempered even though I still hold some strong criticism for this games protagonist Ratonhnhaké:ton or just Connor for all intensive purposes. And just to get that criticism out of the way I will say this. Yes I do feel like Connor from time to time is a rather boring character but in all honesty it makes sense due to upbringing and if anything he is more similar to Altair where he is far more noble or stoic and not the charismatic type like Ezio Auditore. His naiveté is something that I admire from a writing standpoint since it highlights the atrocities of colonial America and how someone that's native may have tried to rely on people like that. Of course I'll just leave the rest of the story up to the player because honestly Ubisoft set out to make a very mature Assassin's Creed game and this one is definitely a lot darker to a certain degree and I truly love that aspect. Now, on the meat and potatoes.

Assassin's Creed 3 is the fourth entry in the series taking place in colonial America and from a writing standpoint I admire this decision since that entire era was a powder keg of revolution and bloodshed. Instead of being in the fancy boots of Ezio you now take on the role of a new Assassin by the name of Ratonhnhaké:ton or just Connor for simplicity sake. Throughout the game you assist many political figures with the intention of saving your tribe and over throwing another Templar scheme which should be par for the course at this point in the series. However for the first time in the series you are no longer limited to the urban town settings of the previous installments, you are now able to freely explore and hunt in the woods of colonial America and honestly I'm not surprised that they added hunting to this game since originally this came out a month before Far Cry 3, another game developed by Ubisoft that reinvented its series with added hunting and exploration. 

Outside of feeling like a mohawk predator jumping from tree to tree, AC3 adds its own version of the villa from AC2 which is none other than the amazing homesteading feature. There is nothing more satisfying then slowly watching your plot of land develop over the course of the game since your near virgin cut of land slowly becomes a thriving community that opens numerous opportunities for making money, It also adds a lot of character shading for Connor which honestly I never noticed back in 2012. Also one of the other big features of this game that comes from the homestead is the incredible naval missions. The thought of commanding your own vessel of war on the high seas was a spectacle back in 2012 and since Assassin's Creed 4 has come out it may feel rather antiquated in comparison but either way it's still a blast to play through the short list of missions.

To top off this review I MUST give a disclaimer to potential buyers. This is the only way to play Assassin's Creed 3 now in 2021 and since it's a "remaster" there may be the typical Ubisoft charm of strange graphical anomalies but to me that's the least of my worries. My biggest worries is that you NEED Assassin's Creed Odyssey installed in order to get the activation code for this game to work. I don't know why that's such a big issue with this game but when you buy this make sure you buy Odyssey alongside it and if that turns you off then this may not be the game for you. But if you are looking to marathon this series you'll probably end up buying it anyway. But please keep this in mind when you purchase the game.

Alright im going to start this review off by saying that I do like this game and the story is great, Connor is a great character and I did have fun but there are a lot of flaws with this game that I will go over. Firstly, the "remaster" really doesn't feel like one and while yes the environments do look good, certain character models look worse than the original which for some reason ubisoft thought that it was a good idea to not allow you to purchase the original version but none the less the remaster isn't great and if anything, this shouldn't have been the game to get a remaster, ac1 or ac 2 should have been the games to get the remaster because the original version of this game still held up and some might say even looked better than the remaster. Also I am not a huge fan of the gameplay, The combat is great with cool tactics and weapons to use, from chain killing to great double kill animations, the combat is an acceptation to the bad gameplay but the parkour and stealth isn't. The stealth in this game is really bad and guards will spot you in a fraction of a second. It is overly difficult and I found it easier by just rushing in and felt like stealth wasn't viable. And the parkour feels really janky and Connor will constantly not go where you want him to and it became frustrating near the end. The animations are great and might trick you into thinking the parkour is fluid but it really doesn't feel that way. Does this game deserve the hate? No but it defiantly isn't the greatest ac game. If you are going to get this game, get in on a sale because 50cad is way too much for this game at least in my opinion.

It's 100% worth playing if you are an Assassin's Creed fan! You will get two games (Assassin's Creed III Remastered including DLC & Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered).

[b]Assassin's Creed III Remastered[/b]
It's second time I played this game, not because I liked it so much but I got it free with Season Pass from Odyssey. But I am so glad I played it again, first time I finished original game. The graphics are much better in Remastered. You can notice a lot of bugs in this game, I don't know why are more bugs in this version than the original, at some point it was annoying. At the end of the day it's a good game.

[b]The Tyranny of King Washington DLC[/b]
Very good DLC, first time playing it, it was a good experience. Parallel world of the main game and story. Some cool new skills are introduced into the game.

[b]Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered[/b]
First of all, playing it on PC it's a bad experience for some players, I experienced some nasty stuff about resolution or FPS drops, but you can fix it. I started with low expectations regarding this game, and at the beginning of the game I really felt it as I expected ("I just want to finish it"), but after some hours I enjoyed very much and I was very wrong about the game. Originally released for PlayStation Vita only it's not a suprise you can have problems on PC. I liked the story, the gameplay (fighting, parkour). This protagonist is more charismatic than Connor from AC III. Very good!

In the end, all three : 8.5/10

This game... stinks.  I am a big fan of the Assassin's Creed series.  I played Assassin's Creed II, Assassin's Creed Brotherhood, Assassin's Creed Revelations, Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag, Assassin's Creed Syndicate, and Assassins Creed Odyssey.  I enjoyed every one of them, except for moments in the Ezio series (ACII, Brotherhood, and Revelations), and my favorite part was what I call "easy stealth".  While it is not always "easy", it is a lot less complicated than games such Hitman and Dishonored.  The problem with the game is that "easy stealth" is either really hard, or impossible most of the time.  Not only are the enemy placements terrible, and the pathfinding when getting back to their places imprecise at best, making it impossible to double assassinations, the game bugs out half the time when you are climbing, again making it hard to do stealth.  The enemy's also like to detect you inconsistently and their noise detection is completely over-powered.  The open-combat is fine, similar to black flag, if a little bit harder.  The naval  combat is fine, but is done better in black flag.  Basically, this entire game is basically a worse black flag with horrible stealth (Stealth is the reason I buy these games).  I got this game with Assassins Creed Odyssey, and it is the only reason you should get it.
Edit: As I played on I unlocked more recruits, which give you special powers such as covert escort, and that made the game infinitely more playable.  Maybe my standards lowered, maybe I got better, but I started not hating the game as much.  My negative review does not change, but my overall rating does to 6/10.  Get it with the Odyssey season pass when it's on sale.

Amazing continuation of AC series. I really liked setting and new main protagonist. The Tyranny of King Washington is incredible DLC with new mechanics that make gameplay even more enjoyable. 
AC Liberation is good either, especially wardrobe feature, it's quite unique.

Third in the title after the conclusion of the Ezio trilogy the game starts by following a man who later turns out not to be what we expect him to be and continues the story following his son Ratonhnhaké:ton (Connor). We quickly see him grow, under the guide of an Assassin mentor Achilles, into a man who eventually becomes an Assassin himself with strong principles and stronger determination to make things right, fighting to protect his people against the rising number of those encroaching on their lands and the approaching Revolutionary war around the area. Throughout the game Connor's stoic demeanor slowly succumbs to more emotional state when time and time again he's pushed into realization that the people he chose to help end up being no worse than the ones he's been fighting against. His personality perfectly conveys his internal struggle to fight against the oppressors and at the same time wisdom, passion and kindness to help those being oppressed themselves. Helping the Americans succeed in their independence however, he fails in what he set out to do, to keeps his people and land safe from the expanding colonists' territory and in the end losing a lot more than he had in the beginning both from his own perspective and that of his people. He's physically the strongest Assassin we've played with, with equally strong heart to do what's right, incorruptible and kind, showing restraint and wisdom when he's given none.

A new addition to the game is helping people in need and giving them a place to call home, in tern expanding the homestead and profiting from their wares. Although some getting used to, the convoy system of trading is simple to use and allows some items available to buy in stores to be crafted instead. Naval battles also play a role in both expanding the story and serving as DLC expansion, setting the naval stage for the following game in the franchise to take over.

The Tyranny of King Washington DLC shows us what would've happened if George Washington never found a confidant in Connor to come to at his hour of need. It made him realize how dangerous the Piece of Eden is to corrupt a man by showing him how different his life could be if he were to remain in longer possession of it. At the end he's still strong enough in that moment to recognize the descending path the Apple has been making him go down on and has more than enough trust in Connor to do what's right with it.
The DLC also introduces us to Connor's animal powers which are a joy to use, especially with an overwhelming amount of enemies around the cities and the Frontier, although having a strong restriction on how many times they can be used is sometimes to the detriment of the game itself. Where Eagle flight uses little health the Bear takes off a lot of it, and with the amount of enemies that spawn often times out of thin air it can harm more than help if used more than twice. The Wolf Cloak is most useful going after collectibles and sneaking around said large number of enemies, but in a densely crowded area often times fails even if successfully avoding people because the rats also contribute to physical contact and the Cloak inevitably fails if not quick enough to make notice and avoid the "tiny citizens". Overall all three powers are fun to use and add a new way of moving around the overrun cities and taking down enemies.

The remastered version also comes with Liberation, taking place around the same time ACIII does, but following an already established female Assassin Aveline who works to free the slaves and end corruption in her city of New Orleans. The first thing players will notice is the nostalgic controls most associated with earlier games in the franchise, and for whoever played them it will take no effort in getting back to the old ways. There are three ways to move around the city which are unique to Aveline - The Lady, The Slave & The Assassin, all contributing to different ways of getting certain collectibles, most of them exclusive to each persona, in both the city and the Bayou, revealed by exploring the areas as well as doing missions scattered around without the need to buy maps. The posters and bribes make a return as well adding to the nostalgia and the introduction of the new weapon, the Parasol Gun, removes the bounty just as quietly and efficiently. Money is earned through ship trades and, although it takes a while to start earning larger sums of money, once more trade routes are opened it becomes a lot easier. Although made for a handheld console the game holds its own, retaining the charm, combat, story elements, movement, weapons etc. of the main games in the franchise. The difference in how it's presented though, is attributed to the fact the game is Abstergo's released product, making it essentially a game within an Assassin's Creed Universe, which is also why it has two endings. The story of Aveline is far from finished and with the small connection it made to Connor it would be amiss not to get a main game featuring her as the protagonist.

Both games and their DLCs packaged in HD release offer a lot of hours of gameplay to enjoy two different parts of the American coastline in the 18th century, with both old and new mechanics. After the Ezio trilogy Connor's story is a fresh new start to the ever expending Assassin Universe that hopefully doesn't end for a long time to come.

A Mixed Bag.  Perhaps I was spoiled by getting into the AC franchise with Black Flag and moving backwards?  I supposed had I started with the early games I would have more investment in the Assassins v. Templar theme, and the whole Apple of Eden quest. As it stands, in AC III on, I feel like it is a distraction from the core game. 
AC III inexplicably opens with some mysterious "Desmond" modern character, who reminds me of Ben Stiller, attempting to play an exaggerated dumb jock. He's standing in front of a cave, so you walk into the cave, turn left ... Cinematic ... Okay, no big deal, now I'm in the cave, oh, this is teaching me to run and climb. Okay, I get it ... Cinematic.  Okay, now we're playing the game! I'm Hatham Kenway, son of Pirate Edward Kenway from Black Flag! Cool!  I'm in pre-revolutionary Boston! Cool!  I meet Ben Franklin! Cool!  This is pretty cool!  I get to ride a horse around (why don't people get out of the way of a sprinting horse?) I meet a beautiful native American woman and ... have sex?  Wow! Great game!  Wait ... what?  Back to Desmond ... still in a cave ... doesn't get along with his dad ... well, yeah, they're both jerks I don't identify with ... Now I'm a kid?  Playing hide-and-seek with other kids?  What happened to Kenway?  What game is this? NOW you roll the credits!?  I've been playing for hours over several days (with breaks) and we're just NOW getting to the ACTUAL game!?  Who wrote this mess!?  Who thought this was a good way to structure a game?  Who thought "Connor" sounded Spanish!?  LOL!
Once the game gets going, it is entertaining. Connor's tomahawk is a lot of fun. The controls are a little cumbersome on PC. Not sure what its like on console, but glad they figured out better ways by AC4 and AC5.  The game is MUCH longer than Black Flag or Rogue.  Lots more to do, but unfortunately, most of it entails riding around on horseback, dodging red coats, who are constantly just annoying enough to make your tasks a challenge, but not tough enough to be challenging (if that makes sense). 
Still, a fun game, not too fiddlely with skills and other complicated mechanics that later games took on. Much more to see and do than Black Flag and Rogue. Enjoyed re-living the setup to the Revolution War.  Time for a replay to see what I missed the fist time.
I love it!

Yeah... this game was so bad it made me change my review of AC:Revelations.

Story - Extremely boring and single threaded. It is the most boiler plate revenge story ever with the most unlikable characters ever. Basically the story follows a kid who has his home destroyed and he proceeds to seek revenge, during this, the american revolution is also playing out in the background. There are no twists, no turns, just a mad Main character and people dying. The game low key gives Conner the credit for a bunch of the key moments in the revolution despite his complete lack of interest in the war. Like he literally goes on a walk, looking for a dude and gets involved in the Boston tea party. He goes for groceries and he's involved in the Boston massacre. I probably shouldnt be annoyed by this but the revolution was driven entirely by passion, but the character they chose to credit with the achievements and victories of the revolution is also complaining the whole time for having to participate.  I hate Conner he's always mad, at everyone, for everything, all the time even at his allies....... because his mother died in a fire...... His character can be summarized as morally indignant native american - which yeah okay that can be a powerful character trait, but if that's all he has going on then he's going to be supremely boring. In the ezio trilogy we had the interplay of the personal life and the ideology which drove the assassins. As far as I can tell Conner doesnt care at all about the assassin vs templar conflict, and instead kills dozens of people for no other reason than a personal vendetta. There's a lot more about the story that I could talk about but ultimately it just boils down to the story being boring so lets move on.

Gameplay - what have they done? They ruined it. Oh my god its awful. So they removed the divide between sprinting and freerunning so anytime you try to sprint, if you're close to a freerunning snap point you might jump to it, meaning a borderline successful escape attempt can be cut short by conner jumping on to a fence you run past. They game also tries to assume where your trying to drive your character which means that sometimes you might jump in completely the wrong direction if theres a snap point the game thinks your aiming for, it just feels like you're not even in control sometimes and that you just have to press forward and hope it goes right. They also updated the climbing points and integrate them better with the environment, however since the game also largely takes place in the wilderness the points you can climb and the points you cant climb become much harder to see and differentiate between. Anyone who has 100%'ed the pegleg trinkets (and didnt use a guide) understands this extremely well. Guns have effectively been ruined. I'm not sure if theres an in story explanation as to why instead of using ezio's op semi-auto wrist pistol instead of this flint lock pos but we need to go back, the bow is slightly better but I never had arrows, I'm not really sure where to get them tbh. Lockon is effectively gone. Instead of a proper hard lock on the game decide who it wants you to attack at random, you can switch targets but it'll switch it for you..... you know just to completely **** you over. Swords and Axes felt pretty useless, I didnt feel like I could really fight until I got my hands on a heavy club, and I just used that for the rest of the game. Combat is cancerous now, you cant use anything but your melee weapons now, the game actively blocks you from swapping to certain items during combat, you can get 1-3 (depending on the gun) shots off during a fight but then the gun is effectively useless. Countering is inconsistent and you have to memorize what type of counter works on what types of enemies now as "guard break" seems to be completely useless. The frontiersman system replaced the shop buying system from the old games. It was pretty interesting and could have been great but the UI was really hard to understand and you get the last craftsmen near the end of the game so by the time you're able to fully utilize it you're almost completely done with the game. Mission objectives and desynchronization  are now more annoying than ever. Missions often come with sets of optional objectives depriving you of your own agency and creativity than ever before, whats worse is the game often does not display the optional objectives until you have failed one at which point the game pops up a nice red x just to let you know how much of a failure you are, which really ruins the hype if youre on a roll killing guards or blowing up barrels or w/e.  Desych (aka mission failure or death) also annoyed me. checkpoints were poorly placed often tiomes failing a missing near the end would have you restart from the beginning several checkpoints ago, and on missions with hidden failure conditions, such as dont walk next to a certain tree, dont climb anything or go  through a "building escape" can be quite annoying. For example in one mission you have to assassinate some enemies on horses, but if you kill any of the other enemies on the road you instantly fail and are taken back pre cutscene no where did it say "dont kill anyone". In addition not skinning animals gives you a desynch warning  - this probably annoyed me the most because theres a certain area near the first frontiersman mission objectives where there is an elk spawn a bobcat spawn and a wolf spawn which leaves you in an endless loop of quick time events as you kill hundreds of wild animals because as soon as you kill one of them the next one attacks and in the mean time the others respawned. I think I killed about 40 animals before I could edge my self out of the triangle murder and then as I left my screen started flickering like crazy because "Conner skinned all the animals he killed" - Look devs, you almost entirely removed the need for money in this game and then added an abusive amount of aggressive wild animals to the game, I am NOT wasting my time to skin every friggin wolf that wants to cause me problems...... Ship combat was pretty cool I guess.

Overall this seems like a direct downgrade from the prior games, combat is worse, movement is worse, the story is boring and the frontiersman system while nifty was too hard to use and not fully functional until a point in the game where it was no longer valuable.  Of the assassins creed games I've played so far (1,2,brotherhood, rev, 3, origins, odyssey) I rate this one the lowest. Unless you're playing this one to complete the Desmond story, I'd recommend you skip it entirely.

Following the end of Ezio’s trilogy, I will now talk more in-depth about the true sequel to Assassin’s Creed II and this one is called Assassin’s Creed III (logically, but hey, sometimes they name sequels differently).

From this review on I won’t be mentioning any of the stories anymore. Because a) I can’t put them into words well enough to make sense and b) because I myself have a hard time keeping up with the overarching story(lines).
What I can tell though is that this story starts of really, really slow.
So onwards to the gameplay we go:

Instead of an entirely new game that would justify this being the third in the series we basically got the same old Assassin’s Creed without any real innovation. Well, that’s a lie. There’s one part that’s completely new to the entire series and that’s naval combat which I will discuss in a minute.
For now know that you can climb more obstacles and that you can dual-wield weapons. Combat in general has been revamped making it a little more challenging, but nothing a veteran wouldn’t be able to handle.
A lot of the changes have been made under the hood and therefore they’re not really obvious to the average gamer. That’s why I and so many others find it so underwhelming. And that’s a shame.
As I mentioned the naval combat is new to the series and you can steer (and upgrade) your own ship during some of the missions. Naval combat is just like it says; ‘combat’, so there isn’t any exploring. It’s just you, the enemies and the ocean (or: rogue waves). It works very well and it looks great in motion. In fact, it works so well that Black Flag is largely based around this gameplay mechanic. But that’s something for another time.

When this game was first released it was gorgeous to look at. Beautiful snowy environments and a cold climate that would make you shiver in your own warm and comfortable home; it was perfect. And even after the snow had melted it was amazing. Apart from a few too many houses being copy-pasted the variety in environments was also incredible. The series never had any issues with well animated characters and this one was no different.
Same goes for all of the sounds, music and voice actors; all of them are of incredibly high quality.
Audio-visually it was a stunner and it was proven to be a true sequel.
I casually go over these things in all of my reviews, but I mean them. And this is because of two reasons: I want to talk more about the game itself (but I do want to mention it) and for the older games I usually can’t completely remember all of the finer details.
(With the HD update the game still looks mighty pretty by the way)

I must admit there’s still enough to enjoy Assassin’s Creed III, but for many fans - including me - it wasn’t the sequel we were hoping for. With new graphics new and more varied gameplay mechanics were also expected, but it just felt like playing any previous Assassin’s Creed game in reality. Just with some added detail. The bugs and glitches also didn’t contribute to a good experience. A real shame. Fortunately Ubisoft listened and with the arrival of Black Flag they would once again redeem themselves. Until next time!

I was really excited for this game - especially considering its historical setting. And on the whole, I can't say I was disappointed - the increased freedom of movement you get when compared to the previous games is great. Moving around the world feels smoother, on the whole. I liked the traditional native hunting mechanic, the feeling that you're still an outsider - even in the supposed "safe zones", and how they connected the two father-and-son stories that were happening at the same time. I also appreciated how they explored not only the colonial perspective on the revolution, but the native and even the British perspectives (through Shaun) as well.

For those of you who got this game free with Assassin's Creed Odyssey- Gold or Ultimate Edition, you have to run Odyssey and register it first in order for this game to be able to run. This is not clearly laid out and if you are trying to play the games in order then you will be stuck here. That was the case with me for I bought the entire collection and when I got to this one it asked for a CD Key, which Steam does not provide but fail to let you know what you have to run Odyssey first. 

When I asked Steam customer support for the CD Key their response was to (and this was inspired) "restart Steam and Ubisoft connect and it should work". Needless to say that Steam's "solution" to this problem did nothing and after 2 days of back and forth emails between Steam and I, I decided to contact Ubisoft and it was them who told me about the actual solution within a couple of hours. In spite of the hiccups I am fortunate that the game runs smoothly and without problems.

"Remastered"

Whoever oversaw this remaster was either paid-off or blind. The graphics are just as dated as when it released almost a decade ago, and you'll see it when you play it. This is a shoddy excuse to push it out for a $40 price tag, and absolutely not worth it. Don't pick it up unless it's on-sale for $7-10, and even that's generous. You'll see how much of a cash grab this was in the first 5 minutes, between both gameplay and cutscenes, which REALLY sucks because I LOVED this game when it came out, and was thrilled to see that it'd been re-worked.

Don't do this to yourself, or wait til it's 90-95% off.

Years ago I used to pre-order every Assassin's Creed game. The last one I pre-ordered was Black Flag. That was mostly just due to a change in consoles as well, and feeling cheated by getting Rouge instead of Unity.

Why do I say this? Because Assassin's Creed is one of my favorite game series.

This allows me to confidently say that Assassin's Creed 3 is the worst in the franchise and should be skipped. The only reason to play it is for Desmond's story. 

I do recall enjoying it when it first came out, but I couldn't replay it for the life of me. The controls are weird, it takes forever to get anywhere, and the story is probably one of my least favorites out of all the games. 

2/10

I got it for free in the Odyssey season pass. I loved the original AC despite of all the bugs it had at that time and with a remastered, I was expecting more than just a few UI, light and reflection upgrade (which tbh, looks worse in some places). The game have almost all the bugs it had in the original. I don't think it is worth buying at all.

I don't know what they did... and WHY!, but remastered feels so broken. Wonky controls, weird lighting, AI feels like missing some brain... I have played original game and it was 110% better. 

The Tyranny of King Washington is a bust DLC...  it should not exist at all in this game. Does not have any connection to the story of AC at all, AI of this DLC is even worst then main game, difficulty of the game is fixed, what ever you pick game will try to kill you everywhere you go. I recommend to play original game if you into AC story line, 20hours all it takes. Skip the Tyranny.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Explore the 1700's American era of Boston & New York during the integral revolutionary war period
    [*]Contains a small epilogue to Desmond's story
    [*]The new naval combat system is very simple and satisfying to operate, full sync requirements are a challenge but are not unreasonable (tank mission intensifies)
    [*]Accounting book system is a versatile trading/income management tool that allows for multiple revenue streams at a fast rate; although appearing more complex than previous passive income systems in AC titles, the accounting book is a useful tool to maximize the productivity of your homestead
    [*]Collectibles are much more reasonable and rewarding, no longer collect 100 of every objective, instead chests now contain crafting recipes & other collectibles are less scattered and easier to obtain
    [*]Tyranny DLC is an interesting "what-if" scenario that introduces ridiculous overpowered but enjoyable abiltiies
    [*]Contains "Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered", play as Aveline another assassin who is operating in New Orleans around the same timeline; her adventure is a good added 20hrs at most (To access Liberation you must launch it from your steam library through AC3's "Play" button, players will be prompted to select which game to play)
    [*][b]Haytham {No Wearable Outfit}[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Riddled with bugs: markers not showing on the map, incorrect markers being displayed, textures, physics, & crashes
    [*]Enemy groups are too heavily bunched, and the aggro range of detection in high profile makes fights 2-3 times longer due to luring enemies from the next town over
    [*]No explicit instructions or directions on how to access Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered
[/list]

If you are about to buy this game, stop immediately.  I've got four hours into it and I would rather exchange that time for having watched Phantom Menace while chewing on aluminum foil and shaving my head with a cheese grater.

First, the keyboard controls are highly resistant to customization.  You go into the Controls section and try to arrange the movement buttons to how you want them...and the buttons you want to change are the same buttons that shift the highlighted button in the list to the next button!  So if you want to change 'Move Forward' from 'W' to 'E'...such as if you, like me, have larger hands that don't fit well into W,A,S,D movement keys...you highlight 'Move Forward', click 'Enter', and then hit 'E', right?  No.  Hitting 'E' shifts the list of controls up by a line.

I had to work my way around the keyboard several times before it would finally accept the basic movement configuration that fits my hand.

Then there's the plot.  They suddenly introduce Desmond's father as though he's been with you since the end of the last game.  But he did not show up at the end of AC 2, so why is he here all of a sudden?!?

Next is the voice acting.  This is some seriously third-rate acting.  Sorry to the V.O. folks who did the work.  I imagine they could have done better, but were given bad direction.   Terrible.

But the worst part is the graphics.  I've got a top-of-the-line Alienware gaming PC and I can't turn my vision by more than ten degrees without the universe suddenly lurching thirty degrees farther than I wanted to look.  And when I try to look back the other way, it happens again!  I tried adjusting the graphics both up and down and it still does it.  

I am at this point cutting my losses and quitting the game.  And the entire AC series.

Seriously, Ubisoft.  Get your shit together.
I loved playing the game when it first came around but this is a huge improvement i love it

Firstly, I must address that I have never played any of these games or game before.  This is a review for someone who is jumping straight into the game such as I did.  The game was not fully as I expected.  I picked this specific one because it was a time period that was interesting to me, and it had its ups and downs.  It firstly looks beautiful, which is part of the reason that it drew me in.  But the problem, is that this game feels too open.  I never thought I would be complaining about something giving you lots of options, but you almost never feel motivated to go outside the main quest.  You have no incentive to buy better weapons, catch the book pages, and hunting quests.  There is just so much busy work that it doesn't feel meaningful.  It wasn't totally what I had expected, but it just delivered and took away some parts in different places.  I feel that if the map would have been smaller, it would be more meaningful and it would nail the revolution theme even better.  If you are buying this game, you are buying for the story and the game play, because to me, the replay value is non existent to me.  Now, the story inside the actual animus has to be one of the best stories in a game.  I love how it stars a Native seeking to essentially kill his father, who aligns with people who want to burn down their town.  As to outside of the animus, I am basically clueless as to what is happening, so maybe as to not start with this installment if you are interested in the lore about Desmond, the actual character who relives memories.  I have no clue about who Judo is and what Desmond was doing in Brazil, but I just went with the flow.  And I still don't fully understand why the Assassins and Templars don't agree, but again, I just went with it. It is like a story inside a story, and the one in the animus really drew me in.  Achilles has such a humanized personality and feel like a real character, along with his side kick or main character, Connor or as I would try to say his real name Ratonhnhaké:ton.  I love this character as he embraces a brave and persistent soul.  And as soon as he threw the axe into the column, I knew that I was in for a ride.  The game play is par.  Nothing to special, but the combat is significantly harder only because of the wacky controls.  Not in the key binds, but in the way he moves.  I could count hundreds of times where I have climbed or fell of something and many times it had cost me a life.  But otherwise, very average and enjoyable game play.  This game tends to have tons of glitches.  Sometimes I would load in and it would just not let you back in, which was the most common, but still rare enough as to not affect the experience.  Next, sometimes I would load in, and only certain parts of the textures were there.  Half would be see through, and half would be there.  But other than these gripes, this game is definitely worth playing for the story.  And once you pulled out the axe out of the column, is was one of the coolest symbols in game.

Assassin's Creed 3 Remastered is a decent game with some notable flaws. To begin, at least with the version I have, it includes Assassin's Creed 3, Assassin's Creed Liberation, and the King Washington DLC. I believe I got this from one of the Odyssey editions. These games take place during the French and Indian War as well as the American Revolution. Each game and the DLC took about 10-12 hours.

Even though its remastered Assassin's Creed 3 itself still could use some work. The first 5 sequences feel like a extremely drawn out exposition and tutorial. For those used to the fast travel of more recent titles it mainly serves to get you to different parts of the world and is lacking inside these parts. This is most obvious on the frontier where you can access a horse that sometimes isn't worth the hassle. Some naval combat is introduced which is a nice feature. Modern day is interesting with the story following Desmond Miles.

AC: Liberation
I personally enjoyed Liberation more than AC:3. The pacing and dialogue were both smooth if a little quick at first. Naval combat was not present in the game, however it did introduce the "persona" system which offered a unique perspective to stealth and infiltration. There was very little content related to modern day, which mainly took the form of extra cut scenes. The main issue I ran into was occasional lag and frame drops.

In conclusion, AC 3 Remastered has a decent story and fair gameplay. I would recommend it for those interested in continuing the Assassin's Creed series especially if it can be bought at a discount.
Great game

[b]ACIII[/b]
I played the remastered version pretty much straight after playing the original, so it gives me the ability to really compare. Overall, it seems like such a missed opportunity to change some of the shortcomings of the original game.

Sure, the graphics have been greatly improved (i.e. water and HDR lighting), but that is tempered with the graphical quality on the character faces being a bit 'off'. The bugs are still there from the original version, which is quite frankly quite annoying.

Overall, the game isn't as 'fun' as the previous instalments (as some of the optional objectives are just tedious), although the enhanced dynamics in fighting and movement do enhance the realism and immersion.

[b]ACIII: Liberation[/b]
Certainly not the best in the series, but still reasonably enjoyable. The story is bit formulaic, but as it is built on the ACIII engine, the fighting and character movements are dynamic and fluid, which keeps things engaging.

Certainly worth picking up as part of AC: Odyssey Season Pass, but probably not something you would go looking for on its own.

I first played AC3 on the PS3 and remember absolutely hating it. Upon revisiting it almost 6 years later, I was delightfully surprised, but the game crashes every ten minutes and I will not let you forget.

AC3 seems polarizing whenever I see discussions about the story, some people think Connor is whiny and trying too hard to be a badass to the point where he mostly comes across as a cunt. Others find Connor to be stoic and harsh, slow to trust most people as a result of his childhood trauma.  Personally, I found that the game crashed every ten minutes, and Connor to be an interesting character with engaging relationships with the rest of the cast, after I stopped comparing him to Ezio. It’s not that as a character Ezio is much better than Connor, it’s just that Connor isn’t allowed to have as much fun as Ezio is, and that adds to the atmosphere for a slight detraction in dialogue. As for the rest of the cast, their pretty top notch. Some people hate the opening bate and switch, I found it refreshing and a great way to SHOW what the villains are about, instead of just being TOLD, in a game that crashes every ten minutes. As for the villains themselves, Haytham is enjoyable and his relationship with Connor leads to a fair amount of interesting exchange, most of it is just you’re an idiot, but he brought in a unique perspective in a game that crashes every ten minutes. Lee on the other hand is a well-built villain, there’s nothing overwhelming powerful about him, you never tread your encounters, but having witnessed everything he’s done, and everything Connor has done to find him, it’s fun when the two meet, and the final kill scene is the best death the series as ever put out, and it earned a lot of points for me. General story events are ripped straight from the American revolution in a disjointed way, making most things you do feel disconnected and as a result personal invest suffers. It’s worth noting that having a vague understanding of the American revolution timeline, add some entertainment as you can now go, “hey I know that guy,” or “hey, I know what’s gonna happen kinda,” or, “hey, the game crashed again.” Modern day is back again, having been built up in AC1, 2, and Brotherhood, and then immediately dropped in Revelations, only to return here where it crashes every ten minutes. Modern day takes a lot more relevance in the story, before it was mostly just adding to the depth of the overall story, in AC3 it was used to dump dialogue and do some neat parkour. You only visit a few places, and for a small amount of time, but actually playing in the modern day this time around was so damn refreshing. Sure, the tension between Desmond and his father was so wooden I was worried that I’d get a splinter, and the whole interrupting game moments got annoying, I’d still say it’s the best and most engaging modern day we have… gameplay wise. 

AC1 brought in the idea of counter killing, and the AC2 trilogy brought in chain killing, what then does AC3 do, guns I guess and crashing every ten minutes. However, it’s the same case here as it was with revelations, what ain’t broke don’t need fixing. Chain killing is still fun, now with newer and more creative animations, and with how often the game throws large waves of enemies at you, you’ll find the combat in AC3 to be fluid, addictive, and mindlessly easy. It turns out being able to insta kill most enemies makes encounters simple. Provided the game hasn’t crashed, the devs solution to the lack of difficulty is to occasionally add in some two or three shot enemies, which helps more than you think but less than they should. Another quirk of AC3 is opponent's attacks not always being properly telegraphed, and while this can be chalked up to a glitch, I’m going to call it a feature. Mainly because it makes fights more engaging by forcing you to pay attention to everyone and their behavior, and not just little red triangles, and if the game has crashed.

A criticism of the new Assassin’s Creed games is the lack of depth in the parkour, it’s not that the previous games were particularly great at parkour, but it required a little more than just holding W. While each building is no longer a mini puzzle on how to climb it, the parkour system now has a sense of flow that was near impossible to achieve in previous games. The puzzle nature however, is not completely eliminated unlike the crashing. Viewpoints and parkour heavy missions demand some thought into where you place yourself in order to complete the objective. Not to mention traversing in the trees, which while heavily underutilized, requires a good amount of attention without damaging the pace. I prefer the old parkour system, it was very stop and go but it made climbing each building interesting, but I can see why others prefer this system. 
If me mentioning that the game crashes every ten minutes has somewhat annoyed you, then imagine playing the game. Are there other bugs in the game, yes, do they matter, typically not. Every now and then a guard will spot you when they have no right to, but generally all that does is limit full synchronization, which if you’re going for then expect some bullshit regardless of developer intent. Admittedly the game does gain better stability as you progress, although it’s still not worth it unless you have a good SSD, and CPU to reload the game fast. No, it isn’t a testament to this game greatness that I played through it even though it crashed more than most crypto currencies, but a testament to the auto save feature, since I rarely lost more than a minute’s worth of progress. Don’t get me wrong, it was still frustrating beyond belief, but I’ve seen worse.

Lastly, it’s worth mentioning that this game in its entirety can be bought either separately or in the gold edition of Odyssey. I highly recommend the latter. On sale, this game is less than 10 CAD, as opposed to 25 when purchased alone. And while I had a tremendous issue in the game’s stability, you probably won’t, since I don’t see it as too widespread a problem. 

Tyranny of Kings is also included here, and wow is it… apart of the game. The whole concept of alternate history is oozing with potential and AC3 did it’s best to tell an amazing story in the most boring possible way. Lazy storing telling aside, the gameplay is shockingly not just more of what the none DLC has to offer, we have three new abilities. There’s the coyote ability which grants invisibility and is so much fun in stealth situations, an eagle ability which allows you to basically teleport around the map, and a bear ability which sure exists! I cannot recommend the Tyranny of Kings enough but do make sure to beat the regular game first, what little the story does have to offer is only in Connor vaguely knowing he’s in an alternate reality, and it’s meaningless unless you’ve played through the campaign.
