Assassin's Creed III is an 'alright' game, but this remaster is a hot drip of donkey ass sauce. They completely ruined the graphics, and while visuals and skylines can look nice sometimes, all the character models look like a play-doh pizza. I found numerous performance issues as well, and while some have been fixed since release, it's still not acceptable for the full price, £60 I payed for it. But the real kick in the shin, is that they de-listed the original, most stable, version of the game from steam. You can no longer purchase, and play the original AC3.

This game is a clear cash grab, and I despise it. But unfortunately this is currently the only way to play AC3 (on steam). If you want to play AC3, it's likely you will have to bite the bullet and play this heaping pile of horse shite, or pull out your xbox360/PS3 and play it there.

Notes: I got this game for free, and I've played the original on multiple platforms (Nostalgia Free), and I've played some of the remastered version on Switch. 

Assassin's Creed III was a good game. Despite having lows, it was fairly solid. 
Assassin's Creed III Remastered, however, shits on the legacy of the original. 

Being the only version of ACIII on on PC, and being the only remaster of any of the first trilogy games, this should be the definitive experience. Nope. Despite being "Remastered", the only things improved were lighting and textures. 2019 models and textures paired with original 2012... everything else makes characters and the world look out of place. Only remastering visuals also means the gameplay experience is the same. The same large amount (if not more) bugs still exist and have not been paid attention to, one of the worst being enemies seeing you through walls. Yeah, so much for stealth. And to finish off, pricing. Since Ubisoft markets this game as "Remastered", they feel you should shove that up your ass and pay them $40. Costing twice as much as the previous non-"remastered" game is unacceptable. 

TL;DR: Despite being originally good, ACIII adds numerous technical and gameplay bugs that make the game unenjoyable 
            and almost unplayable.

This review includes AC Liberation at the end.

ACIII is not as bad a game as you might have heard.

First of all, the Remastered really only has better graphics than the original, so don't buy this if you've played it.

I personally don't think that this game is a bad game or a bad Assassin's Creed. The story is good and has a few very interesting turns - it also presents the finale to the first trilogy of games [spoiler]because it's the last game with Desmond[/spoiler] and makes that enjoyable and worthy of the previous games.
You are guided through two very important cities of the American Revolution: New York City and Boston, as well as the uncolonised lands in the west and - of course - a place for you, the player, to build up from scratch. Unfortunately, Ubisoft has reworked the viewpoint-system and these now don't reveal the entire map anymore - instead, you have to run through the dark areas now if you want the entire thing revealed because the big circles around the points leave quite a few spaces. This was probably meant to encourage exploration, but quickly deteriorates into senseless running around, only staring at the map.
The story introduces multiple important characters of the American Revolution and makes Connor participate in or lead many events you might have heard of. Next to that, he tries to get revenge on a Templar who had burned his home village in his youth - yes, a typical revenge story, but it's very well done and atmospheric.

The controls have definitely improved from the ACIIs. Running and climbing feel a lot more accurate and good. Additionally, a ship has been introduced, which allows for some exciting naval missions where you fight pirates or Brits or just good ol' Templars. This doesn't feel as good as in Black Flag or Odyssey, but good enough for the first AC where this was tried out.

So, the base game is good, but there is a DLC: The Tyranny of King Washington. This play in an alternate universe where George Washington got a hold of an Apple of Eden and instituted a monarchy in the United States and now has plans for world domination - and Connor naturally has to stop that from happening. They actually introduced new mechanics here: abilities you gain from psychedelic drugs which make you imagine animals. These are quite cool and allow you to become invisible, fly or stamp your feet at the ground. The downside is that they cost health which devolves a lot of fights into "ability, ability, run around until health has recovered, ability"-repetitions; the game spawns too many enemies to allow for normal combat. And there comes a big critique: because you have these abilities, it is assumed that you want to use them all the time and so you don't actually get a choice here, the game just spawns endless enemies. Even if you're not in combat. I'm not making things up here: sometimes when running (or flying) to the next mission and closing in on it suddenly a group of enemies was spawned out of nowhere. And because within a certain range all soldiers are automatically drawn into fights, this prevented me from beginning the mission for quite some time. Additionally, some climbing mechanics somehow are made worse in the DLC. I don't know how or why, they just feel more cluncy than in the base game.
Other than that, the DLC isn't too bad. It isn't as good as the base game but good enough.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

And now to AC Liberation.

Mechanically, both games are quite similar, although one aspect was added here: the ability to switch costumes. This allows the player to become a lady, assassin or slave depending on what's necessary or what is needed for the mission. All costumes have their up- and downsides, the lady for example can't climb while the assassin will always be investigated by guards on sight. This feature sounds fun, but quickly becomes annoying because missions sometimes switch costumes automatically and running around the world as a lady is just not enjoyable.

The game is set in New Orleans, the surrounding swamps and Chichén Itzá. The world feels a lot smaller than in other ACs, but that may be due to the fact that the game was originally developed for the PS Vita, which arguably isn't as powerful as a PC or modern console.

This leads to another weakness of the game: The story. Theoretically, it's aspects allow for a good adventure, but because the Vita is a portable console, the story isn't exactly contiguous. Oftentimes, it feels like aspects or scenes are missing: most relationships and some strings of the storyline don't make a whole lot of sense and might require some reading-up. This goes so far that I didn't understand how the ending came to be and how things got the way they are presented. Dialogues also oftentimes seem too short for the content they are supposed to deliver.
But to get into details: The game follows the young assassin Avelin de Grandpré in her quest to... free slaves? Work for the brotherhood? Help smugglers? The game can't really decide between the three and just switches between them, making the character Avelin less sharp and understandable - although it becomes clear that she isn't too certain on who she is and her inner conflict is built up throughout the game, culminating in an epic finale.. Connor also gets a mission, but there he feels weirdly superficial and unlike the master-assassin you got to know when playing ACIII.

All in all, I have mixed feelings on this game. On the one hand, the story presents the player a very interesting Coming-of-Age adventure and - as always - the world is very interesting and exciting to explore. On the other hand, the continuity is kind of missing and the costume-mechanic doesn't feel entirely finished.
I would only recommend playing this if you either picked up the Remastered anyways or if you want to play through the entire series. Otherwise it just isn't as enjoyable as other Assassin's Creeds.

As a runner-up to Assassin's Creed Revelations, this game is... alright.

[h1] PROS [/h1]

  1. I don't very much like the setting of the revolutionary war, but I have to give credit for the attention to detail and how living and breathing the world felt. Not to mention the lighting and environments in the frontier were actually really pretty for how old the game is. 
  2. Combat movements/attacks/finishers felt much more fluid, however this resulted in issues with responsiveness.
  3. Connor's relationship with Haytham was super cool and interesting to see.
  4. Awesome new environments, a lot less "don't be detected" missions than other games. 

[h1] CONS [/h1] 

  1. Once again, I was not at all incentivized to complete any side missions whatsoever. I never bought an item from the shop, I never completed side quests, I never invested, I never did anything that weren't the main missions because I wasn't rewarded and it wasn't fun.
  2. Because of the fluidity of the attack movements, controls themselves take a massive blow. Counters would only work about half the time despite being pressed at about the same time, this could be my fault but I didn't have this issue in the other games. 
  3. Counter and then clicking attack doesn't attack. Very cool!
  4. The game sometimes doesn't tell you what you need to do or where you need to go during certain missions, so you have your objective but no idea how to get there. I failed the final chase scene several times because I had no idea what the game wanted me to do. 
  5. Connor is not that likeable in my opinion. I like how his speech is very proper, and its cool how we have conversations in his native language, but his demeanor doesn't sit with me the same way that Ezio and Altair did. 
  6. So many bugs, an exterminator couldnt take care of them. More than the other four games combined. 
  7. At least for keyboard and mouse, the controls were drastically changed, AGAIN. I hate hate hate hate hate how the games change the controls for every single game, and I understand it may be to introduce new features, but this one was so unbearably foreign to me that I had to dedicate time to learning the controls. 
  8. Desmond's face was changed from the last game, and even further from the games before that. Why??
 
[h1] VERDICT [/h1]

  Overall, it was a very cool game and I was glad I played it as the next game in the Assassins Creed franchise, however I found myself sprinting towards the next mission to finish the game as fast as possible. I was so hopelessly bored with side missions, and at some points the main story stagnated, so I got really frustrated and ended up playing Halo. 
  Ultimately, I recommend playing the game for anyone coming from the previous games in the franchise. If you haven't played those, I could not recommend this game simply because you really won't care about what's going on behind the scenes. That was why I played the game in the first place. 
  6.5/10, 7 if you really stretch it.

Assassin's Creed III Remastered is a transition game with a lot of good... and bad qualities.

On the good side? There was a lot of quality of life improvements in this remastered version, naval combat, GREAT world/story, and a pretty interesting main character.

On the bad side? This truly felt like a transition game after the Ezio trilogy where they were trialing a lot of half-baked ideas, naval combat is a plus but it was improved upon further in AC: Black Flag, and some of the follow x person to y locations got somehow even more pathetic than previous entries in the series.

I personally would recommend this game because I enjoyed the time period and the improvements in the remastered version but it is very much a "depends on who you ask" game on whether it was well received or not.
This game gets a bad rep for pacing, but the gameplay is some of my favorite in the series.
Just buy the Assassin's Creed Odyssey Ultimate edition. You will get the free copy of this game. Buy it when the game is on sale.

I have played some AC titles before and took one of the last promotions as chance to play the whole series and enjoy how the story around Desmond evolves while enjoying spending hours playing.

However AC3 is definitely the worst AC I have ever played. 
Of course it is still a playable AAA a title with established game mechanics and if it was an indie studio it would be double thumb-up but for UBISoft in comparison to other AC title, it is a clear thumb down.
As someone else commented: buy it if you think you have to complete all titles of AC but skip it if you are looking for story and gameplay.

I am playing the remastered version and cannot compare to the original release.
- For a remastered version and how much effort they put into graphical update, some models and textures look terrible. Other things look very nice, but they did already in the initial release.
- Most bugs I have ever seen in all other my AC games combined. Backwards running people, missing quests NPCs, enemy guards despawning when moving close, spawning when going away and coming to aid other NPCs in fight, ....
- The worst of all, bad parkour mechanics probably made even worse by map design. Running does not feel satisfying by taking obsticles but combersome to avoid being stopped by obsticles because Desmond likes to jump on everything while he should just run, makes heroic jump from a stair or doesn't jump at all, ... most of it is maybe typical behavior seen in other AC games but here it feels so much annoying.
And simply things that don't work. Like some specific jumps I could not manage and had to search in internet to find the solution on how to do the jump exactly and still had to try several times (this is supposed to be a one button spam jump game not a rogue like plattformer).
- Fights... swarmed by NPCs plus bad fight mechanics like 3 seconds assasination animation during which Desmond can be attacked and interupted and NPC that always attack after the 1 second. Weird parry/counter mechanics, which I enjoyed in other AC titles, are here just frustrating. 
Some quicktime events are broken I would say... eg the mission encounter with three wolves, when the first wolf always failed... always. Although I fought six bears in a row without a single fail.
- Map design... feels boring. I can see they put some efforts to make it look living places ... but they somehow didn't manage. It still looks empty, with dozen of people running around. 
The wilds ... looks interesing but adds nothing to the game, is time consuming to travel has only boring quests, silly, full of cliche
- Quests... beside the main quest line, are either simple as taking a lolli from a baby or just insanly difficult to finish, not because of required skill but of luck. Vastly majority of those quests are, bring this, take that, kill one guy / animal, search for hours,... and they always come with more time spent to run to/from the quest rather to do the quest.
Freeing forts is plain stupid and in the end I can even be attacked afterwards for helping the patriots.
- Main story... in its basics it is interesting but executed purely. Each event does not really make sense.
And everything... everything is done so slowly... animations take ages, most time spent in running from one location to another, even some of the people speak slowly
Maybe for Americans it is interesting to see the guy from history lessons animated in their games but for the rest of the world those are just some dudes and I don't need to know five persons few on the same event when the persons and the event does not mean anything to me.

And things like... 
why are there more soldiers than citizen in towns?
why am I known in the wilds but unkown in the city?
why do I, the proud last american assassin, do delivery jobs for people I don't like or know?
why do I even care about the revolution, as Desmond says several times he doesn't?
why ... just why is this game made to bad?

Update:

I stopped playing when spawning at a checkpoint that is located in a restricted area, i front of two guys who immediatly notice you... in a mission in which you must not be detected. seriously?!

I remember that I loved Assassin’s Creed 2 and then I wanted something different, I felt as if Ezio’s story was over and as if the franchise had more potential to explore different characters and worlds.

Turns out the developers didn’t feel that way, or maybe it was Ubisoft, either way, we got sequels, but they were directly related to AC2, we got Brotherhood and Revelations, games that I don’t personally dislike but that, at the time, I never got to play, because, frankly, I wanted something different for the series, other time period, other historical context, another kind of protagonist, just something that wasn’t the same.

It took them around 4 years to make a different game, it was still Assassin’s Creed, but it was a different character and a different time period.

I pre-ordered the game because at the time there wasn’t as much stigma around doing so, from what I remember at least.

It was also my first lesson as to why I shouldn’t pre-order games.

It was supposed to release at midnight it ended up releasing at 3am that night.

It was hell going for it, but in retrospect it had a bit of an adventurous vibe and I don’t regret waiting till 3am feeling quite groggy only to then go to the game store where they were a bunch of other people like me, dressed the same, even with the same haircut too, it was pretty wild.

The guy at the register looked like he wanted to be anywhere else but there, I got the game, got back home at around 4am and, my grandmother who I was living with at the time, encouraged me to play it, in a way I think she wanted me to enjoy it.

So, I started to play the game and, after two hours or so, I turned off my ps3 and felt cheated and disillusioned about the whole thing.

It was infuriating how terrible it was, I still played it the next day, but I never finished the game, and eventually I even sold it (if my memory serves me right) something that I regret doing today, because then I wouldn’t just have this story but I would have factual proof to go alongside it, then I could stare at the game in my collection and chuckle as I remember how it all went.

Over the years the game got a bit of bad rap, a lot of people disliked the bait and switch of playing initially as a different character than the one in the cover and after a while they disliked the game even further for then making you play as the main character from his childhood to his adulthood.

After a while and today, the game started getting more positive impressions, people generally liked the combat and the mission structure and what used to be considered annoying with the different protagonists and people you got to play as, now is seen for the most part as bold and interesting.

It was definitely a game that made a lot of people discuss it and with this remastered I decided to give the game an actual try and attempt to finish it.

Overall, I enjoyed the game, the stuff I disliked from before I still disliked this time around but it didn’t hinder my experience quite as much, I still enjoyed the combat and the historical recreation of revolutionary America, despite the AI behaving a bit silly at times and stumbling among one another.

I really liked the story as well and how gory the combat system is, it works fairly similar to the past Assassin’s Creed games, you counter then you get the chance to disarm or chain a series of kills, it’s all fairly spectacular and violent, like a ballet of gore that doesn’t demand much from the player in terms of interaction, but that does enough to not make you feel like the game is playing itself.

Biggest issue still remains the pacing however, there are a lot of missions that are devoted to explain to your individual game mechanics, like how to hunt or how to lower your notoriety.

A lot of the times I felt as if these mechanics truly didn’t deserve their own missions, in past AC games you got most of these mechanics and systems explained in a mission or two, in this game it takes them a while till they instruct you into each of them and the saddest thing is that most of these systems aren’t that complicated or difficult to learn to begin with.

 Generally speaking, though I did enjoy my time this time around, a lot of the missions I found to be boring in the past are now relaxing and/or interesting and I appreciated a bit more the themes and the ways such themes were discussed throughout the story this time around, AC3 is widely considered to be the “black sheep” of the “classic” AC games before they changed the series substantially and made it great but completely different games.

I think this remaster is a fantastic way to try the game, is much better optimized than the original title was on pc. Ironically with this remaster I can achieve 60fps in most areas where as in the original game I could not.

The game also looks better generally but there are some sequences and set pieces that in close inspection look worse than the original, although for the most part the graphical and aesthetical changes are an improvement in my honest opinion.

I got the game as part of the gold edition of Assassin’s Creed: Odyssey, it includes which includes all dlc content for Odyssey and 3, including 3’s spin off, Liberation.

Assassin's Creed 3 used to be one of my favorite games growing up, and I had always hailed it as one of the best of the series next to AC 2 and Black Flag. But with this remaster, I can say that my opinion has definitely changed. It was a mystery as to why when I started to play the game that it had mixed reviews on Steam. I now know why. 

The game's graphics are barely overhauled with changes seen in regular gameplay, but in term of the cutscenes, they do not seem all too different. This can be easily said for the cutscenes in the Tyranny of King Washington DLC, wherein the scenes are super grainy and blurry, showing obvious evidence that nothing was changed whatsoever. 

In addition to the issues with the graphics, any bugs that were present in the original release, still plague this remaster. Minor bugs throughout games have never bothered me all too much as long as they don't inhibit gameplay or affect the stability of the game. AC 3 Remastered contains both of these problems and more.

Looking back on this game, I only finished the base game and DLC's simply on nostalgia. The passion and love I had for this game will forever be soiled by this remaster, and I can only recommend it to others who want to play it for the same reason, nostalgia. But for others wishing to get into the AC franchise, don't start with this one.

In the words of parents across the world, I'm not mad, I'm just disappointed.

This is definitely the weakest, and easily the worst Assassin's Creed game I've played yet. 

When the games were first coming out, I'd only played the first one on a struggling little laptop. As an adult, I've managed to play and finish AC1, AC2, AC:B, AC:R, and of course decided to play the next in line, AC3.

The story is not terribly interesting compared to the previous installations, and the characters simply lack the character of those in the preceding games. There are interesting historical figures, sure, but they just feel boring, and the "friendships" and "alliances" if one can call them that between Connor and the other would be assassin recruits feel forced. One second they just met, and in the next, the two act as if they are very close and of the same principle, when in reality, very little dialogue or planning at all has transpired between them. I can go on, but I won't.

The locations are dull and plain. Setting an AC game in the Revolutionary War sounds like an interesting idea, but really as soon as they reached the point of level design, SOMEONE should have pointed out that there isn't anything really amazing about colonial architecture. The frontier is terrible and is an absolute SLOG to get through. Great, more and more two story buildings.

I'd heard a lot of criticism of this game when it first came out, and I must say that none of them seem unfounded now that I've experienced it for myself. I cannot comment on the quality of the remaster, as I did not play the original game when it released. Please see other reviews for a better grasp of it - though from what I've read myself, it appears that this is a shameless Ubisoft cash-grab.

Ultimately, I decided to play this game because I really wanted to know how the Desmond story continued, and am OCD enough that I really wouldn't be able to move on to Assassin's Creed IV, which I intend to do right now, without first having played Assassin's Creed III. I would only recommend people play ACIII for completionist reasons, and basically no other. For that reason I have decided to give this one a thumbs down.

I finished this game solely because I gave myself the challenge to 100% sync the entire mainline Assassin's Creed franchise, and this one tried my patience very passionately. It has enough bugs to be considered a beta access game, which I consider unacceptable for a REMASTERED game. I mean you could at least put some effort into quality control.

SPOILERS IN THE BUGS YOU ARE WARNED!!!!

List of a few (not all) the bugs I encountered:

-Guards track you through walls (even if the arrow is grey and they're "toning down the chase/about to lose you). they just stay there look at you and the chase arrow stays grey but never goes away unless you can move far away enough for the chase to reset (normally it disappears after a certain time the guards don't see you)

-When  looting bodies, the camera angle will lock 1/3 times, it becomes impossible to move your cam unless you take the time to aim with a ranged weapon and move the view around significantly, otherwise the cam just goes back to the angle it had when it locked itself  

-Reflex shot tends to bug out by either not showing the hand or gun animation (one or the other) abd sometimes doesn't even fire, yet still spends your ammo. The sound on it is also bugged when this happens.

-Animals sometimes respawned immediately after the kill right beside me, which is all good an nice until it's a predator or elk which attacks you, which makes it impossible to skin your current kill, but you also can't go away, because not skinning that animal causes you to desync.

-I've had the citizens from citizens missions randomly attack me while I was helping them (they were straight out hostile to me, this shouldn't be) and if you counter, it says you failed the event because you hurt/killed the civilian you were supposed to help (I WAS TRYING TO BUT HE WANTED TO TAKE MY HEAD OFF, DAMN IT UBI)

-Your horse can't back up or move through spaces if he doesn't have at least 1-2 feet between him and the walls of the gap you try to move through, but he can magically pass through when you dismount him. I stopped counting the number of times the horse got caught on terrain and He just stutters and glitches there until I dismount, then he magically stops glitching and gets unstuck like it was the easiest thing in the world. Also if you summon him while on the downward slope of a hill, since it always spawns off cam (which is most often straight behind you) he can spawn under the map, into the hill.

-Rooftop snipers sometimes detected me through walls, enough said

-Voice audio wasn't always present, thank god for subtitles, because otherwise I would have only one end of some of the in-game conversations you have (cinematics included in this)

-Speaking of subtitles, they too are bugged, and will most often go too slow for the conversation which means some of the dialogue doesn't make it's way to the subs you see on screen, meaning again if it's in a convo where you lost some of your voice audio, well you're fucked mate good luck piecing that dialogue together.

-I've had ships bug where the enemy's ship had no reload time, they just constantly fire without end.

-DLC Tyranny of King Washington is completely broken for me, event objectives bug out and get considered  failed main mission objectives, and main mission progress tracks but all collectibles reset once I leave and reload the game (they should not)

-Some DLC content (West Point) is available before events in the game which it references, breaking continuity. (I mean I berat Washington for what happened in Monmouth, but I have yet to meet the guy in the main story (note that this DLC is available while you do the main story, it's activated as soon as you enter New York)

-Enemy ships never take any damage from Rogue waves, no matter their positioning or ship state.

-Some interactive convo markers never dissapear, even if the person has nothing more to say, meaning you never know if that person has new dialogue for you, making it incrediblky tedious to check.

I'll end it there because this is becoming a long list, but there are more, be sure of it

I'll end this with a rant on how they screwed up the free climbing system they spent 4 games tuning beforehand. Let's simplify it so much it breaks it,  sums it up pretty good. seeing as you have no more high/low profile actions. Now you just have plain Free Run mode, which means that your guy will auto jump and grab ledges. But since you don't have to press an additional button to start climbing, you grab on to anything climbable as long as you pass within 1-2 feet of it. And well there are a lot of chases through narrow alleyways that have the immersion ruined because your guy compulsively tries to climb anything within reach, even if it's 45° out of the way you're pointing your joystick. Connor will also almost never take the optimal place to grab when jumping across gaps. For example you jump from 1 roof top to the next, even if you seen him make longer jumps and reach the other side standing and still running, momentum unphased, he will chose to jump down to one of the grips on the wall of smaller gaps rather then jump straight to the other ledge, once again breaking your chase/escape momentum and breaks the flow of the game.

As if all of the above shit wasn't enough, the game has 5 FULL MEMORY SEQUENCES OF INTRO AND TRAINING BEFORE YOU GET TO THE MEAT OF THE GAME. There are 12 sequences in total, meaning almost half the main game is the intro and training.

IT's also the end of Desmond's story, though the Antagonist he releases isn't addressed (only mentioned a few times) in any of the following games, they had to wrap that storyline with a damn comicbook. So the story doesn't really have any impact or repercussions in the following games because the high stakes story they set up at the end of the game, never develops into anything concrete in any other video game of the series that comes after.

All-in-all, the bugs and poor gameplay changes completely ruined this game for me, now that I've 100%, never playing it again and have uninstalled.  Seriously, out of all the games in Assassin's Creed, I've come to understand why this one is the most disliked.

Just feels really unpolished as the concepts in it are good, after all AC IV Black Flag is basically a really well polished AC3 gameplay mechanics wise. But yeah go play Black Flag and leave this crap nightmare behind
I remember when the world almost ended in 2012

Optional objectives in this game is the stupidest idea ever, Some of them are insanely unfair, frustrated, And don't make any sense, I Fxxxing hate it.(I think dev was intentionally make people suffer, I mean who heart you? Like one of them "Don't push any people" when you chase the target, and they put so much people along the way, A slightly touch will ruin your whole mission, Seriously?)

Bug never fixed(Sometimes after you search body your camera will randomly freeze), Low poly NPC everywhere, And the control!!! The Fxxxing control!!!!! How do you even possibly make it worse than AC1???

Some tutorial doesn't even show up, Like one mission want me to tackle someone from high up, but it didn't tell me how to do it, I spent an hour on try to figure out which button do that, And then i have to google it to find out it was B key on my controller, but in game it just said B is to drop down. WTF!!!

And the ending, sigh...
Again, I was randomly search online, then find out they made the story into a comic book, and hardly anyone know that, they never explain in the game, They just abandoned the whole story line.(Glad to see Desmond in Valhalla, Even tho he doesn't have much story to tell.)

I played the original AC3 I didn't remember it was this frustrating, Damn.

Assassin's Creed III is simply boring and a huge mess. Story is boring and long, graphics, for a remaster, are shocking, music is dull and repetitive and even the difficulty for some sections is furiously hard.
The Story starts you off as Haytham Kenway, where you play roughly 3 whole sequences with him, only to then have to start all over with Connor afterwards. The story really only gets good sequence 7 onwards with even then having mostly boring quests and constantly feeling like an errand boy. The VO for Connor isn't great either, with him always feeling like a mopey 16 year-old.
Graphics are honestly shocking. Even more so for a remaster. Revelations looked better than this. In more than a few cutscenes peoples heads turned into cylinders, which was actually quite amusing. Controls were unresponsive, although combat had been slightly improved since revelations.
The Music is terrible and overly repetitive, although the combat and chase music are good and fill the moment with the needed thrill.
Finally, the difficulty. This game isn't actually difficult, but some sections are REALLY badly designed. A chase at the end is so badly designed it takes 30 minutes and a Google search to figure out where to go. And sadly this isnt the only time you have to do this, which is very infuriating.
Overall, Assassins Creed III has some great parts of Story and Gameplay, but honestly feels like a huge waste of time. The story has a confusing and bad ending, the graphics are bad and the overall gameplay is clunky and just makes you want to play something else.
Assassin's Creed III gets a 3/10.

I did play AC 3 back in the days and had a nice memory of it ; wanted to play it again. 40€ for a remaster? Sounded a bit much, but hell I can offer me a present once a year.

I regret. This game is bad. 

I can't really see what has been remastered, sure the graphics look nice, the forest are pretty, and the towns feel lively. But not spectacular. The cut scenes in particulars are just ugly. Eyes like fishes, dead corpse facial expressions, laughable gestures. Connor still has his fat chin making him look ridiculous, and he tries way to hard, he just feels like a needy brat. Cut scenes are to be skipped.

And oh boy do they like their cut scenes. If you treat this game seriously and want to follow the story, don't. It's bland and childish. And I'm not even speaking of the "present-day" part of the game with Desmond Miles aka the most boring character ever - no bad surprise there, its just baffling as expected.
Wouldn't be such a problem if you could easily skip it and enjoy the game as a sand-box. But no. This is an AC where everything is locked behind the story line. You have to spend HOURS with Haytham B-lining the tutorial section before starting the real story. And then you're not done. You still need to spend an incredible amount of time with Connor to unlock most of the maps and mechanics, and for it you have to cope with uninteresting cut scenes with uninteresting missions between. N.Y map for instance : you're coming to New York through a mission. Once there, you  can NOT explore the city, you HAVE to follow some block on its horse and hear its sob story. Then a 'tail that convenient weird guy' mission occurs. Then boring eavesdrop on say guy. Then boring city street chase. Then prison. Then dumb, slowmo assassination. Then you come back in the present as Desmond (fun fact: as Desmond, you don't have displayed objective, so if you skip cutscenes, you just have to guess what to do. Fortunately, you just have to run everywhere like a wild goose, a cutscenes to the next chapter will trigger soon enough). You NEVER had the chance to explore New York, you just pass through in a never ending row of (boring and insipid) cutscenes, loading screens and dumb missions. I skipped EVERY cutscenes and it still took me nearly 2 hours of boilerplate gameplay - and I still can't explore NY by myself !.
In general, 80% of missions are just going from point A to point B, to trigger another cut scene. And this is not going parkour-like, stealthy and such. You have to do it on horse, or in the middle of nowhere, or following Jon MacSlowy telling you how badies are bad and goodies are good - and you can't stop sticking its boot because the mission will abort if you're too far. Sometimes there are some explosions or filters to make you feel a bit under stress, but the mission is still the same : just press Z (or W), slighty move your mouse, your done! Some quests (for instance when Achilles sends you in the far side of the Manor map to gather a futile item - deep in a cave ofc) even DISABLE fast travel to force you cross the entire map, running several minutes in the most undesired and artificial way. It's so boring and preposterous. Then you have some stats about random events which occured or not during your stroll, and impact the level of synchronization, then a loading screen, then the next cut scenes. 

Character controls and interactions with scenery make me sad. They're awful. In the Frontier map, 50% of viewpoints are the same tree, recycled over and over again. And this tree is just a pain to climb up to. Now that I know how to deal with it, it takes me 3 or 4 times to climb it. Connor desperately wants to jump out this fricking tree, he's so damn mesmerized by hay or something. He's also commonly glitching into an impressive amount of game artifacts, sometimes during mission, which is quite frustrating as save points are erratic at best and you often respawn way before the point you were stuck. Did I mention the missions where horrendously boring? Maybe because you don't have much to do in them, but must endure it several times.
Combats are not that interesting, and repetitive. And what's the point of knocking down an opponent if you can't finish him while he's down? Yeah that's it with big targets: they attack, you block, then kick them off in counter... then wait them to pick themselves up. You, as a gamer, are spamming the attack button ; Connor just awkwardly wave his weapon upon his opponent. Any game would allow you, with skills, to shorten a boss fight. This one don't, you just have to repeat your routine 5 or 6 times and the guy's finally done.

The optional missions are a failure too. Most are just the same as main missions : going to point A to point B (everybody needs a postman). And even if you select the "interesting" ones, hunting for instance, the mission will change if you approach a interesting point, a fort say. I was hunting a legendary bobcat, and in the middle of the chase: "hey look at these bloody redcoats! let's go nuts and trash their place for no well explained reason". Thanks game for screwing yourself. Of course the bobcat mission needs you to go far away to respawn, and in this map (Frontier) which is HUGE, there are... 4 fast travel points, right in the far side of the map. Genius.

But well, if you spend 6 or 7 hours B-lining the main story, you can then cool off your frustration by having a nice walk in the woods - which are nice it's true. That's what I like in AC: the sense of freedom. Chilling out, hunting, leveling up my town, crafting, trading (oh god don't get me started on the inventory/crafting/trading interface...). Such a shame this game does not free the player much sooner.

Played this on the xbox 360 and I don't mind playing it again! It's worth playing all the assassins creeds (though Unity could be skipped).

Pros:

* Excellent graphics - you can tell they upgraded the texture, lighting and LOD quality significantly 
* Naval Combat is great
* They re-did the mini-map and main maps - better, more colorful, easier to read
* AC3 still has the best combat system in all of the Assassin's Creed series. Excellent animations, human shields which act as a very viable and logical way to engage enemies at close range with firearms and survive
* Improved the crafting system - fixed some of the bugs and navigation
* They added in some side content missions that were originally PS3 exclusive (Benedict Arnold Missions)
* The music in AC3 is pretty darn good - not as good as the Ezio games, but still really good, especially the patriotic theme
* Despite Connor himself not being my favorite Assassin, I always thought his outfit was pretty awesome. It fit the location really well and looked cool

Cons:

* Wish they had gotten rid of the "constraint" system on missions - the poorly implemented constraints were something that were heavily criticized back when this game was first released - sometimes they flat out don't work, sometimes they're just stupid / make no sense within the context of the mission, and in many cases you don't even see them display as they pop up DURING the mission while you're in the middle of a chase
* Building on the above point, honestly the biggest problem with AC3 is the mission design. Many of the missions are so poorly designed that it can infuriate the player - if you aren't an absolute expert with the stealth / sneak system and know exactly how enemies will behave in certain situations, chances are high that you will desync missions frequently 
* There are also some missions where, due to targeting bugs, and other wonky movement behavior, you can desync by your horse just stopping during a ride for no reason or your gun not firing no matter how many times you push the fire button, etc. This game is a text-book example of why Ubisoft's QA department has the reputation that they do throughout the world
* They still have not fixed the broken stealth system where Connor will not hide in the bushes properly if anyone is looking his way - this issue does not exist in AC4 / Rogue
* The tailing system in AC3 is absolutely abysmal. I don't mind tailing missions like some people seem to, but they just need to be implemented far better
* Never been a fan of the AC3+ movement system of just holding RT and having the system auto-pilot for you - for multiple reasons. 1.) It limits your control, sometimes your character will jump or climb buildings aggressively when you don't want to. 2.) It's just sloppy and takes away some of the enjoyment of the climbing system. 3.) I miss feeling like I was doing some of the climbing myself in the earlier Ezio games where sometimes you had to use the Climb Leap technique to reach certain holding points, etc. 

Game Length: Assassin's Creed 3 took me 56 hours. I did nearly everything except collecting feathers (since they play no part narratively in the story). 

Final Rating for AC3 (does not include Liberation): 9/10 - this was a really well done Remaster. I don't know why I see so much negativity on it on the messageboards. It runs fantastic, the textures and visual quality upgrades are great and I didn't really run into any new bugs. Some bugs from the original game were fixed, but not all. I'd say with this game and Liberation included, you should feel comfortable picking it up for $10-15. Honestly if you own the original game, think of the Remaster as just paying for a DLC that includes an image quality overhaul

Liberation Remaster Review (below): Wanted to put a section into this review dedicated to AC Liberation since it's included as part of the game, although it's my first time playing it -

Pros: 

* New Orleans is pretty
* I enjoy Aveline's different outfits / personas that give her different skills and vulnerabilities - this adds an angle of realism for blending that hasn't been in any previous games. It's also good to see Ubisoft actually innovate a little bit with something like this instead of just going vanilla or copying mechanics from other games 
* Combat system is a clone of AC3 (great mechanics)
* The Bayou location is really well-rendered and pretty as well (a very unique location). There is a lot of really good free-running via the trees in the Bayou
* Aveline acquires a pretty cool tool to use - a dart gun via her umbrella as a lady which I thought was good ingenuity - Assassins would generally come up with pretty good tools for sneaking around and killing people undetected which I think is a mechanic that's a bit under-utilized in the series along with disguises which this game makes good use of on both fronts 
* <light spoiler> - I liked Aveline's outfit for the snow during one of the later missions in New York, designers did a nice job with that by adding the fur in the right areas, looks very sleek, and also that Connor was in the game briefly 

Cons: 

* The game runs like crap - a lot of hitching and a lack of smooth framerates. I did some research on it and it appears the game was originally developed for the PS VITA so I suspect the engine simply isn't as robust as the AC3 engine and as a result struggles with modern graphics features
* Game does not seem to recognize DSR resolution options or various display ratios - it's just a poorly coded game in terms of graphics options and performance 
* The game crashes whenever you quit the game (hello Ubisoft QA)
* Aveline copies Connor's combat animations - she should have her own. Lazy development
* There's no present-day story in the game, so really no context in how it connects to the present day storyline
* Same bad mission constraint system as AC3
* The voice actress for Aveline is the same girl that did Cristina in AC Brotherhood - nothing wrong with her, but it's so obvious that it's a little irking and removes any immersion every time Aveline talks as I hear Cristina, not Aveline. This is a common issue with Ubisoft games - they frequently use the same voice actors for multiple characters in the same franchises and it hurts immersion
* They don't do a very good job of fleshing out the story - it feels very disjointed like they don't give you enough details on what's going on so sometimes you're wondering about story details and a ton of time passes between sequences (years) so it makes you wonder what's happening during those long stretches of time
* No real fast travel. And there are a bunch of instances where you have to travel across the city - sucks to have to walk / run ~300-400 units frequently throughout the game due to no fast travel
* Mission design is exceedingly poor. You'll frequently have no idea why you're doing things and / or wonder how Aveline just knows to go to a specific part of the city to do a mission or find a missing person, etc 
* Map design is also infuriating, particularly in the Bayou - it's fun to move through the trees in the Bayou, and very pretty during the day, also, but when you are in areas where you have to move on the ground, navigation is tedious and unenjoyable 
* During the game you'll use a canoe in certain areas of the Bayou and Mexico to move around - the canoe steering controls are about as bad as could be 
* In typical Ubisoft fashion there's a good bit of feminism / wokeness in the game which is a turnoff for normal folks 

Game Length: ~16 hours - I did most things in the game minus some of the collectibles. I imagine if you did every little thing you'd be looking at around ~20 hours total 

Final Rating (Liberation): 5/10 - This game has a lot of issues as outlined in the cons and they are pretty major. Too many for me to recommend it 

Final Rating (Liberation + AC3): 7/10. Overall between both games, I'd recommend because of AC3, just go into Liberation with low expectations.

Before I start with my review I will say that I wasn't sure if I should recommend this game or not but I put yes because of some "overall" experience. 

To begin with, this is a great deal if you have Assassin's Creed Odyssey and Season Pass with it. You get this game for free so no complains about that. If you unfortunately want to buy this game as a standalone product then rather save more money and buy something else. This game is definitely NOT worth $40 whatsoever.

First I am gonna talk about some downs. This game, as every product by Ubisoft, has lots of bugs, errors and crashes. This game is particularly for some reason very unfriendly with my hardware. This is not happening to everyone, but for some reason I am experiencing screen flickering and I got BSOD 3 times so far and I tried to fix it but nothing worked. That is indeed very annoying but I was very persistent and I managed to do solid 51% of the game. Then another issue is definitely character models. I guess you have seen many pictures on the internet where people compared Remastered and Original version. Do not worry. It is not as bad as those pictures show, but it is also not good either. (The pictures on the internet are mostly on bad display and graphics settings so they look worse than they actually are). The characters lost their shading which was making their faces look more realistic, lightning is improved ONLY on environment but completely screwed on characters' faces. They indeed in most of the moments look very bad compared to the original game. The characters never had eyelashes anyway so this new character modeling makes that even more noticeable and their eyes indeed look really weird. The facial animations also got really weird as much as they also lost their facial details. Lip sync is still screwed as much as it was before. Quite a down is also not having multiplayer and some players have experienced the issue of missing some side missions too.
Now to add some ups of this game, I think they also improved lots of stuff and the first thing is definitely environment. You can indeed notice the difference in textures, shading and lightning of the buildings. The parkour is also very enjoyable, the animations are smooth, they made controls easier so now you can free run with only Shift and it brings the old good feeling of an Assassin's Creed game of course. They also added some new sounds, there are more animals, although I haven't really noticed that the cities became more crowded. As much as I remember they still remain the same, but almost nobody cares about this feature anyway. The less tackling the better. The really good thing is that they added more legacy outfits which is amazing but Alexios's outfit doesn't really suit Connor, it is quite bad. The gameplay atmosphere also became "happier". The nature really looks beautiful and you will indeed enjoy while playing those Homestead Missions once again. 

They also changed icons from white to yellow and the old white loading screen which was probably giving you flashbacks all the time is now changed too and they put black instead.

Overall I think this game could have been made better, maybe more friendly with every hardware, every software, they could have perhaps taken more time to do characters properly, but I had a bit of a fun to play as the true Assassin once again, in higher resolution of course, and I loved that they added more legacy outfits. Do I recommend this game tho? I can't tell. My feelings for recommendation are mixed. Read the rest of the reviews and see for yourself.

I played through the Altair/Ezio games in the past and quite enjoyed them, so when I saw an offer on the AC3 remaster, I thought why not give it a try?  Well, so far in terms of gameplay I feel rather let down.  The controls feel clunky and some of the combat has quick-time events that feel unnecessary.  At points the game will show combat tips which often vanish before you have time to read the full message.

Perhaps the most frustrating part is that after getting past the very linear first part of the game and finally feeling like I have more freedom to explore, the game introduced a new feature in the way of crafting through the ledger system, which is massively bugged and has managed to glitch to the point where I cannot open the ledger without my controls completely locking up.  And because of the auto-save system that the game relies on, I don't have the option of reverting to a previous save.  Some quick Googling for potential fixes and it turns out this bug has been a known issue ever since the original release of the game back in 2012; they've had years to fix a game breaking bug and done nothing?  A disappointing effort all around.

I wish I could comment on whether the plot is any good, but given that my current choices are either repeat five chapters and hope I can get around the bug the second time around or attempt the rest of the story knowing that a major aspect of gameplay is unavailable to me, I'm struggling to find the motivation to continue.

Overview

This is a decent game which brought a lot of new things to the series. It's just a shame this one was where the story really fell apart. 

Note: I'm mainly reviewing the original here, not the remastered version, since you can't even buy the original one anymore, it felt pointless to do it there. I have played the remastered one and it was fine I think, didn't notice that much of a difference to be honest. I don't remember that many glitches.

Gameplay

The gameplay is solid. Cool combat, stealth and exploration. This game also introduced the naval gameplay which has since become a staple of the series. No complaints here.

Story

Why wasn't this Desmond's game? The overarching plot of the previous 4 games was so clearly leading to that but then they just decide to go with a brand new time period and a new ancestor at the last minute right before the climax? Huh? I mean there's nothing wrong with that inherently, it just made so little sense narratively. I get they were looking for the vault and all that but why? Why couldn't they just have had this set in the modern day, maybe with a few past segments here and there? That would have been so much cooler and a much more satisfying conclusion to Desmond's story in my opinion. 

Or they could have even continued his story in the modern day and split the series in two with this one: One like watchdogs for the modern day story and one for the genetic memory, treasure hunt through time stuff. Two series out of one. That would have been cool.

-SPOILER-

But no, all that build up just to have Desmond touch an orb and die. What.

-END OF SPOILER-

I actually liked Haytham though, he was cool.

Conclusion

Gameplay is solid, story is not. Still worth a play. 6/10.

I want to preface this review by saying that I love Assassin's Creed. I've been playing since AC2 released and have played almost every single game since then. And I loved Assassin's Creed 3 when it first came out. Ratonhnhaké:ton is one of my favorite assassins, if not the best in my opinion. His character and the story he goes on really gripped me. And I felt like if the original game was given more time in between story beats to develop, it could have been a fantastic game.

But this is about the Remastered Edition. And I can say with complete confidence that you should not buy this game. The graphics are barely better than they were in the original. Given that its suppose to be a "remaster," it is unbelievable how many bugs there still are. Voice lines will overlap, subtitles will not play at the right times that the dialogue does, animations in cutscenes are sometimes bugged to make characters stiff and motionless, enemies will get stuck in areas you can't kill them, and the parkour and gameplay can be so janky at times. This remaster is a fucking mess and a half. Do not buy it. If you received it for free with Origins or something, play it. If you loved Connor like I did, you will find it bearable for him. Otherwise, don't. This is honestly such a disappointment.

Altough the story is VERY interesting.. The controls SVCK! Like.. For me the controls make the game really boring and really hard to play. I've play almost the entire Ac saga (except for Valhalla) and this game AC3 is the biggest dissappointment for me.

I didn't have any game-breaking bugs or glitches that made me restart several times. However, this game feels really boring to play. I played through all the story missions and could barely remember what happened. I did like the Tyranny of King Washington DLC though. That campaign was hella dope to play even though it was only 5 hours long

Buy it as a bundle with Odyssey. 

Assassins Creed III: Why do people hate this game again? Oh right! I totally forgot about the tutorial that literally lasts half the campaign (or more?). I actually enjoy the first three sequences, but then it just keeps going on and on and on... The map IS fun to clear, though, once everything really does open up. The story is good. Not great, but good with some memorial moments. The combat is enjoyable, especially the naval mini game. 

Liberation: Take it for what it is. A minor title in the series without a ton of time put into it. You can really see how many corners they cut when you get to the horribly designed bayou. The combat is still fun, and the story seems to be ok. The "persona" mechanic is interesting, in that it's probably the most realistic way that Assassins would navigate the world. Makes me wonder why future titles didn't develop on it more.
Ngl something about the way it looks just seems... off...
Builds off of Assassin's Creed II and friends with nice visuals, solid narrative and additional gameplay features. I'm really enjoying it.

Like, this isn't even worth being a bonus for getting the collectors edition of Origins. The character model textures are somehow worse than the original game. All in all, I don't want to be an Assassin, Baby!
Oh also the ending is abrupt as all hell, like, really not worth playing whatsoever.

This game is so poorly done I could not recommend it for free! There seems to be a poorly done AI aim assist that causes half your attacks to miss, even if you buy both arrow and pistol ammo no control on a gamepad lets you change between them (picking up a rifle will let you use pistol ammo). Ranged weapons seem to miss at least 1/2 the time for no reason even if you hover the cursor on target out of combat. I also noticed I cannot access the assassin's tomahawk that claims to be in inventory, but one of the enemies around Conner has no problem clubbing Conner with it as they always seem to have it instead.

I quit this game after 23 hours of trying to push through. About the only fun part of the game was the ship battle after picking up the cannons. I hope the other Assassin's Creed games are made better, if this is what I based them on, I would avoid them and play Skyrim for the 20+th time instead.

Well, where to start. I genuinely liked AC 3, back in 2012, although it received a lot of negative comments.

Remaster was something, I was looking for, to see the game in a new coat, with improved quality of life, addressed problems from 2012 release et cetera.

Boy, if I was mistaken with my expectations. If I wanted to point out every single bug, every single glitch which made me restart the game, I could write a thesis. Lets point out a few, that were annoying as hell.

Audio glitch - Damn, that was something extra. At one point of the game, I had three different soundtracks playing at the same time. When I was checking if it can be fixed, all Ubisoft did about it was telling the players "restart their games". Lovely.

Missing NPCs - Nothing makes the game better than crucial NPC just disappearing from the game. (probably couldn't stand the Bugmaster either). 

More invisible walls - YAY! Riding a horse on the road and all of a sudden can't move, cause some force throw an invisible wall in front of me with size of the whole road and something extra.

"Little things" that should have some honorable mentions. 

1. Original AC3 problems didn't get addressed (of course). Taking a quest from an NPC, markers did not appear, had to re-save the game and wait till the NPC shows up again, that's some good old AC3 problem.

2. NPCs stuck in objects, preventing me from finish objectives, like liberating people from convoys et cetera (TOKW)

3. Try to corner-kill as little enemies as possible, especially if there is a chest ;) ... Sometimes they don't die, they just pretend they are dead, getting alarmed by your pressence and you can't do a thing about it except ... restarting the game, so you can approach it differently and open it.

All in all huge disappointment, if you got this game with Origins (I think it was that special offer) and have nerves of steel, go and give it a shot, it has it's positive side... sort of. If you didn't get it, stay the hell away from it, especially if it has 40€ price tag on it, definitely not worth that price.

A serious step back in the Franchise. It's good to make changes between installments but Ubisoft overstepped. Plot itself maybe 10 hours long which is around on par with the other games, but the scavenger hunt aspects have been ramped up through the roof. Wherein the other installments would have one or two things to hunt for with these objects being within a dozen or two items ACIII has over a hundred or so things to scavenger hunt. But I can forgive that it's the backbone of Ubisoft games. What I can't forgive is the how they radically changed the controls that stayed the same for ACI, ACII, ACR, and ACB. Also the voice actor for the main character sounds like he couldn't be bothered to actually put effort into his lines. Also other things that I like to complain about in this game is the facial animations and random animation mishaps. Its mostly because this is clearly a remaster for the console but the animal's and NPC's just bug out and get stuck in walls and so forth. uhhhhhhh yeah other parts of the game are pretty bad but thats all that comes to mind at the moment.


That being said there is the ship mini-missions / mini-campaign that don't have any bearing on the plot, but is the basis for ACIV, the best game in the franchise.

Maybe not quite as coherent a package as AC2 or Brotherhood, the game makes up for this in its sweeping northern american natural setting, a decent storyline and a fantastic new naval combat system. Conor is the dullest protagonist so far, but the Desmon storyline holds up better in this game than in others. The DLC were my least favourite yet (with part 1 being all out boring) but with Liberation bundled in here too and for the prices it's going for now, this is a no-brainer of a buy

Assassins Creed III Remastered is not a remaster. To be honest, the experience of playing this game was about the same as playing it on the Xbox 360 7 years ago. For me, this was exactly what I wanted. Assassin's Creed III Remastered took me back in time to those cold, snowy days in early 2014. 
The game play is nothing to write home about because it is not drastically different than the rest of the early Assassin's Creed games. If you liked the game play of any of those, then you will like the game play of this.
One more thing of note is that I played this game with the Japanese voices to get a slightly different experience than when I played it originally and I have to say, like most things the Japanese do, they did a great job with the voices.
Experiencing the story of Haytham and Connor, and the bigger plot of the first few Assassin's Creed games, is something that I will treasure for the rest of my life. If you played AC3 back in the day, and even if you didn't, I would seriously recommend picking this game up when it is on sale.

Basically just a high rez texture pack AC3.  I got this with AC:Odysee (which you have to download, install and launch before you get access to this because the free AC3 remaster key is linked to that game) and played it because I never got into it on the Xbox 360 and skipped it 2 missions in as Haytham, so I wanted to give it a go.  

Not a bad game, but Jesus there are some ANNOYING bugs, especially with map markers just not showing up in the two main cities for liberation missions and THE LEGWORK that just inflates your play time.  I got about 55-60 hours out of this doing every mission, nabbing every collectible, all upgrades, homestead things, the ship things, I would say a good 5 hours were just uncovering the maps and getting to things.

Personally, I would pick this up on its own for $10-20 knowing how much of my time it ate up, note the wording there.  There are things they could have tweaked to make the game so much more fun, like Sync point ranges, how much of the map you uncover by walking around (yeah there is no district by district map reveal in this), giving you access to the fast travel network in-city WAY damn earlier, especially the second city (Jesus that was bad, I got it at about the last mission after chasing down every collectible, do not know if you can get it earlier)

TL;DR $20 tops, lotta filler good story but we know how it has to end.

Given that I played this entry in the series fairly recently, when the remaster was first released on PS4, I was happy to play it again. When it comes down to it, this is one of my favorite games in the AC series because of the wide range of environment. That being said, the story is incredibly lackluster, feeling more like a weird interactive PBS kids special than a fun game. There are elements that are interesting, but overall it's a stale story. The conclusion of Desmond's participation in the overarching story isn't as fantastic as you'd hope for someone you spent the last five games playing as. The gameplay itself suffered in some weird ways. I didn't get a lot of the Homestead missions until after the story, at which point it felt like I was rushing through something that was supposed to take a longer period of time to do. 

Connor is a stiff character that doesn't really exhibit any personality. In some games, this kind of protagonist is great because you can mentally insert yourself a bit more. But following a protagonist as charismatic as Ezio, it's a disappointing change. Achilles is the highlight of the story, with regards to characters, though the inhabitants of the Homestead are also pretty interesting and fun. 

As with the previous entries, I wouldn't skip this one if you enjoy the overall story of the series. But if you're not a fan of American history or want a more interesting main character, you're probably safe to skip this one.

I don't understand the mixed reviews. They upgraded the minimap markers for example and now you can aim freely with your weapons, and you don't have to lock on a target like in the original. The game looks better and they improved the combat system a little bit because now you can perform a double assassination while running. If you liked the original Assassin's Creed III then you will like this one even more. Simple as that.

Stealth is buggy making some of the full completion stealth portions nearly impossible. I uninstalled on the ship boarding mission after I could not stealth kill the boat full of people after hours and dozens of attempts. Guys will spot you through this ship, down in the water, from the other end of the ship, up in the rafters, through crates, whatever. Its nuts.
Great game for everyone who loves history and videogames! Not quite as good as Assassin's Creed II but still very fun.

Despite a few highlights, I still feel like I wasted my time playing it. Too many poorly zoned/plotted missions. It's in the uncomfortable spot between a game like Fallout 3/4 (where everything is tagged or easily located on a map, and you can fast travel easily to almost everywhere) and a more prescriptive game like Prince of Persia.

Game received free with Odyssey. I own but never played the original. Performs perfectly on Arch linux with GE Proton.

So this game is, essentially, a series of mini-games. Each mini-game has two Success states: Perfect & Imperfect, based on how well you manage the optional goals. You can Fail, in which case you simply restart the mini-game. Nail all Optionals and you get Full Synchronisation. Nailing some of them appears identical to doing none. I have, frankly, no idea what the difference is in terms of 'rewards' for achieving perfect sync, other than some in-game cosmetics. I'm playing as Total Psycho, killing freely and not caring *at all* about Optionals. I've managed some parts perfectly by pure luck. I'm zipping through the game with no obvious issues. I consider this ideal, since I'm playing purely to catch up on the series.

Closing note: We, gamers, need to have a serious chat with game developers about *incredibly annoying* final sequences. The kind of thing where you're stripped of abilities and have instant-fail mechanics, and have to redo the entire sequence if you make a single mistake. This game has one of those endings (two, really), where they 'ramp up the tension' by just making the game suck. This is not cool or fun. It actually kills otherwise amazing experiences. If the only way you can make an ending 'dramatic' is by butchering everything you've managed up to that point, you really need to get another job.

The person who decided the run and climb button should be the same one should have been hired, fired, and hired and fired a second time because a single firing isn't enough for this pants on head stupid decision.

The linearity of this missions with automatic fails for getting spotted 2 seconds in or other stupid things, and the hidden secondary objectives that you cant see until you reach a checkpoint past them and fail them also suck.  The secondary missions and collectibles are the most fun part of the game.

Overall score:  Meh.  Control score: ridiculous.
There are a lot of glitches, but it's still a fun game and a nice story

There are multiple aspects to consider when deciding to recommend this game. One is the game itself of course, while the other is the "Remastered" part. As a remaster, this is very disappointing and improvements are slim to none (at least on PC). In fact because the lighting is heavily altered in this remaster, certain cutscenes will have character models looking much worse than they did in the original purely because of unintended lighting effects on characters' faces and such. This "remaster" on PC is essentially just slightly improved render distance and UI elements.

Remaster aside, Assassin's Creed III on its own is mostly mediocre. If you've played 1 through Revelations and you're invested in the story at this point, I recommend this game to at the very least see the continuation of those stories (at least for modern day and First Civilization storylines).

That being said, this is potentially one of the weakest entries in the series. Unlikable protagonist and mentor, largely forgettable cast of side characters, a setting that is not well-suited for the free-running gameplay, lifeless and uninteresting side content. The modern day story has some interesting missions you play as Desmond, but the ending was so awful that modern day has never been able to recover since. The only saving grace I could find was Haytham Kenway, who not only breathes much needed perspective on the Templar Order, but also ends up being one of the most compelling antagonists in the series. The story overall has a few highlights, but is ends up falling flat.

Free-running has been fully re-worked from the previous games thanks to the new engine, and the animations have been drastically improved. This allowed parkour on more complex architecture, including trees in the wilderness, as well as more fluid movement. Unfortunately the aforementioned issue with the setting has led to this new parkour system being largely wasted. Previous entries would occasionally have the player perform certain inputs in order to do more complex moves such as side-ejects, climb leaps, etc. or the buildings would sometimes require the player to plan the right path in order to climb it. Both of these aspects of parkour have been largely removed, and now almost all climbing is simply holding RT and forward. While it is prettier to look at now, it feels shallow and boring to play.

Combat has been more or less improved from the Ezio trilogy. Although countering is still the most viable combat option, you will now have to use other combat options as well since any non-basic enemies will be invulnerable to this move. Guns are pretty prominent in this period, you will see them quite a bit in combat and either have to use someone as a human shield or run away in time before getting shot. The new engine has improved animations in this area as well and overall the combat is not only the most satisfying visually, but the most complex (so far).

Overall, while the game is certainly not bad, it fails to be great in any aspect. I recommend purely for people already invested in the franchise as a whole... otherwise the Ezio Trilogy and Black Flag are perfectly fine to play on their own.

Sadly, this game has stability issues. I really loved AC3, as it was my first AC game and thus made me a fan of the series (I own all games in the franchise, even the Chronicles/2.5D ones), but I get frequent frame drops to zero about once a minute (or even more often, depending on background apps and for some weird reason, whether the controller is connected seems to make a difference to the frequency in which the issue appears).
I wrote to Ubisoft and provided them with numerous files (from system config files to images of resource usage and a video of the issue), but they couldn't suggest any solutions.
Unfortunately, I have read forum posts on other sites where people with computers way faster than mine (see my profile for my specs) - including some using new Intel CPUs and Nvidia GeForce 2080 GPUs - are having the same issues, so it's obviously not an AMD-related problem. Thus, as much as I love this game, given how badly the remaster was mishandled/botched I would recommend trying to get a steam key for the original version instead (some resellers like Kinguin still offer legit steam keys for the original game, even though it's no longer officially sold on Steam).

Not only the most undeserving remaster in the history of gaming but also probably the worst remaster. I use the word undeserving because, arguably, Assassin's Creed III is the worst entry into the main series, and the game itself is less than a decade old.

On top of this, the "remaster" is a complete misnomer. The new lighting often makes the cutscenes look worse, the environmental textures are not improved as far as I can tell and the game still feels like it came out in 2012. Not only is the "remaster" graphically unimpressive but it is also a technical mess with many of the bugs and glitches from it's original release coming along into the "remaster" and in some cases they feel as if they have been amplified.

It is a real shame that something this awful has replaced the original title on the Steam Store.

Poorly optimized, particularly for a game of its era.

Ludicrous bugs that have yet to be addressed (infinitely spawning guards, objectives failing at random, glitching models notably when falling, environmental clipping errors, NPCs that sporadically disappear, etc) despite the years and the so-called "remaster."

A central protagonist with all the charisma of a rock and a voice actor that does his utmost to impersonate one.

Abysmal attempt at recreating the period, with inaccurate attire, weaponry, social structures (including racial and gender representations that would lead you to believe two-thirds of colonial America was comprised of free blacks and women) that make a mockery of American history for the sake of appeasing contemporary mores.

The "hunting" feature is entirely superfluous and objectively baffling: animals spawn atop one another, bears move in packs (I slaughtered sixteen in a single wooded grove... bears, the enormous terrestrial predators that are notoriously solitary) while wolf packs are seldom more than three wolves.

The less said about the addition of quicktime events the better. Courtesy of such, a single wolf is a more significant threat than an entire squad of men with rifles.

Counters no longer reliably lead to a kill. More often than not, Conner will simply toss the offending soldier aside, rather than kill them outright even when wielding the hidden blades (unlike Altair and Ezio who were both consummate fighters). It conveys a radical and unwarranted sense of pacifism on his part, completely out of touch with his in-game character, as he's seemingly desperate to avoid harming anyone while unnecessarily prolonging the fights.

The notoriety system is COMPLETELY broken.
Engage in "open conflict" with a guard, even if it's a single person in a back alley with no witnesses: it will contribute to your notoriety. Kill some in the woods near a rural area: the guards in the city know and are on alert. Posters to remove your notoriety infrequently appear and demand you be "anonymous" to interact... because heaven forbid you tear a poster down in the midst of a fight? Kill a single guard, climb a building and watch as every road is suddenly filled with guards, whose floating GUI blips appear to indicate they're unaware of your location... yet they're all facing you and lined up to block the roads.

Worse yet: reach three stars and the guards begin spawning infinitely.
Right in front of you. Literal nine man squads materialize out of the void.

It's like TES:Oblivion with telepathically linked, teleporting law enforcement and every bit as tedious.

I should caveat my recommendation. Of all the Assassin Creed games, this is probably the most controversial in terms of game play/story. If you decide to pass on it, I don't blame you. But if you're going to play it, play it remastered (And if you want it, I picked this up bundled with AC Odyssey DLC and recommend you do the same). I did a side-by-side with the Xbox 360 version and there is no comparison. Going from 720p 30fps to 1080p/4K 60fps with enhanced graphics makes this decade old game look and feel smooth. And you'll need that smoothness to get past the clunky mechanics.

A good remaster, considering the original product, and one more step to keeping your early 2010s library relevant.
The remastered edition not only pimps the graphics, but also optimizes some gameplay features. The real problem remains the lousy upgrade scheme.

The only thing that was good in this game is the graphics. The Connor plot is acceptable, but the Desmond plot is woeful; it really feels like the producers were short of ideas and time and made content to fill up. So as an advice, don't bother finishing the game after Connor buries the amulet; the rest, including the epilogue is a waste of time. Still on the contents, the side missions are pretty irrelevant as you do not need any of them to complete the game. There is no clear indication of how the controls work, and having finished the game I'm still unsure of how to fast-travel for example. Several signs and changes in colour or appearance are also unexplained. In conclusion, not a great game! I bought Odyssey as a package deal, and I hope it will be better, failing which that will be the worst Steam buy of the year :(
