This is not a remaster of Assassin's Creed III, This is the same Assassin's Creed III you played on your Xbox 360, 9 years ago, but this time the game is layered in auditory bugs, the faces of all the characters are completely shaded out, and you have to pay $40 for it. I thought when I first bought it that the overall rating score on this game was a bit exaggerated. It looks nice and the story was interesting. But oh boy, that mixed score was well earned. Maybe even a bit generous. This game is by far the worst Assassin's Creed I've played. Half the time the buttons don't respond, and when they do it doesn't help cause you've been screwed over six times already. When I have to restart a segment of a memory 10 times because the game refused to running assassinate even when I held the buttons to do so, then I think it's safe to say someone needs to check the code again. And while you're in there, you should also fix how much you're telling the player. This game has a chronic problem with telling the player either too much or too little. The game will lock the camera into certain positions to try and show you where to climb to. Not a bad idea with esoteric level designs like on a cliff face, but I think I can figure out that the obviously climbable wooden planks are climbable. And how about when the game says to kill someone before they reach a location? Okay simple enough the game was telling me to chase him, there will obviously be a place for me to use my hidden blades to kill him. Nope. He stays just out of reach and you don't know until it's too late. And by god, who was bug fixing because they clearly slacked. Try and kill an animal above, have fun falling through the floor. Want to complete liberation missions, this one will inexplicably disappear from the map forcing you to wander around until you can find it again. I would also like to remind everyone that this is the REMASTER. I shudder to think what the original was like. In short, fix this broken car before it crashes and burns.

This is a time when I wish that Steam had a 'neutral' review option - there's definitely both pros and cons, so read on to see why I've gone for the 'negative' rating.

As this is a remaster of the original AC III, the storyline and gameplay are essentially unchanged, apart from minor improvements such as being able to double-assassinate more easily and an upgraded minimap. One note here, though: after playing Origins and Odyssey, the combat and control fluidity definitely feel a bit primitive, so do be warned of that.

The biggest upside is naturally the graphical quality; almost all textures in the environment have been brought up to newer standards. Despite this, it appears that very little has been done to improve the character models - faces in particular are laughably unrealistic and the game still very much shows its age in this regard.

Overall opinion: This is a fairly good remaster of AC III in terms of some graphical and gameplay quality-of-life enhancements, but also comes up short in some areas. I've given it the 'negative' review because of the simple fact that this product, as a standalone, is certainly not worth the $40 price, though as part of the AC Odyssey season pass, I would say that it's a nice benefit.

[b]Final rating: 5.25/10 -- Neutral, but not recommended due to price[/b]

“Mother. Father. I am sorry. I have failed you both. I made a promise to protect our people, Mother. I thought if I could stop the Templars, If I could keep the revolution free from their influence, then those I supported would do what was right. They did, I suppose, do what was right - what was right for them. As for you, Father, I thought I might unite us, that we would forget the past and forge a better future. In time, I believed you could be made to see the world as I do - to understand. But it was just a dream. This, too, I should have known. Were we not meant to live in peace, then? Is that it? Are we born to argue? To fight?
So many voices - each demanding something else.
"It has been hard at times, but never harder than today. To see all I worked for perverted, discarded, forgotten. You would say I have described the whole of history, Father. Are you smiling, then? Hoping I might speak the words you long to hear? To validate you? To say that all along you were right? I will not. Even now, faced as I am with the truth of your cold words, I refuse. Because I believe things can still change.
"I may never succeed. The Assassins may struggle another thousand years in vain. But we will not stop."
"Compromise. That's what everyone has insisted on. And so I have learnt it. But differently than most, I think. I realize now that it will take time, that the road ahead is long and shrouded in darkness. It is a road which will not always take me where I wish to go - and I doubt I will live to see it end. But I will travel down it nonetheless."
"For at my side walks hope. In the face of all that insists I turn back, I carry on: this, this is my compromise.” 

~ Ratonhnhaké:ton (Connor Kenway)

In AC3, the main story severely lack the feeling of an assassin and not so open. Usually, it has only a few options (or only one way) to finish the main objective, not to mention the side objectives (which point out to only specific moves). The objectives are also annoying as they are shown while the mission runs and you may not have time to carefully read what you have to do. And yes, in many occasions they are fights against the time. The spawn point is another annoying flaw; sometimes the game loads on an open ground where guards are going to start a conflict in a second, while I couldn't even recognize the environment. Connor can better be a postman, a merchant, a sailor or even a commander, but less being a real assassin if you don't spend time walking around the city and try to find someone to kill. Connor often forces himself into an open conflict by the story - so, would be better described as a furious warrior. I understand that the devs try to be more creative and introduce various things to play, but I think the main concept of being an assassin is degraded. There are lots of tools for assassination but only a few occasions to really use it, again if you don't try to find a random kill. Guards are always present in a large group or adjacent to each other, despite lack of crowd-control tools to use so, usually end up an open conflict. Also lots of guards are not shown on the mini-map or even show up from nowhere (not sure it's a bug or intentionally make it more difficult). The story it self is insensible in many points. [spoiler] Once, it said the British army was marching to lay siege on New York, the Patriot's HQ; but what I really found was New York full of British guards and flags - so, they were attacking their own city? Another point, Connor walked towards his life-long target and several guards only to say 'Hi, I come to kill you' and let him get away. He can kill dozens of guards in combat, but easily got caught by a few weaklings, unable to resist!!! [/spoiler] The graphics of city areas are magnificent, but the Frontier (forests and mountains) is not impressive - I thought the beauty of American nature was the highlight of this game. The TKW DLC is far better than the main story, offering a super hero version of Connor and more a deadly assassin with all-new play tactics - though other flaws are still present. Lots of promoting media show Connor fighting in a battlefield - the game really far from that.

For Liberation, the game is quit short and fewer elements to play with. However, it gave me more sense of assassin than AC3. The multi-persona theme is interesting and the maps look better though with some compromised graphics. Most elements in the game are too straight-forward and almost no alternative options are present for each mission, just follow the guide. I feel the story more sensible than AC3 though not as interesting as other ACs. If you accept Liberation as a compact AC side-game, I would say it fulfills its job.
Really like the whole storyline of the game and the way it's build up. Kind of sad that i can't manually crouch nor hide behind a wall though.

Out of all of the Assassin's Creed games I have played so far, this game is easily the most accurate to the historic setting it takes place in. The mechanics and combat received a fairly good improvement from Revelations, although the story does lack in some aspects. Connor does not feel as interesting as an Edward Kenway or Ezio Auditore but his life is still interesting to follow in the American Revolution. As for the out of world things; it is an aspect of the series I personally really enjoy, however in this one it really comes up short. Some of the missions throughout the game are really cool and fun to do as you play essentially a modern day AC game, but the ending (which I will not spoil) was very lack luster in my opinion and a poor way to cap of the Desmond story line. Overall though, if you like the American Revolution as a historic era and generally enjoy the concept of an AC game, you will like this game, and I would recommend it.

[h1] Assassin's Creed III Remastered [/h1]
Assassin's Creed 3 is a mayor improvement from Assassin's Creed Revelations and earlier titles when comparing in terms of graphics, map, combat system, parkour and other game mechanics in my opinion. It's important to separate what was already featured in the original Assassin's Creed 3 and the remastered. In both versions the graphics are a clear big improvement where the remastered is somewhat better. In comparison with the Ezio games, the total of size of the games maps is also bigger than any other. The kill animations are more brutal and the combat is far better. The game features assassinations with other weapons than the hidden blade, fully developed gun aim and control plus bow and arrow, fast travel from anywhere, mini games (board games), big naval combat and missions and animal hunting. 

The story is rather different from earlier games as you start with playing as Haytham Kenway but then play as Connor who is on a quest for revenge and change in the colonies. Unlike the last game where the map was only to be revealed by synchronizing on various point, this game take the concept where you ha to fill the map by walking through it with the help of some synchronizing points. I am personally not fully a fan of this as it take a lot of time to reveal the whole map since the radius of uncovering is rather small compared with the size of the maps. Then there are many side quest like "The Common Man" or frontier quest that makes 100% completion a bit dragged out. Now, the remastered wouldn't be such a problem if it weren't for some bugs which makes playing the games at times frustrating. Such as the freezing/stuttering bug that would show up from the start to about 15 hours playtime. But with the fact that the game comes with Assassin's Creed Odyssey I can see past most of the negative experience. 

7/10

[h1] DLC: The Tyranny of King Washington [/h1]
The Tyranny of King Washington DLC on the other hand is honestly just unnecessary. It basically tells of a what if scenario that reuses previous map and adds a few new missions. Thankfully the DLC comes fully in the game the DLC has no real impact on canon. In the DLC you get to have 3 types of superpowers which I think was rather unfitting for this game. Also the DLC isn't bug free either which makes it less appealing to play. 

5/10

[h1] Assassin's Creed Liberation REMASTERED [/h1]
This game is quite familiar to Assassin's Creed 3 in aspect of graphics, game mechanics and bugs. The storyline is somewhat short but honestly I think that is perfect as some games need to be shorter than others to make the longer games better. Also with the smaller map, a shorter story fits better. The game features a new interning mechanic where the player can switch between different personas, "The Assassin", "The Lady" (civilian) and "The Slave" (something more in the middle), who have then has specific missions to said personas. Another new feature is chain-kill, which allowed Aveline to take out multiple opponents during combat which can speed combat up somewhat. My major problem with this game is first the need to walk around the map to uncover the map like Assassin's Creed 3. The second major problem is the smuggler bug which makes the player unable to finish a specific mission even though the mission wont effect 100% sync or achievements. But with the fact that the game comes with Assassin's Creed Odyssey I can see past most of the negative experience.  

6.5/10

Assassin's Creed III:
I will reviewing this game as a whole, not just the remaster.
Assassin's Creed III was the first I played in the series, and therefore I kind of hold it above the rest. It is my favorite in the series, and while it has its issues, there is plenty to love. I 100%ed the game on the Xbox 360.
The story is pretty good, taking place during the American Revolution. While the main story can kinda be seen as a revenge story, I think there's enough twists and interesting moments to keep it interesting. Besides, revenge can be a great motivation for a story all on its own. The graphics look pretty decent, especially the lighting. The faces can look a little clay-like, but I feel like that's pretty common for games that came out around the same time (the remaster did help quite a bit, in my opinion.)
The gameplay is excellent. The combat is different from the previous games, and I don't think the change is good or bad. It's just different, and I like it. It reminds me of games like Shadow of Mordor or the Batman Arkham series, but is still unique enough to be its own system. There's also plenty of sneaking and assassinating, and there are also naval missions. If you've played Black Flag or Rogue before, they're not too special, but if this is your first time hitting the seas in an Assassin's Creed game, it's great fun! Free running has also been reworked, and this is something that I have mixed feelings on. When it works, and Connor (your character) does what you want, it feels great. But it can become pretty frustrating pretty fast. Sometimes I feel like I have less control than I did with Ezio in the previous games, and sometimes I feel like I'm a hardcore parkour king. It really just takes patience and practice.
There are some downsides. Probably the most frustrating thing that I ran into was that my horse kept getting stuck on random bits of terrain. I know that sounds like a silly complaint, but it's pretty annoying when you're trying to chase someone down and your horse gets stuck on a tree. Another thing that can be bothersome is if you try to 100% the game, the optional side objectives are a nightmare. Back on the Xbox 360, I did get 100% synchronization, and on some of the levels, it just isn't fun. That's why if you're on your first playthrough, I'd recommend ignoring them or only doing the easier ones, because restarting all the time to try to get the optional objectives can be really frustrating and destroy the pacing and fun of the missions.
Overall though, this is a wonderful game. I would definitely recommend it to fans of 3rd person action/adventure games and of course to AC fans. It's different enough from the previous titles but still retains the AC feel.

Assassin's Creed: Liberation
This game also comes with AC: Liberation, which is a remaster of the PS Vita game. While many don't consider it to be a mainline game, I definitely think it's worth a playthrough. The gameplay will feel very familiar after having played AC 3, and while there are no naval missions, the gameplay that is on offer is still excellent and varied. A new mechanic that's introduced is the persona system, where you can change your outfit depending on the situation you're going into. If you need to do some fighting, best to go in your Assassin gear. If you need to do some blending in, dress as a lady and wander the streets charming all the men in town. If you need to blend in with the crowd, but still be able to get dirty if you need to, then you can dress up as a slave and blend in with the New Orleans population.
I actually like the story. It's very short, since this was originally a handheld game, however it gets right to the point and isn't bloated like a lot of games can end up being. The main character Aveline is an excellent character and I really got to like her by the end of the game.
Liberation, while short, is definitely worth a playthrough, even if it is just for the main story. You could honestly probably beat it in about 12 hours or less, depending on how quickly you go.

მოკლედ აშკარა განვითარებაა წინა ნაწილებთან შედარებით (რომლებიც ასევე 100%-ზე დავხურე), ყოველი თამაში რაღაც ახალს ამატებს და ეს ახალი ერთიან სამყაროს ქმნის, კარგია, კარგი.  მიუხედავად იმისა რომ ბოსტონმა და ნიუ იორკმა ისიე არ მიმზიდა როგორც ფლორენციამ და რომმა წინა ნაწილებში მაინც ვნახე ჩემი მყუდრო ადგილი დავენპოროტში. დავენპორტის ელემენტი გენიალურია, პატარა დასახლება რომელსაც შენ აფართოვებ ნელ ნელა და პლუს ვაჭრობა და ხელსაქმე. საზღვაოსნო ელემენტი აშკარა პროტოტიპია რაც შემდეგ ნაწილში როგორც ვიცი ბევრად უფრო დახვეწილია. საბოლოო ჯამშ მშვენიერია.
 მაგრამ... ახლა ნაკლები ჩამოვთვალოთ, პირველი რაც ძალიან ცუდად მომხვდა გულზე არის 93%-ზე უსაშველოდ გაჭედვა. გემის მისია გაიბაგა და გემის გარეშე ვჩნდებოდი ზღვაში. ყველაფერი ვცადე, აბსოლუტურად ყველაფერი მაგრამ უშედეგოდ და შესაბამისად ახლიდან მომიხდა დაწყება. ნუ ყველაფერი ისევ 100% მინდოდა მარა ვერ მოგართვითო, 3 დელივერის მისია გაიბაგა და ვერ ვაბარებ ნივთებს. ამჯერად ახლიდან არ დავიწყებ 99% იყოს, თავში ქვა უხლიათ, საფორთს მივწერე. თუ მიშველიან კაი თუ არადა რომელიმე ნოსტალგიის შემოტევისას შეიძლება მივხედო. რუქის მართვაც საშინელი და საკმაოდ არაინტუიციურია, თამაშის შუის იქით ძლივს მივხვდი რა როგორ ხდება და პლუს ასასინების მართვის მენიუც, არა ეგ კიდე უფრო უარესია. ზოგიერთი არამთავარი მისიის დროს შენი მოტივაცია გაუგებარიია და ასასინები კიდე საერთოდ შემთხვევითი ტიპები არიან, ყველაზე არა საასასინე მატერიალი რაც კი მინახავს აქამდე. ერთი მომენტი კიდე არის ის რომ საიდან იცოდა *სპოილერები* კონორმა მამამისი ვინ იყო ან მამამისმა კონორი ვინ იყო წარმოდგენა არ მაქვს, ჰაითამს რომც ცოდნოდა ასასინები ჯერ კიდევ იყვნენ, ვერ ვხვდები საიდან იცოდა კონორის შესახებ. ხო კიდე, აქილევსის საწოლის სცენები საშინელებაა, რაღაც იაფფასიანი თამაში ხომ არ არის მოდელებზე და ანიმაციაზე რომ დაეზოგათ, საწოლში მაინც ჩაეწვინათ წესიერად და ზედ არ "დაედოთ". ლიბერაციაში ფილიპეს საბანი მაინც აქვს გადაფარებული ბოლო ბოლო (მაგრამ ეგეც ტანსაცმლიანი წევს). ახლა კი ლიბერაციაზე გადავიდეთ.
 ლიბერაცია არ ვიცი რატომ არის "დეგრადირებული" ფორმატის. მგონი ტაბლეტებზე იყო გამოსული და მაგიტომ. ნუ მიზეზი რაც არ უნდა იყოს, ბევრად უარესს მოოველოდი ამ წინასწარი ინფორმაცით მაგრამ საკმაოდ კარგი და დახვეწილი თამაშია. ბევრად უკეთესი ვაჭრობის სისტემა აქვს, ჩემი აზრით.  ბრძოლის და მექნაიკის მხრივ თითქმის იგივეა რაც მესამე, ოღონდ მცირე მასშტაბებში.  ერთადერთ რაც სულით მძულს არის კანოეები, სატანის მოგონილი მოწყობილობები. სხვა მხრივ ნორმალურია, პერსონის ელემენტიც ძალიან კარგად არის ჩასმული.

[h2] 7/10 [/h2]
Assassin’s Creed III is a game that has a good main story, great gameplay, and has plenty of optional side-missions. They’ve improved and trimmed the AC formula to make gameplay better (however still has that “AC quirk” from the preceding games). The game introduces a new world and characters; this may either feel like a slog or a joy, depending on the new colonial American skin it has put on. For me, it felt like a slog at the beginning, then joy crept-up as the story evolved. The story carried me to finishing this game together with naval combat (yes, it’s that good). As for Desmond’s, let’s say that segment is starting to get old and unnecessary.

NOTE:
For Steam, you need to buy Assassin's Creed Odyssey Gold or Ultimate edition to play. You need to download and play AC Odyssey first for the AC III license to activate

[url=https://martopad.medium.com/assassins-creed-iii-review-e583e0fdc1a9] For full review [/url]

Updated summary: I was going to just barrel through the main story to at least see the story to completion but this is NOT worth my time.  So-so gameplay and crap story plus numerous bugs?  I have better things to do with my time off.

Complaints in no particular order:

Says you only need an Ubisoft account but I had to install the Ubisoft U-play client.  Free-running (and in general the controls) are sometimes frustrating.  Menu interaction is not great a lot of the time and you have to move your hand off WASD or take your hand off the mouse.  Areas that seem like they're meant for climbing can't be climbed at all, but an area a few feet away is just fine.  Inventory management is unintuitive.  It does a poor job of helping you sometimes.  For example, both times I sent trade convoys they were attacked and it warns me that they were under attack but provided no info on how I might actually help defend them.  Other times it just doesn't explain things.  Liberation missions?  They're all over the map but what's the point really?  So blue-coat soldiers can attack you instead of red-coats?  Lots of crafting stuff is possible, it seems, but you'll amass a TON of recipes very early that are unusable because you don't have the materials and/or craftsmen.  Combat is okay but it's super annoying how troops sometimes seem to just continually spawn or warp in.  Combat on stairs is straight-up stupid.  Wasted a bunch of time collecting feathers then got curious about what the reward actually is... and it's a costume I have zero interest in ever using.  Makes me curious how many in-game objectives are basically only for completion's sake.

Lots of glitches / bugs in this game.  I've gotten stuck on terrain and had to fast-travel to get out of it.  I got sucked into a conversation once while the game continued on around me and I was beat to death while I listened to the NPC.  I had a fort captain disappear somehow and had to reset & clear the fort again.  Just now I quit because I didn't get credit for the story quest objective (kill a dude).  I've had a restricted area with no visible troops on the map or on my screen literally spawn a half-dozen soldiers once I stepped foot into the area.

It's not a horrible game but I wouldn't recommend PAYING for it, especially not for full price.  I got it as part of a bundle when I purchased AC: Odyssey.

Edit: One thing that really irritates me is how the game seems to randomly choke and stutter.  When it does this, the mouse input seems like it's multiplied.  A movement that might normally move the camera slightly instead swings it around wildly.

Edit 2: I am at the start of Sequence 8 (out of 12) and uninstalling this.  The story is trite and the cast seems to be comprised of a bunch of white pricks gas-lighting the PoC main character.  "I know I was just shooting cannons at everyone and trying to kill them but really what I wanted to do was TALK."  And we're supposed to accept it like the MC is just too hot under the collar?

The missions also have a lot of optional stuff that is just plain stupid -- like to get an air assassination off in an area that is basically flat land with no trees or buildings nearby.  I started doing homestead quests and then got bored of that.  The additional NPCs are boring as heck and I can't imagine the rewards are worthwhile.  It's just busy work to pad the play-time of the game.  Oh and the missions to level up your homestead is crap like, "Now that we've disabled the fast-travel points, please run across the map, then back across the map, now run across it again.  Okay last time!  Done!"  Who designed this garbage?

Ran into more bugs where I didn't get credit for a quest and needed to reload THREE times.  Wth?  Ran into another bug where the fast-travel menus just didn't work even though the feature was enabled at the time.

I was going to just barrel through the main story to at least see the story to completion but this is NOT worth my time.  So-so gameplay and crap story plus numerous bugs?  I have better things to do with my time off.

I seriously do not understand the hate towards this game.
I chose to play through every single Assassins Creed game, and while doing so I dreaded the moment where i'd have to choose between buying this remaster or somehow getting my hands on the original. I had heard so much complaints about this remaster that I went into the game expecting an absolute bore of a story and an abysmal excuse for a remaster.

Boy was I wrong, kinda

[u] Music [/u]
The Ezio trilogy is known to have some of the best music and soundtracks in the entire Franchise, but i swear to god when i first opened the game and heard that theme is was blown away. Sure, its nothing compared to "Earth" or "Ezios Family" but boy is it awesome. The only musical downside for me is that the game seems to play the same song every single chace sequence, or when you alert an enemy. Also [spoiler] The song used when Connor is forced to kill Haytham [/spoiler] is Amazing

[u] Characters [/u]
Not much to say, Desmond is the same old Desmond, Achilles is a stereotypical old/wise man, Haytham is a complete Badass, and Connor is a child all the way through (If you aren't considering the unused dialogue at the end of the game). I think they could have used [spoiler] Daniel Cross [/spoiler] more during the modern day sections, considering how important he is to the history of both the Assassins and Templars.


[u] Story [/u]
Definitely not as good as the trilogy preceding it, but watching Connor meet familiar faces and struggle to hunt the man he blames for the burning of the village is pretty cool. I think if they matured Connor more, the story would have benefited greatly. The twits regarding [spoiler] Washington and Connor [/spoiler] is kinda Eh, and they seem to drop it entirely and focus more on Lee.

[u] Graphics [/u]
Clay faces of not, this remaster is beautiful, you'll miss the enhancements if you move directly onto black flag or rogue.

If you want a (Somewhat) satisfying conclusion to Desmond's story, buy it. If you're skeptical and would rather the newer more refined games, wait for a sale and get Odyssey and its season pass

I got AC3 Remastered with AC Odyssey, and the game has 3 parts: the base game of AC3, the DLC for AC3, "Tyranny of King Washington," and AC Liberation.

Firstly, I quite like AC3. I haven't experienced the bugs and glitches to the extent that other reviews mention. In the 25 hours it took me to play, the game crashed one time and I only experienced a few bugs. The game was more stable than regular AC3 on my Xbox 360. While AC3 is one of my least favorite Assassin's Creeds, this is definitely the definitive version. One complaint about AC3 remastered is that while everything looks much better, everyone has that weird "playstation face." Everyone looks like their face is made of clay. I would give AC3 a 7.5/10 for the weak story and weak protagonist but good overall gameplay and sound.

Next, Tyranny of King Washington is very underwhelming. The reveal at the end is mildy interesting and it takes about 5.5 hours to finish, which is a good length for a DLC. However, the game is extremely frustrating at times. Unlike the game game, in TKW there's significant issues with locking on to targets and input seemingly not being received. Also, Connor will randomly stand in bushes while sneaking in the many instant-fail stealth missions. The game compensates for a lack of difficulty by putting an enormous number of enemies on every street corner. Fights aren't challenging, just long. 5.5/10.

Lastly, AC Liberation took a little over 9 hours to finish, having skipped some side quests. The game looks very impressive at times, especially in the Louisiana bayous. The story is very simple and easy to follow in the beginning, which is a nice change of pace for an AC game, however it becomes very convoluted and confusing in the last hour. The music is very hit or miss, with some songs being genuinely impressive and others sounding like they came straight out of a Mario game. In my opinion, ACL is one of the most underrated AC games and would definitely recommend buying AC3R just to play it, if you haven't already. Overall, 7/10.

Summary: 
Assassin's Creed III is probably the most underrated game in the AC franchise. It's certainly not perfect, but if you like the mechanics of AC2 - AC: Syndicate, have an interest in US Historical fiction, and/or don't mind the jank of this old engine, then you will likely enjoy it.

Context: 
I originally played this on PS3 on release, received this for free when buying AC: Odyssey, and decided to revisit it...

Pros:
Great Story - I personally liked the characters and story. The prologue is a legendary hook. The game has lots of shameless American History "fan service", but they do a good job of inserting Ratonhnhaké:ton (Conor) into a lot of historical events without it being too ridiculous (except the Tyranny of King Washington DLC, that timeline is straight-up nonsense).

Setting - Assassin's Creed games always nail the aesthetic of their setting, and this entry is no different. Wandering around the frontier, leaping through the trees, and exploring early American cities around New England is incredibly fun and feels authentic (though I'm no history buff). 

New Mechanics - The guns were implemented well. They don't feel OP like I feared. Most of this is due to the fact that guns in this time period were very cumbersome and are only really good for a quick shot or two. The tree climbing is fantastic and a welcome addition. The hunting is also surprisingly fun despite being simplistic. 

Cons:
Glitchy... oh so glitchy... - This game has glitches everywhere from objects behaving weirdly to quests straight up breaking because certain things didn't spawn in.  It's almost impossible to run across a city or complete a story mission without encountering a significant glitch. The physics are unpredictable, the combat is janky, and Ratonhnhaké:ton's model CONSTANTLY misinterprets and straight up ignores player inputs leading to fatal free-running mishaps and failed combat encounters. 

Difficulty - I've played every Assassin's Creed game and this one so far is the hardest one, for all the wrong reasons. Enemies are cheap, bonus objectives are actually impossible in many cases, and the constant glitches can sabotage a flawless execution. My advice is to ignore the bonus objectives all-together and just enjoy the story and exploring the world. 

Neutral:
The Remaster - Subjectively I like the new graphics. Some people don't like the lighting or character textures, but I found them to be good (not great). I played through this on PS3 originally, and the remaster on top of the PC upgrade made a huge difference for me. The remaster does seem half-assed, with a lot of models, textures, and lighting in areas being missed. It's certainly not worth paying for the remaster since it does not make this game seem next-gen, but if you don't already have the original on PC, it's a welcome upgrade.

Assassin's Creed 3 is a favorite of mine, but this remastered leaves much more to be desired. The good things they added to the remaster is improved graphics (supposedly), better UI with weapon statistics, etc., and better optimized for high end PCs. The real issues are the following: some lackluster detailing with written stuff in game, enemy AI prompts when they attack sometimes doesn't show up, unable to properly counter their attacks, and absurd optional objectives that're a lot harder to accomplish (some of them) than I could recall from the original AC 3 on XBOX. Overall, ONLY buy this game if you really want to. But only buy it when it's on sale. It's not worth the full price, even if it comes with the DLC and AC Liberation.

First of all, the remaster looks beautiful!

That's where the good stuff ends for me.

Gameplay is kinda okay, but it feels like a downgrade from Revelations. Kill animations are good, but the fights are very dull.

Story is probably the worst one I've ever played in a AAA title, definitely the worst in the AC series, for me at least.

Voice acting is laughable and audio mastering and the delay between a character saying something and somebody else reacting is pathetic.

A meh remaster of Assassin’s Creed III, which is already a meh game. It also includes a meh remaster of Assassin’s Creed Liberation HD, another meh game, that was originally released on the PlayStation Vita.
Assassin’s Creed III has a lot of scope and ambition, and while it feels like a true sequel to the Ezio trilogy, it fails to deliver in so many things. It does some things well. It has a fresh and bigger setting in Colonial America. It has 2 major cities, Boston and New York, and a big Frontier section to explore. It has a homestead that you gradually build and upgrade. Combat has slick animations, especially the double kills. It introduced the awesome naval battle mechanics that made Black Flag so successful. The soundtrack is good. The assassins that you can recruit are no longer generic, and while there are only 6, each is unique and has its own backstory. The story has a lot of teasing moments and explore the Templar side of things. It has tons of things to do for 100% completion.
However, it lacks in many things. The remaster itself is a bit ugly and removed some of the grey atmosphere of the original. Worse of all, it broke the combat counter mechanic. Lots of times the counter indicator comes too late or doesn’t appear at all, and that leads to frustrating combat, which is a core mechanic of the game. That didn’t happen on the original, but since I’m reviewing the remaster, this is a big minus. While the story and villains are interesting, the main assassin, Connor, is just uninteresting. Parkour was downgraded. The first quarter of the story feels like a long tutorial and features a better protagonist. Missions are scripted and rarely allow you some freedom. Plus, they have lots of dialogue in them. It concludes the Desmond storyline, and while the modern missions are not bad, they distract you from the main game.
It’s not a bad game, you can see it has a high production value, but lacks polish in some things. The remaster makes things worst, breaking combat which was one of the best parts of the game.  It also includes The Tyranny of King Washington DLC, which has a short but better story, and some new and cool mechanics. It has bad side content, but I really enjoyed it for the story.
About Assassin’s Creed Liberation HD, it’s what you expect from a watered-down portable version of Assassin’s Creed – a short and repetitive Assassin’s Creed. It has the first playable female assassin, but the story and characters are uninteresting. But it has surprisingly good combat for a handheld, almost as good as its big brother. And it has a cool swamp area, The Bayou, with tree climbing and canoe riding. Just think of Liberation as a standalone expansion for Assassin’s Creed III, it gets a bit better if you think about it that way.
Anyway, this package has good value, especially if you get it as part of the Assassin’s Creed Odyssey season pass. As a standalone title, it is worth a playthrough on sale if you’re an Assassin’s Creed fan. Otherwise, I recommend other, better Assassin’s Creed titles, like II, Brotherhood, IV Black Flag and Rogue.

I bought this on sale with a bunch of other Assassin's Creed titles and gee I sure hope the other titles are better than this. Assassin's Creed 3 is visually impressive, is well voice acted, obviously had an enormous budget in expectation of enormous earnings, but it all just seemed so ... silly. It's painful to look at such a huge investment of skill and resources and come to that conclusion, but that is the way the scale tipped in the end. Why? Because AC3 is more a melodramatic action movie than a game. And what would the billing of this action movie be? Forrest Gump as the Prince of Persia in Mel Gibson's the Patriot directed by Michael Bay. I just cannot recommend it, for the reasons below.

Connor is literally all over the map. There is not one major event of the Revolutionary War he is not in some way responsible for. Half way through I came to believe that the Animus is actually a daydream machine that is playing out some school boy's fantasy as his mind drifted away during history class. The formula is relentlessly repeated over and over. Some historical figure is ineffectively standing around hopelessly waiting for Connor. He approaches and the historical figure is either really nice to him (which he responds to with disdain) or they treat him like garbage (which makes him more determined to prove himself to the jerk). He charges off on some "impossible" task, which is actually really easy for an Assassin to accomplish. So, Connor has to make up some laughably inefficient way to pull it off (these are called "optional objectives" and they are the only thing that add any challenge to the missions). 

If it is a boss mission, it ends with some overly long monologue from a dying villain who, for some reason, always attempts to gaslight Connor with stunningly bad sophistry, which is completely pointless because we have all seen the atrocities Connor has suffered at the hands of these people. Connor then goes home and argues with the old man who lives in his house. Over and over and over.

What elements of game play exist have been ruthlessly butchered to fit into the director's vision for this melodrama. The missions are scenes in the movie. The player is a keyboard stuntman off camera. Your job is to learn the script in real time, and trigger Connor's stunts at just the right moment. If you screw up, Connor gets teleported back in time about 10 - 30 seconds so you can try again.  Some mission segments are so linear, hyper-stylized, and choreographed that they might as well just be a cutscene, then you could at least enjoy the chaotic grandeur of fire, gunshots, and explosions Connor is running through but that you have no time to appreciate because you are trying to figure out the next stunt the director wants you to execute without knowing the script.

The fighting system relies on the worst movie trope for action films: bad guys always surround the hero and attack one by one, giving the hero a chance to kill each one in order while the rest wait for their turn to be murdered. Little lights go on above their head so that you know which one is going to attack and you can press the right key to get Connor to do his choreographed fight move. Don't try to speed up the process out of boredom. You are going to have to sit and watch 9 guards get slaughtered sequentially with various fighting moves that are all triggered the same way, otherwise they will land a hit and interrupt the choreography, slowing down the process even more. 

Just accept what you are! An afterthought. As if someone had to keep reminding the developers - you do know this is a game right, not a movie? Oh right - well, have the player push E really fast after 3 minutes of exposition, that will count as gameplay, right?

In between missions, you can take Connor out on a tour through the country and the city. The game makers have given you this nice little pointless sandbox that it is unnecessary to participate in to complete the game, but is one heck of a time waster. Let's get the Assassin to climb into a tree to collect eagle feathers! The reason people bought this game was to watch some guy climb clones of the same tree over and over, right? 

Well, maybe he should go hunting instead? This too is a silly distraction. The animals don't path very well, so hunting them stealthily or with traps is just a waste of time. Just chase them briefly until they bump into something and then stab them. And some zones are so thick with animals that you will only be able to walk a few steps between them. At one point, I was taking Connor out for a walk on a path, where he was sequentially attacked by 6 bobcats in about 2 minutes. They were lined up in a row of carcasses on the path. I started out by skinning them, but after #4 I started to get worried I was stuck in some infinite loop of bobcat attacks. 

And then it occurred to me - Desmond's objective is to learn by reliving the life (or fantasy life) of his ancestor. Does he really have any motivation to waste his life climbing dream trees, slaughtering digital wildlife with retractable assassin blades, or organizing trade caravans of flowers? I mean, we are the players after all, not him.

The strongest points are 1.) Stunning graphics, 2.) Naval missions, 3.) Compelling historic references, 4.) The Desmond Miles 2012 story arc. Liberation had some great points too, shaking things up a bit with Aveline's three personas.
The single weakest component is the main storyline. It makes little sense on its own terms, it's such a striking contrast with the games before and after, and by the end I could not explain the actions of either Connor or his adversaries. I don't have much praise for the Liberation storyline either.
The reason I ultimately give it a thumb's up are the gameplay mechanics and the continuity with the AC series. I don't regret purchasing or playing the game through to completion, although it could have been so much better.

Assassins creed III definitely improved over the previous games (Ezio Saga) in terms of mechanics. The fighting is way more fluid and the combat is a joy to play with. What the game lacks in however is in story telling and character development. The game feels like it just pushes you through each mission. I found myself just going straight to the next mission instead of exploring the world and doing random quests in this game compared to the previous games. This game really does feel like just a segway to the next games. You feel no emotional attachment to the Conner. The DLC was interesting where it introduces some mechanics and "powers" that you would not normally find in AC games. But overall everything felt tedious and you are better off just watching a youtube video for the story.

AC3 is considered a weaker AC game, but is still a good game in its own right. The Revolutionary America setting makes for an interesting story. In this remastered edition version the game mechanics seem good, but sometimes the same issues from previous AC games of grabbing or jumping off in the wrong direction just when you don't need it to. They could still do with a first person camera option. Graphics and atmosphere have been updated pretty well. Now you also get the extra dlc and Assasins Creed Liberation with this edition. Ignore the negative comments,  this one is well worth getting.

Assassin’s Creed 3 is a step in a new direction for both the story of the franchise and the gameplay. It’s quite different from past games in both of those regards and whilst it’s definitely an enjoyable experience, it’s also an incredibly buggy one that sometimes became a drag to get through.

[h1]What I like:[/h1]

+ As is usual with Assassin’s Creed, the environments in this game are fantastic. However, Assassin’s Creed 3 takes it to the next level. There are three main areas you can explore; Boston, New York and the Frontier, the latter being a forest environment. All three of these are massive areas, packed with detail, and the remaster helps tremendously with bringing these locations to life.

+ While it definitely stumbles with pacing, the story is pretty good. Set during the American Revolution, for the majority of the game you play as a native, Connor, and experience his journey on becoming an assassin. While it takes a while to set off, AC3’s story is entertaining, and sets itself apart from past games.

+ The characters, whilst nowhere near the same quality as characters in previous games, are memorable and well written. The main characters, Haytham and Connor are definitely the strongest of the bunch, and while it definitely takes time to like Connor, he gets better as he matures and develops. 

+ It’s safe to say that the combat in AC3 is the best the combat has ever been in the franchise up to this point. From both a visual and a gameplay standpoint, the combat is fluid and incredibly satisfying. The new weapons, with the exception of the bow, are all entertaining to use and vary the combat up greatly. 

+ The soundtrack is another aspect that deserves praise. Despite not being as remarkable as past games, the music and ambient sounds do a good job at setting the mood for the game. The voice acting is also very good, especially for the main characters.

+ The modern-day sections in AC3 have been the best so far. While there are a couple of hick ups, the modern-day story line is the most productive the series has had. You learn a lot more about the people who came before, and the conclusion is a good set up for the next chapter of the franchise.     
 
[h1]What I don’t like:[/h1]

- Assassin’s Creed 3 is quite a buggy experience. Considering this is a remaster, you’d think bugs wouldn’t be much of a problem, right? I wish. Some of the most annoying bugs however, happen when you are climbing, whether it be your character just decides to jump to his death, not move at all, not being able to do a simple climb or just ignoring your every command. 

- As I mentioned before, there are pacing issues in the story especially with the introduction of Connor. This part of the game was a massive drag, and felt like the equivalent of watching paint dry. Other parts of the game are either too fast or just boring altogether. Luckily the last third of the game doesn’t have this issue.

- Another big issue with this remaster is the character models. The lighting works really well on the environments, but completely destroys itself with the characters. They either look like wax dolls or crack heads. The modern-day characters in particular, look absurd.  

- Going back to bugs, there’s plenty to choose from; Attacks not working properly, camera not moving at all, bow not firing arrows, repeating music tracks, music not working, cutscenes not playing, character models flying around after death, enemies forgetting you exist when you jump into a bush, your horse not coming to you when you want him to, not being able to climb a tree or slightly touch a fire and die instantly. I could go on, it’s honestly awful. 

[h1]My Overall Thoughts:[/h1] 

Assassin’s Creed 3 is definitely an ambitious title. It introduces many new elements to the series that set the franchise as a whole in a new direction. It’s a game that, despite its issues, is worth the time and investment. 

Does it have as strong a narrative as Ezio’s games? Nope. Does it stand strong on its own? Absolutely. While I did find Connor annoying, as time went on, he got better, similar to how I felt with Altair. The gameplay however is a definite step up, with a level of refinement that was much needed for the franchise.

This is, however, one of, if not the buggiest Ubisoft game I have ever played, and considering that this is a remaster, it shouldn't be. The bugs hamper almost every aspect of the game, with the ugly character models being the cherry on top.

As a sequel to Revelations, this game is a success. It picks up where it left off and tells a memorable and entertaining story. As a remaster? Try again Ubisoft.  

[h1]My Final Rating:[/h1]

[b]7/10.[/b]

A polished gem that has scratches and flaws but it is still a jewel with value. I got this version through the Odyssey package. I have played the original and yes the remastered has bugs of its own but its textures have been upscaled rather well. It's a unique setting in colonial america with a decent story. 

A couple segments of the game take place during the winter season & the environments are absolutely beautiful. The main protagonist Connor is a brooding no nonsense type of guy that tells it like it is. 

This game came out originally after the "Ezio" saga ended so I applaud Ubisoft for taking a different route & not trying to give us another Ezio like character. Bottom line, get this version on sale or through the AC Odyssey package. This game has some bugs, but there is a lot of enjoyment to be had from this title. It's pros far outweigh its cons.

It doesn't seem like a remaster just the base game and all the DLC. It’s an older game so I won't knock it on the graphics. Seems like a lot of folks have had issues with glitches, I haven’t found anything major so far. The gameplay feels like a downgrade from AC2. It doesn't help that much of the game takes place in the wild and the free running and climbing there feels much worse than the last one.  The MC is stiff, wooden, boring, etc. I know they probably wanted to go the opposite direction than Ezio but having the MC on Ambien doesn't make for an engaging story. Takes about 8 hours to get out of the tutorial section and the world to finally open up. I feel the start with the Assassin turned Templar opening bit, is a complete waste of time and the game should have started around sequence 5 or 6. Loads more of the Assassin and Templar bs, I know it’s called Assassin's Creed but the Assassin and Templar power battle, to me, is the least interesting parts of these games. All in all, not as good as AC II and its sequels or most of the games that came after it, but better than the first one. Though the modern-day stuff is way better that the modern-day stuff in Black Flag. The only one with modern-day elements that I liked was Odyssey, mainly because the only pulled you out of the animus 2 or 3 times and you could head right back in without waiting. 11 games in and Ubi finally figured out most people don’t care about the modern-day segments. Hopefully Valhalla won’t even force you to leave the animus, but I doubt it.

I never played the original game and didn't really intend to play the remaster, even after I noticed that I had received it for free with my Odyssey season pass purchase. Eventually thought I started to get more interested in US History so playing something that would immerse me in the Revolutionary War period became very appealing.

I was pleasantly surprised by how well the core components of the game hold up to modern standards, although that may speak more to the lack of gameplay innovation in the industry than anything else. In fact, there are several aspects in this game that you could consider better than later AC games, like lip syncing, social stealth, and free-running. 

Visually, with the slight improvements from the remaster, the game holds up very well and performance was not an issue at 1080p with a GTX 1070, which gave me steady 60+ FPS. I wish they would have included more graphics options though. Boston, New York, and the Frontier are alive, active, and display why Ubisoft is a top tier creator of immersive environments. 

As with most AC games, I recommend playing them to those particularly interested in the historical tourism aspect, but from a gameplay perspective there wasn't enough to keep me engaged after completing the main missions and none of the side content really pulled me in. We're past the point where open world games can simply put a marker on my map to draw my attention to that content, especially since side content isn't necessary in this game to continue through the main missions.

This game gets pretty mixed reviews here compared to every other game I see in the Assassin's Creed Series. I personally don't understand why. For background, I played AC Origins as my first AC game earlier this summer, and have since played the Ezio Trilogy as well. This being my 5th AC game, I have some point of reference. I would say that the graphics and mechanics are a significant step up from Ezio trilogy, and there is more variation in weapons. The maps are also much more varied and colorful making the open world more immersive. Currently in sequence 9/12, I have thoroughly enjoyed the story and have found the templars more compelling that any that Ezio faced off against. The downsides: It is true that connor is incredibly boring compared to Ezio. Also the music is nowhere near as great as the background music in the Ezio trilogy. That being said, I have still enjoyed this game a lot, and the variation in different parts of the map (i.e cities, vs fronteir vs homestead) as well as variation in missions (Homestead missions, naval combat, liberation missions, etc.) are probably better than any other AC game I have played, origins included. Origins obviously has far more quests, but they are all one-off and lack the feeling of progress you get from completing liberation, homestead and naval missions. Overall I would Rank this just below Origins, tied with Revelations (which was my favorite of the Ezio trilogy due to Old Ezio and a fantastic story), and slightly ahead of 2 and brotherhood. Brotherhood had good side content but all of the side content in AC 3 is a significant step up. If you can just get over the fact that connor really does suck as a character, then this game is so much fun.

Edit: This game comes with AC Liberation and is totally skippable, in fact I highly recommend you just skip it and spend your time playing much better games or doing something else entirely. I played through 3 of the 9 sequences and the "story" just feels like a random compilation of really uninteresting missions with no overarching plot. The open world, which is one of the reasons I have gotten so into Assassin's creed games lately, is so dull and lifeless, which I guess isn't shocking since it is a PSvita game. Again, I don't have super high standards for open world content (really enjoyed the ezio trilogy) but this open world is worse without any of the redeeming qualities the ezio game had. No real side content besides collectibles and I'm not a completionist so I don't care about gathering diary pages. Play AC3 and maybe the Tyranny of King Washington (I know many people love it, I kinda hated it).

Overall, I enjoyed this game. I can see why there are some mixed feelings about it, especially the opening, but I found it not as slow as some complained. I completed 80% of the game and main story in about 30 hours.Negatives:-High points, the cornerstone of Assassin’s Creed are a bit dull. It’s either Churches, or these annoying giant and glitched trees you can’t always climb. It’s really noticeable in Black Flag how they added more variation to address this.-The wilderness seems a bit empty. You either run into nothing, or 4 animals at once, and the quick time wolf/cougar attacks seem very random and hard to complete. I died 80% of the time in this game from these.-Freeing districts doesn’t make sense. There is an explanation/piece of narrative missingPositives-Forts are fun. -You aren’t overwhelmed by the number of events and things to do. Side note, fascinated by the historical period, I always meant to play this, especially since I live in the Boston area, I was surprised at how little of Boston I recognized. After (re-)reviewing maps of the era, I understand why, there really was a lot landscape changes in the 1800’s

The game still holds the crown for worst Assassin's Creed game ever.


The game also contains AC: Liberation. Game is not too bad if you look at it as a PS:Vita game but for a PC game it definitely isn't worth playtime.

Cons:

Story is bad and slow.

Controls are worse than AC3. You can't really free roam because wherever you try to climb, the game simply tells you "No, I don't want you to go from there. I want you to go from the spesific point I put for you" and I'm not even talking about in missions. I'm talking about "FREE" roam.

Game also contains gazillion of different collectibles with no map to look for them. You can only see them on your minimap if you're close to them. I went for every single thing I saw on the minimap and only managed to complete one set and it gave me the almost exact hat she wears as default on Assassin persona.

Pros:
Persona system is nice at first. Every persona has its own strengths and weaknesses but since you can only change them in spesific spots, you almost never bother.

Assassin persona has a chain system (holding R) which looks nice but pretty luckluster in actual gameplay.

Slave persona can blend in with other slaves without drawing too much attention and it's probably my favorite persona since its weaknesses are not too bad (Low hp and no sword but you can still carry small weapon)

I guess if it was a cannon game, these would be much better so that's why I put them in pros even though they aren't perfect.

There are plenty of other AC games if you enjoy these types of games. I experienced more bugs playing this game than Unity.

Since this is an old game I didn't mind the bad mobility, combat and graphics glitches. There were plenty of other annoyances. For one example there are plenty of ramp-like wagons followed up with poles at the sides of the buildings. Any AC played would go there when chasing someone to take the higher ground. But they rarely lead anywhere, at some quests you even start right next to them. But they go off to a completely different direction than the quest objective. Another example is that after each mission you have a 15 second long time where you cannot see the minimap or anything else because its going through the "synchronization percentage". You can press a button to get into a menu to see more information about it and then exit it, but the animations in the menus takes forever to complete as well so you might as well just wait it out.

The reason I played through this was because of the story, and boy was I disappointed. The dialogues are very weird and far from how people would actually react to what you're saying to them. You go and kill 10 people to rescue a guy the reaction from him is "Lets get moving". Then the quest just ends and it is never spoken of again. After finishing the game I still had to go onto the internets to understand what happened.

Sadly I can't recommend this game for one reason: You are REQUIRED to purchase not only Assassin's Creed: Odyssey but also the Season Pass for Assassin's Creed: Odyssey in order to get the activation code for Assassin's Creed III Remastered. This feels like a dishonest, greedy cash-grab on Ubisoft's part. Want to play AC3 again, only this time in 4k? Pony up $100 extra then, because AC: Odyssey is $60 and the Season Pass is another $40 on top of that without any discounts simply because Ubisoft wants to shove AC: Odyssey down your throat. I haven't actually contacted Ubisoft about this as I do in fact have Odyssey (haven't played it yet because I'm still working on AC: Origins), but I've read online that if you contact Ubisoft to complain and ask for a fix, they'll tell you to go buy AC: Odyssey. Shady AF. People shouldn't be forced to buy an extra game AND that extra game's DLC in order to play a game they THOUGHT they purchased already.

The game itself (I played it on PS3 when it first came out) is pretty good. Not the best in the series, but taking a stroll through American history and being able to take part in the Revolutionary War and the events that led up to it is certainly interesting and makes the game worth it (though NOT worth the $100 USD extra unless you're already planning to buy AC: Odyssey as well as its Season Pass), even if Connor is a bit shallow/bland for a main character.

I can't speak to the "remastered" part of this game as of yet, as I haven't even been able to get past the damn activation code bit, but once I do I'll compare it to what I remember on the PS3 and will update this review to reflect the graphics and any other "remastered" content.

Ubisoft, if you ever read this (which I doubt), what you did in locking this game behind Assassin's Creed: Odyssey and forcing people to shell out even more money to buy a game they may not be interested in just to play a game they already legally purchased is shady, greedy, dishonest and downright wrong. Not to mention possibly borderline illegal.

EDIT: The "remastered" graphics are meh. I definitely wasn't blown away.

For the last 5 months, I've been commiting to a playthrough of the entire Assassin's Creed franchise, from the get-go, it was a fun and intense run, the entire Altair/Ezio saga was an epic to remember, everything seemed good and paying several games consecutively without any breaks in between which felt like binge-watching a good show that never dropped the pace, but then Assassin's Creed III's turn came around and the burnout became more apparent.

Take, for example, The Ezio's trilogy, a coming of age story that takes its time to flourish and develop at a considerable pace through three games, it makes you appreciate the character of Ezio at every stage of his life, meanwhile, AC III tried to cramped everything it can into a single game that goes even beyond a single character. It has you start with Haytham, the Templar father, and then immediately follow his son Connor as he goes from a child, a teenager to eventually an adult, and an assassin master.

Because of the condensed story, it takes over half of the game to “properly” start doing the exciting assassin stuff, the first half was more like a grand tutorial that shows you around, always holding you back on going full explorer and roam around as the story does matter, and even when you make it to the second half the plot is already complicated and more involved, so many characters and players steering the wheel and more often than not the narrative gets lost and bounces around aimlessly.

In terms of the visuals, the game is stunning looking, giving even some recent games a challenge, but I should probably note that I played through the remastered version, and remastered it was. The environment is so dynamic with the night/day, weather, and seasonal cycles that alter all locations to a degree of not recognition. The open world is vast which multiple locations, Boston, New York, and the Frontier, all very unique and have different aspects to them.
Before this, Monteriggioni was my favorite hideout in the franchise, it felt alive, spacious and a safe sandbox for Ezio to chill around in peace, but now that I've experienced Homestead, that would be hard to top. The location is even more spacious, it feels even more alive with more people and animals that inhabit the area, to a degree that every resident has their own dedicated, daily routing depending on their profession, like seriously, I took my time in the game stalking each one of them and observing as they go about their unique daily tasks than to transition in between work breaks and go fishing or hunting to head the sack by the end of the day, only to wake up and do the same thing the next day which a slightly different schedule and activities, I mean, the game is proud enough with this feature that it encourages you to inspect several activities that the resident can do and rewards you with achievement, and even that does cover all that they can do.

The control scheme has seen a complete overhaul to the point I was completely overwhelmed and lost having gotten used to the old control scheme, but after training my muscle memory on this one's, I don't see myself going back. The combat was a major part of the fun that this game provides, it's an entirely new system put into place, it's so fluid, the animations are amazing and it plays very fast but less forgiving than the past games.
This was clearly, very ambitious project, really achievement new records to be broken in the franchise in terms of how to open-world it is. There is just so much to do in the world aside from the story, so much so that I finished the entirety of the Canon missions and my save file was still at  44% of completion rate, I've only managed to 100% finish the game after a slow 2 months with over 92 hours, including all DLC.

All in all, the game really suffered from the fast-paced nature of the storytelling, something that really hurt the character of Connor. While a good character, it did not resonate the same way as Altair and Ezio did.
This was probably the game that gets the most hate in the entire old gen franchise, however, now that I've played it, although years after release, it was a genuinely good game, even if it did not live up to the standards that the Ezio trilogy achievement in terms of storytelling, it seems that the game prioritized the open-world over its story, I mean, they were half right to do so. A story will eventually wrap up, but the replayability of the game can be infinite some would say, but that can't be without sacrificing the aspect of a good and memorable protagonist.

The other reason I gave it a thumbs up is because if you are a die hard fan and want the history and lore for the rest of your collection then you just need to get it because of how it ties a whole lot of things together with the characters and connections to other characters leading up to the present. So my conclusion is if you want to go back and play ACIII again then wait for a sale for this version but I wouldn't pay full price.

As someone who played ACIII the first time around on PS3, this is a pretty big step up graphically and the gameplay. Not sure of all the specifics that went into the remaster of this game but the day/night cycle and the dynamic weather was really fun to experience again and it looks even better on PC. 

There were a few weird bugs with controls but nothing that ruined the game or made it unplayable. Sure, the story kind of drags, especially in the beginning, but they have given you a reason to mess around, do side quests, hunt, and liberate the cities if that's something you're into. 

I think if you can pick this up on a sale or along with AC: Odyssey, it'd be well worth sinking some time into.

[h1] Information [/h1]

Assassin's Creed® III Remastered is an action / stealth / adventure developed by Ubisoft Entertainment.
 
[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The year is 1775. The American colonies are planning an uprising. In Assassin's Creed III Remastered, you play as Connor, the son of a native American and a British warrior. You swore to bring freedom to the people and the nation. As the bloody revolution approaches, your clan is threatened by a powerful group that wants to crush the American Revolution and take control of the 13 colonies. To achieve your goal you have to chase your enemies through a huge, open and realistic game world. Unleash deadly skills in brutal quests that will take you from chaotic streets to bloody battlefields in the hostile wilderness of America and beyond. Meet legendary heroes of American history and team up with them to defeat the enemies of freedom. You dedicate your life to the struggle for freedom after your village has been destroyed and embark on a journey of decades to reach your goal. So your journey begins.

[h1] Combat system [/h1]

Combat combines the armament of the assassins with the equipment of the age.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ lively game world
+ Integration of historical events
+ Assassins / Templars in focus
+ varied main missions
+ good combat system
+ many weapons & tools
+ good integration of firearms
+ intuitive controls
+ Sneaking requires tactics
+ lots of items to collect

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- few remastered features
- Side quests that seem familiar and repeat themselves over time
- Weapon selection could have been solved better

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Assassin's Creed® III Remastered turned out to be a good game, even if the remastered features were neglected.


[h1] Information [/h1]

Assassin's Creed® III Remastered ist ein Action/Stealth/Adventure,  welches von Ubisoft Entertainment entwickelt wurde. 
 
[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Wir schreiben das Jahr 1775. Die amerikanischen Kolonien planen einen Aufstand. In Assassin’s Creed III Remastered spielst du als Connor, Kriegersohn einer amerikanischen Ureinwohnerin und eines Briten. Du hast geschworen dem Volk und der Nation zur Freiheit zu verhelfen. Als die blutige Revolution immer näher rückt, wird dein Clan durch eine mächtige Gruppe bedroht, welche die Amerikanische Revolution niederschlagen und die 13 Kolonien unter ihre Kontrolle bringen will. Um dein Ziel zu erreichen, musst du deine Feinde durch eine riesige, offene und realistische Spielwelt jagen. Entfessle tödliche Fähigkeiten in brutalen Quests, die dich von chaotischen Straßen zu den blutigen Schlachtfeldern in der feindlichen Wildnis Amerikas und darüber hinaus führen. Triff legendäre Helden der amerikanischen Geschichte und schließ dich mit ihnen zusammen, um die Feinde der Freiheit zu besiegen. Du verschreibst dein Leben dem Kampf der Freiheit, nachdem dein Dorf zerstört wurde, und begibst dich auf eine jahrzehntelange Reise, um dein Ziel zu erreichen. Somit beginnt deine Reise.

[h1] Kampfsystem [/h1]

Der Kampf kombiniert die Bewaffnung der Assassinen mit der Ausrüstung des Zeitalters. 

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ lebendige Spielwelt
+ Einbindung historischer Ereignisse
+ Assassinen/Templer-Bezug im Fokus 
+ abwechslungsreiche Hauptmissionen
+ gutes Kampfsystem
+ viele Waffen & Werkzeuge 
+ gute Einbindung von Schusswaffen
+ intuitive Steuerung
+ Schleichen verlangt Taktik 
+ viele Gegenstände, die es zu sammeln gilt

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- wenig Remastered Features
- Nebenquests, die einem vertraut vorkommen und sich mit der Zeit wiederholen
- Waffenauswahl hätte besser gelöst werden können

[h1] Fazit  [/h1]

Assassin's Creed® III Remastered ist ein gutes Spiel geworden, auch wenn die Remastered Features etwas zu kurz kommen.

The exciting conclusion to the original Assassin's Creed Trilogy still holds up to this day. Or to be more precise, better than I remember. When I was a kid I couldn't stand the beginning because it took 4 hours before you could even play as the actual main character Connor, instead you play as his father Haytham. Having a better appreciation for the AC lore and story now, I can see why playing as Haytham was vital in setting the game up this way. Not to mention all the modern day parallels with Desmond reuniting with HIS father, William. Their friction kind of mirrors the kind Connor and Haytham face in the Animus's history simulation. [spoiler] And while I already know that Haytham is a Templar, I can see how shocking it must have been for everyone to play the intro sequence and find out that he was a Templar after doing so much good with freeing Indian slaves.[/spoiler]

Now onto the gameplay. This is the smoothest experience AC must have had, it had a perfect mix of new and old mechanics but streamlined. For instance holding Legs for Fast Walk automatically makes you push people aside instead of making you accidentally pickpocket them when your intention was to blend into the crowd. Now you hold Free Hand to pickpocket and that's the way it should have always been as it was in AC1. Furthermore, simply holding High Profile lets you free run on even surfaces instead of always having to hold Legs in order to jump so that makes it more smooth to play. Not to mention the Manual Side Hops are in this game so it's nice to have that freedom of expression in parkour, especially with Back Ejects that still let you get more verticality from each successive jump. It's just a shame that the setting doesn't allow for much verticality since the emphasis is now on horizontal movement through tree jumping.

This combat style is also a huge improvement from always having to hold Target AND Block in order to anticipate an attack you can counter. Whenever you're in open conflict, you will automatically target the nearest foe and you can no longer hold block, instead you have to time your counters. Very good options to because you can use enemies as human shields to protect you from gun shots and the Kill Streak mechanic introduced from Brotherhood makes its return, except this time you can't buffer your next kill as early as you used to. Instead you have to time it after a kill. Also ACIII introduced multi counter kills, so when two enemies attack you at once, you can kill them both at once and that makes for awesome combat.

The STEALTH in this game is also a huge improvement with Wall Hugging that is very loose and free to use, along with using tall grass and bushes. This makes for a more authentic stealth experience than previous AC installments where you're always just standing around and awkwardly standing by wall corners fidgeting with the camera to get a view. The wall hug is more immersive and functional. The stealth kill animations are also new and improved compared to previous games. They look more realistic and brutal instead of just clunky and mere functional like they were in the first four games of the series.

All in all this makes for an epic conclusion to the original trilogy, even though what they did to Desmond's character at the end was probably the beginning of the end for the entire franchise. As a side note, if you've read my other reviews regarding HUD-less gameplay, this is by far the best game to play it that way as it now features on screen icons that indicate your destination, and the map works properly where it shows the direction you're facing without having to have the mini-map on. I swear that's a dumb glitch that somehow made it to Brotherhood AND Revelations, glad it's fixed now. Plus the HUD elements actually look slick and clean for once instead of awkward futuristic icons that clash with the historic setting. Now they look like a good juxtaposition to remind you its just a simulation. Too bad I play without it though lol.

Anyways highly recommend as this is mechanically the best Assassin's Creed game, at least in the original trilogy. Storywise, at least from what I've experienced so far, is also the best and a good progression of all that has transpired before hand.

Upgrading to a Yes, but only for AC: Liberation Remastered, which comes with AC3 Remastered. Unlike 3, Liberation has a more interesting main character I can actually identify with, and brings some fun new twists to the franchise - for example, 3 personas you can switch between (assassin, fine lady, or disguised as a slave) each with different capabilities and limitations.

New Orleans and the Bayou are visually very cool too. And the trade system is FAR easier that in AC3.

There are still some frustrations, like in some memories you can't switch personas freely, and there is no fast travel except to and from the Bayou (and I suppose NY, though I haven't progressed that far yet). 

Below is my original review for just AC3 Remastered, with an added note at the top.

========================

=caveat, the review below was written after completing the very darn frustrating final chase. I still think it's a weak entry in the AC franchise, though and would still not recommend it unless you are a freak for completion like me=

So, playing this game is =definitely= better than getting your eye poked out with a sharp stick. Not much better, mind you, but I would probably choose playing it over losing an eye. Depending on which eye.

Before playing this, I played AC 2, Brotherhood, and Revelations, and then Odyssey.

The whole Ezio saga was THE BEST video game saga I had ever played. I doubt now that it will ever be equaled. And playing Kassandra in AC: Odyssey was breathtakingly beautiful and fulfilling.

AC 3: Remastered? I wanted to love it, but in the end I merely suffered through it with grim determination to complete it. I have never been less interested in getting 100% sync. Thank god it is over.

The crafting and trade mechanics are tedious. The historical period actually =less= interesting after having played the game. I can't pinpoint all the ways it failed, but for me at least, it did.

Let's see if the next one is any better.

I got this as part of Assassin's Creed Odyssey's Season Pass.

The take away here is you get both AC3, All it's DLC and AC Liberation HD which is a pretty solid deal for the price.

Pros: 
-Visual improvements overall
-Gameplay changes like lockpicking of Chests got removed.
-Story, AC3's has one of my favorite main stories of the series
-Changes to UI elements to make it more akin to Black Flag and Rogue.

Con:
-I find Tyranny of King Washington to be one of the worst Story DLC's of the Series. It's not a continuation of the main story as it's more of a "What If" Situation.
-Liberation is honestly pretty forgettable, aside from a small cameo of Connor it can be skipped.
-After a while the side content and things needed to get 100% sync (Including Club Challenges) are tedious and boring with no real reward.

AC3 is one of my favorite 'original' (as in not the RPG style of Origin and Odyssey) Assassin's Creed, so I was very hyped and happy to hear it got a remaster.
