I got this game when I bought Assassin's Creed Odyssey and as I already said in my review of that game this was the best thing I got out of buying Odyssey. The game was really good in terms of gameplay but I felt like the story was lacking. 
The game had a few problems.
The probably most obvious thing is that the faces look pretty damn bad, especially in cutsceens. I am not sure how it happened but somehow they managed to make them look worse then they looked in the original Assassin's Creed ||| but it happened. Although I have to say you kinda get used to the faces looking like they do but that could also just be because I never played the original and have only seen the comparison videos on YouTube.
I also didn't like that sometimes subtitles would show up even though I disabled them. I can understand when they show up when characters speak in another language which did happen a lot during the earlier sequences, which didn't really make sense since the Animus is supposed to translate everything. The problem is that they also showed up when characters spoke English which sometimes kept me from taking screenshots but honestly that's just a nitpick.
They also kinda dumped down the parkour. The high-profile and free run/sprint button were merged which makes movement feel weird since you don't go into a jog like you did in the previous games but in a full on sprint as soon as you go into high-profile. It also interfered with parkour a bit, sometimes Connor would just run up a wall when I moved to close to it and when I was on something like for example a beam and tried to jump to another one Connor would just run up the wall the beam is a part of. The parkour is also way too safe, there is no real danger anymore since you will only be able to jump when the jump is safe. I don't like how they turned the parkour from a big gameplay element and a way to get around into just a way to get around. It did look pretty smooth and I liked that you could now free run in trees but that wasn't enough to make up for the negatives.

Connor as a character had a lot of potential, I thought he could be really cool but he never developed, he never learned from his mistakes, he just stayed naive. Most Templars in the story actually had good intentions so I never felt satisfied killing them (except for two). He also for some pronounces his "native name" different from everyone else, so either he doesn't know his own name or all the others are assholes (including his mother). His voice was also incredible monotone and he just sounded boring (especially noticeable during the side content). Connor was overall a really disappointing main character that stood in the shadow of the best character in the story, Haytham. Haytham was a really good and interesting character. I loved playing as him for the first three sequences and the parts where he returns were the best of the entire story. The story was also really disappointing, especially after the previous 4 games., it was just way to focused on the war which was a bit annoying. The modern day felt a bit too much like the ancestor story and the ending felt incredibly rushed. I was really disappointed at how they decided to end this story.
Combat was pretty good actually I really liked it. At the beginning of the game I thought it was a bit weird but after I got used to it I had a lot of fun using it. I loved the different tool like the rope darts and so on. The weapon variety was also really cool, i especially loved the Tomahawks. The combat could also get challenging when you fought against too many enemies.
The game also had a really beautiful world. The Cities were really nice to just walk through and looked beautiful and there was also the frontier which was amazing. The biggest problem I had with the world were the viewpoints, they all kinda were the same and in the frontier you have viewpoints on top of trees which are incredibly annoying and weird to reach. Fast travel was also really cool since they used a more fleshed out version of the tunnels. You can now explore them to unlock new locations to fast travel to. Exploring the tunnels was a lot of fun and I like the kinda spooky and creepy vibe they had.
The Recruitment system also returned but it wasn't as good as it was in Brotherhood or Revelations. What I liked though was that the recruits now felt a bit more important then  they did before since you now actually had a real mission that introduced them that was led up to by the liberation missions.
The liberation missions were fun and there was a good variety in the actual missions.
Collectibles in the game were also really cool. I liked collecting them all, especially the peg leg trinkets since they led up to a cool little quest line. The peg leg missions had probably the best setpieces in the game.
Frontiersmen missions were alright but nothing special and the Hunting Society hunts were unique but in the end didn't really give you anything special. The hunting system was pretty cool though and you can earn quite a lot of money with it. Assassination missions didn't really have any context around them and were just go there and kill that guy and didn't really feel important at all. Same for the letter missions, they didn't really do anything but add playtime and have you run around the cities/frontier. The best side content were the Homestead missions in my opinion. I loved seeing the village and the relationships between the people develop, they were really wholesome and the ending of them actually made me feel for Connor.
Naval also had a small part in the main story and had a few mayor side quests. I don't really like it but I also don't hate it. The controls felt a bit clunky at times but were alright.
There was also the Crafting and Trading system which didn't really feel fleshed out enough, they never really explained it to you in the story that much and it didn't play a huge role for me even after I finished the game since I never had any money problems. The crafting system did offer a few really nice upgrades though, like the dual pistol belt and the few weapons and consumable expansions you can craft.

Overall the game was alright. In terms of story the game was really disappointing but I really enjoyed the gameplay. I would say this game is worth it.

An average collection. Worth it only if you're a series fan.

[b]Assassin's Creed III[/b]: 6.5/10

AC3's mediocre reception only put me off continuing the series for 8 flipping years.

It really wasn't bad -- perhaps even better than the mediocre Revelations, which had left a sour taste in my mouth back in 2012.

It's problems, however, are many: This is an amazingly ambitious game for 2012 -- and a mess. A bloated, trashy, buggy mess.

I don't want to write a detailed review, but something about the writing of this series sticks with me that I need to get it out: It's a trashy remnant from the influence of Lost and the Da Vinci Code, both still hugely popular around the start of the first game's development cycle. It's not good -- there is no well-written, deep, complex story to these games, only cheese and pulp and melodrama. Because there's *so much*, though, there are a bunch of small moments that are exceptional, but those welcome moments are always fleeting.

I mean, how do you juxtapose the father-son relationship between Connor and Haytham to Connor's 2-dimensional hunt for Charles Lee. Not to mention all the moments of narrative dissonance -- far too many in this game!! -- where gameplay and cutscenes don't line up at all. (The baffling prison segment is probably the worst offender here.)

Connor's not the most interesting protagonist, either, despite the potential being there. Social justice issues with a historical bent are central to AC3, but they're beaten to a pulp in their handling (with, again, fleeting 'wow' moments).

& good lord, the bugs! SO MANY BUGS. The developers seem to've spent so much time shoving every single possible idea into the game that they accidentally gut the QA/QC budget. What's the point of exploring a fully detailed American frontier if there's still nothing to do and all the collectables and upgrades are more trouble than they're worth?

First time I went out of my way to, er, not go out of my way for side content. Bulldozed the story (~17 hours) and didn't find the other content worth exploring.

Thank goodness they finally ditched Desmond. I was not expecting that. I thought the modern-day stuff would have been building towards him as a hero, but nope.

-----
[b]The Tyranny of King Washington[/b]: 3/10

Absolutely atrocious. Buggier than the base game, somehow.

The gameplay increasingly revolves around and relies upon new supernatural animal powers Connor gets from drinking mystical Native American herbal tea*, and, surprise, none of those powers really work well and are broken in a number of fundamental ways. The original game tackles a lot of sincerely difficult issues, even if it does so mostly in a fluffy, action-movie way -- and then this comes over and just drops a smelly deuce all over that by throwing one offensive trope after another at the player. Yikes.

The missions are frustratingly repetitive and bland; you'll frequently get hung up on a buggy spot that causes you to die a handful of times not for any reason of challenge, but rather because the controls would lose their shit and hurl you into the wrong direction.

The whole Washington-becomes-corrupted-alternate-history approach makes so little sense and has no bearing on the overarching plot that it just feels like a waste of time. I feel like I'm accomplishing nothing for the 5.5 hours it takes to complete this broken mess of an expansion, and I hate it. I just hate this game. It made me genuinely like the base game less.

-----
[b]Liberation[/b]: 6.5/10

Liberation is impressive for a 2012 handheld game -- although I never owned a PSP, it's hard to wrap my head around this level of detail and single-player experience being around on a pocket system. x_x

A few wonderful bright spots that made me happy I gave my time to Liberation on my AC journey:
1. New Orleans is an interesting, well-designed locale, and the time period is fascinating.
2. Avelline rules. I know she isn't written particularly well -- leagues above Connor, but that's not saying much -- but I loved her character and genuinely enjoyed playing as her.
3. No trademark Ubisoft bloat. Just a straight campaign, no fuss. Please do this more often. I do not give a hoot about collecting boondoggles.

Most everything else doesn't work too well:
. The gameplay is finicky a la AC III, but the level design not overcrowded with twigs to get stuck on in the same way. The bayou sections dip into this, but not severely and not too often.
. The writing is as iffy as any AC game, but I give it credit for not getting too far up its own bottom in the same way III did. The denouement is ghastly, though. In fact, the last 4 (of 9) chapters feel rushed and incomplete -- their total length combined is about the same as any single one of the first 4 chapters.The twists are idiotic-slash-nonsensical.
. The mission design is draining -- the entire game is cut-and-paste one of 4 or 5 mission types repeated. Trail this guy; kill those guards without being detected; run over here in a time limit. It's not good. It's most similar to the original AC in its blandness. (I appreciate how easy the targets are, though -- they are not overly beefy with infinite healthbars as Connor's targets were. They just die in a hit or two like any normal human. That's a bit refreshing, tbh.) Yawn.

Good thing it's only 8 hours. Still, I had an OK time with it. I'm glad I played it, but also glad I got it out of the way and can move on to the newer titles. The bad reputations of this and III had put my AC journey on hold for 8 flippin' years, and only now do I feel like I can catch up. :)

I'll miss Avelline, though! I'm sick and tired of brooding manly men being either overly testosterone-y or faux-philosophical in these games.

Like the rest of the series, this features a beautifully realized setting and great level design, but attempts to streamline the gameplay backfired and made it more frustrating than ever, and Ubisoft for some reason decided to respond to the complaints of repetitive missions by increasing the amount of them by 300%. 

This remaster is even worse than the original, with seemingly none of the bugs fixed and a variety of new ones introduced with the "improved" graphics; and the original's open world design and hunting/crafting mechanics feel even more awful compared to modern improvements in these areas.

Unless you're a big fan of the series and willing to overlook all its many flaws in order to enjoy the setting, avoid this game.

The overal review score for this game is "Mixed". the score for the original is "Mostly positive". This is exactly the recommendation I would like to give: play it for the original content, not for the mediocre remaster.

My recommendation:
A. I recommend the game for its setting, lore and historicity(ish). Its still very playable for the most part.
B. Don't recommend for its bland story, glitchy mechanics, over-summarized/one-liner dialogs and bad remaster.

Get it on sale < 15,-

The good:
- Very interesting time period and lore
- Interesting characters and story
- Nice scenery. The cities are very nice and take you back to another time.
- Naval missions are pretty nice
- Graphics are pretty good considering the age of this game
- Nice melee moves, interesting choice in weapons

The bad:
- As an assassin going stealth in this game is insanely hard. Often it rewards more to just charge in and smash some skulls.
- Characters are not given much story and thus feel a bit bland.
- Remaster didn't do much for this game: Didn't solve bugs or glitchy mechanics, didn't improve graphics. In fact it made them worse in plenty of cases.
- Riding a horse is so frustrating even the horse can't stop complaining. Literally.
- Although the story is interesting and the plot points are half decent its still an AC game and thus it's all very short and bland.

Like I saw mentioned more often in reviews, it's not a 100% don't recommend but it's just got too many things wrong. I don't now why they call it remastered as from what I saw the same bugs still exist as in the old version and some were added. 

For a big part I liked the main story but the dumbness compared to the clever schemes of Connor makes him very unbelievable as the hero.
The DLC the Tyranny of king Washington I started but that was just so bad I couldn't I stopped playing it

Then there's the side missions. I liked libearating the townparts which will grant you an apprentice with an unique skill you can use as of then. I liked the townquests which builds up a settlement and upgrades your craftesmen. The crafting/trading linked to it doesnt make sense however. There's hardly anything worth crafting, or buying in shops for that matter. So there's not really a need for money which makes the trading completely obsolete. 

You also get a ship and can do seabattles and apparently some missions. I've done some seabattles and they are just horrific. I guess this was the first failed try on them and they only managed to get it right in AC Black flag.

When fighting wild beast you die as the buttons you have to push to avoid or kill them during the fight don't work (and it's not cause I was too late). If you fight the human enemies it's all too easy if you know the button for the counterattack. Doesn't matter if 5 ppl aim at you from a distance with a gun, that loses less health than someone in mellee punching you once.

Lastly there's the menu and where to find all information. It is very unclear and scattered behind various options. Some things in the map menu, some things in the DNA, some in specific option like the assassins recruit menu. For me it resulted in not being able to find a lot of data relating to for example sidemissions while being spammed with useless data
good story

\Start of the review/
*WARNING: contains spoilers!*
~ A remaster that looks worse than the AC games before it ~ (Well done Ubisoft)
Another long time fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise. 
Coming down with THE WORST game in the Assassin's Creed franchise and possible my entire game library. 
I can say for sure that this was pure agony to play through.. Especially if you're seeking 100% sync. This is my experience and my personal opinion of the agony I had to experience in this game so let me explain in detail:

~BUGS.. 
This game is extremely buggy, you can get stuck just about anywhere, a tree, an NPC, between objects and not to mention other bugs like: disappearing audio anywhere ; graphical glitches (light flickering, random flashing light in cutscenes, stretching artifacts) ; poor optimization in areas ; UI makes the objectives disappear therefore you can't see your mission ; Some of the player actions (sword swings, firearm shots) do not execute ; AI can see you anywhere ; AI can shoot through walls ; quick time events will instantly disappear for no reason ; random crashes ; animals spawning inside wagons ; if you will use stealth assassination then everyone will hear no matter what unless you're right next to them to shove that blade up their a*s ; AI does not react to alarms or other events ; You can bug cutscenes and move in them ; Forts will have randomly doors that wont open no matter what ; Lag spikes randomly occurring ; 
This is only the first 20 hours.. 
But wait, there's more !
Horses getting stuck in random open spots ; missions like the 7th sequence first quest, giving false directions into the river while being next to the objective ; Shop UI bug of crate clipping through all the times you look at when buying ; can't complete no detection assassination 7th sequence boss ; some AI enemies do not continue their routine after interruption ; unpolished map in which there are unconnected bushes meaning you can stand up and get noticed even tho you thought you're in the bush ; Juno unfinished cutcenes (like parts disappearing off her body and instead showing extremely creepy and disgusting character instead of Juno really looks like most of the time ; Falling through the map and dying ; AI attacking without being able to dodge them ; And many more that I'm sure I've forgot to mention
This is all the bugs I experienced in my playthrough.

~PARKOUR: The parkour is just so bad.. I mean a lot of the time it will be your own enemy because you just jump to places that you don't want to and therefore get caught or die accidentally.. So basically, you will not be able to climb things, as there are random walls everywhere and the targeting of objects is absurd. I died so many times because of me trying to do leap of faith and the character not executing my actions.. So basically it's extremely not responsive and extremely poorly made.

~STORY: The story is so f**king bland and boring.. I can hardly listen to anybody talking about anything and half of the time needing to actually read subtitles (In which btw, is also bugged as some of the subtitles are either way too fast or way too slow). I mean seriously the first few hours of the game is just so uninteresting.. You go between characters for such a long time till you finally get to the main character.. I mean I never played this before hand and I was so confused for hours on who am I playing with. And now after beating through the entire game. I can finally say that whoever wrote the entire story and also directed the voice recordings has to be fired. I mean it's seriously been a long while since I've heard such terrible voice acting but also such a terrible story. I can imagine how emotional and interesting it could be if not for the wooden main character and how he only looks at things with emotions instead of using his own brain.. I mean everyone around him already talk to him like a little kid while being careful because he somehow has a lot of power. Oh and everyone calling Achilles an old man is just a terrible taste especially as it leads up to his passing.

~GRAPHICS: ~ look absolutely terrible.. This game was released originally 2012.. Remastered in 2019.. And it still looks like the biggest potato I have ever played. I mean.. Just how ? Insanely overuse of fog all the time.. It's like playing Minecraft on 6 chunks of render distance.. No wonder that you can play on 4K when you can't see sh*t. But besides the point, every character just look like such a massive downgrade of what the precursor games had. I cannot imagine what does a remaster to Ubisoft means but I think they are changing the definition of it.

~GAMEPLAY: Oh my lord.. It is boring AF.. Rinse and repeat.. How many of you would find it fun to run back and forth collecting feathers on trees and doing meaningless quests that gives you nothing useful nor any enjoyment out of it.. While the game gives you overly too much bulls**t bonus objectives for that 100% sync.. Raise your hands people. People with OCD should steer away from this.. Because achieving that 100% can be extremely difficult.. Not only because of the objective but also because you can't see the objectives if the UI makes them disappear so you don't even know that they are there and once you fail them, you can't exactly restart some of the missions to a checkpoint and therefore right back to the start of the mission SO HAVE FUN !!!!

But hold on, that's not it of course.. 

QUESTS: yes I have to make a dedicated section for this.. People writing the material for this, has truly lost a touch to this game and the point of it.. It didn't feel like it was planned out at all. I mean let's look at this example: quests to improve the houses.. Instead of actually improving, we do absolutely the MOST r*tarded quests I could think of that have nothing to do with my goal. It is so detached that it's just sad and extremely un-immersive. So what are the missions you might ask.. So get this, to improve a miners level, aka upgrading their home to produce better materials, I need to help him collect flowers for him to date a girl.. Now the questions is, what does that have to do with upgrading the miner for better materials. Yea I'm speechless about it and that is pretty much a lot of the quests in this game like this. Added with the brain of the main character.. Makes this game like playing Dora the explorer THE GAME. Also: There is a massive bug that basically hides your bonus objectives, meaning you wont know when there is some and whether they are any at all... It just f**king disappears and I was mad.. I was really mad. So you'll be needing to restart those missions a lot if you're seeking that 100% sync.


~ For many of the reasons, that I wrote up above, I will absolutely not put myself through any more suffering for the 100% sync nor the DLC that I did try and failed getting through one part. So I'm just gonna save the last brain cells that I have after playing this game and not continue it ever again.

Conclusion: Don't buy this game, it is not worth the 40$ price tag, it's game that was never finished, it's a game that is absolutely not enjoyable and there are no good perks from it. Avoid this game from this franchise as most of the rest of games are actually good and do have their qualities that you can enjoy. With all of the reasons I mentioned it's up to you whether you want to put yourself through suffering only for the story. 

Additional notes: I put up some pictures in my profile on some of the bugs I experienced if you wanna check them out.

\End of the review/

I received this game for free with my purchase of the Gold Edition of Assassin's Creed Odyssey, and yet, I still feel ripped off. I already wasn't fond of AC3, and this makes the third time I have played through the game. There is honestly just nothing redeemable about this game. Everything good is done better in AC4 and everything bad is just so frustratingly terrible. I was a bit kinder in my previous review of the original AC3, but my patience has run out. I hate this game. Anyway, this "remaster" is little more than a port to modern systems. It marginally improves the look of the game, but it still looks like its from 2012, so a pretty pointless upgrade. Other than that there are some minor QOL changes that the make the game slightly less tedious in some areas, but don't come anywhere close to fixing the big problems of the game. Also, the game is a buggy mess, but that's to be expected from Ubisoft. The fact that they're legitimately charging $40 USD for this is just baffling to me. It is barely an improvement over the original game, however it does include the DLC, Tyranny of King Washington, and the standalone remaster of Assassin's Creed Liberation. These also do not justify the price. I didn't get very far into TOKW, as the game started crashing constantly, and was just otherwise underwhelming. It's little more than an extension of the base game, set in winter in the frontier... fun.... Meanwhile, Liberation is a PS Vita game ported to console/PC, and it SHOWS. The game looks awful and plays worse. I got maybe 2 hours in before giving up, it's essentially a downgrade of AC3, which is an already mediocre game.

Don't buy this. And even if you got it for free with AC Odyssey like I did, it's really not worth playing, especially if you're just revisiting it. Skip this, play Black Flag instead if you really feel like it.

Assassin's Creed III is certainly not the best AC, but it's most definitely not the worst either. Like this era of AC games all lacked, it misses a stealth essential; CROUCH. While I always loved the hidden blade parry insta-kills, I cannot find the actual combat very appealing at all. Look, I love stabbing people in the face 3 times to kill them just as much as the next guy, I can't help but lmao every time I've just shoved a blade through someone's skull MULTIPLE times and they are still alive and almost well. The pasing in this game could be way better. By the time you're adult Conor, with all of the main features of the game unlocked, you're already half way through it. Seriously. There are 12 sequences, and 6 sequences in you are still getting introduced to basic core mechanics. WILD. Speaking of wild, the hunting in this game is not bad. I remember feeling like this was the first AC to really delve into the RPG territory now that crafting was something you did with materials and not just money. The outside Animus sections where you get to actually go and DO something as Desmond are easily the coolest parts of outside Animus sections in the entire franchise, even though Desmond looks really weird in this game and the pre-Unity era AC parkour is very outdated. The story wasn't as bland to me as other people I have shared opinions with. I really liked how we actually got to [kind of] experience Conor becoming an Assassin. Through the story at least. We see him meet his mentor. Bug him to teach him. Get turned away. Fight some dudes outside trying to rob the potential-mentor. Mentor does the old guy Mr Miyagi savior thing. We find out mentor is a Master Assassin named Achilles. And while we don't get any cool training montages, we can still fill it in our imagination, unlike most of the other games.  All in all, I liked this game and I would recommend it to people who haven't played it and are trying to get into the franchise. AC SCORE 7/10 (9/10 being Unity and nothing being 10/10 because Unity would have been if it had a better story. and the glitchy launch didn't help)

I wish there was a 'maybe' option when it came to recommendations as it still retains the moderately compelling story of the original game about Connor's quest for peace and freedom for his people and hunting down the Templars behind the plot of the burning of his village and death of his mother, set during the American Revolution with notable historic figures like George Washington, Benjamin Franklin, John Hancock, etc. The problem is, despite the graphical upgrade which is nicely spruced up with some shinier HD textures and lighting in environments, there is a weird plasticine look to the faces of NPC's and in typical Ubisoft fashion, numerous bugs - whether it's Connor getting stuck on invisible barriers, hitting the air and resulting in a kill of a soldier 2 feet away or audio syncing issues with lip movements appearing a decade after the initial line, it can mar the experience quite significantly. Additionally, there are some moments of juddery framerate but it's inconsistent, performance-wise.

Overall, the story is relatively enjoyable, but there is a dearth of side content besides Homestead missions and Liberation contracts, collectibles can get tedious due to no actual rewards and the cities lack the complexity and depth of newer titles along with the mechanics like finicky controls which can be difficult to go back to after a game like Origins. It's serviceable as an entry in the long-running franchise but the issues that were present in the first game, still reside here.

7/10

(Playing in order, coming from Revelations)

Feels like an entirely new engine, everything is improved, the fighting is smoother, the parkour is smoother and ofc the graphics are better, with new tech such as walking in snow which I remember blew my mind back in the day. 

Full sync is still here and still sucks (edit: is the most frustrating thing in the world, just dont bother doing full sync on the ship missions it's bloody impossible), in some ways it is worse as there are multiple per mission however the fact that you can actually reload the last checkpoint if you fail is much better.

The biggest improvement is that the main story feels like an actual character story, every mission is unique and crafted, characters are interesting.  I'm not saying the previous games had a bad story, just the mission structure feels different here, like an actual full on single-player story, like reading a chapter from a book. It took me 9 hours to get into the whole "okay all the mechanics are available now", so that tell you something about the story (though keep in mind you can explore any time). 
The First Civ and Desmond stuff is absolutely brilliant as always, my favourite part of the games.
The first 3rd of the story is great, 2nd is boring (this is where you spent half your time collecting stuff and doing busy work) and the last is great.

A big positive is Naval combat which is great fun! You can see the impact this game had as to this day naval combat is in every game.

Onto some negatives, View points don't reveal the map, you literally have to walk around to get rid of the fog. View points reveal missions I believe and you can still get treasure maps, this system is just a bit weird. Climbing to the top of trees can be frustrating and then when you get there most of the time you jump and there isn't a bloody bush. Every view point you can safely jump from but not the trees!
I love the main theme but aside from that the music is boring, unlike Brotherhood where I would love collecting stuff outside the city just for the music.

I've completed the main game now in 43 hours 97% sync (I can't be bothered to do all the Clubs missions and challenges, this wasn't a requirement in the last games, I'm not doing it in this one). 

I completed the Washington DLC in probably 5 hours, I skipped everything apart from the story because come on dude I spent hours in the base game collecting everything are you kidding me. This DLC is actually really cool, you unlock really awesome super powers basically. It's an "alternate timeline" (won't spoil anything) but Connor is aware that something isn't right, he was ripped straight from his world into this, so cool.

Completed Liberation story in about 10 hours, missed a lot of the collectables. Really didn't get into Liberation, the worst AC game so far, but, it is a spin off and not a main entry so whatever.

A game about sacrifice, loss and working together for a greater cause, Assassin's Creed III is a great showcase of what Ubisoft is capable of. Playing as Connor in the Thirteen Colonies during the American Revolution feels fantastic - a good campaign (with some holes here and there) and an excellent soundtrack by Lorne Balfe provide a solid foundation, but lacklustre gameplay and shoddy level design drag the game down hard. Half the game is spent doing "classic assassin" stuff like navigating towns and parkour-ing across streets, but the other half is spent trying to manage troops and wading through snow and water (which are painfully slow and time consuming). I loved Assassin's Creed III and the remaster is a gorgeous update to a nostalgic game, but Connor's adventures are half-and-half due to sub-par game design. Play for the story and try not to get frustrated by the gameplay.

Both AC3 and Liberation are fun but flawed games, like basically every Assassin's Creed game. There's definitely some shakiness from the upgrade to a new engine, and the fact that synchronizing doesn't show everything is a dumbass move. But overall, excellent experiences; I really like the writing and characterization in both (I think the Homestead missions in 3 are the best character work in the whole game; I love everyone in that little town). You almost certainly got this as a part of the Odyssey bundle, so you may as well play them.

As a longstanding fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise, I unfortunately can't recommend this game. It is, without exaggeration, the buggiest game I've ever played. I frequently had to restart missions because Connor got stuck or fell through the world, almost every other fight had an enemy's ragdoll start spinning out of control and flying into the sky, or the game would just crash. 

Unfortunately, even without the bugs, this is by far the worst Assassin's Creed game. The story is simultaneously too slow and too fast; it took me 6 hours before I was playing as Connor with all his features, and I skipped almost all optional content to get there. But once you do start playing as him, the story skips over major plot points and feels very rushed; we never get to see Connor actually develop his skills and he becomes an Assassin in a single cutscene. The world is bloated with side activities that basically don't matter. The fast travel system, specifically the underground, is terrible and a massive step back from the AC2 games. 

The only good part of this game is Liberation, which comes with it. It is also a bit buggy, but not nearly on the same scale as 3. Aveliene is a much more interesting character than Connor, and her story, though similar, feels a lot better. Ironically, Liberation feels a bit dry on side content, but considering it was initially a PSP game, I'll give it a pass.

Great story and great characters, this games gets undeserved flak. Definitely worth it

TL;DR: Looks prettier than the original release, but not enough major issues have been fixed, so it's still not much fun and remains the worst AC ever. Controls are too console-oriented to be comfortable on PC, and the menus are a disaster. Avoid this like a smallpox-infested blanket and play any other AC instead.

The American Revolution setting is quite interesting, but unfortunately most events and characters are not, and after seeing the ancient wonders and breathtaking landscapes of other AC games even the environment feels unremarkable.

Stupid ideas are still everywhere. How did they think climbing the same copy-pasted viewpoint trees and towers several times would be fun? Not to mention the awful pig-herding quest. Or the collectible on the island with the only climbable spot of rock not visible at all. Or Oak Island superwolves. I feel I could go on and on before even touching the catastrophic King Washington DLC.

Many quests still lack polish; for example, you may instantly fail objectives because of enemies spawning in unfair spots.

Frequently having to drop everything you're doing and fast-travel to defend a convoy is the AC equivalent of "Another settlement needs your help" in Fallout. With all the notification spam this game throws at you it's also easy to miss those ones, losing lots of valuable merchandise.

I had forgotten how deeply I hated the almanac pages getting lost because Connor tries to do everything but chase the damned things. This is where the poor controls really show.

It's unbelievable how hard it is to run straight. Connor wants to climb every lamp post, wall and tree that he strays too close to, and that seriously complicates movement, especially fleeing from enemies. Separate keys for running and climbing might've helped.

Horses are even clumsier than Connor, making even small rocks and ridges impassable to them. Good luck trying to take shortcuts through forests.

Stealth is difficult, because hiding spots are usually far from each other and in restricted areas (or with some notoriety) enemies recognize you almost instantly. The game randomly stops responding to keys and mouse clicks for a second or two, and you can imagine how that ends when trying to perform time-critical assassinations. This is why the game is full of boring, unnecessary clickfest fights against hordes of soldiers. Trying to reach a crier to get rid of notoriety often turns into more fighting, because towns are so full of soldiers. Insanely, it's much easier to just die or quit.

The game loves to hijack the camera, often making it go haywire when fighting in cramped places like alleyways, and there are some inexplicable forced camera angles throughout the game. I'd much prefer mouse control all the time.

Textures and models are improved and thus most graphics are better than the original, but faces have odd lighting issues and some even look oddly twisted, like they used models with incompatible textures. Mouths look weird with fully lit rows of teeth, and many eyes appear very unnatural. Bloodied people in assassination cutscenes look like they have chocolate on them. The new lighting system makes cannon aiming at sea hard, as sunshine or fog makes it impossible to see the white marked area.

The UI is sluggish because of unnecessary animations that block input. The menus are very unintuitive, and in many of them mouse doesn't work at all, turning crafting, trading and such into arduous chores. It it takes 15(!) key presses just to exit the game and probably more than a hundred to prepare a single trade caravan, because there are no presets or automation to make it quicker. You can't even switch both primary and secondary weapon with a single visit to the weapon wheel. Ubisoft should've hired some UX experts to fix this mess.

The Tyranny of King Washington DLC originally had a game-breaking bug that prevented me from completing episode 1. Unfortunately it feels like it has even more bugs now, but at least I got to play through the whole story. Even with Connor's new superpowers I didn't find it enjoyable.

I haven't played Liberation before, so I don't know how much that game has improved, but I came across the first (amateurish, I might add) bug before even starting a game; trying to adjust key bindings results in having the same key for up and down. Same with left and right. This makes the game unplayble for non-WASD gamers and after a year still hasn't been fixed. I haven't completed Liberation yet, but it surely can't save this dumpster fire alone.

I don't think it was even possible to fix this badly written unimpressive bugfest without starting from scratch, and Ubisoft didn't even seem to try very hard.

I really tried. But thank god I didn't pay for this - just got it free with my Odyssey bundle. The mechanics of this are terrible and there's no real ability to choose your game play style, you're forced to do things how the game wants you to do them and it rarely made sense how they wanted you to do it. I gave up part way through sequence 7 (of 12 I think). It was also VERY heavy on cut scenes - felt like 75% cut scenes. The mechanics of fights, choosing weapons, buying things, basically everything is a pain on a PC and the UI is not particularly intuitive.

Enjoying it for the story and I'm into the whole time period and setting which is honestly doing a lot of the heavy lifting here. With AC3 you can see Ubisoft were struggling to find the balance between cinematic and gameplay presentation and the game is honestly an example of why kitchen sink design isn't always better. 

The titles have since improved but it's rough around the edges here, but here is where the more open world approach began so a little clunkiness is to be expected I guess. As for the remaster, there's a lot they improved under the hood, not just graphically. However, the in-engine cutscene graphics really suffer from plastic face syndrome, almost as if they missed a shader pass. Still, it's not a deal breaker. This all said - I got the remaster for free. This certainly isn't worth the asking price if you've already played the original.

So, I don't know if I was just lucky or something, but I had close to no issues while playing the game. I had one crash to desktop, and then one sidequest glitched a spawn which caused me to fail, but reloading fixed the issue. I got this game and Liberation for free because I bought Odyssey's season pass. I had originally played this on the PS3. This copy includes all the DLC and everything from the original game. It adds some quality to life like being able to whistle from bushes, which you couldn't before. I enjoyed the game. 

The parkour and combat are an improvement from the previous titles. This game keeps the combo system that Brotherhood and Revelations introduced.

The story is pretty good. Not the best but certainly not as bad as Unity's story. Haytham is one of the best written characters in the series.

As for the protagonist, Connor, he takes a while to get used to. Going from a charming and funny protagonist like Ezio to a serious and deadfaced character like Connor was a risky move. Some people like him, some don't. I originally didn't like him when I first played this at launch, but now I do like him. He's bada$s. His combat movement is brutal and he is genuinely a scary dude you wouldn't want to mess with. 

The game gives you tons of activities to do like hunting, fighting, etc but it can get pretty repetitive because the only actual "sidequests" in this game aside from some of the DLC content added are the Homestead quests, which can all be completed in like two hours or so. 

I would not recommend the game at full price. Sure it's titled "remaster" and the game does look a tad bit prettier than the original, but it's really not worth 40 USD or whatever your price is at full price. I highly recommend getting it on sale though or with the Odyssey season pass. 

The reason I'm recommending the game with a thumbs up though is because as far as on my own end, the game ran fine and with no problems, and it's seriously not a bad game.

I am so conflicted about this game.

There are parts of it I absolutely loved. Getting free from Ezio's storyline, hunting in the wilderness, the wide range of weapons and tactics.

There are parts of it that were... ambitious, but maybe not well thought-out. The homestead system, for instance, is a gaping missed opportunity - just a way to artificially restrict weapons with better numbers until you can build them. Convoys are functionally useless, as by the time you're getting real money from them you've got nothing to spend it on. You're not even able to make the best trade goods until the game is over, and then what's the point?

Quick time events make a larger part of the game than I'd like. The ship sections were *great*, and I can see why Black Flag decided to make that a much larger part, but they didn't seem terribly connected to the rest of the game - and you're only doing most of them to make the convoys safer, which doesn't serve any broader purpose.

And then... you get the story. I have no idea why, but it's like they decided they just didn't *need* half of it. They have characters acting like they've already been introduced, characters who've never interacted reacting to each other like they have a long history you should be aware of, or major plot events you only learn about because another character references it.

It also seems like they're trying and failing to make the Assassins v Templars moral debate more ambiguous - great. They way they do that, though, is to have the Templars make a lot of excellent points, and be composed of people mostly trying their best... and then to have no answer on the part of the Assassins. It's answered in-story by having the people you interact with being revealed as snarling, mustache-twirling villains under any stress, but that doesn't answer the argument.

Also, people who *know* you're well-armed keep just... leaving you with your weapons. And then they're surprised when you pick up the gun laying next to you and shoot them.

In the end, I have to recommend it, as it was a fun and engaging experience - but pick it up on sale. If I didn't know Black Flag was coming, and well-reviewed, I might have left the series here.

I am usually not a fan of annual series but Assassin's Creed has always been able to capture my attention. I love the historical settings and stories that capture historical moments in time. I played through the first 4 games years ago and loved them. I started games in Unity and Syndicate and like those but stopped playing because I wanted to play the series in order. Despite that I bought Odyssey when it was released and I think it's almost one of the best games ever created (minus the upgrade system).

After putting 150 hours into Odyssey I decided to play through the entire series. I went and replayed the first 4 games, 100%ing each. I got to AC3 which is where I hit a roadblock the first time through. This time I'd play the remaster.

I tried many times in the past to play through AC3. But the game is just SO BAD. 

Forget about character development. You will never care about the character you're playing. I tried. Really hard. The "intro" is several hours long and only serves to severely disrupt the pace of the game and story. No one in the game has any endearing qualities. It's sad that the only non-white Assassin in the whole series is a complete asshole for no reason. I really wanted to like him but there's nothing to like.
The fighting controls are broken
The climbing is broken
NPC triggers are broken

Each mission becomes an excercise of patience as you try to wade from broken element to broken element. None of it is fun. The story is bad. The gameplay is a chore. Despite all of this I keep coming back telling myself I just need to power through this one game.

I returned to the game today after a few months off. I tried to climb a tree to the 'viewpoint' up top. But there's no discernable path to the top of the tree. You wind up at a branch where your only option is to swing and jump, but there is no where to jump to. No where to climb. I keep falling and dying and going up again thinking I'll find the proper path. But it's not there. Climbing a viewpoint should not be this much of a chore.

... and that 's it. I can't do it anymore. The game is a complete piece. I've started the game at least a dozen times and with dozens of hours played between the OG and the remaster I fail to find any redeeming qualities at all. It makes me sad because I wanted to finish Desmond's story if nothing else. 

With limited time and so many quality titles there is simply no reason to waste valuable time on Assassin's Creed 3. You will get nothing out of it.

>UPDATE: So after letting my frustrations pass I did lock in to power through the rest of the game in a long day.

I have to say that the last 1/3 of the game is significantly better than the first 2/3. The missions became more interesting, the story seemed to take shape and broken elements, while still present, were less intrusive and frustrating. By the end of the game I actually DID start to care for the characters, it took far too long however.

I am glad I powered through and finished Desmond's story. I had spent far too many hours with AC3 that letting it fall by the wayside would have felt incomplete. 

While the game does find itself late I still can not recommend this game to anyone for any reason beyond completionism. It's lacking in every department but most notably it's lacking in fun and in character development, two critically crucial areas.

By far most boring and uninteresting of all AC games. Slow and lame, both story and main characters poorly written and lame without a pinch of charisma or depth, even the history part makes you sleepy and makes you want to skip everything (which I do). Parkour is clumsy and annoying most of the times, combat and even menu navigating not a bit intinituive at its best. 
I got it for free along with Liberation and I will finish both as much as painful it may be, for the sole reason that this are the only AC sequels I did not play (and now I remember why) and I am a completionist by nature.
Still, it is remarkable how sleepy this game makes me, like watching most boring documentary you can think of. 
Not worth it, not even on like 75% discount. Better buy yourself a cup of coffee or something.

With that out of the way I will say why.

The game has a great setting with some interesting characters that brings out the best and worst of that period of history. Gameplay loop is decent for the time of these AC games, but feels very lacking by today's more fast paced standards. The thing I like most is spending time collecting the plethora of collectibles and doing the side missions. Multiple different collectibles and challenges in different areas keep it fresh enough that I stayed engaged. 

Major cons. Some of the optional objectives are absolute garbage and complete bullshit that ruin the missions and immersion in the game. Having this badass moment but having to reload because of these really makes it annoying. Another major issues is the story really slips at the end. Made me loose interest.  Open world is way too big, with too many obsticles which prevent smooth traversal and navigation to destination. good game

I've purchased this game on PS3 (when it came out), PC (when it was released a few months later), and again on PC with the release of this new remaster. I've played through it numerous times, and I've always felt that this was an underrated entry in the series. The only thing that holds it back is the occasional bug here and there.  

These bugs are numerous enough to mention, but not so numerous that they ruin the game in its entirety. Sometimes an enemy counter marker won't appear, sometimes a bug will cause you to randomly fail an optional requirement for a mission, and sometimes a bug will require you to quit the game and come back so you can progress. Normally, that kind of thing would turn me off completely from an experience, but Assassin's Creed 3 has a lot going for it which kind of balance the scales.

For starters, AC3 has the best combat in the entire series. It's fluid, precise, and reminiscent of the Arkham games. Until this point in the series you'd essentially stand in the center of a mass of enemies waiting to counter. While that element still remains, there are enemies that will actively stop you from countering and even attacking. These enemies require different strategies. On top of this, every once in a while enemies will take aim and try to shoot you. You stop this by using an enemy as a human shield. Each encounter becomes an interesting combat puzzle, and you eventually get in to a combat flow. All of this keeps you on your toes in a way that hasn't happened before or since AC3. Even AC4, which uses a combat system similar to AC3, feels sloppy by comparison.   


AC3 also updates ideas from previous AC games and makes them better. As an example; this game also has its own version of the brotherhood, but the brotherhood isn't randomly generated no name npcs, but actual characters that you meet as you liberate sections of each city in the game. Each of these characters has a different skill that can be utilized in different ways. You can do stuff like call your assassins to dress up as Red Coats, "arrest" you, and escort you in to areas you wouldn't otherwise be able to get to. That's just one of six skills.

AC3 also innovated ideas that became standard in later entries. The naval combat was so good they built the entire next game around it, and it remains a part of the series to this day. Even if the idea of naval combat in AC4 turned you off for some reason, you don't have to deal with it much in AC3. Which allows you to give it a shot without risking your entire experience. It may even change your mind about AC4 if you give it a chance. 

In addition to how the game plays, I also really like the story and setting. One of the common complaints is that it takes a while to get to anything interesting. I personally disagree. The setup introduces one of the most interesting and well wrought characters in the entire franchise: Haytham Kenway. There is something about the beginning chapters of AC3 that give greater weight to the events of the main game in comparison to any other Assassin's Creed game.  Moreover, the main game takes place during the revolutionary war, so there was really interesting setting with characters that I was attached to. 
Some people complain about Connor, AC3's main character. I think that's because he isn't anything like Ezio, and not because he's poorly written. To the contrary, when you examine Connor even a little bit, you'll find an interesting character arc. Connor's arc centers around naivete. His beliefs are constantly betrayed by reality. In the beginning he thinks life is fair. By the end, he's grown in to someone who realizes that life isn't fair, but will fight to make it so. The line that defines him is "because no one else will." 
All in all, this is a remaster of a game I already liked, and I think they did a great job.  If you've never played AC3, I'd say give it a shot. My advice to anyone playing this game for the first time is to take your time. You'll hate this game if you rush through the story. Do homestead missions, build up your brotherhood, search for trinkets, do naval missions, etc. If you consider main missions to be the last thing on your list, you'll have a much better time. 

However, if you've already played AC3 and didn't like it, I honestly don't know if this changes your mind. 
Now, I'm sure there are some reading this who already like AC3, and want to know if the remaster is worth it. At around 20.00, I think it is. Anything above that, and I may start questioning whether or not it was worth the purchase. By and large there are nothing but improvements but there are some things that hold it back. The game has a slick new lighting engine, and redone textures that look fantastic. There are also some quality of life adjustments. Generic loading screens are black instead of a blinding white, for example. The only thing I'm not a fan of is the way the lighting engine affects how the characters look sometimes. Sometimes, the improvements to the faces are very noticable. Othertimes, you wonder if they screwed up importing old assets. It's kind of a crapshoot when it comes to the character art sometimes.


I'd give this game a solid 8/10.

I am rather conflicted about this title. There is a good game in here somewhere,.. but I can not find it. I see parts of it here and there, but it keeps slipping away. The game have its moments, some of them are even great momonts, but all of this is shadowed by a huge pile of rubbish you have to dig through to see them.

PROS:
- Desmond's side of the story is ok. The ending is a bit underwhelming after waiting for it for 4 games, but otherwise it is good.
- Sea battles are fun.
- There are time when you realise, that actually this game is far more clever then you give it credit. And if you watch carefully, there are some rather interesting revelations.

CONS:
- Connor story was... meh. Like I said earlier, there are a good moments, but they usually dwarf before the totally uninspired writing.
- I counted 5 places where an opportunity for a good oneliner was totally botched, and we got a belove average one insted.
- Controls are total garbage. I understand you went on to completly new engine and control design, but this sh... stuff will make you die. And die. And die againg. And again... you get the picture. And is it me, or Rematered actualy broke it even more?
- Connor/Ratohnhaketon is a total mess as a person and is all over the place. My opinin - the developers were not sure what to do with him.

CONCLUSION:
I suspect that the game was released totally rushed and underdeveloped. Given more time and a bit of better writting, it could have became one of the best games of it's kind on the market. But in the state it is, it clearly bacame what people feered it would be - a nod to racial minorities, the new political movement at the time.
Runs terrible. Story is lack luster. Hate half the characters in the game. Skip this game.

Alright... After I finally have time to 'try' 100% AC3R , I have a conclusion.

It's the most disappointing Remastered and I felt like as if it's as worst as Warcraft 3: Reforged.
The problem isn't the graphic Ubisoft.... The problem is the gamebreaking bugs. I have finished my original AC3 with no problem and yet when I try to 100% this one it shows an old bug that people already had complained in the forums of original game.

Here's the things that bothers me in game :
1) Wanted Poster --> For realism , I thought wanted posters are supposedly placed on public areas where people can see them but oh they did the same thing like in previous games... It's kinda ridiculous trying to bribe or print news to reduce just a level 1 notoriety 

2) Parkour system is still crap that I feel like the brotherhood and Revelation gave me more combo and fluidity to traverse around better than this game. Maybe it's more to the settings of the world that kinda prevent me from doing so rather than the pre-built course for certain missions

I mean seriously... I thought remaster was suppose to fix bugs that prevents me from completing (And I mean pure completionist) the game. If I have to be honest, I would rather play the previous trilogy or even the AC Brotherhood Remaster that offers not much but at least it doesn't hinder me from completing the game 100%

I've played many games of the Assassin's Creed series and this is by far the worst experience I have ever had. I did not play the not remastered version but without a single doubt I can say that the devs put literally 0 effort into the remaster. Too many bugs to count, starting from the smallest visual bugs which aren't that big of a deal to game breaking bugs in main story missions that require you to repeat the same mission over and over if you're 1 of the people who's trying to achieve that 100% sync like me.

Not to mention there was nearly not a single main story mission that the side objectives were harder than beating a dark souls bosses blindfolded (if you don't believe me simply check online the side objective of any random main story mission of your choice). Having played the crap out of AC Odyssey, I really wanted to like AC 3. Seemed like an interesting setting, and the time it took to reload guns was just kind of hilarious.

However, there are major issues with this game, the bulk of which are the result of poor design choices.

1) Attack and Take Down are the same button, which will sometimes result in your character attacking your target rather than assassinating them. Not necessarily a huge deal, except when doing a mission that requires you to "avoid detection": instant mission failure.

2) The only person that noticed/detected me is the person I'm about to take out, yet this fails me a mission? Unless their ghost is going to inform everyone else, this design decision makes no sense.

3) "Whistle" being the same button as 'loot' and 'interact'. Trying to sabotage some cannon in a fort under cover of darkness? I guess I'll just whistle while I work..................

4) A lack of checkpoints/saves in missions makes it extraordinarily frustrating when you are detected due to a crappy design choice and have to start the whole damn thing over again from the start. Multiple times, as it fails in a different way each time.

This is without getting into clunky controls, sticky ladders, and all the rest of the usual things that tend to be problems in open world RPGs. I'm extremely glad that Igot this as part of the season pass of Odyssey, because I'm be really angry if I had paid money directly for this trash.

I can't finish this mess. I loved a few other AC titles but this is garbage. I am glad it was for free when I purchased Odyssey (a great game).

Note: I got Assassin's Creed III + Liberation Remastered with the purchase of Assassin's Creed Odyssey.

Okay, I have 51 hours playing the game, however, that's more because it takes a pretty bad game for me to drop it completely.  I suppose I'm a bit of a masochist as even if I don't care for a game I still try to complete as much of the side stuff as possible as long as it interests me.

So far, I've only played Assassin's Creed 1 and 2/brotherhood/revelations and though it's been awhile, 3 + Liberation feel like they were a step backwards.  I can't remember how long it took for the previous games to open up, but it seemed like you spent at least half of Assassin's Creed 3 + Liberation playing the tutorial before you have the entire world opening up.  Even then, most of the stuff was pointless: gold was easy enough to make and there wasn't really anything to spend it on unless you are someone who must have every outfit and weapon in the game - as far as I can tell, the different weapons were worthless.  Enemies seemed to die based upon the number of hits and not the amount of damage a weapon does so you can pretty much just use whatever you want.  The side quests were mostly pointless (though I did like the Homestead stuff in 3 as I like base building stuff even if it was really just minor quests) and the viewpoints were absolutely useless - in 3, they don't even unlock new quests like I remember from prior games and barely reveal the map so there was no point in using them.

Traversal was obnoxious - both characters were all too happen to try to climb everything (even if all you wanted was to run - typically away from someone), yet, it seemed like there were few opportunities to actual climb stuff as Ubisoft seemed to have restricted where you climb - this was especially annoying in the Bayou in Liberation as it was hard to find ways up into the trees to avoid the swamps.  I also found the characters had a tendency to love to jump off if you were even the slightest off on your targeting where you wanted to go.  This was made worse in timed quests where you often had to chase someone in a time limit and had to figure out the way you are supposed to go.

To me, Assassin's Creed is all about running around on rooftops and such with cool and unique ways to kill people, but there were too many quests where you have to either slowly tail someone and/or avoid killing anyone at all.  Maybe it makes sense as something an assassin would do, but the majority of the assassin's creed games aren't like that - just a few missions.  They wouldn't be so bad if it was like say Dishonored were you can still fight your way out of things, but in Assassin's Creed, you fail a mission if you are supposed to be stealthy and it's the forced stealth in what I would say is primarily an action game that bugs me.  Want a completely stealthy game? Fine, just advertise it as such and I wouldn't bother buying a game.  Liberation made it even worse - not only were there stealth sessions, but you have 3 "persona" (lady, assassin, slave) that you are forced to play as the lady or slave and in the case of the lady, you can't even run along rooftops which I think is a key point of the Assassin's Creed series.

There's probably more (I know some people hated the protaganist of 3 for some reason, but he didn't bother me), but I can't think of them right now and the review is probably long enough:

TLDR, they are probably okay games, but mediocre stories, pointless quests/weapons/gold (unless you must 100% the game) and too many stealth/no kill missions in a game where I detest those missions, leads me to say no, I wouldn't recommend 3 or Liberation to others.

There are essentially three parts to this remaster - the base game, the Tyranny of King Washington DLC, and AC3: Liberation. All of them are worth playing, but they have their own quirks.

AC3 is an ambitious (for the time) game that feels great to play but could have used a bit more time in the oven. I encountered quite a lot of bugs, such as glitching enemy ragdolls, gaps in geometry, and even targets being stuck inside walls and carriages, requiring a checkpoint reset. The game likes to take its time with you, as well. It takes 8 or so hours to be playing as an adult Connor, which may be frustrating if you don't enjoy the opening story, and some side activities can be very tedious and are best avoided, such as unlocking the fast travel points in Boston and New York through an underground walking simulator. Connor himself is a divisive character who can come across as dull if you don't resonate with him, so be warned that there is a high chance you may just dislike the guy.
On the positive side, the game presents a beautifully realised version of Revolutionary America and managed to bring to life a period of history that, as a Brit, I had no real interest in prior to playing. The three main maps of Boston, New York, and the Frontier, are all fun to explore and look great in the remaster. If you don't mind the long setup in the beginning, the story is great with a lot of interesting character dynamics, especially the one between Connor and his father. Combat is fast-paced and brutal, with some really great animation work, and when everything flows together you really feel like a one-man army. A few of the side missions really shine, as well. The homestead missions bring together a bunch of minor characters in a really endearing set of interwoven stories that made me like Connor a great deal more, and the naval missions are a fun change of pace and very well executed (but do admittedly feel a bit like a tech demo for Black Flag).

The DLC is a standalone story that takes place in an alternate universe where Washington gets the Apple of Eden and uses it to become a dictator. It's much more of a straight shot than the base game, really only consisting of story missions, and is mostly worth playing for the broken animal spirit powers you unlock in each of the three episodes. It's an excuse to have Connor be a badass for a few more hours and as a result it's pretty simple fun.

Liberation is perhaps the easiest of the three to like. It's long enough to feel like there is something real to sink your teeth into, without overstaying its welcome. The setting of New Orleans and the Bayou is great, and Aveline is a solid protagonist.  Its central mechanic, being able to change between three outfits with different abilities, is a bit underutilised, but this can be a good thing as it never feels too gimmicky. Liberation is a lot less buggy than the base game, as well. It's got an old-school vibe that reminded me of early 2000s adventure games for some reason, and overall feels like a mix of the mission structure and gameplay loop of the AC2 trilogy with the combat and free-running of AC3 ported in, which comes together great.

Overall, the three games together are probably not the first Assassin's Creed games you would recommend, but if you are interested in the setting or like classic AC and missed these games the first time around, then It's a solid choice for your next 60-80 hours of gaming (but probably best picked up on sale or free with the Odyssey season pass).

Great game. In fact 2 games included ( Assassin's creed 3 Remastered + Assassin's creed Liberation Remastered). Both games happen in the same timeline of the American Revolution but at different places. Both games are great, but I especially liked AC Liberation the most for its story and its game play.

Combat is great, much better than the system Ubisoft implemented in their AC Odyssey. Progression system is good ,as you progress into the game, you will unlock more powerful tools and equipment.

Only downside of both these games are the graphics. Yes of course, they are better than the originals as they are remastered version, but compared to late AAA games, the graphics are outdated. In AC Liberation, the team seem to have forgot to implement an anti aliasing method....too much aliasing.

Overall, I recommend getting AC 3 Remastered as both games included ( AC 3 + Liberation) have interesting story and good game play and many extra missions as well ( I finished both AC 3 and Liberation in 80 hours).

I got the game via the Assassin's Creed Odyssey Season Pass and it has thus far been a pleasant experience. Assassin's Creed 3 alone is a massive game and the fact that this Remastered comes with it, all of its DLC and a copy of Assassin's Creed Liberation make the pack more than worth it on full price, especially if you are a person who has not played Assassin's Creed 3 back in the day. However if you do happen to own Assassin's Creed Odyssey I would get that titles Seasons Pass as it cost the same amount as this title and it comes with this Remastered on top of all of the DLC content available to Assassin's Creed Odyssey. If you have played the title I would suggest getting this Remastered from a sale. I will mainly talk about Assassin's Creed 3 and not Liberation on this review, as it is clear that most of the changes were made keeping Assassin's Creed 3 in mind and Liberation has just been added here as a pleasant bonus for the people who never had the chance to play it either on the PSVITA or the HD release on other platforms.

 a Pleasant experience through this content rich game, probably the first Assassin's Creed game that could've been considered overwhelming due to the content abundance back in the day. The graphics, draw distances, crowd sizes and textures have been improved for the most part, outside of the character model faces, that at least at the beginning of the title seem somewhat worse than on the original game, most likely due to the new lighting system messing preset details on cutscenes and what not. However basically every other aspect has been updated and improved (in terms of graphics) and some things such as clothes and vegetation are greatly improved. Outdoor areas also benefit from the warmer color pallette as the original release of this game had the potential to look rather bleak, grey and dull in line with a lot of games from the mid / late PS3 / XBOX360 era.

 Other small improvements from the original are small, but still should be talked about. These include changes to the mini map. Now instead of small red dots different types of enemies and the direction they are looking or going to are marked clearly and this makes navigating withing and around them much easier. Alongside this the different button prompts and the actions they cause are displayed on the top right corner of the screen at all times, something most of the games in the series had but for some reason was changed on the original release of Assassin's Creed 3 (the Ezio collection and Black Flag had this button layout alongside some other games) and the addition of this is great as it is far easier to telegraph what different actions during free roam or combat achieve. Free aim for all ranged weapons has also been added, again making the title to be more in line with other games in the series such as Black Flag. You are also able to whistle from most hiding spots, something that used to be reserved for only cover locations such as behind high walls or crates. These gameplay additions make playing the game stealthily far more pleasant and actually going back to the original version of the title just ends up feeling like something is missing from the experience. Other small changes I noticed was changes to the loading screens that used to be blinding white in the original release and here they have been changed to be black, a neat addition if you happen to play a lot during evening hours and don't enjoy having a flashing white light burning your eyes in the dark each time the game wants to load a cutscene or something along the line. Also an annoying lock pick puzzle that used to be there for most treasure chests in the game world has been removed from them and instead can only be found on some doors within the story mode or while unlocking fast travel locations on some of the maps. This change might be small, but it does remove a tedious aspect from the looting and opening of chests during free roam and has in turn made the lock pick puzzles into a more memorable mini game, rather than a tedious grind while playing.

Outside of some average visual jank I did not run into any deal breaker bugs or glitches during my playthrough. The only real noticeable glitch really was the potential to have some sound effects loop infinitely (such as the music for liberating a fort / syncing view points) but a quick fast travel or a return to the main menu of the game and reloading it would fix these issues. Overall I enjoyed my completionist time in the title and was able to find new missions and side activities that I had not done during my original run of the title. Some gripes from the original, such as Connor as a main character being a little bland still stand, and obviously could not have been changed without a complete rework of the title and its story. Thankfully many of the other major side characters shine brightly from the townsfolk of your settlement (Davenport) and Connors Father Haytham Kenway and his Assassin mentor Achilles Davenport were some of my personal favourite characters in the title. 


:so to sum it up the pack includes:
Assassin's Creed 3 
Assassin's Creed Liberation 
updated graphics and some quality of life changes to the gameplay.
All singleplayer DLC released for the two titles
New franchise character costumes can be unlocked for use in-game (through Uplay, which you need in-order to play this Remaster).

:Not Included:
Assassin's Creed 3 multiplayer and any DLC related to the multiplayer game mode of the original title.

 While I had played the multiplayer a fair bit back in the day it by no means has ever been the focus of the series and in all honesty I don't mind it (the multiplayer) missing. This version of the two titles is by far the best way to play them. This remastered does not fix the core issues of the two titles but with the improved graphics and quality of life improvements to the gameplay I can never be able to go back and play the original releases of the Assassin's Creed 3 or Liberation now that this Remastered is out. For veterans of the series this Remaster might not feel as it would be enough of a change to go back, but for hardcore fans of the series, like myself, and for newcomers this is the best way to experience Assassin's Creed 3, Liberation and all the singleplayer content these two titles have to offer.

If you played the original game, don't bother buying this. If you get it bundled for free, go for it. The graphics "improvements" are garbage. The original looked better, had better lighting balance, and less lighting anomalies with fog and object highlights distorting visibility. You can't even adjust the darkness to make things less black, even though there is a brightness setting. (which just makes the whites blinding while not affecting shadowed areas)
Some of the gameplay improvements are probably descent, but it's hard to notice without playing old and new side-by-side. The jerky button mash movement and combat controls have not been improved.

It's still an enjoyable game to play overall, but the technical/interface/graphics bits are frustrating. 

Story=rushed junk with massive logic holes, but I guess you can use your imagination to think up something better and ignore those holes :)

Assassin's creed 3 was alright.  The part about the civil war where you play as C onnor the Indian.  Its a little bit slow, and probably not one of the best AC Games, but it was probably worth playing.  Getting the upgrades for the ship seemed a little bit too easy though in my opinion.  Same with the weapons.  Once you had them there was no point in continuing to trade.  

AC Liberation, on the other hand - total garbage in my opinion.  I still played through it - but I sort of wish I could have those hours of my life back.  The game style was stupid, with 3 different personas to play.  Two of them were nearly useless except when it MADE you use them.  And when you were in the assassin's persona, you could never get rid of your wanted level completely, which I found irksome.  The upgrades on this one were ridiculously easy to get and money was super easy to make.  I had all the desired upgrades in no time flat.  And while I supposedly had a ship at my disposal, playing through the main missions I didn't really see it come into play at all.  Maybe I missed something?  The plot you ask?  Hmm, there was one?  It was so fractured and disjointed.  It didn't really mesh worth a damn, and the whole Citizen E thing was also completely irrelevant.  The game was also VERY short.  I was at the end thinking "Oh maybe the plot will get good now" and BAM, game over.  But not before throwing in a pointless Citizen E assassination.  Man I'm super glad it was included with the odyssey season pass.  If I paid extra for this game I'd have been upset.  I don't know why it was a standalone game.   Also the control layout was still showing a gaming controller, didn't even list the correct commands for PC.  Didn't mark as "free product" because it was part of the season pass.
Ubisoft really messed this up. Don't waste your money on a broken game that doesn't work! They should fix this as it's technically a great game.
