Assassin's Creed III:
Although the title is remastered, it's hardly said as one. The combat just slightly becomes easier but that's it, no so called meaningful improvement or anything. The graphic is more or less the same. And just like any other Ubisoft's games, this game is full with bugs  (I have to repeat missions several times because of either the target didn't come out or because the game stopped in the middle of mission) and the gameplay is unbearably trying my patient. Not many skip option in the naval mission so if you failed, you have to see the entire animation again. Unlike the newest installment, this series doesn't let you to fast travel to all synchronization points that you already unlocked. This is bothersome because you need to travel far just to get to your destination. I played this game because I bought the Gold edition of Assassin's Creed Odyssey and this includes as a bonus. If it wasn't included, I'm surely not going to buy it. I have enough with Ubisoft's products.

DLC: The idea of the spirit animals is amazing however, I find it (whether it's a glitch or not) the control of the eagle flight is a bit off, especially for assassination. The story itself is mediocre for me. As usual, there are some glitches here and there (why I'm not surprised) and some of the optional objectives are really annoying and frustrating. 

Assassin's Creed: Liberation
Hm....FINALLY! I finished these broken trash games. There are several bugs in the gameplay and some of the optional objectives are really unnecessary and annoying, especially the part when Aveline need to navigate through the underwater tunnel by using the canoe. I have to repeat it several times to understand how to steer it since the tutorial is misleading and you can't skip it. Also, is it me or Ubi just port it directly from Switch version directly to PC without giving much improvement? (Whenever I launch the Liberation, the Warning sign always comes very small as if it was fit for Swtich version then after few seconds it zoomed out to match PC display). For the plot, it has potential however, lacking some depths here and there. The only thing that I find cool from the gameplay is the fact that Aveline can get an instant-kill after mauled by an Allie (u called it gators, but I call it Allie since it's cuter). I actually got mauled thrice and honestly, it really scares me. Besides that, the changing persona things are also cool and new to the whole ascreed franchise. Perhaps Ubi should consider to use it again in the next installment. 

Lastly, now I know why Ubi gives these two games as a bonus. It's because they're so lacking in many ways and really if you want to fully synch it, it takes a long time. Not because of the story is long but the fact they're full with bugs and annoying optional objectives.

This review mostly concerns Liberation, not III. 
Crashy, laggy, questionable connection to the ubiservers. Tutorials that come up CONSTANTLY and block up parts of the screen. Holds your hand or outright railroads you through huge sections of the plot. Has a central conceit that concerns a choice of approaching problems yet usually only lets you even try one approach.

Liberation is a really fascinating experiment on Ubisoft's part, but they seem to have no understood what the point of an experiment is. When you conduct an experiment in a business and artistic sense, you strike out and do a small job with a dedicated team, which Liberation received. You don't then expect it to sell gangbusters. Instead you evaluate the end product and incorporate its good ideas and strip its bad ones into your future work. No such thing happened to Liberation - I can't find any trace of its unique ideas heading downstream in later Creed titles. And its unique ideas, when it actually lets you use them and works properly, are gorgeous and fascinating. The different ways the city of new orleans evolves over the plot and the way it shifts the effectiveness and roles of the different personae Aveline can adopt is magnificent, and if you're interested in experiments of this kind it's worth the price of admission when steeply on sale.

But don't expect to have a good time.

EDIT: Just fell through the floor a couple hrs into the game: $30 "remaster" by-the-way.

Assassins Creed 3 is not a good game to begin with, but this so called "remaster" makes it look even worse. The facial animations, even on the main character, are extremely rough, especially the in-game rendered animations. Whereby, they do not even match the words spoken or the mouth just looks floppy and goofy. Truthfully, this is just a graphical upscale, and in no ways fixes any problems the original game had on PC besides allowing it to run better on modern machines and a slight graphical update. Otherwise, its a terrible game, and the "remaster" adds more bugs, glitches, and problems the original game was already filled with. Add a horrible story and an even worse DLC in to the mix and AC3 just leaves you wishing you had never picked it up, even on sale (I got this for free with the Gold edition of AC: O). Overall, I do not recommend AC3, even to fans of the franchise, its that bad, and the remaster is not any better than the original; maybe even worse.

The main character, Connor, is the most antipathetic and uninteresting character I've ever come across. Even the evil protagonists are likable  or at least interesting as characters. 

He behaves like a spoiled retarded brat (sort of a "how dare you" male Grеtа, with Iroquois feathers), not a seasoned warrior who went through personal losses and conflicts to become a man. BTW, he was designed that way, because pretty much every protagonist , ally, enemy or stranger tell this naive DICK to grow the f... up, one way or the other.

Haytham Kenway, among others, is very well depicted and voiced. The historical characters act a little young and immature (common theme here?), but I don't know if it is maybe historical accurate (don't really mind it because it is not bothersome in contrast to Connor).

This is hot garbage in every sense of the word. 

The parkour being moved to one button has ruined it, no longer is your movement around the city smooth and cinematic, instead you now run up walls when going round tight corners, run up fences instead of darting between them, and its blatantly obvious that they changed it thi way to make gameplay previews/trailers look good in the forest, since you can now 'quickly' dart through the trees. That would be fine, except it doesnt even work properly in the trees. If I had a dollar for every time I just jumped out of the tree instead of climbing it or moving to the next one. 


The guards can see you round corners and through walls, and in some places they literally spawn infinitely so you are forced to run away from a certain area. There are so many guards that if you have level 3 notoriety it becomes near impossible to play the game because every guard knows where you are at all times, and when you're running away from one group, the second group that's round the corner suddenly gets wall hacks, and runs right to your position.

furthermore, the town criers, who you have to bribe to lower your notoriety, are mixed right in with the hordes of guards so half the time when you try go to one to bribe them, you just get attacked by all the guards in the area. And when you manage to kill them all, the town crier is scared and runs away. You spend half your time just trying to run away/hide from guards than actually being able to explore/enjoy the game. The audio is horrible, every single "hit" sound is just the same generic slicing sound that just repeats constantly during fights, it sounds awful. Not to mention the "HD" remaster making most of the characters just look like waxwork dummies.

And of course there's the tons of bugs that never got patched out, characters ragdolling/flying everywhere, objects not appearing, props you can walk through since nobody bothered to add collision to them, and the most irritating bug - game doesnt register some button inputs so sometimes you cant block/parry, and everyone looks like a partially melted waxwork. Characters legitimately look better in the original. 

And finally, the sound direction is torture on the ears. The mixing for character audio is really bad, most of the voices do not sound natural or like they are speaking in the location the character is in, everyone sounds like they are talking into a microphone in a sound studio.

[h1] This will be a two part review, as Assassin's Creed 3 and Liberation are essentially joined in the Remastered version.[/h1]

[h1] Assassin's Creed III [/h1]
In Assassin's Creed III You take on the role of Haytham Kenway a British noble sent to assassinate a friend for a mystical artifact, tasked to find the origin of the trinket you are sent to America, where you fall in love with a native woman whom you rescued, as she shows you there is more to the trinket than meets the eye. After a romantic exchange you discover you've been playing as a Templar all along, the native woman baring your child. Enter Ratonhnhaké:ton, or Connor as no one cares to remember the native name or make any effort to pronounce it. Connor's quest to negotiate a future for his people against the backdrop of revolutionary war is well written and often well acted. The game's treatment of issues of race, class, democracy and empire even manages to be insightful, and Ubisoft have no qualms about turning America's founding mythology on its head. But for myself, this is where all the "glory" ended. 

I am pursuing a man in a tricorner hat through the streets of colonial New York. In the top-left of the screen, Assassin's Creed III instructs me to chase him. In smaller text just below it, there is a secondary objective: "Do not shove or tackle anyone". I turn sharply into an alleyway and barge past a woman, earning myself a red X on the mission log and losing my "full synchronisation" bonus. I'm not sure why I want to be fully synchronised, but the completionist in me insists that I must try again.

A few attempts later, I've figured out a system. Stop sprinting when the alleyways give out onto open streets, edge carefully around pedestrians, and continue. It's ludicrous, why on Earth would I not shove someone, if the fate of a nation was at stake, but I've not incurred the red X, I've not lost my bonus. I chase the man and, as is tradition, wait for the cutscene where I catch him. It doesn't come. We pass through the same fishmarket for the second time and I realise that we've done a lap of central New York. The game is waiting for me. "Oh!" I think. "This is an assassination, I do those". I can't get close enough to use my hidden blades so I wait until we're running down a clear alleyway, pull my flintlock, and fire. Desynchronised? Target was killed. 

It takes another couple of tries before I figure out that the game wants me to catch him, tackle him, if you will. My objective is to give chase. My sub-objective is to not tackle or shove anyone. The solution is to tackle someone. You may Google your own facepalm jpeg.

Assassin's Creed III features the strangest and most self-defeating mission design in the the series' history, and it's a huge shame. Making me care little to nothing about full synchronisation. 

The game also has a nack of breaking emersion by ripping you from the animus at pivotal points of the story, so you could continue the tedious life of Desmond. I don't quite understand whether it is the way Assassin's Creed III was written, or whether both protagonists just felt like arrogant children whining about a destiny neither of them wanted, and this in turn made me hate Desmond more than I initially did. As for Connor, he protests every chance he gets, refusing advice and following his "heart". Although on the surface it could make for a great character, it leads to scenarios that could have otherwise been avoided. 

The main plot of the game was fantastic, with multiple sub plots, twists and a conspiracy that would keep you in its clutches, were it not for the constant interruptions of Desmond and his team. The constant interruptions made the game difficult for me to enjoy, especially with no quest markers appearing with Desmond, and at the end of it all, Desmond was but a mere pawn for the precursors leaving him with a "choice" of the world ending once more in glorious fire so it could rebuild, or saving the world by giving his life and freeing a precursor named Juno. Apart from the ridiculously poor conclusion, the game tries its very best to paint heroes as villains and villains as heroes. But in doing so, it resulted in inconsistent personalities and poor story driven choices. It took 5 installments for such a stale conclusion, killing a lead no one cared for. With such a grandiose build up my only question was, what would the templars REALLY have done differently? This made the centuries of war between Templar and Assassin seem pointless. 

Apart from the tasteless conclusion, I've never felt so conflicted with a main characters choices. I couldn't decide if I should sympathise or hate Connor. Overall Assassin's Creed III is undeserving of the praise it has received over the years. The 6/10 rating on steam is definitely more adequate. 

[h1] Assassin's Creed Liberation [/h1]
When Assassin's Creed Liberation was released on the Vita, the series’ ever-growing ambition and scope seemed watered-down and constrained, despite Sony’s powerful hardware. Sadly, seeing it on a bigger screen has only placed a spotlight on its lackluster design. If before it came off like a favorite shirt that got shrunk in the wash, here it looks like someone tried to stretch it back out by pulling on every thread. It’s definitely the best way to experience Aveline’s story, but after Assassin’s Creed Revelations and Assassin's Creed III, Liberation looks and plays like a bush-league imitation. 

Liberation Remastered can, at moments, look like it belonged on the PS3 and 360 from the start, particularly when you roam New Orleans in the comely glow of daylight. Building textures and lighting effects got a lot of love, but not nearly as much was furnished on things like water effects, foliage, or skin textures. Not to mention the poor voice acting with the odd npc shouting "huh" in a dull tone, or even lines being re-used over and over to fill the empty shell of a game. For every minute I spent soaking up the sun and the 18th century ambiance, I spent two more slogging through the blurry, colorless bayou. This visual inconsistency made it difficult to ever truly lose myself in Liberation’s world the way its unique setting begged me to.

The story is an incoherent mess, jumping from one scene to another with no real connection to one another. It feels as if the story was written gracefully and with great intent, but handed to a preschool child to cut and paste his favourite parts of each piece. You start the game off by playing as a young Aveline, chasing after a chicken as if it is some creature of wonder and mystery. But in doing so you lose your mother, desperately trying to find your way back to her, a guard knocks you behind the head for pestering a civilian who bared resemblance to your mother, and as you fall to the ground, you jump back up as a fully grown Aveline fighting thugs. As you finish off the last thug you wake up screaming, only to be comforted by a strange woman. Who turns out to be your stepmother. No proper transition or progression of time, no scene melting from one to another. Just tiny morsels fed to you one by one. 

Missions are, with rare exception, narrow and straightforward, and the number of banal fetch quests boggles the mind. Around half of your 12-hour life as an assassin is spent running painfully long stretches from point A to B only to talk to, pick up, or interact with someone or something.  Your would-be assailants still predictably telegraph every attack, and politely wait their turn to take a swing so you can counter, and instantly kill them in an orderly fashion.

Assassin's Creed Liberation is unfortunately a game in the series that should never have come to pass.

This had the makings of a great game. A fascinating period of history, the American Revolution, to tap into. A half-English, half-Mohawk lead character swept up in a bloody war between proud natives and imperial invaders. Exploring Boston, New York City, and the wild frontier. Hanging out with George Washington and riding with Paul Revere. But when the game was released in the winter of 2012, it sadly failed to live up to the promise of the setting.

PROLOGUE

This is ACIII ladies&gents.The most controversial up to date AC Game.Many opinions out there about this game.But everyone has their own opinion/review.Here is mine.


Story 7/10:Not a perfect storyline.Very long.Many chapters.Connor's vengeance drives this AC Story mainly but there are other moments that define Connor more clearly other than only being a vengeful,brute,and loner character.Not so much depth but many feels and nostalgia will come out of you if you have accepted this game a bit.Sidequests:Because this is an open-wrold type of game of course you would expect to see many sidequests,collectibles etc,ready for the taking.All these are optional but provide for some extra hours of playtime outside of the main storyline after you're done.Or for those that want to get the 100% completion of the game,as i did.

Gameplay 6/10:It takes a bit of getting used to,certainly better than the AC Ezio games but worse than the Edward Kenway AC Game "Black Flag".The aiming system is by far the worst.I rarely aimed with a bow and arrow outside of hunting animals.The parkour system has been re-invented and is essentially a new additon to the higher resolution and higher quality AC Games before the new generation AC Games,like AC Unity&Syndicate.Much better than the AC Ezio games.

Soundtrack 5/10:Pretty boring to say the least.The only soundtrack that i clearly remember is the main menu main theme music.The other parts of the soundtrack are pretty much vague to me.


TOTAL:7,5/10


DLC REVIEW:"The Tyranny Of King Washington"


This DLC surprised me.It's an unconventional one.It's in a different reality and more like a dream for Connor.

Story 7/10:George Washington has gone rogue,is a tyrant instead and has joined the Templars.Naturally,you have to stop him.Sidequests are also present here but have a more structural and important role here.Not all are required.

Gameplay,Soundtrack and soundeffects are the same.


TOTAL:6,5/10

I've got a little over 24 hours of playtime on this game, and there's a lot of things that make it very difficult to continue playing (the only reason of which that I do continue playing is the nostalgia from playing the original on Xbox). There are lots of bugs, including AI pathfinding failures, glitching through the terrain, controls (using wireless Xbox One controller) being slow to respond or stop responding, and being seemingly unable to climb certain terrain such as having to shift to the side in New York on some roofs just to be able to actually climb onto the roof. In addition, sending convoys is pointless as visiting shops does NOT actually unlock many of them, even when restarting the game (for the lucky ones, this works) nor using the accounting books in the shops themselves. If this game got a MAJORLY NEEDED patch that fixes many of these issues, THEN the game would be worth playing a lot more often. My 26 hours (at the time of posting this) has been spread out over MANY days, due to the control issues.

Update: After playing through it for 50-ish hours, I just wanted to update my thoughts a bit. 

Maybe it just took a second playthrough, (the only other time I played it was back on the Xbox 360 when it came out), but I find the game a little less boring. The homestead missions are more in-your-face, now. In a good way. They really add to the story and Connor's personality. 

The story is still pretty boring, though. It only gets "fun" and interesting after Sequence 7 or so, near the end of the game. The pacing of it is probably the biggest flaw of the game.

There are so, so many bugs. Not unplayable bugs, but just frustrating bugs. Anyone who intends to 100% this either needs a lot of patience or just have to accept that some of the optional objectives are near impossible to finish.

The combat takes getting used to, but once you get the hang of it and the enemies, you can fluidly go from one to the other and kick ass. This game STILL has the most combat animations of any Assassin's Creed game so far. 

The DLC, Tyranny of King Washington, is sooo good. Easily in my Top 5 DLC's. I really wish the Spirit Animal stuff was implemented into the main game, along with the way Connor dresses up. Not only does it add to Connor's cool-factor, it makes the game a ton more fun. I think it also adds to the Native history of the game.

It's also probably my favorite Modern Day part of the last 4 games. Being able to travel outside the usual "animus room", albeit just for missions, is a lot of fun. 

All-in-all, it's a good game. Takes some getting used to. You either love it or loathe it. The remastered doesn't change much besides basically add an ENB to the game, but it makes for some pretty screenshots. Get it on sale or part of the Odyssey Season Pass and take a shot at it. 







Old review:

This is one of those games where I wish there was a meh recommendation option.

In short: This is the best way to play AC3. It still has a ton of annoying bugs (mostly visual), but the lightning does look decent and they (mostly) fixed the infamous Boston lag which made the original unplayable for me. Protip I learned from a guide: Go into the .ini and turn shadowquality to 2. It makes the game look infinitely better. For some reason it's set at 0 by default and there's no way to change it in-game. 

It still has the same faults as the original, though. Boring story. Boring protagonist that had a lot of potential to be good. They somehow made the American Frontier a boring setting (I'm Canadian so I don't know a lot of American History, hence why I was excited to explore it, and was disappointed). The game is essentially a long tutorial. Seriously, every sequence is basically just teaching you how to play the game. 

However, I'm mostly only playing it because I like the lore of the series. I'm one of those weirdos who actually like the modern day story. The ending was absolute bull, though. 

But, as I said, this is the best way to play AC3 since it fixes the unplayable Boston lag and SOME of the things that made the original even more duller than it already is. That's why I'm recommending it. 

OH, but don't buy it from here. Only get it from the AC:Odyssey season pass. At least that way you get this + stuff for Odyssey. It's not worth the $50 CAD they're asking for from here.

Good day to you dear reader! After I completed the game, but couldn't get 100% because of the bug, I decided to write a review for this game. I’ll write right away that I did not play in AC-3 (Assassin’s Creed 3) and I can’t compare them. Of the innovations in the game, I can say that they added (partial) control of the ship. And compared to previous parts, the schedule was also improved. The game gives out stably 60 fps per second. And on this note, the advantages of the game end! The scenery and models in the game are worse than in the previous parts. A lot of useless and unnecessary tasks, accumulative things and research. The gameplay is virtually unchanged. If you pay attention, you can notice that the game was unfinished and released as is, but the worst thing is that after the release the game remained unfinished. The fact that I was very seriously disappointed with this plot. There are so many holes and shortcomings in it that sometimes you just want to go out and delete the game to hell. And never run IT again! Before I played this game, I thought the worst of the AC series was Unity, but now I changed my mind. I advise you not to buy this game without a 90% discount and play only to complement the main plot.

[03 stupid Connors out of 10]
P.S: As for Liberation, I can say that it is better than part 3 and for the first time you play as a female character. New opportunities and rethinking of old mistakes are immediately evident. The plot here is more open and understandable, which undoubtedly pleases. Physics and animation, graphics and detailing the environment and the final 3 modes for completing tasks make this game very interesting!

Assassin's Creed 3 Remastered review

Graphics: 8/10
Story: 8/10
Combat: 4/10
Movement: 7/10
Pacing: 7/10
Overall: 7/10

I'm going to start off by mentioning I have not played the original AC3, only remastered version.
One of the first things I noticed was that you can now use eagle vision while moving which was a huge annoyance in the previous games. You had to stop, put it on, and then move (in the first one you couldn't even move at all with it on). The controls had also been improved drastically and were more of a fit for the modern standards. While it means losing some of its uniqueness in that front it makes the gameplay a bit more fluid. Coming straight out of Revelations it took me a few minutes to get used to the new controls and I jumped to my death a few times because I was used to holding the spacebar for free-running which now just jumps off ledges. It does have its downsides as well - you can no longer just run without free-running. That means when you hug a corner a bit it'll start running up the wall rather than running past it. You'd have to release the running button entirely for it not to do that. Auto-follow feature from the previous game was also removed... kind of. In the real world situations it was still there when you talked to your teammates but in the Animus I didn't notice it triggering a single time. Another feature that was improved was hiding in crowds. No longer do you have to stick to pre-determined crowds for it to work - you just have to be near enough random people and you'll blend in. Another small feature that was added but I found tremendously useful and fun was the ability to weave around poles that are in the middle of small paths, meaning you didn't have to drop down, circle around, and then get back up. You just hugged the pole and did a quick turn. Synchronizing the map was made to be non-required by being able to reveal the map simply by walking on it which was a nice change of pace. Synchronization points still existed and were useful to uncover large portions of the map so you could go either route.
The character models were high quality but on some characters the hair looked a lot lower quality than the rest of the model. There were many characters with good-looking hair, even if it was a bit more advanced hairstyle yet some simple ones looked like someone had just used spray tool in Paint. The enormous difference between qualities could be seen everywhere in the game - some buildings were so ridiculously low-res that they stood out merely due to that. In some missions some characters could be missing entirely that were there only for dialogue meaning your character will carry on as if he's talking to a ghost that can't be seen nor heard. Minimap no longer has the distance indicator which was handy in ACR, and it's also misplaced a tiny bit like in AC2 which was a huge bother. In here it's only slightly thankfully but still can be an eyesore. There were also gaps in maps that let you see through it (you could see a starry sky during mid-day when you were underground and looked through one of those gaps, one particularly large), and also the interactable snow cut off in some places causing loss of immersion. Sometimes when the faces were shown up-close the eyes also looked extremely bloodshot. Conversations during walks often lasted longer than the actual walking meaning you missed out on quite a lot of chatting between the characters due to the next part of the mission triggering. Speaking of conversations - subtitles were poorly structured and timed in this game. Simply horrible. Quite often the beginning of the second sentence is put on the same line as the ending of the first even when there's multiple seconds of silence between the lines causing you to have forgotten what the first few words were when the next line finally pops up. And that's not even the worst part - a lot of the times the subtitles had their own pacing, didn't even follow the actual dialogue.
Weapon reloading was a new feature but it sometimes glitched out causing the reload bar to go up and down sporadically making sure that I avoid ranged at any cost. Health regeneration was also increased drastically meaning short fights were even less hazardous but now long fights could actually wear you down. In the long run I find it made it a bit better as it wasn't so easy to tank an army anymore. Combat itself was also a bit more technical than previous iterations meaning there were different types of enemies that took different methods to take down but the downside was that at least two of them required you to counter them to be beatable so you'd have to just stare at them and wait for them to attack to be able to do anything against them which killed the pace.
Running on rooftops that was previously a big thing in AC games is pretty useless in this one as you can't cross most streets on top of the buildings due to the streets being too wide, and in at least one occasion that I can recall it broke a mission - the game wanted me to follow someone on the street instead of roof so at one point they just started circling around until I figured out I had to go down. At that point the game disabled the controls for free-running completely. Pathfinding in general was pretty wonky causing some NPCs to just circle around aimlessly for a few rounds, then continue.
Just like the first AC game this game too had a problem that despite being an open world game it did not really feel like such. I think it's due to the aforementioned rooftop issue combined with the fact that quite often you're punished for walking around by having the guards rush you in large groups and you just end up having to waste quite a bit of time getting rid of them. The game taught you 3 methods to get rid of notoriety but the first one I never actually encountered in the entire game - ripping down wanted posters. I'm not sure if I just wasn't observative enough or if the game was bugged.
Fast travel in this one feels pretty neat because you can go to the unlocked points from anywhere instead of having to first run to a faraway fast travel location to then travel to another connected point (which wasn't really "fast" travel, just "slightly faster" travel). Map also no longer loads forever which was a refreshing experience.
A lot of fleshed out minigames felt underutilized (homestead, lockpicking, and ship sailing come to mind). Sailing did have a couple of its own missions but given how good the actual controls felt I wish there had been a little bit more. I never even bothered upgrading the ship because the missions were over before I realised and I did just fine with the base ship.
Speaking of upgrades - I didn't upgrade a single thing the entire run. The weapons felt strong enough (chain-kills to blame here), the ship didn't seem to require any upgrades, money didn't even seem to do anything so I didn't bother messing with the homestead either. In the previous games everything blended in together in a way (ACR did it the best so far, with AC2 close behind).
And finally, after many years they finally figured out skippable credits. No longer do I have to spend time making sandwiches waiting for it to end.
In summary the game felt like the most fleshed out game from the lot so far although not the best assassin simulator. The gameplay was smooth and graphics nice but it felt more like an angrier Tomb Raider than Assassin's Creed.

As someone who played a lot of AC.. I guess this game is OK but I just can't recommend it. 

First of all I hate majority of the characters especially the main protagonist. Connor is ridiculously stupid and a hypocrite at times.. all he knows and care about is "where is who, how do I get this, blablabla so I can kill him". He really had no real motive against the templars and last time I checked he didn't give a sh** about the Assassin's  brotherhood either. He's nothing but a hot-headed uneducated kid from the woods. His principles are easilly swayed by people around him.. and really? Making alliances with the guy that ruined his family just because he's looking for a specific person? That's just stupid.

On the bright side, I find the graphics really good but not amazing. I understand that this is an old remastered game but the visuals hold up well in 2019 except the character models. Combat is OK and performs well in my PC.

I'm not sure what the heck Ubisoft was thinking here, but I specially created an category 'Someone threw up on the graphics' in my game library for this game. AC3 was a decent game. Not the best in the series, but fun enough and still looks pretty sharp years later.

The remaster though.... Oh boy. Instead of the 'upgrade' they called it (promised higher res textures, better engine etc), it almost looks like they tried to remake it in the GoldSource (Half-Life 1) engine (1995-2000). AC: Liberation Remastered looks like the style of the first Doom game, and AC3: Remastered itself can compete with HL1-style of graphics. Whoever executed this remaster should be fired and virtually hanged, drawn and quartered. For something which should an UPgrade this is an large DOWNgrade. Utterly amazing they messed up that badly.

[h1]The Assassin's Creed That Changed The Game[/h1]

Thus far, the game is beautiful. The graphics are beautiful and things run smoothly, no issues at all. Popped in a Xbox One controller and everything went well! 

Now content wise, whether you like to admit it or not, Assassin's Creed III brought the end of an era for Assassin's Creed games, and Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag would begin to change the way Ubisoft went about this franchise. Love it or hate it (I LOVE this AC game most, it is my favorite don't @ me), it is important to the series and to see it having been remastered just really warmed my heart considering the probably.... four playthroughs and one almost fully complete 100% sync on Xbox 360 I did. I just love it. I love Connor, I LOVE Haytham, I love the story and who these characters are and I just hope that others get some joy from this game being remastered to run better and more beautifully on faster machines. 

For those of us who really loved this game (seems that's not a lot of us), it is like a present from Ubisoft to us. Anyways, is it worth $39.99? Well considering it was released originally in 2012 and this includes all DLC and the full remaster of Assassin's Creed Liberation... yeah. It is worth it. But I am biased in that area. I got it because I bought the Gold Edition of Assassin's Creed Odyssey and have loved that game too. But it's nice to come back to AC3 and listen to Adrian Hough as Haytham and Noah Watts as Ratonhnhaké:ton.

Great game. Completed the main game, Tyranny of King Washington DLC and AC 3 Liberation. There are a few bugs that bother me.
1. The ambient type music when you go climbing to sync the viewpoints keeps on playing and was very annoying. The original did not have that problem. The only way to "fix" is fast travel.
2. The assassin recruits (4 of them) don't have weapons equip and they were useless in the beginning part of the game. The only way to "arm" them with weapons is in sequence 9 when you purchase and craft weapons, as in ALL WEAPONS to buy and craft. Sequence 10 you will craft the last bunch of weapons and the recruits will wield the best weapons in their rank. Originally did not have this problem. This needs fixing.
3. The lighting inside the building on the character looks dull. They should add lighting effects inside the building for your character.
4. Shows rain, wind and snow effects inside the building. The original game didn't have this problem, it needs fixing.
5. The Doctor Lyle quest, the first part does not trigger the fight scene and the original had also this bug as well. Needs fixed.
Those 5 bugs are the main things that need to be addressed and fix. If they fix those 5 bugs then the game will be perfect. I'm glad they fixed the Washington Battle Sword Replica model, the original game had their models switched with Lincolns sword and the stats were fixed as well and improved. The trade economy system is improved as well, the original was hard to make money from trading. Overall I enjoyed the game. Will do a review on AC 4 Black Flag next after completing it and its DLC.

Took a look at some of the other reviews criticizing the performance with issues on start up or with frame rate issues- I haven't had any whatsoever and idle around 60-80 fps on max settings. Anyways, not sure if the game is entirely bugged or not, but the graphics in the game feel like they did in the original. Kinda disappointed in that regard, but I'm more so disappointed in that the game mechanics feel outdated and very buggy, even if it were to be released back in 2012. There are some buggy areas in cutsences where either player models or environmental details "glitch" out- it's not the animus itself, but just the way the textures load in. If it were me, paying the full $40 is a bit overkill at best, in the state that the game is currently in, especially considering when Assassins Creed Origins and Assassins Creed Odyssey offer much more for a cheaper price. (Got this apart of the AC Season Pass) It's a nice trip of nostalgia, although it feels like more of the original than that of a remaster with just a refresh of the graphics and free DLCs. I may change my review if the game or it's performance improves. 

Update 1: I've noticed that the graphics are mainly improved on the aspects of nature and environmental structures, like the trees and buildings. (This is after you get to the colonies) The faces are like they were at original launch, like clay. Definitely not a new game, but a fresh look into what the game would look like had it been released today.

- on  a real note, it feels like they just scavenged some textures and called it a "remaster." wouldn't advise you buy it unless you're playing it only for the nostalgia.

I am a big fan of all the assassin's creed games and it pains me to say this remaster was poorly executed. The graphics are great and everything looks really good. Great game. Completed the main game, Tyranny of King Washington DLC and AC 3 Liberation. There are few bugs that bothers me.
1. The ambient type music when you go to climb to sync the viewpoints keeps on playing and was very annoying. The original did not have that problem. Only way to "fix" it is fast travel.
2. The assassin recruits (4 of them) don't have weapons equip and they were useless in the beginning part of the game. Only way to "arm" them with weapons is in sequence 9 when you purchase and craft weapons, as in ALL WEAPONS to buy and craft. Sequence 10 you will craft last bunch of weapons and the recruits will wield the best weapons in their rank. Original did not had this problem. This needs fixed.
3. The lighting inside the building on the character looks dull. They should add lighting effects inside the building for your character.
4. Shows rain, wind and snow effects inside the building. Original game didnt had this problem, needs fixed.
5. The Doctor Lyle quest, the first part does not trigger the fight scene and the original had also this bug as well. Needs fixed.
Those 5 bugs are the main things that needs to be addressed and fix. If they fix those 5 bugs then the game will be perfect. Im glad they fixed the Washington Battle Sword Replica model, original game had their models switched with Lincolns sword and the stats were fixed as well and improved. Trade economy system is improved as well, original was hard to make money from trading. Overal I enjoyed the game. Will do review on AC 4 Black Flag next after completing it and its DLC.

I repeat, YOU CAN PET ANIMALS. Pigs, dogs and cats. Such a cute feature. For that, I am sold. Also, this game makes me like learning about history. It's very creative. It is literally just Assassin's Creed 3 with some changes to the graphics, not even better, just different. Snow looks terrible now for one and they removed the particle effects inside of buildings that make it look just so boring. The only thing that "updates" the game is supporting higher resolutions.  I don't get why they did this. I received this game as a bundle in the AC: Odyssey deluxe edition and the short version is that this is not worth the money they are asking for it by any means. It is literally just AC3 and Liberation being sold to you again at near full price, for console players who maybe sold their PS3's this might make sense. But for PC players this is pathetic. Do not buy this game at full price.

Since it is literally the same game, let's set graphics aside let's take a look at what AC3 did right in the first place

- Native American protagonist, not many of those around, wish he was in a better game
- Cool setting, the reason any of us play AC games
- Tree climbing was a huge step forward at the time and no other game in the series has it baked into it's DNA like this one does. While you can climb trees in future titles there is almost never a reason to do so. This game meticulously put up paths through the trees that makes you feel like you are a master of the forest and it truly is incredible
- Board games, I wasted so much time back in the day playing these lol
- Homestead, cool evolution from the Villa in 2, your villagers all have personalities and you can do little missions to help them and level them up. Personally I found these enjoyable while not everyone does

Now let's look at what AC3 did wrong TL:DR Basically everything else lol

- Completely wasting historical events and places: the first in a very sad trend for the series, Boston Tea Party and the Midnight Ride are notable examples of tedious or downright boring missions. Made me sad at the time, and make me sad now
- Completely wasting historical characters, scratch that, characters in general: Remember when I said Connor was cool? Well the idea of him is cool. That's about it. The son of two cultures, and his mission is to kill his father and none of these ideas are explored to their full potential. I guess Ubi got scared about talking about the genocide of the Native Americans? They kind of deal with it, but it's half assed. Connor's relationship with Washington and the other revolutionaries is so forced it hurts with no development from anyone, people just magically know things they shouldn't. The script sucks, and not just Connor's story. . .
- Miles and the Future Timeline: Just. . . wow. I was one of the only people who liked the future story. I thought it was cool having a game with an A plot and a B plot and the sci-fi was neat. It wasn't necessary, we all came here for the historical setting, none of the trailers exactly advertised fucking Miles lmao. But I thought it was neat, I was interested to see how it ended after FIVE (5) GAMES OF BUILD UP. And I knew it was going to be a disaster as soon as I launched the game the first time and was greeted with the ugliest character models in the entire game. And that ending. . . woo boy it was bad. I don't want to say any more about Miles, god knows no one does. 

So in conclusion. AC3 remastered is pretty pointless. It doesn't update anything meaningful from the original besides running at modern resolutions. And at times it actually looks WORSE than the original so if you wanted a Resident Evil 2 treatment look elsewhere because this is sadly not it. I wish it was, AC3 could have been great, but like many others in the series it flopped when it came to the execution of a fantastic idea. And as anything other than a bundle with the AC: Odyssey season pass (how I got this game) it is absolutely not worth the money. Also shameful of Ubi to pull the original version from Steam if you preferred the look of the original despite the low supported resolutions. 

Why did Ubi waste resources to remaster the two lowest rated games in the series I will never know. . .

I'm glad to say that I haven't experienced any major bugs or any frame rate drops whatsoever in my time playing this game.  I have a love hate relationship with this game and the reason I decided to play it was that it's included in the AC Odyssey season pass.  Maybe it's the nostalgia and my admiration for colonial America but this game is better than I remember.  Yes the faces of some characters look repugnant but besides that I'm not that upset by this remaster.  In my opinion Ubisoft is pretty scummy for hiking the price on this game so much.  I would have charged 30 dollars USD at maximum for AC3 remastered.

So why am I recommending this game despite hating Ubisoft's business decision?  The gameplay.  The combat and ship combat are incredible.  The parkour is still amazing and I love the animations when you kill a redcoat.  Sure the story is mediocre and the characters are wooden but I have a soft spot for Native American culture and this is the only major game where you can play as a Mohawk!  This definitely isn't the best AC game.  I'd say get AC2, ACB, Origins, or Odyssey if you want a game with great storytelling.  I guess my opinion here is in the minority but I'm enjoying the game now.  It's not performing badly for me.  Perhaps Ubisoft has fixed the bugs?  Who knows.  Definitely get this through the Odyssey season pass if you want to buy this game.  You'll get more content for the 20 dollars.

In short: the remaster is inconsistent.

In length: Do you remember Dark souls remastered? For those who don't, when that title received its "definitive version" people weren't too thrilled since the graphical side was pretty much the same as the original and only thing getting a significant uplift was the performance. Simply put, the game ran better. In contrast Assassin's creed 3 remastered is the polar opposite. Both of the games included have improved textures and lighting for sure, but they run just as bad or even worse than the originals. The AI could have spent some time in the oven as well.
When playing through AC3 remastered I have faced several bugs, these include but are not limited to: some times when corpse hits the ground it does its best impression of octodad entering lightspeed quite literally flipping around with elongated limbs till it disappears completely, during one assassination mission all 4 targets spawned (partly or fully) inside structures some of them could be killed only with explosives that luckily ignore the colliders. Now remember that AI, here's the case. I climbed high to a mast and shot a redcoat to a shoulder with an arrow. Not only did the arrow bounce away (yes that happens every time you shoot with a bow), but the redcoat just went about his business as normal... How? How am I supposed to feel immersed being an assassin when wounding an enemy does not even get their attention?
A little word on Assassin's creed liberation remastered. This was my major concern being the unhappy owner of the Assassin's creed liberation HD which ran like ant in sub-zero temperature. The code was not optimized for PC at all. And to your surprise it still is not. My rig (I7-6700, GTX 1080ti, 16g RAM) can just barely hold onto that 70 fps cap when maxed out in 4K.
This remaster could be good, even great with patching, but it is over half a year since the launch. Let's just say I wouldn't hold my breath.

I played Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered which I got along with Assassin's Creed III Remastered, but there is no separate Steam page for that and I had to put the review here. 

Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered. I liked the game and also the main protagonist Aveline. It is different from Assassin's Creed III, only they both are set in colonial America. Connor and Aveline do meet and there is a mission involving both of them. The game takes place in New Orleans and famous Louisiana swamps are there to explore and missions taking place in them. I'm mixed on this one but ultimately I have to say not recommended. The concepts introduced here make the next game(Black Flag) great, but here it's just a tedious mess. Basing this review off of previous AC games, the addition of Naval voyage and battles are nice, but unrefined. Free running in the wilderness is a straight mess in this game. I'd say 80% of the movement is fluid and then you find yourself disco dancing on a 2 foot rock for over a minute. Or climbing a large tree and jumping to a branch...nope, you just broke your neck. Peace be with you. The weather system is introduced as well and the changing seasons are a nice visual touch but not really game altering. I suppose they are not meant to be but it seems like sneaking around in a heavy rainstorm would be easier. Running in snow is certainly more difficult. But no, npc's and enemies keep to their paths no matter the weather. Maybe colonials enjoyed thunderstorms(free baths). Hard to say. The DLC is a mixed bag as well. Freedom's Cry is more of the same, which is okay but not great. Tyranny is just....ugh. Basically, you turn into spirit animals. Yeah. It's so against the grain of the main content that I thought I was playing a bootleg version before I finally quit. 

The story is there as well. Putting you amid historical American figures was an interesting choice but hey, Ezio use to buddy up to Da Vinci so that kinda falls in line with the series. I will applaud the level of work that the historians who build these games put in. It's fictional, yet you can learn a lot about people and places in history. But if you're playing a game to learn history then that isn't the way to go, Chief.

I've played the original Assassin's Creed 3 and in comparison, this remastered version is worse, here's why:

- The side objectives became buggier, an example being the [spoiler] Boston tea destruction mission [/spoiler] where there is a less than six firearms usage allowed and strangely each usage counted as two instead one thereby failing the side objective. Bad for perfectionists.
- The parkour/free-running is more clunky making harder to outrun your enemies especially on trees and sometimes not jumping to the location you desire.
- This is a personal opinion but Ubisoft should use the old weapon wheel( or whatever it is).
- Another personal opinion, I can't tell the difference in the graphics improvement

I cannot be sure about and pros of the game since I'm biased towards the original AC3 but if you can ignore the cons and you want the whole remastered set, go ahead and no one's stopping you.

[b]Note: This review is for the Remastered version ONLY. For a full review of the game, click [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/THNEmbalmer/recommended/208480/]HERE[/url][/b]

Originally released in 2012, Assassin's Creed III has been known as, arguably, the weakest release of the entire series. That's why it came as a pretty big surprise when Ubisoft announced the Remastered version alongside Assassin's Creed: Odyssey. With that said, this fifth-but-named-third entry into the franchise isn't completely undeserved, as the original had a lot of problems that centered around its mechanics, as well as an overwhelming amount of frustrating glitches. Let's take a look and see what has changed with this version while keeping in mind this is a Remaster and NOT a Remake.

Included in the base game is also the DLC, The Tyranny of King Washington, along with the previous standalone mini spin-off, Assassin's Creed: Liberation. These have both of course received the same audio, visual, and mechanic upgrades as the base game, and it's nice that it's all been wrapped up and included in one Remastered release. It's nice to know what you're getting for your money, and suffice it to say you're getting two full games. With that said, the amount of content is not enough to justify the price, given that there are so few improvements and so many issues left untouched. Let's go ahead and focus on the good first.

Well, first up the crafting system has been modified. It's now more essential than ever to do the Homestead Missions to upgrade your crafters, as you can now craft your own weapons instead of having to rely on purchasing them. Recipes can now be found in the chests scattered throughout Boston and New York, but not all of the chests are available from the get-go. There are also little tweaks to the mini-map that allow you to see which direction an enemy is facing, which helps a lot with combat and stealth. Shortcuts and haystacks are now also shown.

Speaking of stealth, hiding in bushes and whistling is now a thing; thank the gaming gods. This wasn't initially introduced until Assassin's Creed 4: Black Flag, but boy does it make a difference with trying to 100% synchronize the main DNA sequence. It also helps a lot with hunting, as you can now just toss some bait out and wait for an animal to come close to the bushes so you can assassinate it right from stealth. The assassin blades are also automatically equipped for stealth assassinations now, rather than having to remember to manually switch back to them before sneaking up behind a guard and stabbing him. Additionally, Connor now wields the dual-assassination gloves created by Leonardo Da Vinci in Assassin's Creed II so double kills without going into glaringly high notoriety are a thing in the Remastered version.

And now for the bad. This review may make it seem like there isn't as much bad as there is good with Assassin's Creed III Remastered, but that's not the case. There's simply too much that's still wrong with this title to even type out effectively. Everything that was wrong with the original game is still there, aside from extremely minor tweaks to the parkour system. Connor still wants to run up every wall he barely grazes past, he's still far too jumpy, characters still glitch through the floor, the optimization is still horrid beyond recognition, half the time the lips don't even sync up with what the characters are saying, dialogue lines during cutscenes glitch out and just don't get said and it's only by having subtitles on that it's apparent a character has even said anything at all. It's just on and on, and it's obvious that Ubisoft didn't really give much of a crap about improving this title one way or another, except for subtle superficial tweaks.

Why Ubisoft wasted their time remastering Assassin's Creed III and not the very first Assassin's Creed is beyond me. This title surely didn't need a remaster, though the niche audience that absolutely screams this title's praises from the mountaintop are definitely over the moon about it. Despite including Assassin's Creed: Liberation and The Tyranny of King Washington, there's no way on Earth that this Remaster is worth $49.99 CAD. If you received it through the Season Pass from Assassin's Creed: Odyssey, then it might not be so bad. Otherwise, steer clear until at least a 50-75% off sale unless you're really desperate to play the game.

Love ac3, just one question:
Why does the remaster look worse than the original?

Frankly I enjoyed this game for a bit. I won't say it's the best remaster I've seen, but most of the other reviews I've seen were being way harsher than I expected (one said that the combat system's changed and has added a "delay"? Not in my save file, no). However, now AC3:Remastered won't even launch to its main screen; all I see is a black screen and I've spent a little bit of time troubleshooting on the internet. I realized from other people's posts that this black screen issue is actually quite common which annoys me to no end considering this is a remaster, after all. So anyway, I can't play the game anymore because it doesn't go past the black screen. The time I had with it was pretty decent; the lighting is much better now but is also so bright that it exposes how ugly the models and engine are: everyone looks plastic, but I guess they at least get some good lighting now.

 The remastered Liberation was actually decent considering its basically an updated port, but it still feels a lot like a PSP game at times.The dialogue in Liberation is god awful; I've written better lines in high school drama class.  All in all, wouldn't recommend because the bug/issue I encountered in AC3 was definitely game-breaking and I still can't get it to work. Sorry Ubisoft, get your stuff together.

Edit as of 7/24/19: Seems like Ubisoft managed to patch whatever was causing the black screen of death bug. I'll admit I didn't have much hope but props to Ubisoft. I now go back to my original opinion of the game: the remaster might not warrant full price because the improved lighting is a double-edged sword with how plastic character models now seem and the additional improvements may or may not seem all that great to you (such as a reskinned HUD). I do think the game is worth purchase even if it isn't the best entry in the series because when AC3 shines during those rare moments, it really shines.

[b]Intro[/b] 

Not sure why we are having only 25% off now during the summer sale. Currently, the game goes for 30 EUR while I purchased it for 10 EUR only a couple of months ago. Price is the main selling point here since gameplay-wise not much has changed. 

For 10 EUR picking a remastered version with all DLCs included (plus Liberation) is certainly a good deal. As for Liberation: while AC 3 (the regular version) is completely absent from the Steam Store Liberation can still be found - it's 20 EUR without any discount affecting it. In terms of expenditure buying the remastered version is definitely worth it. What about the other aspects of the game?

[b]Updated graphics[/b] 

There are some very detailed comparison videos on Tube showing the visual enhancements done to the game. Lighting, shadows and water reflection make it more beautiful. Some say it gives a different look to the game artistically speaking which is a problem - I'm not sure how it can be a deterring factor. I can only see advantages here. Daylight hunting is amazing now thanks to the improved lighting - I spent a lot of time with collecting extra pelts just for the immersion.

[b]Redundancy Vs Nostalgia[/b] 

And a lot of other things haven't changed. We can still stuck at certain objects which means Connor simply runs / jumps upwards but falling back. Close to an enemy outpost enemy soldiers kept respawning and attacking me: with the "old" counter-based system it was easy to eliminate dozens of them. I was thinking of taking a screenshot as bodies were piling up on the screen and it, frankly, looked ridiculous. 

Notifications given by the Animus system are WAY too many. Sending caravans to the different locations is still very annoying and I still see no point in having a tunnel system as without it we still have enough fast-travel locations positioned very well on each map. The system of picking primary weapons and secondary items could have used a revamp. I understand whistling was picked up from Black Sail which helps getting rid of annoying patrols.

Story remains the same, naturally. It's still weird playing a prologue (= missions with Haytham) for 4-5 hours before we can finally get to know Connor. Back then it was such a letdown for me as Ezio was way more interesting while Connor is simply too stubborn a hero. I had the opportunity to play Liberation and the Washington DLCs so all in all I was satisfied with the game. I do believe, however, that it can only be recommended to those who love the AC series, in general, and they were also very fond of this episode in the first place. I still believe it is a mediocre entry in the series but I had good fun with it before moving on to completing Odyssey.

PS: We have the option to use new outfits that basically include all protagonists' outfit released after AC 3 (yes, it includes Origin and Odyssey, as well).

I decided a week ago to play all the assassins creed games because i have never played them, now i am on number 3, i decided to play the remastered version even though the reviews are so bad. I wish i never started this game.

TLDR:
Get the original even it you have to get it from a 3rd party site because this version is trash.

1, The story is a bunch of disjointed nonsense which is nothing more then boring and all i keep thinking is god sake i wish they would shut up.

2, The music is terrible and does not fit the game at all, i have to mute it because it gives me a headache. 

3, There are so many bugs i don't think i can list them all... in a few hours i have seen people stuck in the floor, horses vanish and appear in front of me, objects that have physics go bonkers especially in the cut scenes, people despawn and respawn right in front of me, People driving the horse and karts have no reigns to control the horses, if you restart a checkpoint the guns are empty and you have to reload them, nobody has footprints even in the snow, the player looks like hes going to fall over when walking upstairs because the animation is broken... there are literally too many bugs to count.

4, The combat is the worst i have seen in a game for a VERY long time, it has no flow like the other assassin creed games, it's clunky and people just don't move in a natural way at all.

5, The stealth is totally broken and it seems that it's scripted unlike the previous games.

6, The worst thing of all is the animations. I don't even know where to start with this one, it's just so bad.... that I can not play this game, Watch a YouTube video or something and see for yourself, they look like a bunch of drunken clowns who's blind and wearing roller skates. 

7, They changed the controls. Why? they worked great before! this new way of block/parry just does not work. The controls also have a delay which makes it hard to do anything other then get hit. The original Assassin's Creed 3 game has no delay in the controls i just checked.

8, Guns... They ruin the game and they are just a pain in the ass and serve no real purpose other then to get on your nerves. They also have a range of less then 20 metres... seriously... i shot someone which was about 2 horse and carts in distance and there was no reaction at all. 

On the plus side it does look pretty damn good even though they did not upgrade the polygon count at all, so a lot of objects look blocky and a lot of the MAIN Npc's faces are so badly drawn they literally look like punch and judy characters. The original only looks a little aged compared to this anyway ans the faces look FAR better because they do not look like melted plastic. 

I am glad i got it for free because if i paid for this crap i would be really upset to say the least.

Just a note to the Dev,
I will not submit a ticket, I will not do your work, if you can't be bothered to make a game properly then that's on you, and if you reply to this thread i will delete your comment because i will not give people the false hope that you actually care and give them hope that this game would be fixed.

I was skeptical when I saw the reviews for this game.  And even in playing the first few sequences, I had a hard time understanding the extent of the bad reviews.  Other than the stunningly awful dialogue sync (which results in VERY drawn out and stilted conversations), most things seemed to be working fine.  But now I'm in the middle of the game, and problems are mounting left and right.  Simple mission objectives aren't functioning, minimally functional minigames are taking over, and it's just gotten to a point where I'm not sure I even CAN play the game any more, regardless of if I want to.

It's unfortunate that even after a full remaster, and several additional patches, that simple game functionality somehow hasn't been addressed.  But if you are thinking of buying this game, I'd highly recommend waiting at least until ubisoft has released another dozen patches or so, if that ever happens.

I received this edition of the game for free with my purchase of the Assassin's Creed Odyssey Season Pass. (TL,DR at the bottom)

The textures of both games have been upped in resolution, and the character models...well, they look shiny. Whether that was intentional of not, I couldn't say for sure.

I didn't have much gameplay trouble in the main game beyond seeing something I think would be climbable (coming off Origins and Odyssey) and not being able to climb it, and the occasional failing of a mission due to something I couldn't control (though that may be user error).

Liberation is always finding one way or another to crash on me. Be it trying to enter/exit the Map, use the Steam overlay's web browser for collectible maps, or just for no reason at all. Considering this is the packed-in Remastered Edition of a PC Port of a Playstation Vita game, that actually makes a bit of sense. A relaunch after a crash will help, but I'm sad that it crashes at all.

TL,DR: I would not recommend playing this edition of ACIII and its expansions UNLESS you obtain it the same way I did. It was a blast to revisit this piece of Assassin's Creed's history, but I cannot recommend it for a first-time player.

I essentially obtained this product for free by purchasing so and so pack with Odyssey, so that was nice, I guess. I still feel like I'm owed a refund, though. Here's a list of what went wrong in the half hour I spent... trying, to play the game.

1. The game got upset when I tried to up the graphics, started spazzing out both of my displays, causing them to go black, causing the contents of the display to be shoved off the side, and so on in seizure like spasms. Apparently the game doesn't like dual monitors. Duly noted.

2. Desmonds still kinda funny looking. Not really a remastered problem, but I feel like it's worth noting. I had to fight the game to shut down after the dual monitor incident, however. It apparently doesn't like tabbing out very much.

3. Hey, I can pause cutscenes-- oh, now my keyboard doesn't work. I managed to force the game to shutdown, then tried again. Keyboard worked this time, until it stopped working again after tabbing out. Woops. This time it held my laptop hostage in such a way that even ctrl-alt-deleting didn't let me close the game. Nothing functioned properly. I had to hard-reboot my laptop. That's not exactly easy on a laptop.

On a more positive note, the game runs more reliably on W10 than the original did, so, uh... kudo's for that, I guess. Shame about... everything else.

Pros: 
*Graphic Boost (If you're in to that sort of thing)
*Stealth Assassinations (A HUGE plus for me as that's the main way I kill in AC)
*Tweaked Crafting Mechanics (Not as horrendous as it was, but still not very good set up)
*Kenway boat missions cleaned up a bit (Don't have to keep walking back to your cabin. Duel with crewman more involved)

Cons:
*Graphic Boost means you need a stronger machine (I don't have that, so I have to drop the resolution)
*Strange Lighting Effects (If the sun is setting, expect to see nothing but a screen of orange)
*Fade to black when entering buildings (Why?! It was so cool to see that the Homestead could be walked into without any load screen or anything. Why a black screen in between now?!)
*FOG (You can only see a couple meters in any direction. The skies never fully clear up. Tower synching is so disappointing now. You can't see a thing.)
*AUDIO GLITCHES (Biggest offender for me. Tower Synch cue gets stuck on a loop forever. Fighting cue will get louder and louder until you just have to mute it. Characters right next to you will be impossible to hear. No matter how you try to readjust your sound mixing, you will never get it right. This desperately needs a patch!)
*PLOT (It's still the same clunky story it was in the original.)
*Acting (Connor is still a plank of wood. Seriously, you couldn't do some rerecordings to make him not sound like he was reading cue cards?)
*Not enough has changed (It's basically the same game. It felt unfinished then. It feels unfinished now. So if a few more pixels on the screen really means that much to you, buy it. Otherwise just forget it!)

This game has received a lot of negativity. A lot of Ubisoft titles usually do, I guess, by default due to Uplay. I never had any issues with that, so that doesn't matter to me.

As remasters go (and I've played the original game A LOT), this is well done. Graphics aside, the settings and controls have been simplified to a point it's actually fantastic. The shooting mechanics were ridiculous compared to other AC titles in this game, and how they actually work. Aim and shoot, not hold an release (except for the ship combat). The environments and textures do look better, crisper, and it's just fun to play.

The endlessly long intro sequence is still there, and annoying as ever, but it says a lot about a game when you're willing to sit through the tediousness of such a long introduction a few times over to play a game. If you know this game, it's worth replaying this way, if you've never played AC III, now is the time, even if you buy it separately, because given the original price with all the DLCs, this is value for money, even if the size of the download has more than doubled.

People complaining about the looks of characters etc., consider the game's age. If this were a reMAKE, I would understand, but it's a reMASTER. It's meant to look a bit better, make it more accessible and offer a more complete game experience. All of this the AC III Remaster does. I'm definitely enjoying another play through, and if you're a fan of the series, you should, too.

Quick note: It's a very clear cash grab. The crappy business practice of recycling the same game for more money with virtually no improvements deserves a low rating which it apparently has. However, it's getting a positive rating from me solely on the merit of the game itself.  But, buy it on sale.  This isn't remastered in any form.

Ironically, I had been playing AC3 the week prior to the release of AC3 remaster paired with Odyssey (a game that, at the time, I had not yet played).  So, I bought Odyssey and scored a copy of a game I was already playing anyway.  That said, I essentially played the game twice side by side as a direct comparison.  There were zero noticeable changes from the original to the remaster.  Frankly, this title does not deserve the notion of having been remastered.  It's a tactic to make an old game expensive again.  That said, I got it paired with another purchase. So, Ubi, thanks I guess.  Now I have two copies of the same thing.

For those that are just interested in this title, however, the game in and of itself is not bad.  The reviews reflect more of a general dissatisfaction of a clear cash grab scheme and, therefore, the reviews reflect poorly on poor business practices.  For my review of the game and because they are essentially the same anyway, I defer to my original AC3 review:

Best of the pre-rpg style assassin's creed games. I really like the ambiance, the story, and the gameplay changes made from the Ezio line. Really got the series started on ship combat which has since produced Black Flag and the upcoming Skull n Bones. Great progression of gameplay and style of the series. However, I do feel that the non-parallel-historical plotline is garbage (the bit which covers desmond and all the non-sensical first civ stuff). But, Connor, the protagonist, is quite fun to play.

As of now (April 3), I have only played Assassin's Creed 3 and I've yet to try Liberation. So, my review will be just about the former.
The good thing is that I got this game from the AC: Odyssey Ultimate Edition completely free and, all things considered, it was not a bad deal at all to get two (three, depending your point of view) full games for the price of one. Furthermore, I never got to play any of the original game DLC's, so now I'll finally be able to.
Unfortunately, if you're interested in buying it, it's not worth it. At least, not with a full price, of course. If you, like me, got it for free, I guess there's not much to complain, right?
Let's go with some [u]upsides[/u]:
- The gameplay was overhauled to make it easier (and more similar to nowadays titles) for newcomers. Now, there's free aim with the right mouse button (although the targeting system is not particularly good) and freerun is done with shift, which makes it simpler than before, as Connor's parkour is more easily handled.
- Some sound effects have been changed. The storms are incredibly pleasant to listen to. HOWEVER, sounds are not consistent. The music played while in conflict sounds louder or quieter randomly for no particular reason. One moment you can barely listen it, then you go deaf.
Now, some [u]mixed[/u] (that can be good or bad depending your point of view)
- The HUD and map has been changed as well. I found it nice, though I'm not particularly fond of the yellow/gold choice of colour.
- A lot of secondary objectives from missions and side-missions have been simplified or removed altogether, which I found pretty annoying.
- The game can run in pretty much any system. I have an old toaster and I'm able to get an average of 45 FPS almost at max settings. There aren't any noticeable improvements, sadly, and the game looks pretty much the same as before. Some facial animations, skin textures and lighting effects seem off and don't always work properly.
- The multiplayer was removed. I just tried it once or twice and could hardly find a game to join (I might have bought the original AC 3 a little late and the multiplayer, at least in my region, was pretty much dead), so it's not something I'm going to miss. Nevertheless, it might be unacceptable to those who played it and loved it, considering that the original game was removed from stores.
EDIT: I also noticed that there's a ridiculous amount of animals around and that pretty much breaks the economy of the game. I found myself having more money that I'd ever need very early in the game. Beaver pelts are ridiculously profitable if sold to the right person, not to mention bears.
Now, the [u]downsides[/u].
- I have been getting a lot of random hard crashes. I lost count after the tenth one. I couldn't find a reason that might cause them and I don't know if somebody else had the same problem as me.
- I have also been getting some freezes. The game freezes for 4 or 5 seconds (sometimes more) while the audio keeps playing. Some of those freezes then lead to the aforementioned hard crashes. Sometimes they happen every half an hour more or less. Though, there have been times in which I did not get any for some hours. I suspect that both the crashes and the freezes have something to do with the autosave system. Fortunately, I have not lost anything so far, despite how many crashes I've experienced.
- A lot of people had problems with screen flickering and it's likely that you will too, unless Ubisoft patches the problem.
- As mentioned before, there are some lighting issues from time to time and, of course, glitches. I haven't found any game-breaking one (thankfully), but some of them can be pretty annoying. Specially when the attack prompt does not appear over enemies and their attacks are unblockable.

So, to sum up, should you buy this game? Probably not. If you never played AC 3 (or Liberation), I'd advise you to wait for a sale (let that 75% discount come). Otherwise, the game in its current state is hardly worth it, specially at THAT price.

EDIT: As of April 26, I have finally finished AC: Liberation. I've yet to unlock ONE achievement (the 100% sync one) because there's a mission that crashes at a checkpoint when I'm trying to replay it. Plus, the last few missions were a complete chore due to the buggy combat in which you wouldn't even get an attack prompt to counter. Furthermore, the game somehow started working worse since Ubi released a "patch" about a week ago. I have no idea how they could have screwed that, honestly.
As for the graphics, same ol' same ol'. I can't notice a clear difference between Liberation HD and Liberation Remaster.
The story is okay and you must bear in mind that this was a PS Vita port, so I'd say they did a pretty good job at it.
Still, my opinion stands that you shouldn't buy it unless there's a ridiculously low discount (+75%) or, of course, you got it from the AC: Odyssey season pass.
