As someone who owns and has played both versions of the game, I can pretty much say that I'm very surprised at how well Ubisoft handled this [b]REMASTER[/b]. [i]([b]NOT REMAKE[/b], as it has already been stated 10000 times since its launch...though most people still don't get it)[/i]

[h1][i](by the way, there's a "TL;DR" at the bottom)[/i][/h1]

Now then, the game is very well optimized, running much smoother than the original version, and yet there are people here with twice the power of my own gaming rig [i](or even more)[/i] who complain about the game not starting or about its alleged poor performance [i](and other absurd issues that I have not encountered)[/i] while I'm getting between 40fps and 60fps at 1080p and all settings maxed out with what is [b]AT BEST[/b] a modest, "old-gen" PC...so since all this hate and the almost 1000 negative reviews make no sense whatsoever, I can only surmise that the people who wrote them:

- have no idea what they're talking about but love to troll around
- have it in for Ubisoft and are taking it out on this game even though they're frustrated by an entirely different title given to them by said company
- might be stuck at a "I only know how to create a new folder"-level where the problem is obviously the user
- were probably expecting some nonsense like a game with graphics such as "Odyssey" and whatnot
- simply don't like the price at which the game is being sold [b]EVEN THOUGH, AGAIN,[/b] it's a very well optimized remaster of an already incredible game that came out 7 years ago [b]AND[/b] also includes "Assassin's Creed: Liberation"
- or they aren't too pleased with the new overall character models [i](which, if I'm being honest, could be [b]THE ONLY[/b] negative aspect about this remaster [b]AS WELL AS[/b] technically the only logical explanation as to why everyone is so angry...but it's still [b]DEFINITELY[/b] not a deal-breaker nor does it have a big impact on the overall immersion)[/i]

By the way, do you remember the whole Boston debacle at the game's original launch in 2012? When people were complaining about the horrible framerate and stuttering upon arriving at the docks? Well that issue, among many others which are still unresolved in the original game, has been dealt with in this remaster, along with many other fixes.



[h1][b]TL;DR?[/b][/h1]

Personally, I got it for free since I own the "Assassin's Creed: Odyssey" Season Pass, but that changes nothing because even at its current price, it's still worth it for what it has to offer, namely a combination of stability, great performance, enhanced graphics [i](which bring its gorgeous world to life significantly better than its predecessor)[/i], awesome new gameplay mechanics and more, all neatly embedded into a vibrant remaster of one of the best and most beautiful games ever created.

One can only hope that they'll do the same with "Black Flag" in the near future, or maybe with the whole series up until "Unity".

So yeah - well done, Ubisoft! Exceptional job! [i][b](the same goes for "Liberation")[/b][/i]
You don't always nail it, but you did this time, and therefore, yet again, you get a much deserved [b]"KUDOS!"[/b] from me.

[h1][b]11/10[/b]:[/h1]
Gaming community: "I really don't think we'll ever get to see Desmond die in HD..."
Ubisoft: [b]"Hold my beer!"[/b]

Onto the review: Assassin's Creed 3 completes the Desmond story along with wrapping up the "2012 doomsday" scenario that was socially popular with the "end of the Mayan calendar". I thoroughly enjoyed this my first time on Xbox 360 and the remastered runs well and without any serious, noteworthy problems. As far as the American Revolution segments go, I loved the early twist with Haytham and his allegiance with the Templar order. This gave me a real motivating factor once it transitioned to Connor (Ratohnhaketon). I enjoyed the focus being from the Native American perspective and how Connor weaved his way through the American Revolution. As in all AC games, you meet popular figures during the period and assassinate your way through the invading British fleet. Combat is fluid, with a lot of different weapon options and the ability to be stealthy or do a more front-facing approach. Hunting is a fun and intuitive component that can fill any completionist's desires. I felt a sense of closure with the ending and for me, it was a good thing. 

The DLC is an interesting take on George Washington and a lesson in how easy someone can fall to tyrannical thinking (you know who I'm talking about). They showcase the slow but seamless transition as Washington loses his sight on the values of the Constitution (but they owned slaves, so there is that), and falls to the power of the apple.

If you haven't played this before, it is worth the full price. If you have played this before, get it on a sale. I got it for free because I bought the Odyssey season pass.

Play the original, not this cash-grab shit... I got it for free because of the Season Pass in Odyssey.

To begin with, characters look far worse than the original, oversaturated and plastic-like. Some enviroments and backgrounds look good but not "Remastered" quality.

NPCs popping out of nowhere mid cutscene (This is a common thing, but strangely it happened to me almost on EVERY ocassion) , the synch theme getting stuck almost everytime and various other bugs that remind you every second, why you shouldn't have bought this game.

The deal breaker for me was the controls. They changed the scheme, you have to use your only 4 quick slots to allocate ALL your weapons and items. Leading you to pause the game every 30 seconds.

I wanted to change some controls for the boat (Because they screwed that too), only to find that whenever you change a key for your boat, it does the same for the character, EVEN if they have separated menus...

Truly dissapointing, this was one of my favorite games and was really looking forward to see it with up to date graphics.

There are too many troll videos out on the net making false comparisons of this remaster to the original, calling it a downgrade and a disappointment. They should be taken with a grain of salt. If you have a decent rig this game can look and run absolutely beautifully. 
The game still behaves based upon AC3's original rule sets. But they've done passes on just about everything to make it that much smoother, and at 60fps with higher definition models, environments, textures. The animations look smooth like butter too. It's a remaster, not a remake. And it is beautiful. 
Thanks Ubisoft for keeping this classic fresh. I hope everyone remembers how gargantuan this game was, and gives this a try to relive it again.

You know, the bar was set REALLY low for this remaster, and that isn't even supposed to be an insult. While I do appreciate that SOME quality of life things were added, the 'new' textures feel so lazily put together it's a slap to the face to the people who played this when it first came out. It's upsetting and ultimately somewhat scummy to not disclose in advance that the multiplayer would not be making a return as it was probably one of the best parts about this game. Obviously I'm still going to play through this mess, as I never got to 100% it on console, but I'm going to be extremely sad doing so, since with many comparisons, the game looked far better in 2012 than 7 years in the future apparently. I think one of the most frustrating things about this remaster, is that I want to like it, I want to genuinely say that Ubisoft did something right to the fans of the series, this being the first and only AC game I've ever played. Yet to charge 40 dollars for something that hardly looks any prettier let alone polished is just an outright sadness I don't quite have the words for. The worst part of it all, is that the original version of this game is no longer able to be purchased on steam, giving us this sham in its place. The only reason I don't feel ripped off entirely, is that I managed to get this for free from a season pass, but I can't say I'm too eager to support Ubisoft for much longer if this is the product they deliver after having 7 years to impress us. Buy it if you must, but don't expect a completely changed and polished game

Assassin's Creed III was the first non-Nintendo game I ever played, it holds a special place. However it had some major issues such as freezing and other small bugs. Despite this the action was greatly exciting, this was needed due to the game being more of a brawler than most of the other games. Even though it was all fun and good the world did seem kind of bland and colorless looking back on it. The remaster completely fixed that though, I haven't binge played a game to this level in years. I played around 50 hours in the first week. Some mechanics have even been improved such as better low profile assassinations and using the hidden blades automatically rather than having to switch all the time. I also really liked the new weapon wheel, having to switch to weapons that weren't on the quick select felt better as it felt more like a time stop rather than a menu. Free-aiming as a great addition as well due to the awkward aiming in the original. 

Overall I had a great experience with this game and in my 50 hours so far I have 90% synchronization in the main game.
If you haven't played the original I recommend just playing this new version of the game, it just provides a better experience.
I give this game a 9/10.

Assassin's Creed III is a very enjoyable game and serves as an important installment in the Assassin's Creed franchise.

This section of the review covers the changes and or upgrades made to the remaster
Pros:
-Lighting engine looks gorgeous (most of the time)
-Revamped combat that gives the player more freedom
-Up-scaled rendering and overall solid port

Cons:
-Broken Face lighting and skin quality on some of the models in the game are very ugly
-Little to no attention paid to grammatical errors
-There is one side objective in a level that is nearly impossible and after further review it appears that whoever made the game did not actually go back through main missions or do much trial testing.
-Nothing impressive enough to even warrant the "remastered" in the title.

Overall, if you own Assassin's Creed III already, just play it again. This is not a remaster worth your money unless you have neither, in which case just pick the cheapest one.

AC3 was my favorite game of 2012. As a historian the colonial setting grabbed me. while the main character was bland everything else from the setting to the naval combat and the supporting characters made the game great. It has only improved with the remaster and i, personally enjoy it far more than odyssey (though getting back to the old block to win combat was a challenge). The graphics and lighting have improved to make the setting much better to look at, stealth has improved allowing you to whistle from stalking zones and double assassinate on low profile, and they even added free aiming. I have yet to play liberation and honestly wont be doing so for a while as i was only interested in AC3 but maybe ill give it a look when im curious enough. Now some misteps of the game is even though there has been improvements in the graphics i still see many glitches from dissapearing textures to npcs spazzing out of control. while it was funny thats something i shouldnt be seeing in a remastered game especially when its constant. the last mistep is the price. while i got it for free with the dlc, some people who haven't think 40 dollars is a bit much and i agree. maybe 30 dollars should've been the price. What i dont agree with is telling people not to buy it because of the price alone and they let the price cloud their judgement on the rest of the game. I cant speak for everyone but for me you definately get your moneys worth cause you are getting AC3, Liberation and all the DLC from both games. I've never played the tyranny of king washington dlc until now. I fully recomend this game to new players who havent played AC3 yet.

My HP Omen has the following setup:-
- GeForce GTX 1050
- Intel i7 7700HQ CPU @ 2,80Ghz
- 8 GB RAM
- capable of 60 fps on 1920 x 1080 resolution

It has run AC Rogue, AC Syndicate, AC Origins, AC Odyssey, TERA, and the more graphically-demanding FFXV Windows Edition on high settings with no significant fps issues, even with anti-aliasing turned on. Yet, I cannot say the same for AC 3 Remastered despite my initial enthusiasm towards playing this game. It suffers from severe fps latency and poor dialogue synchronization at my default high settings, and even when at their lowest, it still can't run at 40 fps smoothly, not to mention the occasional screen flickering and whiteout (to my utter dismay, it occured when Connor axed the pillar during his declaration of war).

I encountered a similar issue of fps stutters when I first played through Yakuza 0, and most recently Yakuza Kiwami. In fact, it was way worse when I was playing the latter (I could barely move Kiryu Kazuma even when asked to follow an NPC), so much so I had to tone down the rendering before gameplay became more tolerable. But ever since Sega released a series of patches for these two Yakuza games, my GeForce Experience automatically optimized these two Japanese beat-em-ups to, of all settings I could fathom, ULTRA and it ran so smoothly and perfectly I had to up my ante with my reflexes in combat and rhythm minigames.

Granted the recommended settings for the two Yakuza games are at least half of what is needed for FFXV or the more recent AC games. But the point is, (Ubisoft, if you are reading the reviews on Steam at all) I feel AC 3 needs a serious patch to address these graphical and performance hiccups, just like what Sega did for the PC releases of Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami. There is no point beautifying an older game or making it easier to play if the final product can't be played smoothly at all, because I still encounter fps stutters whenever I move Connor around the field even at LOWEST graphical settings with anti-aliasing turned off, just like how it was with the two Yakuza games prior them being patched.

Until this performance issue has been addressed, I neither see lots of positive reviews coming from the AC community, nor likely recommend this 'remastered' to anyone in the near future.

I don't post reviews much, a game has to be pretty bad or pretty good to get me involved. This "remaster" was more like a "redisaster"... I could be talked into it being a joke, alas I wasn't because it wasn't. I received it for free and I still want my money back. Dreadful, just dreadful.

Well I'm updating my review because I have played a lot more of this game now. And while the graphics look a lot nicer, almost everything else feels like a downgrade. Combat feels more clunky due either a design decision or a bug (not sure which) where the enemy counter icons flash much later than the original, meaning you probably have to press the counter button before the icon actually flashes in order for it to work, and playing with the UI off actually feels easier than having it on and constantly having to ignore the icon and go with the enemies attack animation instead. The AI also seems more buggy and glitchy and i've had enemies detect me, only for them to walk around randomly while the combat music is playing even thought they don't attack. There also seems to be many issues with the music, with the ambient "music" that plays when you are on top of a viewpoint getting bugged and stuck on loop for the rest of the game, and reloading the game will fix it but its only a matter of minutes before it bugs again. The combat music in the frontier is also bugged and appears to constantly repeat certain parts of the track over and over making it repetitive and tedious, and it ruins one of the best things about this game (which is the soundtrack). I've also had my character randomly teleport into the air and then drop to the ground a few times now. The characters faces in this also look like an absolute joke. They look like wax or plastic and not even remotely like a actual human being, so the cutscenes end up looking far far worse than the original version.

Ubisoft also made the BS move to remove the original AC3 from uplay and steam to force people to upgrade to this new and objectively inferior version. Yeah the new graphics look nice, but everything else is worse, much worse. 

AC3 was always one of the more buggy AC games, but the number of bugs I have encountered in the first 15 hours of playing this remaster is an absolute joke and it feels far less polished than the original which was already not a very polished game. This game should be a free upgrade for anyone who owns the original AC3 on steam, not part of the odyssey season pass, and the absolutely diskish move on Ubisofts part to remove the original version to force people to cough up $40 for this new "upgraded" version means I cannot recommend anyone buys this game even if all the bugs and technical issues are fixed (which they wont, its a Ubisoft game). If you want this game and own odyssey, get it through the season pass, else don't buy it at all or stick with the original version if you already have it.

This remaster is exactly what everyone was told it would be.

- Improved lighting
- Improved performance
- Fixed bugs

You'll see people posting pictures where the game looks muddy, notice that they always pick shots where the light is in the same direction as the camera. They say it looks flat. Guess what, if the light isn't at an angle, you don't get shadows. Anyone who says that the game looks "flat" needs to go back to kindergarten, because they clearly don't understand the concept of what a shadow is. And the crowd that says "Oh it's just a reshade filter, they just upped the saturation"... Well, sure, the game's more saturated, but the lighting in the original never looked this good. I bet you a lot of people didn't boot up the original game to compare it to the remaster, and in their nostalgic haze they're misremembering the original as being better looking than it actually was. It's happened before with video game remasters; memory is a fickle thing.

Original AC3 ran at like 20 FPS on my computer. Remastered AC3? Solid 60. Or "62" for whatever reason. Yeah, it's capped at 60, even though I have my monitor running at 120 Hz, but hey 60 FPS is fine. Borderless fullscreen is there and it functions perfectly, so I'm happy.

The original AC3 was always the buggy one. Everybody knows you had carts flipping out, weird animation glitches, looping audio, sometimes dialogue lines wouldn't play, subtitles would desync, random floating muskets/swords, sometimes people would pop in and out, all that sort of stuff. The game was always playable, but it just looked like it wasn't finished. And it was rushed, you can tell in the last few missions. Have they fixed that in the remaster? For the most part, yes.

I've seen floating muskets once so far, and if you go to the menu to pause a cutscene sometimes the next line of dialogue will be partially cut. But that's it, most of the old glitches are gone or drastically reduced in frequency. It feels good.

I'm not saying this is perfect, very rarely is something perfect, especially a remaster. Let's talk about the bad things.

- The original AC3 is no longer for sale
- No multiplayer
- New glitches
- Activation for those who bought the game through the season pass is annoying

Points 1 and 2 are closely related. Because the original game is no longer for sale, you'd want the remaster to be "Complete." It is complete as far as DLC and content, but they've removed the multiplayer, which in the original AC3 had a story to it. I never played it myself, and I've never cared about multiplayer in Assassin's Creed, but I don't see why they'd remove it after hyping a remaster. The multiplayer for even Revelations is still up and running, though hardly anyone plays it.

It's especially bad to remove the original AC3 when you're going to have people wondering how big the changes in the remaster are. It makes it look like Ubisoft has something to hide, as if they think their remaster isn't good enough, but I feel like it is. This is a genuinely good remaster, and Ubisoft has shot themselves in the foot by thinking they need to cover up the original to sell this.

As for new glitches, these are actually pretty minor. I've encountered two unrelated camera glitches so far, one of them worse than the other but neither of them really bother me much, and usually I hate it when the camera acts up in a game. The one you'll likely encounter pretty often happens when you loot a body. The camera gets "stuck" for anywhere between 2-10 seconds in whatever angle you were looking when you started looting. If you go into combat it usually frees itself immediately from what I can tell. It's more annoying than anything else, and it happened occasionally in Brotherhood and Revelations, though only for 2-3 seconds. The second one is where the camera will sometimes start underground when loading into an area, then it immediately pops up in half a second. That's it. So while some people are experiencing bugs, I'd wager most people aren't, or they're getting these minor bugs that don't matter.

Point 4 is arguably my biggest complaint, and it's only because this isn't intuitive until after you figure it out. So if you got the remaster through the season pass for Odysessy, then you're going to have to install both games to get this one launched. This is a 50 GB game, and Odysessy is something like 60 or 70 GB if I'm remembering right. I'm in the middle of playing through the whole series in release order, so I hadn't planned on installing the games that far ahead. It makes sense why they had to do it that way, but I was very confused at first because all the other Assassin's Creed games I've played give you the CD key through Steam and you plug that in to the uPlay launcher, that's it. My harddrive is pretty full and I can imagine other people being on limited internet data, so having to install an unnecessary 60-70 GB on top of your regular 50 GB download could be a pain in the butt.

Aside from the remaster aspect of things, how good is this game? Very good. This is actually my favorite of the Desmond Assassin's Creed games. Anyone who tells you they like AC4 over this one is plain wrong, and they need to be brought in for treason. I enjoyed the game ([i] Contrary to popular opinion [/i]) back when it came out the first time. It was one of the first games I had played on my ps3, leading to a lot of fond memories of gallivanting around colonial New England. Through it's storytelling (Man, nostalgia's one hell of a drug) I became intrigued in the Assassin's Creed franchise as a whole. So why am I telling you this? It's because I enjoyed the original, not this "remaster". Game mechanics seem untouched (meaning they haven't refined them to the standards present in both Black Flag and Rogue), models appear to be the same quality that they were back in 2012, and resolution didn't do much to improve anything. To top it all off, within about 5 minutes of gameplay the game had inexplicably crashed.

Would I reccomend Assassin's Creed 3? Hell yeah, ps3 and xbone (I haven't touched the PC version) had a good thing going for them.
Would I reccomend Assassin's Creed 3 Remastered? No.

[list]
    [*]No 144fps support, game is locked at 60 fps despite there being a 1920x1080 144hz option in the graphics settings
    [*]Low quality textures on characters and objects
    [*]Bad lip movement (sometimes)
    [*]Sound is missing sometimes during combat takedowns
    [*]Long weapons like muskets are misaligned in the character's hands
    [*]Combat feels dull (press E to block, click to kill the enemy, it can literally be you vs 100 soldiers and you'd still win)
    [*]NPC's stuck into an animation loop and not looking at each other when talking (in the open world, not during cutscenes)
    [*]Pretty often when taking down enemies, when the animation plays, your weapon is not synced with the enemies hitboxes which completely ruins the takedowns for me
    [*]Whose bright idea was to add eavesdrop on so many missions?
[/list]

this game feels less like a remaster and more of a downgrade.
1. Even with a top of the line msi gaming pc the game lags on minimum settings.
2. You cannot lower graphics past the "normal" setting -- ie the original AC 3's max graphic settings
3. unlike every ac game out there, you cannot remap pc keybinds ex: changing the attack button from left click to "z" (less chance of a missclick that screw you over) in fact no keybind can be modified including movement and quickslots. yet the original AC 3 allowed changing pc keybinds. (and dont give me the "just use a xbox controller bullshit -- I hate xbox controls and love being able to keybind everything so I only need my one hand to play) ***it even shows an arrow as though you could change keybinds
4. the sound is glitchy as all hell. feels like I'm playing skyrim or any other game where the sound cuts out until you exit to desktop and then re-enter)
5. the "improved combat" feels more like AC 1 combat than it does like AC 3 or AC Odyssey combat
6. when the sound works fine, it still sounds off -- as though you are trying to listen to it underwater.
7. there is no whistle ability even though the release notes claim its there.

In short, they rushed the game out without any concern for how downgraded it is. Till they fix such issues as sound graphic options, clunky combat, keybindings and add in everything they claim they put in, don't buy the remastered unless you got it from the season pass, at least till they fix the game into something remotely usable for anyone who hates/has no support for xbox controllers.


****For the record, I can play AC Odyssey on max graphics settings with zero lag on anything including conquest battles (while running 37 google chrome pages) yet AC 3R lags on minimum (everything to min)  with no other programs running

This Review is only focused on AC3 remastered, haven't tried liberation yet, and it only focused on the IMPROVEMENTS this remaster brings, not the actual game.

-Graphics look similar to something like AC syndicate except the faces on this remaster look a bit meh.
-performance is pretty good. usually around 60fps at 1440p max on my rig, with a couple drops to 50, never below that though.
-the gameplay improvements, such as free aiming go a pretty long way in making the game better.
-comes free with odyssey season pass, wouldn't recommend for $40 USD though. wait for a sale.
-ALL DLC IS INCLUDED!!!
-New outfits, that have never before been seen in AC3.
-Liberation, although not a fan, comes along as more of a bonus than anything, from what I've seen it's an improvement, but not as much as AC3 is.

Overall, a pretty damn fine remaster with all things considered. the fact it comes FREE for Odyssey season pass holders is a steal. I have never played the AC3 DLC and now I CAN ESSENTIALLY FOR FREE AT HIGHER GRAPHICS! However, buying this on it's own, if you have already played this game, I can't recommend for $40, get it at $30 or below.

Alright so here's my first look at the first couple of hours of the game.
The graphics and fluidity (i.e performance) is a huge leap forward from the previous title. Although I still get the odd choppy cutscene here and there, for the most part, it's okay. 

My biggest issue here is the lack of support for us ultrawide monitor users. Unless they plan to release a patch none of us know about, why is there an option in the menu? I'm literally not playing this game because of that sole reason as I hate playing at 16:9 on a 21:9. Also, another issue is the faces...the faces are really bad, even when everything is cranked to ultra. There's this one scene where haythem is in the Opera House at the beginning and stares at this child (for a reason I will not spoil) and the kid is enough to give you nightmares.

Apart from all that, I would highly suggest this game ONLY if you haven't played ac3 before. I got this for free since I have access to Odysseys season pass. There is a numerous amount of mechanical upgrades such as being able to double assassinate while hidden, free aim, new outfits from other titles, HUD and much more. You get all DLC and liberation for a price of $40 which is actually pretty good. But I still stand to not buy if you have played these titles, regardless if some issues were fixed. 

Score- 7/10
Buy, skip or wait for sale? Honestly a wait for sale.

The game can be fixed and when/if it is, I'd definitely recommend the game.

Got this as part of the AC Odyssey season pass (was really the deciding factor that pushed me over the edge in even buying Odyssey+season pass).

$40 is WAY too expensive for this, but totally worth it in addition to Odyssey (which for all its flaws turned out to be far better than I thought it would be, although no where near as good as Origins, Odyssey took me about 50 hours before I was finally invested enough in the game to really start enjoying it, whereas Origins only took me about 8 hours to really start loving it).

$40 is the price that a REMAKE of an older title should get, not just a minor graphical update with much needed performance enhancements.  This is a REMASTER, so go in expecting the same game with some lighting  improvements, higher resolution textures in some areas and on some models, and better performance from modern systems and you should be happy, provided you think that that is worth shelling out $40 for.  At least it does come with Liberation and all the DLC, but honestly we'd all be pissed off if it didn't.

As for the performance, I get over 60 fps consistently at 4k on my GTX 1080 Ti, however I recommend disabling in-game v-sync and instead setting fast sync through your nVidia driver control panel.  Fast sync crashes new ubisoft games, but thankfully this is on an older engine where it still works, and you'll have the benefits of no screen-tearing without reducing your fps by half if the game does temporarily drop below 60 fps.

A Fantastic game completely reworked , the combat and parkour feels smooth , the enemies AI is improved as they are stronger and sharper and slightly fast. it looks beautiful in every aspect. This game lives upto my expectations for a perfect remastered game. New Moves , new AI for enemies , new Outfits and incredible stability despite the graphics being well detailed and really immersive than the Original Assassins creed 3. Its a must buy for all assassins creed fans , specially the ones who loved Assassins creed 3.

NOTE : Those who were disappointed by the Ezio's remastered , trust me this game makes sure that you have that disappointment removed cause this game is the perfect definition of remastered.
